title: Jared Littman wins primary election for mayor of Annapolis
summary: Jared Littmann won the Annapolis mayoral primary with 67% of the vote and will face Republican Bob O’Shea in the general election. Several aldermanic candidates also secured primary victories, with general elections for mayor and all eight aldermanic seats set for Nov.

title: Trump administration warns Maryland against “DEI” contracts in Key Bridge rebuild
summary: The Trump administration warned Maryland not to base Key Bridge reconstruction contracts on race or gender, claiming such practices could create legal and project management issues. Maryland officials defended the project's legal and competitive process, emphasizing a focus on speed, safety, and economic recovery.

title: Maryland Democratic lawmakers see Kimmel suspension as threat to free speech
summary: Maryland Democratic lawmakers condemned ABC’s suspension of Jimmy Kimmel Live! following controversial remarks about the assassination of Charlie Kirk, calling it a threat to free speech and a form of censorship. They introduced the No Political Enemies Act to protect free expression and criticized what they see as efforts by Trump allies to suppress dissent.

title: CNS News Quiz | Week of Sept. 15: Gov. Moore’s priorities, funding for cancer research and more
summary: This week's CNS News Quiz covers topics including Governor Moore’s priorities and funding for cancer research. It serves as a tool to test knowledge on recent state news.

title: DC Council approves Commanders move from Maryland back to Washington
summary: The DC Council approved a plan to build a new stadium in Washington, D.C., set to bring the Washington Commanders back to the city by 2030. The project, funded largely by the team, includes a mixed-use development along the Anacostia Waterfront with sports, recreation, and cultural facilities.

title: Raskin presses Patel on Epstein files, says tenure at FBI has made nation ‘less safe’
summary: Rep. Jamie Raskin accused FBI Director Kash Patel of compromising public safety and betraying Epstein victims during a House Judiciary Committee hearing, criticizing his failure to fully release Epstein-related files.

title: Microsoft to open a new quantum center at University of Maryland research hub
summary: Microsoft is opening a new quantum research center near the University of Maryland to advance collaboration between academia, government, and industry in quantum computing. The initiative, part of Governor Wes Moore's "Capital of Quantum" strategy, aims to position Maryland as a leader in the field with over $70 million in pledged investments.

title: Annapolis Songwriters Festival connects fans and artists
summary: The Annapolis Songwriters Festival connects fans with both established and emerging local musicians, offering a platform for artists to share their stories and music. Proceeds from the event support the Annapolis Musicians Fund for Musicians, which provides financial aid to struggling local artists.

title: Emmys data shows streaming series have gradually dominated spots for the two biggest awards of the night
summary: The 77th Primetime Emmy Awards highlighted the growing dominance of streaming series in the best drama and comedy categories, with six out of eight best drama nominees coming from streaming platforms. Over the past decade, streaming-only shows have gradually displaced traditional TV series in major Emmy nominations, with the shift accelerating after 2017 and peaking during the pandemic.

title: State orders apartment manager to pay $11.2M to Prince George’s tenants in landmark case
summary: A Maryland apartment complex was ordered to pay $11.2 million in restitution to tenants who endured unsafe and unsanitary living conditions for years, including lack of heat, pest infestations, and structural issues, while operating without a valid rental license. The case, settled in September, involved landlords who continued to charge rent and file eviction actions despite failing to meet basic housing and safety requirements.

title: Joining cancer patients, Van Hollen, colleagues warn against research cuts
summary: Sen. Chris Van Hollen and other lawmakers condemned the Trump administration's proposed 40% budget cut to the National Cancer Institute, warning it could jeopardize life-saving cancer research.

title: Demonstrators march to show support for American democracy
summary: Dozens of demonstrators marched 15 miles through Baltimore County as part of a 160-mile “We Are America” event to support democracy and highlight the importance of government accountability for future generations. Participants, including children who helped copy the Constitution, used creative symbols like a decorated “purple horse” to promote unity and positive dialogue across political divides.

title: DOT Orders ‘Major’ Rail Bridge Reforms After Investigation
summary: The U.S. Department of Transportation is significantly increasing the number of federal railroad bridge inspectors, expanding oversight in response to an investigative report revealing inadequate safety practices.

title: Van Hollen, Merkley condemn Gaza ‘ethnic cleansing,’ call for end to Israel-Hamas war
summary: Sens. Chris Van Hollen and Jeff Merkley condemned Israel’s actions in Gaza as “ethnic cleansing” and criticized the Netanyahu government for systematically targeting civilian infrastructure and restricting food aid.

title: State backs “renaissance” project for this Baltimore neighborhood
summary: Maryland is providing a $5 million loan to support a new housing and community park project in Baltimore’s Remington neighborhood, aiming to boost affordable housing and neighborhood revitalization. The Seawall project will replace a former 7-Eleven site with a six-story building containing 60 rental apartments, commercial space, and a public park.

title: Gov. Wes Moore launches bid for reelection
summary: Gov. Wes Moore announced his bid for reelection, vowing to focus on economic growth, public education, and safety in Maryland.

title: Holocaust survivor calls for peace in daily White House sit-ins
summary: Marione Ingram, a Holocaust survivor, protests daily at the White House to advocate for peace and warn against authoritarianism and bigotry. Despite her age and the challenges she faces, she continues her efforts to inspire others to join the fight for a more just and compassionate world.

title: Railroads spurn system designed to prevent accidents
summary: Despite promises to improve safety, none of the nation’s largest freight railroads have fully joined a voluntary federal close call reporting program two and a half years after a major Ohio derailment. The program, which has reduced rail accidents by about 20 percent, remains underutilized by major rail companies, drawing criticism for failing to learn from past disasters.

title: Off the Rails
summary: The article highlights significant risks and regulatory shortcomings within North America's railroad industry. It calls attention to the urgent need for improved safety measures and stronger oversight.

title: Train derailments and toxic spills: Even after multiple disasters, America’s railroads largely police themselves
summary: America's railroads largely self-regulate, with minimal federal oversight and no public access to their inspection records, leaving communities in the dark about risks like decaying infrastructure and potential toxic spills. An analysis shows hazardous materials are frequently transported near densely populated areas, putting millions at risk.

title: Apply safety rules to more flammable-cargo trains, lawmakers urge
summary: Lawmakers are urging federal regulators to expand safety rules for trains carrying flammable cargo to include those with smaller quantities, following incidents that exposed gaps in current high-hazard flammable train classifications. A Howard Center analysis shows many more trains with lower numbers of hazardous material cars than fully classified high-hazard trains, highlighting the need for broader safety measures.

title: Aging U.S. railroad bridges self-inspected, findings kept secret
summary: Aging U.S. railroad bridges, like the nearly 75-year-old Corvallis bridge, are self-inspected with findings kept secret, raising concerns about safety and environmental risks.

title: Many towns unprepared for derailments, hazmat spills that can trigger fires, evacuations
summary: U.S. towns frequently face derailments involving hazardous materials, often leading to evacuations, fires, or explosions, yet many lack the training, equipment, and timely information needed to respond effectively.

title: How you can learn more about local transportation of hazardous materials
summary: To learn about hazardous material transportation in your area, contact your Local or Tribal Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC), which provides information on emergency plans and chemical use, or consult federal resources like the DOT’s Hazmat Incident Database and EPA’s Toxic Release Inventory. These tools offer publicly available data on hazmat incidents and toxic chemical releases.

title: In the deep woods, a little owl teaches big lessons
summary: Susan Hengeveld has spent years studying and banding Northern Saw-Whet Owls in Indiana’s Yellowwood State Forest, helping to build a long-term dataset crucial for understanding their migration. Through her work, she not only advances scientific knowledge but also passes on a meaningful connection to nature to new volunteers.

title: Trump administration policies pose threats to Maryland’s ambitious climate efforts
summary: The Trump administration’s rollback of climate policies and cuts to federal environmental funding are undermining Maryland’s efforts to combat climate change and manage rising sea levels. These actions, coupled with state budget cuts and worsening environmental conditions, threaten to significantly slow Maryland’s progress on climate and conservation initiatives.

title: About Off the Rails
summary: A collaborative investigative journalism project, "Off the Rails," examines critical safety and regulatory issues in North America's railroad industry, including inadequate training for emergency responders and lax oversight of hazardous material transport. The initiative, led by the University of Maryland's Howard Center for Investigative Journalism and supported by data from RailState LLC, involves multiple university and professional news partners to uncover risks and industry practices that remain hidden from the public.

title: Local Warming: A Q&A on Maryland’s climate efforts
summary: Maryland is taking proactive steps to address climate change through local initiatives aimed at reducing emissions and increasing renewable energy use. The state is focusing on community engagement and policy reform to meet its environmental goals.

title: The industrial sector: phasing out pollutants
summary: Maryland is implementing policies to reduce industrial pollutants, including voluntary net-zero goals for the cement industry, a phaseout of hydrofluorocarbons, and regulations to cut methane and landfill emissions. State funding and legislation, such as Buy Clean Maryland, support these efforts, with progress already seen in emissions reporting and regulatory compliance.

title: The electricity sector: transitioning to renewables
summary: Maryland is advancing its transition to renewable energy through policies like the Renewable Portfolio Standard, offshore wind goals, and energy storage initiatives, supported by carbon trading and community solar programs. These efforts, funded in part by renewable energy credits and emissions fees, aim for 100% clean electricity by 2035.

title: Maryland struggles to meet ambitious climate goals
summary: Maryland is struggling to meet its ambitious climate goals, including a 60% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions by 2031 and net zero emissions by 2045, with progress stalling in recent years. While environmental programs offer hope, challenges such as federal opposition and slow renewable energy adoption threaten the state's efforts.

title: The construction sector: decarbonization and energy efficiency
summary: Maryland has implemented the Building Energy Performance Standards to reduce building emissions, with exemptions for certain facilities and an annual fee to cover program costs, while the EmPOWER Maryland Program promotes energy efficiency through utility-funded incentives and customer surcharges. New regulations aim to achieve zero-emission heating systems and set emissions reduction goals, with progress including updated standards and ongoing efforts to expand energy efficiency and decarbonization initiatives.

title: Farms, forests and land use
summary: Maryland is implementing climate policies to reduce emissions from farming and promote sustainable forestry, including grants for soil health, manure management, and tree planting initiatives. Funding comes from bonds, environmental trust funds, and state budgets, with programs aimed at improving land stewardship and carbon sequestration.

title: The transportation sector: promoting EVs
summary: Maryland is expanding its electric vehicle infrastructure and promoting EV adoption through legislation, incentives, and public transit development, aiming for 1.1 million EVs by 2031 and all new car sales to be electric or hybrid by 2035. Despite federal funding delays, the state is advancing with grants, private investments, and plans for new public transit projects to reduce vehicle emissions.

title: Local Warming: Climate Change in Maryland
summary: Maryland is experiencing the effects of climate change through rising temperatures and increased precipitation. Local officials and scientists are working to develop strategies to address these environmental challenges.

title: Maryland grocery tracker
summary: Rising tariffs, climate changes, and a bird flu outbreak have caused grocery prices in Maryland to increase, affecting staples like eggs and coffee. Capital News Service has launched a tracker to monitor average prices across major grocery chains in the state.

title: The changing climate in Caroline County
summary: Caroline County has experienced a significant rise in average temperatures over the past century, with the annual average increasing from 54.6°F in the 20th century to 56.9°F between 2000 and 2024. Scientists predict increasing extreme weather events, including more hot days and heavy precipitation, as global temperatures continue to rise.

title: The changing climate in Prince George’s County
summary: Prince George’s County has warmed by two degrees Fahrenheit over the past century, with recent years experiencing the highest average temperatures. Scientists predict increasing extreme weather, including more hot days and heavy rainfall, as global temperatures continue to rise.

title: The changing climate in Kent County
summary: Kent County has experienced a significant rise in temperatures over the past century, with annual averages increasing by two degrees Fahrenheit since the 20th century. Scientists predict more extreme weather, including increased precipitation, hotter days, and fewer cold nights, as global temperatures continue to rise.

title: The changing climate in Washington County
summary: Washington County has experienced a two-degree Fahrenheit increase in average annual temperature over the past century, with projections showing more extreme heat, precipitation, and fewer cold days as global temperatures rise. Climate models predict significant changes, including increased hot days and extreme weather events, depending on the extent of global warming.

title: The changing climate in Baltimore City
summary: Baltimore City has experienced a significant rise in average temperatures over the past century, with 2023 being the warmest year on record. Climate projections indicate increasing extreme weather, including more hot days, warm nights, and heavy precipitation, as global temperatures continue to rise.

title: The changing climate in Garrett County
summary: Garrett County has experienced a 1.5-degree Fahrenheit increase in average annual temperature over the past century, with 2024 being the warmest year on record. Scientists predict more extreme weather, including increased precipitation and higher temperatures, as global warming continues.

title: The changing climate in Allegany County
summary: Allegany County has warmed by 1.5 degrees Fahrenheit over the past century, with scientists predicting increased extreme weather and fewer cold days as global temperatures rise. Under various warming scenarios, the county is expected to face more hot days, heavy precipitation, and warmer nights.

title: The changing climate in Worcester County
summary: Worcester County has warmed by 2.3 degrees Fahrenheit over the past century, with scientists predicting more extreme heat, heavy precipitation, and fewer cold days as global temperatures rise. Projections show increasing climate impacts, including more days over 95°F and extreme precipitation, depending on the level of global warming.

title: The changing climate in Howard County
summary: Howard County has experienced a significant rise in average temperatures over the past century, with projections indicating increasing extreme weather events if global warming continues. Scientists predict more days of extreme heat and precipitation, along with fewer cold days, as global temperatures rise.

title: The changing climate in Charles County
summary: Charles County has experienced a significant rise in temperature over the past century, with the annual average increasing by 2.2 degrees Fahrenheit since the 20th century. Scientists predict that continued global warming will lead to more extreme weather, including increased precipitation, hotter days, and warmer nights, with fewer freezing days.

title: The changing climate in St. Mary’s County
summary: St. Mary’s County has experienced a 1.9-degree Fahrenheit increase in annual average temperature over the past century, with 2023 being the warmest year on record.

title: The changing climate in Wicomico County
summary: Wicomico County has experienced a significant rise in average annual temperatures over the past 130 years, with projections indicating more extreme heat, precipitation, and warmer nights as global temperatures continue to increase. Climate models suggest that further warming could lead to increasingly severe changes, including more frequent high-temperature days and fewer freezing days.

title: The changing climate in Talbot County
summary: Talbot County has experienced a two-degree Fahrenheit increase in annual average temperature over the past century, with 2012 being the warmest year on record. Climate models predict more extreme heat, heavy precipitation, and fewer cold days as global temperatures continue to rise.

title: The changing climate in Harford County
summary: Harford County has experienced a 2-degree increase in annual average temperature over the past century, with 2012 being the warmest year on record. Scientists predict more extreme weather, including increased precipitation and heat, as global temperatures continue to rise.

title: The changing climate in Anne Arundel County
summary: Anne Arundel County has experienced a significant rise in average temperatures over the past century, with projections indicating increased extreme heat, precipitation, and warmer nights as global temperatures continue to climb. Climate models predict worsening conditions, including more hot days and fewer freezing days, depending on the extent of future global warming.

title: The changing climate in Calvert County
summary: Calvert County has experienced a 1.9-degree Fahrenheit increase in annual average temperature over the past century, with 2024 being the warmest year on record at 59.4°F. Scientists predict more extreme heat, precipitation, and warmer nights, with fewer freezing days as global temperatures continue to rise.

title: The changing climate in Somerset County
summary: Somerset County has experienced a significant temperature rise over the past century, with the annual average increasing from 56.1°F in the 20th century to 58.4°F in 2000–2024. Scientists predict more extreme weather, including increased precipitation and heat, as global temperatures continue to rise.

title: The changing climate in Cecil County
summary: Cecil County has experienced a 2.2-degree Fahrenheit increase in average annual temperature over the past century, with projections showing more extreme heat, precipitation, and warmer nights as global temperatures rise. Climate models predict significant future changes, including more days above 95°F and fewer freezing days, depending on the extent of global warming.

title: The changing climate in Queen Anne’s County
summary: Queen Anne’s County has experienced a significant rise in temperatures over the past 130 years, with the annual average increasing from 54.7°F in the 20th century to 56.7°F between 2000 and 2024. Climate models predict increasing extreme weather, including more hot days and heavy precipitation, as global temperatures continue to rise.

title: About Local Warming: Climate Change in Maryland
summary: "Local warming: Climate change in Maryland" is a Local News Network project examining the state's climate challenges and policy responses, using archived data from the fifth National Climate Assessment. The initiative, led by reporter Rachel McCrea, will be followed by a 2026 series exploring climate change solutions.

title: The changing climate in Baltimore County
summary: Baltimore County has warmed by 2.3 degrees Fahrenheit since the 20th century, with increasing extreme heat and precipitation expected as global temperatures rise. Climate models predict more hot days, fewer cold days, and significant changes in precipitation patterns depending on the extent of future global warming.

title: The changing climate in Frederick County
summary: Frederick County has warmed by 2 degrees Fahrenheit over the past century, with 2024 being its warmest year on record. Scientists predict increasing extreme weather, including more hot days and heavy precipitation, as global temperatures continue to rise.

title: The changing climate in Montgomery County
summary: Montgomery County has experienced a significant rise in average temperatures over the past century, with 2024 being the warmest year on record. Scientists predict increasing extreme weather events, including more hot days and heavy precipitation, as global temperatures continue to rise.

title: The changing climate in Dorchester County
summary: Dorchester County has experienced a 2.3-degree Fahrenheit increase in annual average temperature over the past century, with 2012 being the warmest year on record. Climate models predict increasing extreme weather, including more hot days, heavy precipitation, and fewer freezing days as global temperatures rise.

title: The changing climate in Carroll County
summary: Carroll County has experienced a 2.1-degree Fahrenheit increase in annual average temperature over the past century, with 2024 being the warmest year on record. Scientists predict significant future changes, including more extreme weather events, longer warm nights, and fewer freezing days as global temperatures continue to rise.

title: Climate change is a local issue – and here’s what’s happening in every part of Maryland
summary: Climate change is increasingly evident across Maryland, with extreme weather events, rising temperatures, and environmental changes impacting regions from Montgomery County to the Eastern Shore. These changes are causing tree mortality, more frequent droughts, flooding, and other challenges that vary by local geography.

title: This school banned cellphones six years ago. Teachers — and many kids — couldn’t be happier.
summary: San Mateo High School in California has banned cellphones since 2019, requiring students to lock their phones in sealed pouches during school hours. The policy, aimed at reducing distractions and mental health issues, has been widely supported by teachers and students alike.

title: Anne Arundel schools pioneer rapid-response program for teens dealing with substance abuse
summary: Anne Arundel County Public Schools launched the STAR program to connect middle and high school students with substance abuse treatment services, following a tragic overdose that highlighted gaps in youth support. The initiative, a partnership with the county health department, enables school nurses to quickly refer students in need to recovery resources.

title: Youth mental health? There’s an app — many apps — for that. But are they effective?
summary: Mental health apps like Finch are increasingly used by young people to manage conditions such as anxiety, offering interactive self-care tools and reminders. However, experts caution that many of these apps lack proven effectiveness and formal evaluation.

title: As young Americans struggle with mental health, online support surges — including in Maryland
summary: Prince George’s County schools in Maryland have partnered with Hazel Health to provide online mental health counseling for students, addressing barriers like transportation and a shortage of in-person providers. Online services have gained popularity since the pandemic, with research showing promising results for treating anxiety and depression in young people.

title: Retired Senior Embraces College Life through UMD’s Golden ID Program
summary: The University of Maryland's Golden ID program enables retired seniors to attend college courses for free. Nancy Loy, a participant, uses the opportunity to learn languages and engage in campus activities.

title: Behind the Butterflies: Hundreds Return to Brookside Gardens
summary: Brookside Gardens in Wheaton has reopened its Butterfly Exhibit, featuring hundreds of live butterflies from regions including North America, Costa Rica, Africa, and Asia. The exhibit offers visitors a chance to experience a vibrant, global display of butterfly life up close.

title: Recovery Through Rock Climbing
summary: Josh Lu, after enduring a severe back injury that left him bedridden for months, draws strength from his support network and passion for rock climbing. His journey highlights how personal motivation and loved ones can play a vital role in the recovery process.

title: Turning Pages, Changing Lives: How Books for International Goodwill is Building a More Literate Future
summary: Books for International Goodwill is a nonprofit based in Annapolis that collects used books and distributes them globally to promote literacy. By transforming discarded pages into educational resources, the organization is helping to build a more literate and connected world.

title: Germantown Senior Aims for 2028 Paralympics
summary: Lisa Markland, a Germantown resident, competed at the peak of her career before the 2008 Beijing Olympics but had to step away. Now, 18 years later, she is training to qualify for the 2028 Summer Paralympics in Los Angeles.

title: To improve youth mental health, these programs start by educating parents
summary: Melat Wondimagegen, an Ethiopian immigrant, transformed her parenting approach through the Parent Encouragement Program (PEP), learning to communicate more effectively and supportively with her children. PEP, part of a nationwide initiative, aims to improve youth mental health by educating parents in respectful, encouraging parenting techniques, supported by grants from Maryland state officials.

title: Maryland’s push to become the world’s quantum capital depends partly on this UMD physicist
summary: Ronald Walsworth, a prominent quantum physicist and director of the University of Maryland’s Quantum Technology Center, is leading efforts to position Maryland as the global quantum capital. Governor Wes Moore’s $27.5 million investment aims to boost quantum research, startups, and workforce development, with Walsworth focused on expanding the state’s academic and industrial quantum ecosystem.

title: Maryland students aim to prevent school violence with help from Sandy Hook Promise
summary: Maryland high school students, led by Evie Graham, are using the Sandy Hook Promise program to promote school safety and prevent violence through initiatives like the SAVE club. The nonprofit, founded by Sandy Hook shooting survivors, aims to educate and empower youth to create safer school environments by fostering open communication and community connections.

title: Inside one federal government building: When a passion for peace is torn to pieces
summary: LaToya, a program specialist at the U.S. Institute of Peace, was abruptly terminated amid efforts to dismantle the agency, joining over 400 employees affected by President Trump's actions.

title: UMD Baltimore’s Dr. Kirsten Lyke, a force in medicine, warns of ‘really treacherous times’
summary: Dr. Kirsten Lyke, a prominent figure at the University of Maryland School of Medicine, has played key roles in developing vaccines for Ebola, Zika, and the Pfizer-BioNTech COVID-19 vaccine.

title: ‘There’s nothing left of the Republican Party’: Maryland veterans join pro-Ukraine GOP group
summary: Maryland veterans and other GOP members are joining "Republicans for Ukraine," a conservative group advocating for U.S. support of Ukraine in its war against Russia.

title: Nine people stand between her child and citizenship. It’s a fight she can’t afford to lose.
summary: A pregnant immigrant, Meny, faces uncertainty over her unborn child's citizenship after President Trump's executive order aiming to end birthright citizenship, prompting her to join a lawsuit under the Asylum Seeker Advocacy Project. The lawsuit, CASA v.

title: College students move across state lines — and lose access to therapy as a result
summary: College students who move across state lines often lose access to their therapists due to differences in state licensing laws, disrupting their mental health care. Mental health professionals are advocating for licensing compacts to allow seamless, continuous care across state borders.

title: Maryland’s largest underground coal mine changes hands
summary: Maryland’s largest underground coal mine, Casselman, was sold to Rosebud Mining Company after its previous operator, Corsa Coal, filed for bankruptcy due to financial strain from falling coal prices and economic pressures. The new owner avoids inheriting Corsa’s safety violation fines and has rehired about half of the laid-off workers.

title: Port of Baltimore unlikely to see tariff impacts until next month
summary: The Port of Baltimore is not expected to see significant impacts from U.S. tariffs on imported goods until June, as larger ports like Los Angeles and Long Beach are already experiencing greater effects due to higher import volumes and geographic proximity to China.

title: Prince George’s far outstrips other Maryland jurisdictions in highway deaths
summary: Prince George’s County has the highest number of traffic fatalities in Maryland, with 34 deaths so far this year, far exceeding other counties like Baltimore and Montgomery. Officials attribute the trend to factors like population density, major thoroughfares, and common crash causes such as speeding and impaired driving.

title: DC area food industry shaken after DHS visits more than 100 businesses
summary: DHS agents visited over 100 Washington area businesses, including several restaurants, to conduct I-9 compliance checks, causing concern among business owners and staff. While no arrests were made, the visits left many in the food industry anxious and highlighted ongoing enforcement efforts to ensure immigration and employment law compliance.

title: Some Maryland brewers concerned tariffs will make tough times tougher
summary: Maryland breweries are struggling with rising costs due to Trump administration tariffs, particularly a 25% tax on imported aluminum used for beer cans. In addition to higher can costs, some brewers are also seeking domestic alternatives for other imported materials like hops and malt.

title: Looking at driving under the influence of cannabis in Maryland
summary: Driving under the influence of cannabis has increased in Maryland following marijuana legalization, though reports have recently declined slightly. The state lacks specific legal THC thresholds for impairment, and developing a cannabis breathalyzer remains challenging due to the chemical properties of THC.

title: Loss of Key Bridge leads to more potholes, truck traffic in neighborhoods
summary: The collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge has led to increased truck traffic in Dundalk, causing severe road damage and a 25% rise in pothole repairs. Local truckers and officials report worsening road conditions that are straining vehicles and repair resources.

title: Sen. Alsobrooks Urges RFK Jr. to Resign at ‘Sick of it Rally’ outside NIH
summary: Sen. Alsobrooks and supporters rallied outside NIH to protest Trump-era cuts and demand RFK Jr.'s resignation.

title: Machine learning — in Maryland and elsewhere — opens new possibilities for suicide prevention
summary: Researchers at the University of Maryland used machine learning to analyze Reddit responses from individuals who have survived suicidal thoughts, identifying key reasons that helped them choose to live. This approach, part of a broader trend in suicide prevention research, aims to help teens and others in crisis feel less isolated by showing them they are not alone in their struggles.

title: Visitors, workers – and Democrats – dismayed at sudden firing of Librarian of Congress Carla Hayden
summary: President Donald Trump's sudden firing of Librarian of Congress Carla Hayden, the first African American and woman to lead the institution, sparked outrage among visitors, workers, and Democratic lawmakers, who viewed it as a setback for diversity and democratic norms. Hayden, appointed by President Barack Obama in 2016, had led efforts to modernize the Library of Congress and expand its public reach.

title: Here’s how federal and state action may affect Maryland electric vehicle programs
summary: Maryland joined a lawsuit against a Trump executive order blocking federal funding for electric vehicle charging stations, aiming to counter efforts that could hinder the state's electric vehicle growth. The state has seen significant expansion in electric vehicle infrastructure and ownership, supported by programs designed to reduce emissions and promote cleaner transportation.

title: Disappointing apathy in Maryland and beyond, says Jan. 6 Officer Harry Dunn
summary: Former Capitol Police Officer Harry Dunn, who experienced the January 6, 2021, insurrection, expressed disappointment that many Maryland residents either didn't know about or didn't care about the event, which he said influenced his failed congressional campaign. Dunn, a lifelong public servant and local Maryland native, ran for office inspired by his service but faced low voter turnout and apathy in the 2024 election.

title: Pardoned Maryland Jan. 6 participants find support after convictions
summary: Steven Cook, a Maryland participant in the Jan. 6 Capitol riot who was pardoned by Donald Trump and served part of a 28-month sentence, has found community support and was celebrated as a "hero" at a Republican women’s banquet.

title: Antisemitism and Islamophobia soar in Maryland after October 2023 Hamas attacks
summary: Antisemitism and Islamophobia have significantly increased in Maryland following the October 2023 Hamas attacks, with anti-Muslim incidents more than tripling and antisemitic incidents rising sharply. Experts attribute this surge to heightened emotions and political conflict, which create fertile ground for various forms of hatred and bias.

title: Maryland lawmakers decry possible Medicaid cuts amid 24-hour protest near US Capitol
summary: Maryland lawmakers and advocates held a 24-hour protest near the U.S. Capitol to oppose proposed $880 billion in federal Medicaid cuts over the next decade.

title: CNS News Quiz | Week of May 5: NIL deals, exports to China and a Supreme Court case from Maryland
summary: The quiz covers recent news topics including NIL deals, exports to China, and a Supreme Court case from Maryland. It aims to test knowledge of current events covered by Capital News Service.

title: Drought in Baltimore County is not letting up. What does this mean for summer?
summary: Baltimore County is experiencing a prolonged drought with no relief in sight, prompting concerns about rising water bills, restrictions on lawn care, and reduced water-based activities as summer approaches. Authorities are urging voluntary water conservation measures to prevent more severe restrictions in the future.

title: After a historic 2024, a Baltimore violence prevention program is in peril
summary: Baltimore's Safe Streets violence prevention program, credited with reducing crime in 2024, faces potential collapse due to $1.2 million in budget cuts from the Trump administration. Without continued funding, experts warn that recent progress in curbing gun violence could be reversed.

title: How the Key Bridge collapse upended workers beyond the Baltimore region
summary: The Key Bridge collapse in March 2024 disrupted workers beyond the Baltimore region, with emergency state relief funds reaching applicants in Pennsylvania, Delaware, Virginia, and other states after they lost jobs linked to the port. While Maryland residents made up most of the 3,363 approved applicants, the economic ripple effects highlighted the broader impact of the disaster on connected communities.

title: Supreme Court hears Maryland case on opting children out from LGBTQ+ book lessons
summary: The Supreme Court heard arguments on whether parents have the constitutional right to opt their children out of school lessons featuring LGBTQ+ themed books, in a case originating from Maryland's Montgomery County Public Schools. The case centers on a school policy that eliminated a prior opt-out option, with parents and their attorney arguing it violates religious freedoms, while the school system defends its updated curriculum and refusal to notify parents of book readings.

title: ‘BookTok’ has fueled a literary comeback
summary: BookTok has driven a literary resurgence, boosting print sales and propelling both new and classic authors into the spotlight. Despite a long-term decline in bookstore sales, the trend, along with the rising popularity of Kindles, has helped sustain reader interest in books.

title: Caught in the Crossfire: Chinese Students Navigate US-China Tensions
summary: Hundreds of Chinese exchange students in the U.S. have had their visas revoked as tensions between the two countries escalate.

title: Volunteer Ushers Keep the Hippodrome Theater Alive
summary: Volunteer ushers play a vital role in preserving the Hippodrome Theater's legacy in Baltimore. Their dedication, exemplified by long-time usher Murray, ensures the historic venue remains a thriving center for live performances.

title: High School Sports and NIL: An Explainer
summary: A video produced by students at the Shirley Povich Center for Sports Journalism explores how Name, Image, and Likeness (NIL) rights are affecting high school sports. The investigation highlights the inconsistent state-by-state approaches to NIL and its financial impact on student-athletes.

title: Little League Baseball provides big stage for youth athletes but its NIL rules are murky
summary: Little League Baseball has not established clear NIL policies for its young athletes, leaving it uncertain whether they can profit from their exposure, even as the Little League World Series draws large audiences. The organization has stated its focus is on protecting players' eligibility for high school sports but has not confirmed whether it has a formal stance on NIL.

title: Impact of NIL on transfers is unknown but raises questions for high school officials
summary: High school officials are questioning the influence of Name, Image, and Likeness (NIL) on student-athlete transfers, despite no direct evidence linking recent moves to NIL deals. While collectives that support NIL compensation are not permitted at the high school level, the potential financial incentives are changing the landscape of high school recruitment and competition.

title: Even in the era of high school NIL, most states oppose collectives
summary: High school athletes in 41 states and Washington, D.C., can now earn money through Name, Image, and Likeness (NIL) deals, but most states ban collectives—groups formed by boosters and families to fund these payments. Officials worry collectives could create unfair advantages for wealthier schools and disrupt the competitive balance of high school sports.

title: For College HUNKS, Portland Gear, high school athletes are star endorsers
summary: College HUNKS Hauling Junk & Moving signed Alexis Ewing, a high school volleyball star and daughter of basketball legend Patrick Ewing, in what is believed to be Maryland's first NIL deal with a high school athlete. The partnership reflects growing interest among businesses in engaging with high school athletes through name, image, and likeness agreements, despite the uncertain return on investment.

title: Boom in NIL opportunities exposes need for education for athletes and their parents
summary: A growing number of high school athletes are engaging in Name, Image, and Likeness (NIL) deals, but most schools and states do not provide formal education on the topic, leaving athletes and parents to navigate the rules on their own. Only a few states, like North Carolina, require educational resources to help student-athletes understand NIL and avoid losing eligibility through mistakes.

title: Can high school athletes get NIL deals? It depends what state you’re in
summary: High school athletes in 41 states and D.C. can earn money through Name, Image, and Likeness (NIL) deals, though rules vary widely.

title: As NIL comes to high school sports, its impact is being hotly debated
summary: California's 2021 Fair Pay to Play Act, which allowed college athletes to profit from their Name, Image, and Likeness (NIL), has now expanded to high school sports in 41 states and D.C., sparking widespread debate. While proponents argue that high school athletes deserve to benefit from their fame, critics warn it could shift the focus from the love of the game to professionalism and create unintended consequences.

title: Former gymnasts are shaping NCAA judging
summary: Former gymnasts now make up many of today's top NCAA judges. They bring their experience to ensure safe and fair scoring in the sport.

title: Scholars weigh in on the removal of DC’s Black Lives Matter Plaza
summary: DC Mayor Muriel Bowser approved the removal of the Black Lives Matter Plaza, a 50-foot set of yellow letters near the White House. Scholars expressed concern that the move signals a threat to public art and its role in social activism.

title: Walk the Walk Foundation: Empowering Annapolis’ Children in Need
summary: The Walk the Walk Foundation in Annapolis, Maryland, is dedicated to empowering underprivileged children through faith-based service. The organization encourages individuals to contribute their time, talents, and resources to support children in need.

title: Retired racers’ lives slow down after retirement
summary: Retired greyhound racers transition from a high-speed lifestyle to a slower one after their racing careers end. Organizations like Greyt Love Retirement in Hanover, Virginia help these dogs find new homes and adjust to life as pets.

title: The Price Tag of Living in Northern Virginia
summary: Northern Virginia's rapid growth has led to increased economic disparity due to high living costs, particularly in housing. Rising rents and limited affordable options are pushing many residents to reevaluate their future in the region.

title: Governor Moore announces a new hiring process amid federal layoffs
summary: Governor Wes Moore announced a streamlined hiring process for four state government positions to help Maryland workers affected by recent federal layoffs, which caused the state to lose 3,500 public sector jobs in March. The initiative allows federal workers to apply for multiple roles across agencies through a single application, with expedited consideration for available positions.

title: Maryland’s goods exports to China increased in 2024 despite national decline, but tariffs pose potential threats to future trade
summary: Maryland's goods exports to China increased by 10% in 2024, mainly due to higher coal and petroleum gas shipments, even as U.S. exports to China declined nationally.

title: Parents often struggle to find help for troubled youngsters — but this Maryland program can help
summary: A Maryland program called BHIPP places social work interns in pediatric offices to provide free behavioral health support to children, helping parents like Mallory Churchey address their kids' emotional and behavioral challenges quickly and effectively. The program, which has received high satisfaction ratings from families, is unique among similar national initiatives for its success and accessibility.

title: Van Hollen and fellow Democrats plan Senate vote on Trump deportation policy
summary: Senate Democrats, led by Chris Van Hollen and Chuck Schumer, introduced legislation requiring the Trump administration to report on its compliance with court orders related to the wrongful deportation of U.S. residents to El Salvador and to assess the country's human rights record.

title: CNS News Quiz | Week of April 28: Trump’s executive orders, a warning from diplomats and more
summary: This week's CNS News Quiz covers key events including Trump's executive orders and a warning from diplomats. It challenges readers to test their knowledge on recent news developments.

title: Trump is following the ‘universal autocrats playbook,’ US diplomats warn
summary: Former U.S. ambassadors warn that the Trump administration is following a "universal autocrat playbook," undermining democracy through tactics like eroding checks and balances and spreading disinformation.

title: Box office bounces back in historic Sinners, Star Wars weekend
summary: Ryan Coogler's *Sinners* set multiple box office records with a historic second-weekend hold, while the re-release of *Star Wars: Episode III – Revenge of the Sith* earned over $43 million globally. Together, they helped propel April's box office to a strong rebound after a slow start to the year.

title: Timeline: Milestones from Trump’s first 100 days
summary: President Donald Trump marked his first 100 days in his second term with a series of executive actions, including ending birthright citizenship, creating the Department of Government Efficiency, and dismissing 17 inspectors general, signaling a dramatic shift in federal governance. His agenda, focused on reshaping U.S.

title: Trump’s 100 days, in 5 charts
summary: In his first 100 days of his second term, President Donald Trump signed over 120 executive orders, made numerous personnel appointments, and implemented significant federal workforce reductions. His administration also introduced major spending cuts and tariffs, while facing extensive legal challenges over his rapid policy actions.

title: Photo Gallery: Trump’s first 100 days in office
summary: The photo gallery captures key moments from President Donald Trump’s first 100 days in his second term, including protests, the inauguration, and controversial events like a midair collision and agency dismantling. Images highlight public resistance, political actions, and the impact of Trump’s policies and alliances, such as with Elon Musk.

title: Wes Moore wants to offer stability amid Trump “chaos”
summary: Governor Wes Moore emphasized Maryland’s stability and steady leadership as a contrast to the “chaos” in Washington, highlighting his recent trade mission to Japan and Korea as a way to build economic relationships independent of federal policies. He aims to showcase a different approach through tax reform and government efficiency, though the practical results of his initiatives remain to be seen.

title: Schools can screen students for behavioral health issues – but many are reluctant to do so
summary: Schools in the U.S. can use behavioral health screenings to identify students in need of mental health support, but such practices remain uncommon due to limited resources and concerns about responsibility.

title: Maryland crabbers grapple with inflation and tariff prospects
summary: Maryland's seafood industry is facing challenges from rising inflation as crab season begins. The Chesapeake Bay Seafood Industry Association and restaurant owners are closely watching how these economic pressures will impact sales.

title: Supreme Court hears LGBTQ+ book case from Montgomery County, Maryland
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court is considering a case about whether parents should be notified if their children are exposed to LGBTQ+ themed books in school.

title: CNS News Quiz | Week of April 21: Science at risk, cannabis stats and more
summary: A weekly news quiz tests knowledge on current events, including science, cannabis statistics, and other top stories. The quiz is offered by Capital News Service to engage readers and keep them informed.

title: Beyond the high: Diving into Maryland’s cannabis data
summary: Maryland's legal marijuana use has revealed growing concerns, including over 4,400 cases of cannabis use disorder, with women disproportionately affected. Additionally, about 2% of survey respondents reported experiencing cannabis hyperemesis syndrome, a severe condition linked to prolonged use.

title: ‘Playworks’ reinvents recess as a learning experience
summary: Rhawnhurst School in Philadelphia partners with Playworks, a nonprofit that transforms recess into a structured learning experience focused on life skills like confidence and conflict resolution. By incorporating games and play into daily school life, the program has shown success in reducing bullying and fostering inclusivity across diverse student populations.

title: It’s hard to become a city, but these residents keep trying
summary: Maryland has not created a new city in over 20 years, despite numerous attempts by unincorporated communities like Edgewood to establish local governments. County governments, which hold final approval power, typically deny incorporation requests due to financial and political incentives.

title: Oklahoma City marks a deadly attack and ongoing threat
summary: Oklahoma City is commemorating the 30th anniversary of the 1995 federal building bombing that killed 168 people, including 19 children, with a remembrance ceremony at the Oklahoma City National Memorial & Museum. Experts warn that domestic terrorism remains a pressing threat, as right-wing extremism and homegrown violence continue to rise in the U.S.

title: Returning from El Salvador, Van Hollen says ‘we need to bring Mr. Abrego García home’
summary: Sen. Chris Van Hollen returned from El Salvador, where he met with detained Maryland resident Kilmar Abrego García after initially being denied access by authorities.

title: ​​These aid workers are still trying to get their Afghan allies to safety
summary: Sophia Wilcox is working urgently to help her former Afghan team, who aided a U.S.-funded agricultural program, escape danger as the Taliban targets U.S. allies and refugee admissions to the U.S.

title: U.S. dominance in science at risk with Trump cuts, scientists warn
summary: Scientists warn that Trump administration plans to cut federal funding for science threaten U.S. global leadership in research and innovation.

title: Maryland High School graduation rate reaches seven-year high
summary: Maryland's high school graduation rate reached 88% in 2024, the highest level in seven years, with significant improvements among Hispanic and multilingual student groups. Anne Arundel County Public Schools and initiatives like Project Graduation are credited with contributing to the state's progress.

title: D.C.’s Go-Go Museum showcases the music genre’s local roots, global influence
summary: The Go-Go Museum & Café in D.C.'s Anacostia neighborhood celebrates the city's go-go music heritage, a genre born in the 1970s and now officially recognized as the city's music. Founded by community advocate Ronald Moten and scholar Natalie Hopkinson, the museum emerged from a grassroots movement to protect go-go's cultural legacy amid gentrification and racial justice issues.

title: Maryland lawmakers, legal experts press Trump to return Abrego García from El Salvador
summary: Maryland lawmakers and legal advocates are urging the Trump administration to secure the return of Kilmar Abrego García, a U.S. resident mistakenly deported to El Salvador's CECOT prison, where he has been held without contact for over a month.

title: Fans flock to Nationals Opening Day
summary: Nationals fans gathered for Opening Day, showing excitement as the team returns after a disappointing 2024 season. The event symbolizes renewed hope and enthusiasm for the upcoming baseball year.

title: Maryland federal contractor layoffs increase as Trump slashes federal spending
summary: Layoffs at Maryland federal contractors have surged as the Trump administration reduces spending and reorganizes federal agencies, with over 3,000 workers notified of job losses this year. Many affected workers and companies were linked to USAID, which faced significant budget cuts and reorganization under the administration's policies.

title: Despite earlier proposal, youth mental health initiatives see minimal cuts in Maryland state budget
summary: Maryland lawmakers rejected Governor Wes Moore’s initial proposal to drastically cut funding for youth mental health programs, instead approving $70 million for the Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports in the 2026 fiscal year. Advocates praised the decision, noting that the funding will help maintain and expand mental health services in schools across the state.

title: Environmentalists worry what the plane-copter collision left behind in the Potomac River
summary: Environmentalists with the Potomac Riverkeeper Network are concerned about potential contamination from a January 29 plane-helicopter crash but lack the funds to test for fuel and debris in the river. While they collected water samples, the group is struggling to secure resources for analysis as the full extent of the spill remains unclear.

title: Red Line funding survives in tight budget year, but some other transit goals are on hold
summary: Maryland’s Red Line project received continued funding support in the state’s tight budget year, despite broader delays in transit expansion plans due to financial constraints. While some lawmakers questioned the priority of new projects over inflation adjustments for existing systems, state leaders emphasized the importance of moving forward with planning to secure future federal backing.

title: Lawmakers join wife of mistakenly deported Maryland man to demand his return
summary: Lawmakers, including members of the Congressional Hispanic Caucus, demanded the return of mistakenly deported Maryland resident Kilmar Abrego Garcia, who was sent to a dangerous prison in El Salvador despite having legal protection from deportation. A U.S.

title: The Silver Lining of Shepherd’s Table
summary: Shepherd’s Table in Silver Spring provides meals and support to those experiencing homelessness, offering a daily refuge and resources. The organization operates without missing a single day, addressing the growing need in the community.

title: The struggle for wheelchair coverage: One Virginia family’s story
summary: Ann Bailey Corbin, a four-year-old from Northern Virginia, began needing a wheelchair after her legs stopped working, but her mother faced challenges getting insurance coverage through Blue Cross Blue Shield. The family's experience highlights the complex and often difficult process of navigating insurance for medical equipment in the U.S.

title: Local woman helps to feed D.C.’s homeless community
summary: A local woman known as "Miss Mary" is helping to feed Washington, D.C.’s homeless community by collecting food from restaurants and distributing it daily. Her efforts provide essential support to those in need across the city.

title: Left Behind: The Harsh Reality of U.S. Maternity Leave
summary: New mothers in the U.S. face significant challenges due to the lack of comprehensive maternity leave policies, leading to strained family dynamics.

title: Maryland will slow – not stop – its investment in schools
summary: Maryland lawmakers passed a revised education reform bill that made only minor cuts to the state’s Blueprint for Maryland’s Future, preserving critical funding for students in poverty, special education, and English language learners. While scaling back requirements for teacher collaboration time and pausing some funding increases for two years, the bill still represents the largest single investment in K-12 education in state history.

title: How families might fare under Maryland’s new state budget
summary: Maryland's new budget, passed after a tense legislative session, includes significant spending cuts and tax changes aimed at closing a structural deficit and creating a fairer tax system. While Democratic leaders claim it will benefit most residents by lowering taxes for 94% of filers, Republicans argue it unfairly burdens working families and fails to adequately control costs.

title: After Federal Layoffs Hit Hard, Montgomery County Community Offers Support
summary: Federal layoffs have left residents like Casey Recabarren and Katie Sandlin struggling to rebuild their lives. In response, a Gaithersburg workshop partnered with a photographer and make-up artist to provide free services and community support for affected employees.

title: After years of growth, Disney pulls back on Marvel, Star Wars releases
summary: Disney is scaling back the frequency of new releases for its Marvel and Star Wars franchises after years of explosive growth in film. Both brands have shifted focus to Disney+, producing high-budget television content to maintain their dominance in the evolving entertainment landscape.

title: Maryland session concludes with balanced budget and Trump concerns
summary: Maryland lawmakers passed a 2026 budget that raises taxes and cuts programs, including adjustments to the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future education plan, to address fiscal challenges amid uncertainty from federal policy shifts under President Trump. While Democrats claim the budget preserves key priorities and strengthens the state’s fiscal position, Republicans argue it unfairly burdens taxpayers and question its alignment with public sentiment.

title: Maryland’s House Freedom Caucus says Democrats aren’t what the doctor ordered
summary: Maryland’s Republican House Freedom Caucus criticized Democrats for failing to address the state’s energy crisis and high utility costs, accusing them of harming the middle class through ineffective policies. While they praised one aspect of Governor Wes Moore’s education plan, they called for further delays in its implementation.

title: Maryland officials wrap up business with worry about “chaos” to come
summary: Maryland Democratic leaders expressed concern over the potential impact of Trump's policies and Elon Musk's influence as the state legislature adjourned, warning of threats ranging from federal funding cuts to immigration enforcement. To address these challenges, lawmakers established a bipartisan oversight committee to monitor federal actions affecting the state.

title: Teenager in wheelchair defies odds and plays lacrosse
summary: Caleb Krewson, a freshman in a wheelchair, scored his first high school lacrosse goal during a game between Severn and Saints Peter and Paul Schools. His coach and teammates praise his dedication, seeing him as an equal competitor who inspires them through his hard work.

title: Rapid-response teams aid troubled youths in New Jersey – but funding limits Maryland’s similar effort
summary: New Jersey's Mobile Response and Stabilization Services helped a troubled 6-year-old avoid suspension and intensive hospital care by providing timely mental health support, leading to significant behavioral improvements. Maryland, which launched a similar program in 2022, faces challenges in offering the same level of care due to insufficient funding.

title: Maryland homeless services are nervous about federal funding
summary: Maryland's homeless service providers are growing concerned as federal funding from HUD continues to arrive late, threatening the stability of emergency and supportive housing programs. While HUD has begun distributing some grants, uncertainty remains about future funding cycles, prompting worries from state officials and lawmakers.

title: Maryland delegation appalled by Trump tariffs amid stock market plunge
summary: Maryland Democrats criticized President Trump’s broad new tariffs, calling them a harmful tax on American families and a major cause of the stock market decline and manufacturing job losses. The tariffs, which include 10% on most imports and higher rates on China and the EU, were framed by Trump as a move to end trade imbalances but were met with warnings of economic damage.

title: Maryland lawmakers push for new power amid concerns about high costs
summary: Maryland lawmakers are pushing for new in-state energy projects, including natural gas, nuclear, and renewables, to address rising costs and grid reliability concerns amid increased demand from data centers and electrification. Experts warn of a strained approval process for new projects, which is contributing to soaring energy prices despite current grid stability.

title: Maryland wrestles with blow to the state schools budget
summary: Maryland lawmakers face a $418 million shortfall in federal pandemic-era funding for public schools, forcing reconsideration of the state’s education budget and the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future. Republican Sen.

title: It’s a tough budget year, but Maryland lawmakers are moving toward a plan to deal with it
summary: Maryland lawmakers are nearing a budget agreement that includes spending cuts and tax hikes to address a growing $3 billion deficit, with Democrats defending the plan as fair and Republicans criticizing the higher taxes on earners. The budget negotiations have been shaped by federal funding cuts and efforts to protect essential services like healthcare and education.

title: Maryland reported 3 measles cases in March. Here’s what you need to know.
summary: Maryland confirmed three measles cases in March, all linked to international travel and connected to Washington Dulles International Airport, but unrelated to larger outbreaks in other states. Nationally, 378 cases have been reported in 2025, mostly among unvaccinated individuals, with the majority of hospitalizations affecting children under 5.

title: About half of Baltimoreans felt impacted by Key Bridge collapse, Hopkins survey says
summary: A Johns Hopkins University survey found that about half of Baltimore residents felt their daily lives were disrupted by the Key Bridge collapse, with many facing challenges in commuting and visiting loved ones. Most residents believe rebuilding the bridge will take more than four years, reflecting a widespread distrust in government's ability to manage large infrastructure projects.

title: Legislation seeks to protect Maryland immigrants from Trump’s deportation push
summary: Maryland is advancing the Immigrant Justice Protection Package, a set of bills designed to shield immigrants from federal deportation efforts and protect sensitive locations like schools and hospitals from immigration enforcement. The legislation also aims to prevent federal authorities from accessing state and local databases to safeguard immigrant families' information.

title: Quiz: Are these strange Maryland laws fact or fiction?
summary: Maryland is known for some unusual laws, though many are just urban legends. A recent quiz challenges residents to distinguish fact from fiction in the state's legal code.

title: Maryland faced coldest winter in six years
summary: Maryland experienced its coldest winter in six years, with an average temperature of 39.3°F and 13 inches of snow. Despite the recent cold, long-term data shows a warming trend in winter temperatures across the state and the contiguous U.S.

title: Schools face a shortage of social workers – but Howard University has a plan that helps
summary: Howard University's Project PRESS is addressing a nationwide shortage of school social workers by placing second-year social work students in D.C. public schools to gain experience and encourage them to pursue careers in the field.

title: Allie Coyle becomes the first female to win a Maryland Boys’ Soccer State Title
summary: Allie Coyle, the head boys’ soccer coach at Montgomery Blair High School, became the first female to lead a team to a Maryland Boys’ Soccer State Title. Her historic victory defied gender stereotypes and inspired both young women and her athletes.

title: Loss of federal funds could leave migrant children in the lurch
summary: The Trump administration plans to end federal funding for legal representation of unaccompanied immigrant children in Maryland and nationwide, potentially leaving thousands without court assistance. This decision could force minors to navigate complex immigration cases alone while managing school, work, and emotional trauma, increasing the risk of deportation.

title: Education Department employees cheered as they leave, warn of impacts of cuts on the future
summary: Laid-off Department of Education employees were met with cheers and support as they left their offices, with some raising fists in defiance amid widespread protests and solidarity demonstrations. The mass layoffs, reducing the workforce by 50%, have raised concerns about the impact on public services and followed a controversial reorganization of downsizing procedures.

title: Van Hollen, Subramanyam lead Democrats against Trump’s efforts to move federal agencies
summary: Democrats led by Sen. Chris Van Hollen and Rep.

title: DOGE is cutting GSA  leases across Maryland and D.C. Here’s why the market’s optimistic
summary: DOGE has terminated nearly 30 GSA leases in Maryland and D.C., claiming $7.5 million in savings as part of its broader effort to reduce federal office space and save taxpayer money. While the move has drawn criticism from local leaders, real estate markets remain cautiously optimistic about the potential for future lease reductions and office space availability.

title: Trump wants the Panama canal back, but Afro-Caribbeans are staking a personal claim
summary: Trump's comments about reclaiming the Panama Canal have reignited debates over its history, particularly for Panama's Afro-Caribbean community, whose ancestors provided much of the labor during its construction. Community leaders emphasize their heritage's critical role, fearing their contributions could be overlooked in ongoing discussions about the canal's legacy and control.

title: Van Hollen, other Senate Democrats call Social Security nominee unfit
summary: Senate Democrats, including Sen. Chris Van Hollen, accused President Trump’s nominee for Social Security Administrator, Frank Bisignano, of being unfit and misleading the Senate on his ties to Elon Musk’s DOGE, which seeks to drastically reduce the agency’s workforce.

title: Former NIH director urges patients to speak out against Trump’s health cuts
summary: Former NIH director Dr. Francis Collins urged patients and families to speak out against proposed health cuts, warning that continued reductions under the Trump administration could harm NIH's life-saving research and operations.

title: GOP-controlled panel rejects Mfume’s efforts to get documents on federal firings
summary: House Republicans rejected a Democratic effort led by Rep. Kweisi Mfume to obtain Trump administration documents related to the firing of federal employees, including those in diversity and oversight roles.

title: A shift in Christianity across the U.S. may continue as Gen Z ages
summary: Christianity in the U.S. is declining among younger generations, with only 45% of Gen Z identifying as Christian, reflecting a broader trend of decreasing religiosity.

title: How the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse is reshaping daily life in Baltimore
summary: The collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge has significantly disrupted daily life for many Maryland residents, particularly commuters who relied on the bridge for shorter travel times. With alternative routes causing major traffic congestion, some, like Pam Moffett, have had to make major lifestyle changes, including relocating closer to work.

title: Baltimore averted economic crisis one year after Key Bridge collapse
summary: Baltimore avoided a major economic crisis one year after the Key Bridge collapse due to a swift federal response, state support, and community resilience. The port reopened within 77 days, and many affected workers, like trucker Reginald McMillan, found new ways to adapt and recover.

title: Wealth, fame help pro athletes to help others — but leading a charity can be challenging
summary: Ryan Kerrigan's charity, Blitz for the Better, which helped ill and special needs children, declined after financial struggles and time constraints, highlighting the challenges athletes face in sustaining philanthropy. While some athletes successfully support causes through nonprofits, others encounter obstacles like administrative demands and limited resources.

title: As philanthropists, some athletes look to fans, sponsors while others rely on personal wealth
summary: Professional athletes fund their charitable efforts either through personal wealth or external support from fans, sponsors, or teams, with experts divided on whether the source of funding affects the legitimacy of the cause. A review found that many athletes rely heavily on public donations, with some contributing less than half of the funds raised for their foundations.

title: When starting a charity is too much, some pro athletes join a nonprofit team
summary: Professional athletes like Baltimore Orioles pitcher Tyler Wells are choosing to support established nonprofits like Vs. Cancer and Big League Impact rather than starting their own charities.

title: Frances Tiafoe gives back to College Park youth tennis center via charitable fund
summary: Frances Tiafoe, a top tennis player who grew up at the Junior Tennis Champions Center in College Park, launched a charitable fund in 2023 to support youth tennis programs in Prince George’s County. His $50,000 donation to the center aims to help local kids, especially those from underrepresented communities, pursue tennis and college opportunities.

title: From military families to chronic disease, athletes choose charitable causes that hit close to home
summary: Golfer Billy Hurley III, the only U.S. Military Service Academy graduate to win on the PGA Tour, founded a nonprofit to support military families affected by service.

title: By the numbers: More than 60 pro athletes in the D.C. area founded charities in the last 10 years
summary: Over the past decade, more than 60 professional athletes in the D.C. area established charities, including notable figures like Lamar Jackson, Russell Westbrook, and Michael Phelps.

title: In Massachusetts and elsewhere, youngsters find healing through art
summary: In Massachusetts, children participate in art therapy programs like Raw Art Works, using creative activities such as building mazes to express themselves and heal from personal struggles. These initiatives, found nationwide, help youths process challenges and find resilience through artistic expression.

title: As youngsters struggle with mental health, some get help from peers
summary: Peer-led mental health initiatives, such as Sources of Strength, are helping students across the U.S. and Canada by providing support and fostering connection among young people struggling with mental health.

title: As Black Lives Matter Plaza becomes rubble, onlookers mourn symbol of hope
summary: Workers in Washington, D.C., began demolishing the "Black Lives Matter" mural on 16th Street following pressure from the Republican-controlled Congress, sparking emotional reactions from onlookers. The removal of the symbol, painted after the 2020 protests, has been seen by some as an erasure of the message that "everything matters" in the current political climate.

title: Lawmakers seek to ban gender-affirming medication for those under 18
summary: Lawmakers in Maryland are considering the Protect the Kids Act, which would ban gender-affirming medications for minors and penalize providers with felony charges. The bill faces strong opposition from transgender rights advocates, as the state currently safeguards such care through its Trans Health Equity Act.

title: At the Department of Education, protests – and warnings – over firings
summary: A Department of Education employee, Sarah Newman, protested outside the agency's headquarters after being laid off in a major workforce reduction that cut nearly half the staff, expressing concern over its impact on student equality. The layoffs also eliminated investigative staff in seven of the Office of Civil Rights' regional offices, raising concerns about the enforcement of educational equity.

title: Metro sees a spike in rides amidst return to work orders
summary: Metrorail has experienced a significant increase in ridership in early February, attributed to federal and private-sector return-to-office policies and seasonal travel. While ridership has not yet reached pre-pandemic levels, the trend could benefit Metro financially, though potential federal funding cuts and service adjustments remain concerns.

title: Maryland lawmakers target the tranquilizers behind recent overdose deaths
summary: Maryland lawmakers are pushing to restrict two veterinary tranquilizers, xylazine and medetomidine, which are increasingly found in overdose deaths, but the state health department resists, fearing unintended consequences. While neighboring states have scheduled xylazine, Maryland has not, drawing criticism from some Republicans who blame the inaction for preventable deaths.

title: In crowded town hall, Maryland constituents air worries about government cuts
summary: Hundreds of Maryland residents expressed concerns at a town hall about Trump administration efforts to dismantle federal agencies and cut programs, particularly affecting veterans and education. Lawmakers emphasized opposition to these cuts and urged constituents to continue advocating for their rights and benefits.

title: On NTSB recommendations, FAA closes helicopter route near DC airport weeks after tragedy
summary: The National Transportation Safety Board recommended closing a helicopter route near Reagan National Airport following a deadly midair collision, and the FAA quickly agreed to implement the changes. The move aims to address unsafe airspace overlaps between landing aircraft and helicopters, especially after data revealed thousands of near-collisions in recent years.

title: Maryland’s Elfreth leads legislative effort to protect fired probationary federal workers
summary: Maryland Rep. Sarah Elfreth introduced the Protect Our Probationary Employees Act to help federal workers who were fired by the Trump administration reclaim their seniority if rehired.

title: Trump’s immigration arrests and deportations, by the numbers
summary: President Trump's administration has seen a rise in immigration arrests compared to President Biden's term, though deportations have fallen short of officials' expectations. While ICE reports higher book-ins and daily arrests, removal numbers remain lower than some months under the previous administration.

title: Other states have tackled youth gambling. Why hasn’t Maryland?
summary: Maryland is seeing a rise in youth gambling, with nearly one in five high school students having gambled in the past year, but the state lacks a comprehensive education policy to address the issue, unlike several others. While programs like MD-Smart Choices exist, staffing shortages and limited resources have hindered their reach and effectiveness.

title: Lawmakers battle between cracking down and easing up on prison sentences
summary: Lawmakers in Maryland are divided over prison sentencing reform, with one bill allowing good-behaving offenders to seek reduced sentences after 20 years and another aiming to block violent offenders from earning time off. Both proposals, which faced emotional debate and failed last year, are again being pushed amid strong support and opposition from victims' families and formerly incarcerated individuals.

title: Anti-gang efforts in the Caribbean are feeling the Trump cuts
summary: U.S. funding cuts to anti-gang programs in the Caribbean have disrupted initiatives aimed at reducing violence and supporting at-risk youth.

title: Maryland federal properties targeted for sale – but the list changed (then disappeared)
summary: The Trump administration initially listed 443 federal properties, including 83 in Maryland, for potential sale, but later revised and removed the list, reducing the number to 320. The sudden changes drew criticism from lawmakers, who accused the administration of causing chaos and targeting essential government facilities.

title: Lawmakers, environmental groups say Trump freezes threaten local water quality
summary: President Trump’s spending freezes and grants cuts are hindering clean water initiatives in the Chesapeake Bay region, according to lawmakers and environmental groups. Coalition members report that frozen federal funds have stalled critical projects, threatening both local economies and the health of the Bay.

title: Maryland energy proposal leaves the door open for new gas plants
summary: Maryland's proposed Next Generation Energy Act aims to lower utility bills and promote cleaner energy projects, but environmental advocates are concerned it could lead to the construction of new natural gas plants. Critics argue provisions in the bill favor gas over renewable alternatives like battery storage, despite the state's climate goals.

title: Maryland lawmakers, unions denounce continued Trump firings of federal workers
summary: Federal workers, unions, and lawmakers gathered in Washington to protest what they call Trump administration efforts to undermine civil service protections through widespread firings and job cuts. They argue the actions threaten the merit-based system and jeopardize the dedicated work of public servants.

title: Marylanders decry Trump’s Ukraine stance as threat to democracy
summary: Hundreds of Maryland residents rallied in Annapolis to protest President Trump’s handling of Ukraine, expressing fears that his policies threaten democratic values and align the U.S. with Russia.

title: While movie theaters close nationwide, Maryland’s independent theaters survive
summary: While movie theaters nationwide have declined, with nearly 5,000 screens lost since the pandemic, Maryland’s independent theaters have managed to survive by offering unique repertory programming. These theaters attract dedicated cinephiles with rare and older films, providing a distinct value that sets them apart from struggling major chains.
