title: Gov. Moore’s proposed tax breaks could mean service cuts in lower-income counties
summary: Governor Wes Moore's proposed tax reforms aim to provide tax relief to most Marylanders by doubling the standard deduction and eliminating itemized deductions, but officials in lower-income counties warn it could lead to significant budget shortfalls. County representatives argue the changes will disproportionately harm their communities, despite the administration's claim that the reforms will benefit low- and middle-income households.

title: Youth mental health profiles by county
summary: The Local News Network is investigating youth mental health solutions in Maryland through its project "Youth mental health: What Works?" supported by a grant from the Solutions Journalism Network. The initiative examines innovative programs in schools and communities across the state’s 23 counties and Baltimore.

title: Youth Mental Health: What Works?
summary: Effective youth mental health interventions include early screening, access to school-based counseling, and community support programs. Combining therapy, family involvement, and reduced stigma leads to better long-term outcomes for young people.

title: How one Maryland school district turned around student behavior with ‘restorative practices’
summary: Pocomoke High School in Maryland has significantly improved student behavior and academic outcomes by implementing "restorative practices," which focus on building relationships rather than relying on traditional discipline. The approach has led to a 28% drop in violent incidents and a 100% graduation rate for the Class of 2024.

title: State officials brace for big layoffs of federal workers
summary: Maryland state officials are preparing for potential large-scale federal worker layoffs by expanding unemployment benefits, job assistance programs, and hiring fairs to support affected employees. Governor Wes Moore and Labor Secretary Portia Wu are leading efforts to connect displaced workers with resources and local job opportunities.

title: Sudden firings by Trump administration rock key climate and weather agency
summary: The Trump administration abruptly fired hundreds of employees at the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration, giving them less than two hours to leave the office and turn in equipment. Termination letters cited a lack of fit with the agency's current needs, leaving many, including a long-time marine biologist, in shock and disarray.

title: Former USAID workers grieve the life-saving work they used to do
summary: Former USAID workers, including Elizabeth Glidden and Allison Eriksen, are mourning the loss of their meaningful jobs as the Trump administration initiated a reevaluation of federal aid, leading to widespread layoffs. Many former employees, who once took pride in humanitarian and global development work, now face uncertainty and feelings of betrayal.

title: Caribbean islands mark Carnival in a time of emergency
summary: Trinidad and Tobago is holding its vibrant Carnival celebrations amid a declared state of emergency, with partygoers largely undeterred by heightened security measures. Despite the emergency, there is no visible military presence or curfew, and the city continues to function as usual with bustling streets and festivities.

title: Thousands of Maryland students are chronically absent each year. Here’s what we know
summary: Chronic absenteeism among Maryland students has risen significantly since the COVID-19 pandemic, with nearly 27% of students missing 10% or more of school in the 2023-2024 academic year. Factors contributing to absences include unsafe school environments, family responsibilities, health issues, and community challenges, all of which can negatively impact graduation and college enrollment rates.

title: Baltimore’s Red Line and other Md. transit projects face tough odds this spring
summary: Maryland lawmakers are reconsidering major transit projects like Baltimore’s Red Line due to uncertain federal funding and budget constraints, despite their economic and community benefits. While some advocate for pausing these initiatives until more favorable conditions arise, others push for continued investment in anticipation of future federal support for transit.

title: Fired federal workers descend on Senate to put human faces on Trump-Musk cuts
summary: Nearly 40 recently fired federal workers visited Senate offices to share their stories and oppose the Trump-Musk-led Department of Government Efficiency, which has resulted in nearly 30,000 layoffs. Democratic lawmakers condemned the cuts, with some renaming the agency the "Department of Government Evil" and arguing it undermines public services for political gain.

title: Merrill College capstone class descriptions
summary: Merrill College students in the Annapolis bureau cover state government and key issues through daily reporting, research, and interviews, with stories published on CNS and distributed to major news outlets. The program, held in a historic newsroom near the State House, offers undergraduates flexible scheduling and coverage of diverse beats such as health, environment, and cybersecurity.

title: State youth mental health grants in Worcester County

title: State youth mental health grants in Queen Anne’s County

title: Maryland spent big on youth mental health — but then the budget crisis hit

With ongoing budget challenges, Governor Wes Moore now proposes $40 million annually through 2030, far below his original $130 million annual goal, drawing criticism for potentially harming emerging student services.

summary: The Maryland Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports awarded $945,000 in youth mental health grants to Somerset County in 2024. summary: The Maryland Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports awarded $2.02 million in grants to St. Mary’s County to improve youth mental health services.

summary: The Maryland Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports awarded $975,000 in grants to Kent County organizations to improve youth mental health services. For All Seasons Inc.

summary: Baltimore County received $8.87 million in state grants to support youth mental health through eight local organizations. The funding will expand services such as therapy, medication management, prevention programs, school interventions, and counseling for a range of mental health issues.

summary: The Maryland Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports awarded $2.9 million in youth mental health grants to seven Calvert County organizations. summary: Maryland awarded $1.47 million in youth mental health grants to five Dorchester County organizations in 2024. title: State youth mental health grants in Charles County
summary: The Maryland Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports awarded $3.97 million in youth mental health grants to four Charles County organizations in 2024. The funds will support services such as therapy, telehealth, skill-building, and mental health education for students and families.

summary: Maryland's Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports awarded $12 million in youth mental health grants to 11 organizations in Baltimore City in 2024. title: State youth mental health grants in Wicomico County
summary: The Maryland Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports awarded $965,000 in youth mental health grants to Wicomico County. title: State youth mental health grants in Washington County
summary: The Maryland Consortium on Coordinated Community Supports awarded $4.1 million in youth mental health grants to six organizations in Washington County in 2024. title: About “Youth Mental Health: What Works?”
summary: Student journalists at the University of Maryland are investigating youth mental health challenges and effective solutions through their project "Youth Mental Health: What Works?" supported by a grant from the Solutions Journalism Network. title: Gov. Moore’s cuts to Blueprint plan face major pushback
summary: Gov. Wes Moore's proposal to freeze and reduce funding for parts of Maryland’s Blueprint for Education reform has faced strong opposition from advocates, students, and educators who argue it disproportionately harms low-income and minority students.

title: DC Metro transit needs money, but Maryland’s not in a great position to help
summary: D.C. Metro officials are asking Maryland for financial help amid a budget crisis, but lawmakers say the state cannot afford to increase its contribution due to its own $3 billion deficit.

title: Van Hollen calls GOP budget plan, Trump cuts ‘betrayal’
summary: Sen. Chris Van Hollen criticized the GOP budget plan endorsed by President Trump, calling it a "betrayal" for cutting Medicaid and other public programs to fund tax breaks for the wealthy.

title: Maryland Democrats appalled by Trump’s Ukraine stance
summary: Maryland Democratic lawmakers condemned President Trump for criticizing Ukrainian President Zelensky as a dictator and for downplaying Russia's role in the Ukraine war. Zelensky accused Trump of living in a "web of disinformation," as tensions flared over U.S.-Russia talks that excluded Ukraine.

title: State may block Trump administration from Maryland databases
summary: Maryland lawmakers are proposing the Data Privacy Act to restrict state agencies from sharing resident data with federal immigration authorities without a valid warrant, aiming to protect privacy and prevent federal overreach. The legislation responds to heightened immigration enforcement under the Trump administration, which has raised fears within immigrant communities about safety and access to state services.

title: Egg prices hit record high amid bird flu outbreak
summary: Egg prices reached a record high in January due to a bird flu outbreak that has decimated poultry flocks across the U.S., including Maryland, leading to empty shelves and purchase limits at major retailers. The American Egg Board warns that high demand and ongoing HPAI outbreaks will keep prices elevated until the poultry supply stabilizes.

title: Craving more energy, Maryland looks to nuclear power
summary: Maryland leaders are pushing for new nuclear energy projects as part of efforts to meet clean energy goals and ensure power reliability. The ENERGIZE Maryland Act and other legislation aim to classify nuclear as clean energy and establish a process for developing new nuclear facilities in the state.

title: Maryland considers shake-up in how judges are picked
summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering two conflicting proposals to reform how circuit court judges are selected, with one aiming to improve the current contested election system and the other seeking to eliminate such elections entirely through a constitutional amendment. The debate reflects a long-standing division over whether contested elections help voters shape the judiciary or undermine judicial impartiality.

title: New Md. bill could improve police awareness of unseen disabilities
summary: A new Maryland bill, Eric’s ID Law, would allow residents to indicate invisible disabilities on their driver’s licenses or state IDs and require police training to improve interactions with such individuals. The proposal aims to enhance safety during encounters with first responders, particularly for Black individuals with hidden disabilities.

title: Test: Breakthrough in Fusion Energy: Scientists Achieve Record-Breaking Power Output in Latest Experiment
summary: Scientists have achieved a record-breaking power output in a fusion energy experiment, marking a significant breakthrough. This advancement brings the potential of clean, sustainable energy closer to reality.

title: Fearing ICE raids, Delmarva immigrants mostly stay home
summary: Undocumented immigrants on the Delmarva Peninsula are staying home out of fear of potential ICE raids, causing a noticeable quiet in once-bustling immigrant neighborhoods. Many worry that their absence could disrupt key industries reliant on their labor, including agriculture, construction, and hospitality.

title: Maryland constituents voice worries about Trump actions during senators’ call-in
summary: Maryland residents expressed concerns during a virtual town hall with Democratic senators about the Trump administration's efforts to dismantle federal agencies, citing potential harm to public health, research, and federal jobs. Sens.

title: Lawmakers spar over Trump-Musk efforts to dissolve USAID
summary: Lawmakers criticized the Trump administration's attempt to dissolve USAID, arguing that freezing the agency's funding without congressional approval violates constitutional and legal procedures. During a House hearing, Rep.

title: State apologizes to man wrongly imprisoned for murder
summary: Marando Warthen received a $3 million compensation and a formal apology from the state of Maryland after spending decades in prison for a wrongful murder conviction. His convictions were vacated in 2023, and he was released from a 103-year sentence.

title: Maryland officials denounce Trump efforts to dismantle federal civil service
summary: Maryland officials and federal employee unions condemned the Trump administration's efforts to dismantle the civil service, criticizing the influence of Elon Musk and the politicization of federal agencies. They called for ending what they described as an illegal operation aimed at privatizing the federal workforce.

title: What will win best picture at the Oscars? Here’s what the data says
summary: The 2024 Oscars Best Picture race lacks a clear frontrunner, with various critics and outlets favoring different films such as *A Complete Unknown*, *Wicked*, and *The Brutalist*. Based on data analysis comparing factors like budget, box office, and nominations to past winners, Netflix’s *Emilia Pérez* remains a strong contender despite recent controversies.

title: Advocates fight cuts to Maryland’s disabilities agency
summary: Advocates in Maryland are urging lawmakers to reject proposed $200 million in cuts to the Developmental Disabilities Administration, warning of severe impacts on essential disability services. As attention shifts to broader financial mismanagement concerns, the disability community fears its needs are being overlooked in the state budget debate.

title: Georgia requires little basic training for new police officers
summary: Georgia requires only 160 hours of basic training for new police officers, significantly less than the national average. Critics argue the short training period may not adequately prepare officers for real-world law enforcement challenges.

title: Super Bowl LIX: How Kellen Moore’s ‘genius’ game plan helped Eagles to dominant win vs. Chiefs
summary: Kellen Moore's strategic game plan was instrumental in the Eagles' 40-22 victory over the Chiefs in Super Bowl LIX, as he effectively countered Kansas City's defense and showcased his offensive brilliance. Despite the Chiefs neutralizing key weapons like Saquon Barkley, Moore adapted by utilizing Jalen Hurts' passing and rushing abilities to exploit weaknesses in the opposing defense.

title: Trump moves could mean bigger cuts in state budget
summary: New decisions by the Trump administration could lead to deeper cuts in Maryland's state budget, with concerns over federal Medicaid reductions and cost-shifting increasing the financial burden on the state. Senate President Bill Ferguson warned that these moves could have a devastating impact on the state's economy and its ability to fund essential programs.

title: Super Bowl LIX: Maryland upbringing set stage for Thomas Booker’s NFL success
summary: Thomas Booker, a defensive tackle for the Philadelphia Eagles, credits his Maryland upbringing and academic discipline for his NFL success as he prepares to face the Kansas City Chiefs in Super Bowl LIX. With a strong educational background and a family rooted in law and finance, Booker is expected to achieve even greater success beyond his football career.

title: Democrats and protesters rally against Trump-Musk efforts to shut down USAID
summary: Democrats and protesters gathered in Washington to oppose the Trump administration’s attempt to shut down USAID, calling the move illegal and unconstitutional. They also criticized Elon Musk’s role in pushing to eliminate the agency, which provides critical global humanitarian aid.

title: Musk targeting key weather forecasting and scientific research agency, Van Hollen says
summary: Senator Chris Van Hollen alleges that Elon Musk and his associates are targeting NOAA, gaining access to its systems and disrupting operations under the guise of complying with DEI-related executive orders. Van Hollen warns that such actions threaten the agency’s critical role in weather forecasting and scientific research that saves lives.

title: Gov. Moore calls for courage amid Trump “chaos”
summary: Gov. Wes Moore urged lawmakers to confront Maryland’s $3 billion budget deficit with courage, calling for tax hikes and program cuts amid uncertainty from the Trump administration.

title: Lawmakers debate the sentencing of youth as adults
summary: Maryland lawmakers are debating whether to reduce the state's practice of automatically trying serious juvenile offenders as adults, with a revised proposal allowing juvenile courts to handle some violent crime cases by default. While reform advocates argue the adult system worsens outcomes and increases recidivism, prosecutors warn that shifting more cases to the already strained juvenile system could threaten public safety.

title: Report finds unjustifiable grounds for picking Greenbelt as new FBI Headquarters
summary: A federal inspector general found that the General Services Administration used unjustified reasons and provided inaccurate data in selecting Greenbelt, Maryland, as the new FBI headquarters site. While the report did not recommend a new selection process, it raised concerns over cost estimates, missing equity data, and poor record-keeping, prompting criticism from some lawmakers.

title: Maryland gets a glimpse of design for the new Key Bridge
summary: Maryland Governor Wes Moore unveiled the design for the new Francis Scott Key Bridge, which will be taller than the previous one and is expected to be fully funded by the federal government. Construction is set to begin in spring 2024, with the new bridge projected for completion in 2028.

title: Lawmakers hope to cut utility bills, expand Maryland power grid
summary: Maryland Democratic leaders introduced a new energy plan aimed at expanding the state's power grid, promoting renewable and nuclear energy, and reducing utility bills. Republicans criticized the proposal, arguing it lacks short-term solutions and fails to address the immediate concerns of high energy costs.

title: Health, environmental concerns divide East Palestine two years after train derailment, toxic fire
summary: Two years after a Norfolk Southern train derailment in East Palestine, Ohio, spilled toxic chemicals and caused a deadly fire, cleanup efforts have removed vast amounts of contaminated soil and water, with environmental officials stating no current risk to public health. Despite these efforts, residents continue to report health issues they attribute to chemical exposure, and concerns over long-term effects persist.

title: Two years after derailment, trains with toxic chemicals still roll through East Palestine
summary: Two years after a Norfolk Southern train derailment in East Palestine, Ohio, released toxic chemicals, trains carrying the same hazardous materials still pass through the town with little oversight or public awareness. Despite concerns, there is no legal requirement for railroads to disclose detailed information about hazardous cargo to local officials or residents in advance.

title: Maryland may dip into its climate fund to pay for other things
summary: Maryland Governor Wes Moore's 2026 budget proposal includes redirecting $150 million from a renewable energy fund to address a $3 billion budget deficit, despite concerns from environmental groups. While the plan increases funding for climate initiatives, it also reduces general support for environmental agencies, relying instead on special funds.

title: Figure skating community devastated by D.C. plane crash
summary: The figure skating community is mourning the loss of at least 14 young skaters and several coaches following a mid-air collision over the Potomac River, which devastated the Skating Club of Boston and other affiliated clubs. The tragedy echoes the 1961 crash that wiped out the U.S.

title: Investigators dig into the “why” of the American Airlines crash
summary: Federal officials, led by the NTSB, are conducting a thorough investigation into the mid-air collision between an American Airlines flight and a U.S. Army Black Hawk helicopter near Washington, D.C.

title: Travelers at Reagan reflect on safety – and life – after fatal crash
summary: Travelers at Reagan National Airport reflected on safety and life following the fatal midair collision of an American Airlines jet and an Army helicopter near the Potomac River, which resulted in no known survivors. Despite the tragedy, airport activity gradually resumed, with passengers like 70-year-old Lynn Vera continuing their journeys, expressing no fear but deep sympathy for the victims' families.

title: Without evidence, Trump blames DEI hires and Democrats for deadly plane collision
summary: Former President Donald Trump blamed Obama and Biden administration diversity initiatives for a fatal plane and helicopter collision near Washington National Airport, despite offering no evidence. Aviation experts and lawmakers criticized his remarks for undermining established investigation protocols.

title: Should Maryland grant parole to more elderly and ill inmates?
summary: Maryland lawmakers are divided over proposed reforms that would make it easier for elderly and seriously ill inmates to seek early parole, with supporters arguing it is a matter of justice and opponents insisting on strict sentencing. Current state law imposes strict eligibility criteria for medical and geriatric parole, which advocates say contradict the original intent of the programs.

title: Officials switch from rescue to recovery at site of deadly American Airlines crash
summary: Officials have shifted from rescue to recovery efforts following a deadly mid-air collision between an American Airlines flight and a U.S. Army helicopter over the Potomac River, with no survivors expected.

title: Trump’s funding freeze draws ire of Gov. Wes Moore, other Democrats
summary: Governor Wes Moore and other Democrats strongly criticized Trump’s federal funding freeze, calling it irrational and harmful to Marylanders, and vowed to challenge the decision. Over twenty states, including Maryland, plan to sue to stop the order, which critics argue represents executive overreach and creates widespread uncertainty.

While the risk to humans is low, concerns remain about potential mutations that could lead to a pandemic, especially as wild birds and farm proximity continue to pose challenges for containment.

title: Advocates say budget cuts would harm Maryland residents with disabilities
summary: Maryland advocates warn that proposed budget cuts to the Developmental Disabilities Administration could harm vulnerable residents by reducing care quality and affecting provider wages. title: Marylanders mark an iconic week of Trump and MLK
summary: Maryland lawmakers reflected on the legacies of Donald Trump and Martin Luther King Jr. during a politically charged week marked by contrasting emotions and priorities.

title: Maryland joins fight against Trump’s order to end birthright citizenship
summary: Maryland joined 16 other states in suing President Trump over his executive order to end birthright citizenship, arguing it violates the 14th Amendment and federal law. The states claim the policy is unconstitutional and un-American, vowing to challenge it in court.

title: Police drones are flying over Maryland. Will state lawmakers regulate them?
summary: Montgomery County police in Maryland are using drones to respond to emergencies, with the program having addressed nearly 2,000 calls since its launch. State lawmakers are now considering regulations to address concerns about privacy and the legal implications of expanding drone use in law enforcement.

title: Trump resumes power and promises a “golden age”
summary: Donald Trump was inaugurated as the 47th U.S. President, vowing to end America’s decline and usher in a “golden age” marked by isolationist policies and border security measures.

title: Marcus Garvey pardon brings long-awaited joy to supporters
summary: After decades of effort, Marcus Garvey is set to receive a posthumous pardon from the U.S. government, a decision that brought relief and satisfaction to his son Julius Garvey and supporters in the Black diaspora.

title: Lawmakers may allow “X” for sex on Maryland birth certificates
summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering the Birth Certificate Modernization Act, which would introduce a gender-neutral "X" designation on birth certificates to better recognize transgender and non-binary individuals. The bill aims to streamline gender amendments on official documents and protect against discrimination, especially amid concerns over potential rollbacks of LGBTQ+ rights under a potential Trump administration.

title: Trump draws boos and cheers from weekend crowds
summary: As Donald Trump's inauguration approaches, Washington, D.C. saw mixed reactions this weekend, with pro-Trump rallies and diverse protest groups converging to express both support and resistance.

title: Gov. Moore’s proposed budget features massive cuts and tax hikes
summary: Gov. Wes Moore proposed a budget aimed at reducing Maryland’s $3 billion deficit through tax hikes on top earners and cuts to education and disability programs.

title: Four pressing questions about the state budget
summary: Maryland faces a $3 billion budget deficit, prompting debates over potential tax increases, including a "millionaire tax," as lawmakers aim to avoid raising taxes. title: Gov. Moore hopes to make Maryland the quantum capital of the world
summary: Governor Wes Moore is investing $27.5 million in Maryland's "Capital of Quantum" initiative to position the state as a global leader in quantum computing. Despite recent market volatility in the industry, Moore believes the investment is a smart move for both short-term economic growth and long-term technological leadership.

title: Gov. Moore previews possible tax hikes for prosperous Marylanders
summary: Governor Wes Moore is proposing tax reforms that would cut taxes for most Marylanders and lower the corporate tax rate, while asking higher-earning individuals to pay more, as part of a budget plan aimed at addressing a $3 billion deficit and promoting economic growth. Republican lawmakers express concerns over potential reckless spending and call for dedicated funding sources for major programs like the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future.

title: Gov. Moore orders state to tighten its belt — but bigger cuts are coming
summary: Gov. Wes Moore has launched the Government Modernization Initiative, directing state agencies to identify and eliminate wasteful spending with a goal of saving $50 million this year.

title: Families salute Maryland women of “Six Triple Eight”
summary: Families of 19 Maryland women who served in the historically Black 6888th Central Postal Directory Battalion during World War II are celebrating newfound recognition through Tyler Perry’s film *The Six Triple Eight*. The movie has brought public attention to the unit’s contributions and inspired pride among descendants, highlighting the women’s perseverance in the face of segregation and societal barriers.

title: Jimmy Carter and the diverse voters who loved him
summary: Jimmy Carter's 1976 presidential victory was built on a fragile coalition of rural, urban Black, and white progressive voters, which has since unraveled, with many rural counties now reliably Republican. His state funeral prompted Democrats to reflect on how to rebuild the diverse unity that once defined his political success.

title: Jimmy Carter’s state funeral marks end of an era
summary: Former President Jimmy Carter was honored with a state funeral at the Washington National Cathedral, attended by all five living presidents and featuring eulogies and tributes that highlighted his legacy of humanitarian service and leadership. Remembered for his commitment to peace, public health, and compassion, Carter's death marked the end of an era as the nation prepares for a new presidential administration.

title: Gov. Moore plans huge cuts to state budget
summary: Governor Wes Moore has announced a budget proposal that includes $2 billion in cuts to address Maryland's largest structural deficit in two decades. With potential federal funding reductions under the new Trump administration, balancing the budget is expected to be the top priority for the General Assembly in the 2025 session.

title: Explore Congressional Travel in Searchable Database
summary: A new searchable database allows the public to explore detailed records of congressional travel. The tool provides transparency by listing trips, destinations, costs, and purposes of travel by members of Congress.

title: Tech lobby uses glitzy electronics show to woo key house policymakers
summary: The Consumer Technology Association, which includes major tech firms like Microsoft and Google, sponsors House staffers to attend the Consumer Electronics Show in Las Vegas, using the event to push for federal privacy laws that would override state regulations. Over the past decade, CTA has funded the travel of hundreds of lawmakers and staff to the event, aiming to shape national policies on privacy and AI.

title: State eyes new way to count students in need
summary: Maryland is considering a new approach to identifying students in poverty to ensure more accurate funding for schools, as the current method undercounts low-income and immigrant student populations. The state aims to move beyond outdated and incomplete data sources like free meal applications and social program enrollments to better allocate resources for students in need.

title: ‘Hello Girl’ from Maryland may soon win a medal for her World War I service
summary: Marie Edmee LeRoux, a World War I telephone operator known as a “Hello Girl,” may soon receive a congressional gold medal for her service, which has long been overlooked. As part of the U.S.

title: Algerian journalist and activist, 65, pardoned during third stint in prison
summary: Algerian journalist Ihsane El Kadi, 65, was pardoned and released from prison in late October 2024 after serving 22 months on charges related to his media company and foreign funding. This marked his third arrest and imprisonment, with his release coinciding with a broader presidential pardon linked to the anniversary of Algeria’s independence war.

title: Roman Ivanov’s story is a microcosm of media censorship in Russia
summary: Journalist Roman Ivanov was sentenced to seven years in prison for criticizing Russia's war in Ukraine and spreading what the government deemed false information, exemplifying the growing crackdown on dissenting voices in the media. His case highlights President Vladimir Putin's broader strategy to silence critics and control independent journalism through legal persecution and censorship.

title: Exiled for reporting: The story of Nicaraguan journalist Victor Ticay Ruiz
summary: Victor Ticay Ruiz, a Nicaraguan journalist, spent 517 days in a harsh prison environment after being arrested for filming a Holy Week procession, which the government deemed a crime against national sovereignty. He was released in September after 17 months and exiled to Guatemala, joining over 200 other journalists forced out of Nicaragua by the Ortega administration.

title: Vietnamese journalist, former UMD fellow, imprisoned amid nationwide crackdown on press freedom
summary: Vietnamese journalist Truong Huy San, known for his bold political commentary, was arrested on charges of "abusing democratic freedoms" after years of criticizing the government online. His imprisonment reflects a broader crackdown on press freedom in Vietnam under new leader To Lam, who has expanded the role of security forces.

title: Little Belarus: Warsaw becomes home for exiles
summary: A bakery in Warsaw, Kawairnia Bialoruska, has become a cultural and emotional sanctuary for hundreds of Belarusian exiles who fled repression under President Alexander Lukashenko. Exiled journalists, now based in Warsaw, continue critical reporting and use creative methods like "balcony analysis" to maintain their connection to Belarus and inform the public.

title: An emerging crime in Hong Kong: Freedom of speech and press
summary: Hong Kong has experienced a dramatic decline in press freedom since the imposition of China's National Security Law in 2020, leading to the arrest of journalists and the closure of independent media outlets like Apple Daily. Once known for its vibrant media landscape, the city now ranks among the worst in Asia for press freedom, with many journalists either jailed or unemployed.

title: Iran’s oldest political prisoner released, still an activist
summary: Keyvan Samimi, Iran’s oldest political prisoner, was released in 2023 after more than a decade in and out of prison, having been arrested at least 10 times since 1966 for his activism and journalism. His case highlights Iran's ongoing suppression of free speech, with journalists and pro-democracy advocates frequently imprisoned for challenging government narratives.

title: Israel’s War on the Media: Palestinian Alaa Al-Rimawi one of nearly 50 journalists imprisoned; many more killed in war
summary: Alaa Al-Rimawi, a Palestinian journalist and director of J-Media, was arrested by Israeli forces in October 2023 and is being held under administrative detention, a policy that allows indefinite imprisonment without trial. His case reflects the broader situation of nearly 50 Palestinian journalists imprisoned and many more killed by Israeli forces during the conflict with Hamas.

title: Inside Azerbaijan’s crackdown on independent media: The case of Aziz Orujov
summary: Azerbaijani journalist Aziz Orujov remains in pretrial detention over a year after his arrest, which his family and colleagues claim is part of a government crackdown on independent media. Orujov and other journalists face what they argue are fabricated charges, including currency smuggling, allegedly used to silence critical reporting ahead of key political events.

title: A map geek’s quest to clean the nation, one watershed at a time
summary: After a disappointing election result, Jon Merryman turned his frustration into action by cleaning up trash across 22 counties, finding emotional relief and a sense of purpose in environmental stewardship. His passion for protecting the environment began in childhood and has since driven him to dedicate much of his life to cleaning watersheds and educating others on the impact of pollution.

title: 5 artists from Maryland to add to your playlist
summary: Maryland is home to a diverse range of musical talent beyond its famous crab cakes and lacrosse culture, including folk-pop artist Maggie Rogers and punk band Turnstile. These artists, along with others highlighted, showcase the state's growing influence in the music scene with innovative sounds and dedicated fanbases.

title: Maryland tribe’s first female chief fights for identity, equality and preservation
summary: Donna Wolf Mother Abbott, the first female chief of a Maryland tribe, leads the Nause-Waiwash in preserving their cultural identity and history through education and community outreach. As chief for a decade, she balances tribal leadership with collaboration on conservation and cultural projects.

title: Some people need abortions later in pregnancy – many come to Maryland
summary: Maryland is a key destination for later-term abortions in the U.S., with two clinics offering procedures into the third trimester as restrictive laws in other states increase demand. These clinics see a growing number of out-of-state patients, especially after the Dobbs decision, with many seeking care due to fetal abnormalities or health risks.

title: Patients travel hundreds of miles to Maryland for abortion care
summary: Patients travel long distances to Maryland for abortion care, as the state remains a key access point following the overturning of Roe v. Wade and restrictive laws in neighboring states.

title: Lamar Jackson, Jayden Daniels and the new landscape for Black quarterbacks
summary: Lamar Jackson and Jayden Daniels delivered a standout quarterback matchup in Week 6, showcasing the growing prominence of Black quarterbacks in the NFL. Their performance reflects a shifting landscape where Black QBs are increasingly recognized for their skill, with experts predicting they will soon make up half of the league's starting quarterbacks.

title: If only birds were ‘puppies’: Lights Out Baltimore tracks 3,000 window collisions since 2018
summary: Lights Out Baltimore, a volunteer initiative started in 2008, has collected data on nearly 3,000 dead or injured birds since 2018, resulting from fatal window collisions during migration. The group advocates for bird-safe building practices and works with building managers to reduce the number of collisions by dimming lights and raising awareness.

title: The new Big Ten is resulting in sharply higher carbon emissions
summary: Carbon dioxide emissions from Big Ten football team travel more than tripled in 2024 compared to 2023, largely due to the addition of West Coast schools. Experts say the increased air travel contributes to global warming, pollution, and environmental harm, though the conference has not considered environmental impact in its scheduling decisions.

title: Trump and GOP Congress will have a 60-day deregulation fast pass
summary: With Donald Trump set to return to the presidency in January, backed by a Republican-controlled Congress, his administration is expected to aggressively use the Congressional Review Act (CRA) to roll back regulations from the Biden era. The CRA allows Congress and the president to quickly disapprove recent federal rules, preventing agencies from reinstating them in a similar form.

title: From Africa: Pathways to the NBA
summary: A documentary titled "From Africa: Pathways to the NBA" showcases the journey of top African basketball prospects at the NBA Academy Africa, highlighting their dedication, camaraderie, and aspirations for the NBA. The film was directed by Jenna Bloom and Alexa Wootten, with executive producers Mark Hyman and Nathan Stevens.

title: NASA to Maryland lawmakers: ‘High risk’ Goddard project had unrealistic launch schedule
summary: NASA canceled the $2 billion OSAM-1 project, citing excessive risk, high costs, and unrealistic goals, despite objections from Maryland lawmakers. The mission, based at Goddard Space Flight Center, faced years of delays and funding overruns before its official termination.

title: Carroll County’s transgender policies clash with Maryland Department of Education guidelines
summary: Carroll County Public Schools require parental notification when a student wishes to change their pronouns or gender identity, a policy that conflicts with broader state guidelines which do not mandate such disclosure. Advocates argue that the policy could be harmful, particularly for students with potentially abusive or unsupportive parents.

title: Trump’s DOD pick worries some Maryland vets
summary: Maryland veterans, including Army veteran Jennifer Hunt, express concern over renewed debates about women in combat, which they say distract from critical issues like military strategy and readiness. Trump’s Pentagon pick, Pete Hegseth, and the Project 2025 plan have reignited discussions on gender in the military, prompting backlash from women veterans who emphasize their long history of service.

title: As top Democrat on House judiciary panel, Maryland’s Raskin says rule of law will be top priority
summary: Maryland Rep. Jamie Raskin is poised to become the top Democrat on the House Judiciary Committee, vowing to prioritize the Constitution and rule of law.

title: Chance Stephens uses cryotherapy to enhance recovery from knee injury
summary: Chance Stephens tore his patellar tendon before his Maryland basketball career began but has since returned to play after a difficult recovery. Cryotherapy played a key role in helping him regain his performance on the court.

title: Maryland Democrats prepare for Trump 2.0
summary: Maryland Democratic leaders are preparing to resist potential Trump administration policies, particularly on immigration, while seeking areas for bipartisan cooperation. The state is bolstering its workforce and policy readiness to counter what they view as aggressive and potentially harmful federal actions.

title: Maryland’s Senate race drives record outside spending
summary: Outside groups spent over $57 million in Maryland's 2024 congressional races, with 90% of that driven by the Senate race between Angela Alsobrooks and Larry Hogan, far exceeding the state's previous spending record. While independent expenditures typically reflect support for candidates who already align with the groups' interests, the unprecedented spending highlights the growing influence of money in politics.

title: Maryland adult-use cannabis sales expected to yield over $100 million in tax revenue in 2025
summary: Maryland is projected to generate over $100 million in cannabis tax revenue in 2025, with retail sales expected to exceed $1.1 billion. Tax revenue is distributed among state and local funds, while health officials report a rise in cannabis-related emergency room visits, particularly among young adults.

title: Many Americans get their news from influencers with a conservative lean, according to Pew study
summary: A Pew Research Center study found that young adults, low-income workers, and Hispanic Americans are more likely to get their news from social media influencers, with nearly 40% of adults under 30 regularly consuming news this way. This shift in media consumption correlated with increased support for Donald Trump, particularly among younger voters and Hispanic communities.

title: On the basis of sex? SCOTUS hears arguments on Tennessee trans care ban
summary: The Supreme Court heard arguments on the constitutionality of Tennessee’s 2023 ban on gender-affirming care for minors, with the U.S. Solicitor General claiming it violates the 14th Amendment’s equal protection clause by discriminating based on sex.

title: Journalist fatalities are rising, a memorial is going up in their honor
summary: A new Fallen Journalists Memorial is being planned for the National Mall in Washington, D.C., set to honor over 3,100 journalists killed worldwide since 1837. Nearly 90% of these deaths have occurred in the last 50 years, with the memorial aiming to recognize those who lost their lives covering the news.

title: Trump’s mass deportations could hit Maryland economy, experts warn
summary: Experts warn that Trump’s proposed mass deportations could harm Maryland’s economy, particularly affecting the state’s large undocumented immigrant population. Communities like Langley Park, with high concentrations of Hispanic residents, could face panic and long-term social and economic consequences.

title: Try our Maryland-themed crossword | CNS Games
summary: CNS Games has launched three Maryland-themed puzzles, including a crossword, Wordle-style game, and word search. The crossword, created with PuzzleMe's generator, challenges players with clues centered around Maryland's favorite things.

title: A Wordle-style guessing game for Marylanders | CNS Games
summary: A Maryland-themed Wordle-style guessing game has been created by CNS Games, featuring a word puzzle, crossword, and word search highlighting local culture. The word guessing game gives a hint: "Something Baltimore is known for."

title: Search for popular Maryland words | CNS Games
summary: CNS Games has launched three Maryland-themed word games, including a Wordle-style puzzle, a crossword, and a word search. The word search, created with PuzzleMe's generator, challenges players to find terms related to Maryland's culture and identity.

title: Maryland grants help businesses avoid debt after Key Bridge collapse
summary: Maryland provided worker retention grants to help local businesses, like the Fraley Corporation, avoid debt and keep employees paid following the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge. Many business owners preferred state and city aid over federal SBA loans due to past financial obligations and a desire to avoid additional debt.

title: Serious and fatal crashes significantly reduced in Montgomery County
summary: The Vision Zero Initiative in Montgomery County has led to a more than 10% decrease in serious and fatal crashes. The county is implementing traffic signals, sidewalks, and bikeways as part of its plan to eliminate such collisions by 2030.

title: Gov. Moore puts $1.8 million toward making Maryland the “cyber capital” of the nation
summary: Governor Wes Moore has allocated $1.8 million to Maryland’s 16 community colleges to expand cybersecurity training and career opportunities, aiming to establish the state as the nation’s cyber capital. The funding, provided through the Accelerating Cyber Careers grant, supports a partnership with BCR Cyber to offer hands-on cyber-attack simulations and enhance workforce development in the cybersecurity field.

title: Trump’s return has these conservative Latinos excited
summary: Trump's 2024 election victory has energized conservative Latino Republicans in Maryland, who are now more vocal and organized in supporting his policies. Juan Leo Salazar, a Peruvian immigrant and local organizer, believes Trump's agenda, including tax cuts on tips and overtime, will benefit the Latino community and is rallying support for a Latino-Republican political movement in the state.

title: Biden asks for aid for Baltimore’s Key Bridge rebuild in disaster package
summary: President Biden has requested a $98 billion supplemental spending package to fund disaster relief, including the rebuilding of Baltimore’s Francis Scott Key Bridge, which collapsed in March after a ship collision. Lawmakers are hopeful that some form of funding will pass before Congress adjourns, despite ongoing negotiations and past delays in approving disaster aid.

title: Maryland gives go-ahead to wind project despite objections from Ocean City residents
summary: Maryland officials approved a permit for an offshore wind project near Ocean City despite local opposition over environmental and economic concerns. Critics argue the project threatens the fishing industry and local culture, while supporters emphasize its potential for renewable energy development.

title: Trump’s Kennedy nomination casts long shadow over NIH
summary: NIH Director Dr. Monica Bertagnolli faced tough questions from House Republicans about rebuilding public trust and managing a $50 billion budget amid concerns over misinformation and shifting demographics in clinical research.

title: Senate panel OKs measure aimed at luring Washington Commanders from Maryland to DC
summary: A Senate committee approved a bill to transfer control of the RFK Stadium land in Washington, D.C., from the federal government to the District, potentially helping lure the Washington Commanders back to the capital. Maryland officials oppose the move, arguing the team should remain in Prince George’s County, where it has played since 1997, and are working to offer incentives to keep the franchise in Maryland.

title: Senate panel passes bill making Chesapeake National Recreation Area a national park unit
summary: The Senate Energy and Natural Resources Committee passed the Chesapeake Bay National Recreation Area Act, advancing legislation that would establish the area as a National Park Service unit in Maryland and Virginia. The bill aims to promote public access, environmental restoration, historical recognition, and economic growth in the region.

title: Maryland video game studio reacts to volatile industry by unionizing
summary: Amid record industry revenue and major acquisitions, video game studios like those in Maryland are unionizing as developers face layoffs and industry instability. The sector, once a niche market, has become a mainstream entertainment staple but is now consolidating around major platform owners like Microsoft and Sony.

title: Montgomery Co., Maryland hosts video contest to increase awareness of drug overdosing
summary: Montgomery County, Maryland, is hosting the Speak Up, Save a Life video contest to raise awareness about the dangers of drug overdosing, particularly from fentanyl. The initiative, supported by Magnolia Companies and the county’s State Attorney, was inspired by a mother who lost her son to an overdose and now educates students on the risks.

title: Local Baltimore residents and politicians call for change as juvenile crime remains high
summary: Baltimore residents and politicians are calling for the removal of Department of Juvenile Services Secretary Vincent Schiraldi as juvenile crime remains high despite an overall decline in crime. They demand changes to address the ongoing issue with youth-related offenses in the city.

title: Beloved owner of RJ Bentley’s in College Park, Maryland dies at 77
summary: John Brown, the beloved owner and co-founder of R.J. Bentley’s in College Park, Maryland, has passed away at 77.

title: Councilmember Trayon White asks fellow councilmembers for leniency in federal bribery case
summary: DC Councilmember Trayon White is seeking leniency from his colleagues and constituents amid a federal bribery investigation. He is accused of accepting kickbacks in exchange for securing deals for a violence prevention community group.

title: Ten Maryland veterans in need of transportation gifted cars
summary: Ten Maryland veterans struggling with transportation will be gifted cars in honor of Veterans Day. The initiative aims to provide them with greater freedom and reliability in their daily lives.

title: Three Maryland lawmakers urge Biden to sanction two top Israeli officials
summary: Three Maryland lawmakers and nearly 90 congressional Democrats have urged President Biden to sanction Israeli Finance Minister Bezalel Smotrich and National Security Minister Itamar Ben-Gvir over their alleged roles in promoting settler violence and annexationist policies in the West Bank. The lawmakers argue that such sanctions are consistent with Biden's existing executive order targeting individuals who threaten stability in the region.

title: Maryland schools get new rules for shooter drills
summary: Maryland schools will implement new guidelines for active shooter drills starting in 2025 to reduce their negative impact on students' mental health, banning elements like simulated gunfire and requiring parent notification. The changes, driven by state law and concerns over rising youth anxiety, also aim to assess the psychological effects on students, staff, and families.

title: Climate activists urge Maryland lawmakers to brace for Trump
summary: Maryland climate activists are urging lawmakers to secure state funding for clean energy and climate resilience as they worry federal support will decline under President-elect Donald Trump. The proposed RENEW Act aims to generate funds by imposing fees on the oil and gas industry to offset climate impacts in the absence of federal assistance.

title: Trump makes inroads in true-blue Maryland
summary: Despite remaining a blue state, Maryland saw a significant shift toward Donald Trump in the 2024 election, with most counties showing increased support for him compared to 2020. Trump made notable inroads in both Democratic and Republican-leaning areas, contributing to a statewide swing that reflected the broader national red wave.

title: Maryland’s Ukrainian community awaits Trump’s next moves
summary: Ukrainian Americans in Maryland are anxious about Donald Trump's potential return to the presidency, fearing it could weaken U.S. support for Ukraine amid the ongoing war with Russia.

title: Antisemitic incidents surge across the U.S. in the wake of the October 7 attacks
summary: Antisemitic incidents have surged across the U.S. since the Hamas attack on Israel on October 7, 2023, with over 10,000 incidents recorded by the Anti-Defamation League between October 2023 and October 2024.

title: Trump’s pledge to ‘drain the swamp’ risks thousands of Maryland federal jobs
summary: President-elect Donald Trump’s plan to reclassify civil servants as political appointees threatens thousands of federal jobs in Maryland, raising concerns about economic impacts and government stability. Local leaders and unions warn that reinstating Schedule F could undermine job security and protections for nonpartisan federal workers.

title: Maryland conservatives make gains in school board races
summary: Conservative school board candidates in Maryland, backed by the 1776 Project PAC, made significant gains in the 2024 elections, winning or leading in key districts despite the state's blue leanings. While the PAC claims victory over the teachers' union's spending, Democrats also targeted and defeated several "extreme" conservative candidates, though not as many as they had aimed for.

title: Democrat McClain Delaney declares victory in Maryland’s 6th District House race
summary: Democrat April McClain Delaney declared victory in Maryland’s 6th Congressional District House race, securing over 51% of the counted ballots and leading Republican Neil Parrott by nearly 10,000 votes. While Decision Desk HQ, CNN, and NBC have called the race for Delaney, the Associated Press has yet to declare a winner, and Parrott has not conceded.

title: Vice President Kamala Harris’s concession speech leaves supporters optimistic
summary: Vice President Kamala Harris delivered a concession speech at Howard University, acknowledging Donald Trump’s election victory and leaving many supporters feeling optimistic. Her remarks, attended by over a thousand people, elicited a range of emotional reactions from the audience.

title: Maryland lawmakers optimistic about local projects under second Trump term
summary: Despite the Republican takeover of the U.S. Senate, Maryland Democratic lawmakers remain optimistic about advancing key local projects, including rebuilding the Francis Scott Key Bridge and relocating the FBI headquarters.

title: Maryland abortion vote is part of national wave
summary: Maryland joined six other states in codifying abortion rights in their constitutions, reflecting a national trend in favor of reproductive rights despite a Republican sweep. While Democrats had hoped abortion would boost their federal election prospects, the issue's impact on federal voting outcomes remains uncertain.

title: Maryland’s top 5 takeaways from the 2024 general election
summary: Maryland remained a solidly Democratic state in the 2024 general election, with Kamala Harris securing all 10 of its electoral votes and Angela Alsobrooks making history as the first Black woman elected to the U.S. Senate from Maryland.

title: Senate to have two Black women for first time following Alsobrooks win
summary: Angela Alsobrooks and Lisa Blunt Rochester will become the first two Black women to serve simultaneously in the U.S. Senate, marking a historic milestone.

title: Maryland’s US House races not quite settled
summary: Maryland’s 6th Congressional District race between Democrat April McClain Delaney and Republican Neil Parrott remains too close to call, with results likely hinging on mail-in ballots from Montgomery and Frederick counties. Meanwhile, Republicans and Democrats secured victories in several other House races, with Rep.

title: Larry Hogan bows out with a message of hope
summary: Republican Larry Hogan, after losing his Senate race in Maryland, accepted defeat and praised the democratic process, congratulating Democrat Angela Alsobrooks on her historic victory as the first Black woman elected to the U.S. Senate from Maryland.

title: Maryland goes for Harris: “Girl power” beats out Trump
summary: Maryland was called for Vice President Kamala Harris by the Associated Press shortly after polls closed, continuing the state's long history of supporting Democratic presidential candidates. Voters, including many first-time participants since the Obama era, expressed enthusiasm for Harris, particularly her housing policies aimed at helping first-time homebuyers.

title: Maryland enshrines abortion rights in its constitution
summary: Maryland voters approved a referendum enshrining the right to reproductive freedom in the state constitution, ensuring the ability to make decisions about pregnancy, including abortion. Critics worry the broad language could expand access for minors and include unrelated issues, while supporters emphasize the need for permanent protection following the overturning of Roe v.

title: Alsobrooks wins historic race for Maryland’s Senate seat
summary: Angela Alsobrooks has made history by becoming the first Black woman elected to the U.S. Senate from Maryland, securing a critical Democratic victory in a closely contested race.

title: Optimism runs high at Alsobrooks, Hogan parties
summary: Supporters of Angela Alsobrooks and Larry Hogan are filled with optimism as they await election results, with volunteers expressing strong confidence in their candidates' chances. Both campaigns are marked by a jubilant atmosphere, with Alsobrooks supporters emphasizing a desire for a decisive win and Hogan supporters expecting a victory.

title: Maryland 2024 Election Results
summary: Maryland voters overwhelmingly re-elected Democratic candidates in the 2024 elections, maintaining the state's trend of strong support for Democratic leadership. The results solidified Democratic control of key state offices, including governor and attorney general.

title: Live from the polls: what Maryland voters are saying on Election Day
summary: Maryland voters, including first-time voter Ivana Martin, shared their excitement about voting for women candidates on Election Day, particularly in the competitive Congressional District 6 race. The district is set to choose between Democratic candidate April McLain Delaney and Republican Neil Parrott for the House of Representatives seat.

title: When can Marylanders expect election results?
summary: Maryland voters can expect election results to be released gradually, with initial results including mail-in and early voting ballots followed by Election Day votes. Due to the state's slow vote-counting process, provisional and some mail-in ballots may not be counted until days after polls close.

title: Marylanders help out in the swing state next door
summary: Democrats and Republicans from Maryland are crossing into Pennsylvania to support their respective candidates in the key battleground state. Both parties are organizing events, rallies, and outreach efforts to influence the upcoming presidential election.

title: These voters are fired up to vote on their own darn turf
summary: Smith Island residents in Maryland have regained the right to vote at a local polling place after it was removed during the 2020 election due to pandemic restrictions. The return of in-person voting at Ewell Elementary School is seen as a significant victory, rekindling a cherished community tradition.

title: Solar farm debate heats up in Montgomery County
summary: A Maryland solar company, Chaberton Energy, seeks to build two large solar projects on agricultural reserve land in Montgomery County, sparking a debate between climate activists and farmland preservation advocates. While supporters argue the projects are essential for reducing emissions, opponents fear they undermine efforts to protect farmland critical for agriculture amid climate change.

title: Gov. Moore, NAACP team up to turn out young voters
summary: Maryland Gov. Wes Moore and NAACP Legal Defense Fund President Janai Nelson urged young voters to participate in the upcoming election, stressing that voting is essential to shaping their future and ensuring their voices are heard.

title: Almost a million Marylanders turn out for early voting, up from last two presidential elections
summary: Nearly a million Marylanders voted early ahead of the 2024 election, marking a 14% increase compared to 2016. While Democrats still led early voting, Republicans showed greater enthusiasm than in previous years, reflecting a potential shift in voting behavior.

title: At braid shop, women share election hopes and fears
summary: At Nadine’s Hair Braiding in Bowie, Md., Black women gather for braids and political discussions as they prepare for the upcoming election. The shop, run by Cameroonian entrepreneur Nadine Djuiko, has become a community hub where issues like immigration, the economy, and voting rights are shared and debated.

title: As fighting in Ukraine approaches three years, both sides prepare for the US general election
summary: A former Navy general and a Ukrainian frontline soldier discuss how the upcoming U.S. general election could influence the ongoing war in Ukraine.

title: Montgomery County Executive Marc Elrich meets with African American community to discuss budget
summary: Montgomery County Executive Marc Elrich met with African American community leaders for the first time to discuss the upcoming Fiscal Year 2026 Budget. The meeting is part of a broader effort to engage diverse communities in the budget planning process.

title: Washingtonians blast &pizza and demand change in fallout over dessert that mocked former Mayor Marion Barry
summary: &pizza faced backlash for a dessert that mocked the late Mayor Marion Barry, prompting protests and boycotts. The CEO issued a joint statement with DC activists, taking accountability for the offensive marketing campaign.

title: Electric vehicle infrastructure becoming more accessible in Montgomery County
summary: Montgomery County, which accounts for over 30 percent of Maryland's registered plug-in vehicles, is working to expand EV charging infrastructure. The county is strategically placing charging stations in areas with high concentrations of disadvantaged populations to improve accessibility.

title: National Teen Driver Safety Week highlights dangers of distracted driving
summary: National Teen Driver Safety Week encourages parents to talk to their teens about safe driving practices. The campaign emphasizes the importance of avoiding distractions and adapting to various driving conditions.

title: Members of Congress have taken hundreds of AIPAC-funded trips to Israel in the past decade
summary: Over the past decade, hundreds of U.S. lawmakers and staff have taken AIPAC-funded trips to Israel, often aligning with the Israeli government's right-wing perspective.

title: Sugar industry pays for House trips to help safeguard subsidies
summary: Sugar industry groups have funded hundreds of trips for U.S. House members and staff since 2012 to promote the economic importance of sugar production and maintain federal subsidies.

title: Live from New York! It’s Saturday night politics!
summary: For over 50 years, *Saturday Night Live* has played a significant role in political satire, shaping public perceptions through iconic impersonations of presidents and candidates. This year, the show continues its tradition by parodying figures like Biden, Trump, and Vance, building on a legacy of political comedy that often outlasts the real-life events it mocks.

title: What issues matter most to Asian American voters?
summary: Asian American voters, the fastest-growing electorate group in the U.S., prioritize issues like affordable and culturally appropriate healthcare, as well as addressing hate crimes and racism. Many, like Elizabeth Chung, advocate for policies that support marginalized communities and ensure equitable access to essential services.

title: Maryland officials keep ballot boxes under 24/7 watch
summary: Maryland election officials are monitoring ballot drop boxes 24/7 with video surveillance and law enforcement support following recent incidents in Oregon and Washington where boxes were set on fire. While no major attacks have occurred in Maryland, officials remain vigilant amid concerns about efforts to disrupt the election process.

title: Election season heightens stress for Maryland Latino community
summary: The 2024 election is increasing stress within Maryland's Latino community due to political divisions and anti-immigrant rhetoric. Despite this, many young Latino voters feel empowered to represent their families at the polls, even as they face fears stemming from conservative attacks on immigrants.

title: Caitlyn Phipps begins her next chapter as Georgetown University’s new head coach
summary: Caitlyn Phipps, a former University of Maryland assistant coach who helped lead the team to five NCAA championships, has been named the new head coach of Georgetown University’s women’s lacrosse team. She brings extensive experience, including coaching multiple Tewaaraton Award winners and winning the award herself.

title: Advocates say Alsobrooks is best Maryland Senate candidate to combat climate change
summary: Environmental groups are endorsing Angela Alsobrooks for the Maryland Senate, citing her strong climate record and commitment to reducing emissions and improving water quality. While Republican Larry Hogan has also received environmental endorsements, advocates say Alsobrooks has demonstrated a more consistent and aggressive approach to climate action.

title: CNN bans founder of conservative PAC funding MD school board candidates
summary: Ryan James Girdusky, founder of the 1776 Project PAC, was banned from CNN after making a controversial joke linking MSNBC commentator Mehdi Hasan to a deadly Hezbollah pager attack. CNN stated there is "zero room for racism or bigotry" and confirmed Girdusky will not return to the network.

title: Gunpowder Riverkeeper files motion to join Maryland’s suit over water pollution near Joppa
summary: Gunpowder Riverkeeper has filed a motion to join Maryland’s lawsuit against developers of a Harford County housing project, alleging numerous water pollution violations. The environmental group aims to hold the developers accountable and support state efforts to enforce environmental laws.

title: Faith leaders express support for abortion rights
summary: Faith leaders from various religious backgrounds in Maryland expressed support for reproductive rights and the proposed constitutional amendment to protect abortion access, emphasizing that the issue is a matter of healthcare and challenging common assumptions about religious opposition. The event aimed to highlight the diversity of religious perspectives on the issue, as voters prepare to decide on the ballot measure.

title: With one week to go, Harris rallies before White House, makes appeal to protect democracy
summary: Vice President Kamala Harris delivered a campaign rally near the White House, urging Americans to reject Donald Trump and protect democracy, calling him a threat to the nation. The event, held at the site of Trump's 2021 speech that preceded the Capitol attack, emphasized unity and warned against the dangers of divisive leadership.

title: Biden touts White House successes in Baltimore visit
summary: President Biden highlighted his administration's economic and environmental achievements during a visit to Baltimore, announcing a $3 billion investment in U.S. ports, including $147 million for the Port of Baltimore.

title: Baltimore metropolitan area traffic remains affected by the Key Bridge collapse
summary: The collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge has significantly disrupted traffic in the Baltimore metropolitan area by disconnecting the Baltimore Beltway and forcing detours for vehicles, including hazardous material trucks. Alternative routes are now experiencing heavy congestion, with traffic data showing a substantial increase in vehicle volume since the bridge's collapse.

title: Election forecasters signal trouble for Maryland GOP hopes
summary: Maryland Republicans are optimistic about improving their electoral prospects in the 2024 cycle, led by former Governor Larry Hogan's Senate bid and a more competitive 6th Congressional District following a redistricting change and an open seat. Despite the state's strong Democratic lean, Hogan's high approval rating and moderate image, along with an unfamiliar Democratic challenger in the 6th District, have raised GOP hopes for potential breakthroughs.

title: Maryland and DC attorneys general sue licensed Maryland gun dealers
summary: Maryland and DC attorneys general have sued three Maryland gun dealers for allegedly enabling gun trafficking by allowing a convicted trafficker to purchase over 30 firearms in six months. The lawsuit underscores the significant flow of illegal guns from Maryland into the District.

title: Traveling Postcards exhibit brings awareness to trauma while promoting art-based therapy
summary: The Traveling Postcards exhibit in Washington highlights the stories of trauma survivors and promotes art-based therapy as a means of support. It showcases how art can foster connection and healing, even from a distance.

title: Maryland and DC tattoo artists speak about the industry and the advantages technology has brought
summary: Tattoo artists in Maryland and DC discuss how technology and social media have transformed the industry. They highlight the benefits of these advancements while addressing lingering stigmas.

title: New polling says Latino support for Democrats shrinks
summary: A new NBC poll shows Vice President Kamala Harris leading Donald Trump among Latino voters with 54% support. However, this marks a 15-point decline in Democratic support since 2016.

title: A charity organization travels to North Carolina to provide supplies and homes to displaced animals
summary: A DC-based charity is partnering with Georgetown University students to rescue displaced and abandoned animals in North Carolina following Hurricane Helene. They will transport the animals to DC and accept supplies to support affected pet families.

title: Food trucks in Montgomery County compete for electric generators
summary: Montgomery County food trucks are competing for a limited number of grants that support switching from diesel to electric generators. The initiative aims to reduce pollution and noise but can only assist 25 of the 185 food truck businesses.

title: Metal detectors in Prince George’s County Public Schools get mixed reactions
summary: Prince George’s County Public Schools in Maryland has installed metal detectors in all high schools, making it one of only two districts in the state to do so. Reactions from students and staff are divided, with opinions split on whether the detectors are a helpful security measure or an inconvenience.

title: LGBTQ+ troops kicked out during ‘don’t ask, don’t tell’ get benefits upgrades
summary: Veterans discharged under the “Don’t Ask, Don’t Tell” policy are now eligible for upgraded military benefits. Over 800 service members will have their records changed to honorable discharges.

title: Maryland election officials enforce safety concerns as early voting starts
summary: Early voting has begun in Maryland as election officials nationwide face increasing threats. Maryland officials are working to ensure voter safety and the integrity of the election process.

title: Three Maryland school board candidates have faced legal issues
summary: Three Maryland school board candidates have faced legal issues, including an Anne Arundel County candidate acquitted decades ago of child sexual abuse, a Somerset County candidate involved in a peace order dispute, and a St. Mary’s County candidate against whom a tax lien was filed.

title: “No grass, no crabs”: Maryland community grapples with Gunpowder River mud pollution
summary: Residents of Maryland's Gunpowder River community are raising concerns over severe mud pollution and a nearly 91% decline in underwater vegetation since 2021, which they blame on D.R. Horton's development projects.

title: Basic truths and blatant errors: What AI says about the presidential election
summary: A survey found that many U.S. adults distrust AI's reliability, and an experiment showed ChatGPT-4 provided both helpful overviews and notable errors about the presidential election.

title: Early balloting starts in Maryland, turning out voters, volunteers, workers and watchers
summary: Early voting in Maryland saw high turnout, with thousands of voters, volunteers, and election workers gathering at polling sites as soon as polls opened at 7 a.m. Many voters expressed strong motivation to support candidates like Kamala Harris and Angela Alsobrooks in key races.

title: Conservative PAC, Dems face off over Maryland school board races
summary: The 1776 Project PAC, a conservative group focused on school board elections, has endorsed 19 candidates in Maryland, facing pushback from Democrats targeting "extreme" conservatives. The PAC was fined over $20,000 in 2023 for violating campaign finance laws by sending unattributed text messages to voters in 2022.

title: Angela Alsobrooks spent significantly more on radio ads than Larry Hogan ahead of election
summary: Angela Alsobrooks spent 124% more on radio ads than Larry Hogan between March and October, with over $220,000 compared to Hogan’s $52,000, as both campaigned for Maryland’s Senate seat. Radio advertising allows for cost-effective, targeted outreach, and recent polls show Alsobrooks leading Hogan by nine percentage points among likely voters.

title: McClain Delaney, Parrott tangle in Maryland’s most competitive House race
summary: Democrat April McClain Delaney and Republican Neil Parrott are locked in a heated and competitive race for Maryland’s 6th Congressional District, highlighted by a tense exchange during a recent forum. McClain Delaney, a Biden administration alum and mother of four, is focused on issues like abortion access and online safety, while Parrott, a three-time candidate and former state delegate, seeks to regain the seat.

title: D.C. Council bill would prohibit utility shutoffs in summer, winter
summary: A new bill before the D.C. Council aims to prevent utility companies from disconnecting electricity and gas for vulnerable households during the summer and winter months.

title: Maryland bear hunters say they do it for love of family and community
summary: Matthew Lidie and David Lidie Sr., two brothers from Baltimore County, successfully hunted a black bear in Maryland’s western counties as part of their bucket-list goal and a family tradition rooted in their parents' values of family and hunting. The annual bear hunt, part of Maryland’s bear management plan, allows licensed hunters to help regulate the bear population, with DNR staff collecting data to inform wildlife management strategies.

title: Interactive Guide: Learn more about Maryland’s school board candidates
summary: An interactive guide has been launched to provide information about the candidates running for Maryland’s school boards. The tool allows voters to explore candidates’ backgrounds, positions, and endorsements ahead of the election.

title: Maryland’s bear-hunting season opens with gusto and concern
summary: Maryland's bear-hunting season has begun in western counties as part of a population management program, with 950 licensed hunters participating despite controversy over the use of lethal methods. While the state argues the hunt helps control bears moving into populated areas and funds conservation efforts, animal rights groups oppose it, advocating for non-lethal alternatives.

title: School Board Voter Guide
summary: The voter guide provides information to help voters make informed decisions in school board elections. It outlines key issues, candidate positions, and the impact of local education policies.

title: Is Maryland’s ‘Blueprint’ the path to better schools? We asked school board candidates
summary: Maryland school board candidates are divided over the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future, with some praising its potential to improve education and others criticizing its funding challenges. While many candidates support its goals, concerns remain about the financial and logistical demands of implementing the 10-year, $30 billion plan.

title: On school safety, Maryland school board candidates push for officers, mental health services
summary: Maryland school board candidates across the state are emphasizing the need for improved school safety, with many calling for the addition of law enforcement officers and mental health services. Concerns range from student behavior and the threat of violence to issues like bullying, overcrowding, and poor building conditions.

title: Should Maryland schools ban cellphones? Here’s what school board candidates say
summary: A majority of Maryland school board candidates support stricter cellphone restrictions in schools, citing concerns like distraction, cyberbullying, and addiction. Some districts, like Washington County, have already implemented policies requiring devices to be off and out of sight during instructional hours.

title: Support for book bans varies in Maryland school board races
summary: Support for book bans varies among Maryland school board candidates, with many advocating for a review process involving professionals and public input rather than outright bans. Some candidates, like Sarah J.

title: On gender identity in schools, Maryland school board candidates are divided
summary: Maryland school board candidates are divided over whether to prioritize parental notification about students' gender identity or to let students choose their pronouns to foster a safe school environment. While 32 candidates argue policies go too far and emphasize parents' rights, 29 support inclusive practices that may withhold such information from parents.

title: Environmentalists push for ban on Maryland’s industrial chicken farms
summary: Environmentalists are urging Maryland's government to impose a moratorium on industrial chicken farms due to environmental concerns, particularly related to poultry waste and nutrient pollution. The state is gathering public input through listening sessions to inform revisions to the animal farming permit, with a final decision expected after public and federal review next year.

title: Hogan donors are more politically diverse, but Alsobrooks is strong among Democrats
summary: Republican Larry Hogan is attracting more politically diverse donors than Democratic candidate Angela Alsobrooks in their Senate race, with over 31% of his Maryland donors between July and September being non-Republicans. In contrast, Alsobrooks received support mostly from within her own party, reflecting differing campaign strategies in a deeply Democratic state.

title: Poll workers are in high demand – especially Maryland Republicans
summary: Maryland election officials are struggling to recruit an equal number of Republican and Democratic poll workers, as required by law, with some counties facing shortages of Republican judges. Concerns over fairness and transparency have been raised by local Republicans, including some who claim their applications were overlooked.
