title: With Senate control at stake, top Republicans give millions to Hogan’s bid
summary: Republican Senate leaders Mitch McConnell, John Cornyn, and John Thune are heavily supporting former Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan’s Senate bid with significant financial backing, despite his independent messaging.

title: Maryland approves $3.4 million bond for affordable housing in Columbia
summary: Maryland has approved a $3.4 million bond to replace a 62-unit affordable housing complex in Columbia with a new 68-unit apartment complex focused on residents earning 30% to 60% of the area’s median income. Governor Wes Moore highlighted the project as part of broader efforts to address the state’s housing shortage and affordability challenges through targeted, sustainable housing initiatives.

title: Maryland building more electric vehicle charging stations with boost from federal, state funds
summary: Maryland is expanding its electric vehicle charging infrastructure with over $33 million in federal and state funding to install stations at 29 highway sites. The initiative, led by the Maryland Clean Energy Center, aims to improve access in underserved areas and create jobs through workforce training.

title: Donations to Harris campaign from South Asian Marylanders soared after announcement
summary: Individual campaign contributions from South Asian Marylanders to Kamala Harris' presidential campaign surged to nearly $21,000 per week following her July 21 announcement, compared to much lower donations before Biden dropped out of the race. While Donald Trump’s campaign also saw a modest increase in donations from the community, it remained significantly lower than those to Harris.

title: Election experts warn of bad actors and trickery, but it’s not all gloom and doom
summary: Election experts warn that misinformation, partisanship, and artificial intelligence pose significant risks as the November election approaches, with concerns over last-minute influence and the challenges of countering false narratives. Rising costs and cybersecurity threats further complicate election integrity, especially in competitive regions where polling locations may be vulnerable to bad actors.

title: Alsobrooks campaign for Senate may create a power vacuum back home
summary: Jolene Ivey, running for a county council seat in Prince George’s County, aims to eventually replace Angela Alsobrooks as county executive if Alsobrooks wins her Senate race. Ivey emphasizes supporting Alsobrooks and Kamala Harris, while preparing to lead the county through a period of political transition.

title: Virtual Event | Youth mental health: What works?
summary: The Local News Network at the University of Maryland is hosting a virtual town hall on October 28 to discuss effective approaches to youth mental health, seeking input from young people, parents, and professionals. The event marks the start of a year-long project to highlight successful solutions, with stories to be published beginning in January 2025.

title: Traveling Postcards exhibit brings awareness to trauma while promoting art-based therapy
summary: The Traveling Postcards exhibit in Washington highlights stories of trauma survivors and promotes art-based therapy as a form of emotional support. It aims to raise awareness about the healing power of art and the importance of community support from a distance.

title: Response times increase as short-staffed county firefighters are reallocated across the county
summary: Residents of Greenbelt and other parts of Prince George’s County, Maryland, are worried about reduced fire protection as 55 firefighters were reallocated from four stations. Response times have increased, prompting Greenbelt to consider legal action.

title: DC councilmember Trayon White battling charges and lack of voter confidence as he seeks re-election
summary: DC Councilmember Trayon White is running for re-election while facing federal bribery charges. The allegations have raised concerns and weakened his voter confidence in Ward 8.

title: Congress sends more help, but security concerns persist after Trump assassination attempts
summary: Congress passed new security measures and approved additional funding for the Secret Service to enhance protection for presidential candidates following recent assassination attempts. A former Secret Service agent emphasized the need for top-level security for candidates like Kamala Harris and Donald Trump, despite the significant cost and strain on an already overburdened agency.

title: Battle of the Beltway: What to expect from the Ravens vs. Commanders game
summary: The Ravens face the Commanders in a highly anticipated matchup on October 13, dubbed the "DMV Super Bowl," featuring a clash between two-time MVP Lamar Jackson and rookie sensation Jayden Daniels. Both teams are coming off strong performances, with Jackson leading the league in total touchdowns and Daniels setting early career records.

title: Maryland Senate candidates Hogan and Alsobrooks face off in debate
summary: Republican Senate candidate Larry Hogan sought to distance himself from the GOP during a debate with Democratic opponent Angela Alsobrooks, emphasizing his independence and criticizing party leadership. Alsobrooks challenged his claims, particularly on issues like abortion rights and the influence of a potential Republican Senate majority.

title: Moore cancels back debt for thousands of parolees
summary: Governor Wes Moore has canceled over $13 million in outstanding debts for more than 6,700 parolees and probationers in Maryland, removing their financial burden from supervision fees. The move aims to support successful reintegration, reduce recidivism, and promote economic equity.

title: Queer female students face higher rates of sexual violence in college
summary: Queer female students in American universities face disproportionately high rates of sexual violence and harassment, with bisexual and lesbian women reporting significantly higher incidents compared to their heterosexual peers. Despite increased awareness, many LGBTQ+ students, particularly queer women, remain hesitant to report assaults due to fear and a hostile social climate.

title: Alsobrooks and Hogan square off on abortion
summary: Alsobrooks and Moore accused Hogan of flip-flopping on abortion rights, claiming his recent support is politically motivated, while Hogan denied the allegations, calling them false and misleading. Alsobrooks highlighted Hogan’s veto of a 2022 abortion-related bill and his past record, while Hogan defended his positions as consistent and criticized her campaign’s portrayal of his stance.

title: Marylanders warned of scam text messages as election nears
summary: Marylanders are being targeted by scam text messages falsely claiming they haven't registered to vote in the upcoming election. Election officials warn these messages are designed to steal personal information and urge voters to ignore them.

title: Immigrant groups back Harris, warn of “unsparing” deportation to come
summary: Thirteen immigrant-rights groups endorsed Kamala Harris for president, warning that a Trump victory could lead to the largest and most indiscriminate deportation operation in U.S. history.

title: How the Harris campaign is galvanizing young voters in Maryland
summary: Kamala Harris's campaign has sparked a surge in young voter registration in Maryland, with significant increases in the weeks following her July announcement. Counties like Baltimore City, Montgomery, and Worcester saw notable jumps, as young voters expressed enthusiasm for her fresh approach and message.

title: Maryland unions seek influence in election beyond membership numbers
summary: Maryland unions are focusing on influencing the election by promoting policies that support workers' rights, such as the PRO-Act and Public Service Freedom to Negotiate Act. Union leaders emphasize that endorsements depend on candidates supporting labor-friendly legislation rather than party affiliation.

title: After World Series triumph, Nats suffer a historic five-year fade
summary: The Washington Nationals' post-2019 World Series decline has been historic, with a .407 winning percentage over the past five seasons—the second-worst among any World Series champion in that timeframe. Unlike the 1913 Philadelphia Athletics, who faced financial turmoil and player losses, the Nationals' fall has occurred without major external disruptions or dramatic setbacks.

title: Maryland spends millions to settle lawsuits every year – and officials don’t like it
summary: Maryland officials are frustrated by the state's frequent spending of millions to settle lawsuits, including a recent $50,000 case involving strip searches at a correctional facility. While the settlement was approved, critics questioned the lack of transparency and the decision to settle rather than go to trial, calling for more data on how often such cases occur and are resolved.

title: Maryland approves $2.75 million settlement for discrimination by state police
summary: Maryland officials approved a $2.75 million settlement to address discriminatory hiring practices by the Maryland State Police, as revealed by a two-year U.S. Department of Justice investigation.

title: Gov. Moore takes aim at Baltimore’s vacant properties
summary: Gov. Wes Moore signed an executive order to launch the "Reinvest Baltimore" program, aiming to convert at least 5,000 vacant properties into homes or businesses over five years.

title: Orioles in search of first playoff win since 2014
summary: The Baltimore Orioles are hosting the American League Wild Card game against the Kansas City Royals, marking their return to playoff baseball. The team aims to break a seven-year playoff win drought and advance beyond a single series in October for the first time since 2014.

title: College Park releases warning after spike in invasive Spotted Lanternfly
summary: College Park officials have issued a warning due to a spike in Spotted Lanternfly sightings, an invasive species that damages trees. Residents are encouraged to report any encounters with the insect in Maryland.

title: Phones Off, Focus On: How Maryland schools are cracking down on cell phones this fall
summary: Maryland schools are implementing stricter cell phone policies this fall, with many requiring devices to be turned off and stored away during school hours. Some districts, like Caroline County and St.

title: In deep-blue Prince George’s County, running as a Republican is tough. Michael Riker is trying anyway.
summary: Michael Riker, a Republican candidate in deep-blue Prince George’s County, is challenging the Democratic stronghold by running for county council, despite being the only Republican to do so in the 21st century. With a background in law enforcement and a personal drive fueled by faith and a sense of duty, Riker faces long odds against a well-known Democratic opponent in an overwhelmingly blue district.

title: Alsobrooks details her tax controversy – and shifts focus to Hogan’s independence
summary: Angela Alsobrooks detailed a tax credit controversy involving improper claims on her Washington, D.C., and Maryland properties, stating it was a mistake and that she is resolving the issue. She shifted focus to her Republican opponent, Larry Hogan, challenging his claim of independence by highlighting the $18.2 million in ad buys from a pro-Republican Super-PAC.

title: Baltimore dockworkers strike over contract talks
summary: Dockworkers in Baltimore are striking over stalled contract negotiations, with protests continuing along the East Coast as workers demand a fair agreement. President Biden has urged the involved parties to resolve the dispute without government intervention.

title: How “blue” is Maryland? A closer look at the state’s voting history
summary: Maryland has consistently voted for Democratic presidential candidates in recent elections, with only three Republican wins since the 1960s, reflecting a strong blue-leaning electorate influenced by factors like education and racial demographics. While the state is not considered a swing state, current polls show a significant lead for the Democratic candidate, Kamala Harris, over Donald Trump in the 2024 race.

title: Banned books find shelter in new “sanctuary library”
summary: Anne Arundel County in Maryland has become the first library system in the state to be designated a "book sanctuary," pledging to protect and preserve challenged books amid increasing calls for their removal. The initiative follows the passage of the state's Freedom to Read Act, which prohibits the removal of library materials based on partisan or ideological grounds.

title: Maryland revenues see “slight positive adjustment”
summary: Maryland officials slightly increased their revenue estimates for fiscal years 2025 and 2026, calling it a modest but positive adjustment amid stable economic conditions. However, the state still faces growing budget deficits, with a projected structural shortfall of $2.93 billion by 2029.

title: Federal judge to hear arguments Monday over University of Maryland’s Oct. 7 vigil cancellation
summary: A federal judge is set to hear arguments over the University of Maryland's cancellation of a student-led vigil commemorating the Israel-Hamas conflict one year after the events of Oct. 7.

title: ‘Vinyl Revival’ podcast: Zamrock – the coolest music genre you’ve never heard of
summary: The "Vinyl Revival" podcast explores Zamrock, a psychedelic Zambian music genre from the 1970s that has seen a global resurgence. Produced by University of Maryland journalism students, the podcast highlights the genre's history and revival through in-depth storytelling and rare vinyl finds.

title: Health care grant aims to help underserved patients in Maryland
summary: Twelve Maryland health care organizations have received a $41.5 million grant through the HERC program to expand access to care for underserved communities, with a focus on reducing health disparities. The five-year initiative emphasizes addressing social determinants of health, such as transportation and education, to improve health outcomes across the state.

title: Chesapeake Bay is cleaner but will miss 2025 pollution targets, EPA, Maryland lawmakers say
summary: The Chesapeake Bay is improving but will not meet its 2025 pollution reduction targets, according to federal and state officials. While progress has been made, lawmakers and environmental leaders emphasize the need for increased efforts to protect and restore the bay's health.

title: New power lines could threaten farms throughout Maryland
summary: Maryland farmers are worried that a proposed 70-mile power line project could negatively impact farms in Baltimore, Carroll, and Frederick Counties. The project threatens long-standing agricultural operations, family traditions, and years of crop development.

title: King of Jordan visits Maryland State House but … why?
summary: King of Jordan, Abdullah II, made a historic visit to Maryland's State House, hosted by Gov. Wes Moore, as part of a broader effort to expand Jordan's diplomatic ties with the U.S.

title: Black Maryland medic honored with Distinguished Service Cross for D-Day heroism
summary: Army Cpl. Waverly Woodson Jr., a Black combat medic who saved an estimated 200 soldiers during the D-Day invasion at Omaha Beach, was posthumously awarded the Distinguished Service Cross after decades of advocacy by his family.

title: Senators, witnesses argue over the impact of Supreme Court’s presidential immunity ruling
summary: Senate Judiciary Committee members clashed over the Supreme Court's presidential immunity ruling, with Democrats criticizing it as a shield for future presidents and Republicans defending it as necessary for protecting official duties. The hearing, led by Sen.

title: Senators grill Novo Nordisk CEO about high costs of weight loss drugs
summary: Senators grilled Novo Nordisk CEO Lars Fruergaard Jørgensen over the high U.S. pricing of diabetes and weight-loss drugs like Ozempic and Wegovy, which are significantly cheaper in other countries.

title: Cannabis tax receipts reach new heights in Maryland
summary: Maryland collected $22.3 million in cannabis sales tax revenue from April to June, marking a 52% increase from the previous quarter. The growing industry is seen as a driver of economic growth and equity, with funds allocated to support minority-owned and women-owned businesses.

title: Maryland sues ship owners for fatal bridge disaster
summary: Maryland has filed a lawsuit against the owners and operators of the container ship responsible for the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge, accusing them of gross negligence. The state aims to recover damages for lives lost, economic losses, and infrastructure costs, while efforts to rebuild the bridge by 2028 continue.

title: Planes, trains and luxury stays: Despite reforms, lobbyists still involved in House travel
summary: Nearly two decades after reforms aimed to limit lobbyists' influence on congressional travel, an investigation reveals these rules are not effectively curbing privately funded trips by House members and their staff. The study, conducted by the Howard Center for Investigative Journalism and Boston University, found continued involvement of lobbyists in arranging luxury travel.

title: When House members travel the globe on private dime, families often go too
summary: House members have accepted over $4.3 million in private funding for travel over the past decade, with nearly $1.4 million covering expenses for family members. A recent investigation found that lawmakers, including Rep.

title: Think tanks, often funded by foreign governments, send House members on trips around the world
summary: U.S. House members and their staff took over 4,000 international trips in the past decade funded by nonprofit think tanks, many of which receive undisclosed foreign government support.

title: Maryland lawmakers ask NASA why it’s cancelling Goddard spacecraft project
summary: Maryland lawmakers have written to NASA demanding an explanation for the cancellation of the OSAM-1 spacecraft project at the Goddard Space Flight Center, which aimed to extend satellite lifespans in orbit. They argue the decision undermines U.S.

title: Experts see AI contributing to election misinformation with little federal government response
summary: Experts warn that AI could contribute to election misinformation, but Congress has yet to pass legislation to address the issue ahead of the 2024 election. While concerns remain, most experts believe AI is unlikely to significantly alter election outcomes, though it has already been used to spread misleading content.

title: Lobbyists use nonprofits to sponsor trips for House, revealing blind spot in ethics rules
summary: U.S. representatives and staff have taken thousands of trips paid for by nonprofits linked to lobbyists, exploiting a loophole in ethics rules that allows these groups to sponsor travel without direct lobbying registration.

title: Getting Ready With Us: Maryland Election Day
summary: Maryland is preparing for Election Day with voter registration drives and polling place readiness. Voters are encouraged to check their registration status and plan their voting options ahead of the upcoming election.

title: About this project
summary: An investigation by the Howard Center and Boston University revealed that congressional reforms meant to limit the influence of lobbyists on lawmakers' privately funded travel have failed, with data showing continued access for lobbyists. The project combined House filings, historical data, and OCR technology to analyze trips and expose patterns of influence.

title: With abortion question on the ballot, Maryland voters debate reproductive rights
summary: Maryland voters will decide in 2024 whether to enshrine reproductive rights in the state constitution through a referendum, with supporters arguing it would provide lasting protections and opponents claiming it stifles legislative debate. This issue comes amid a national trend of abortion-related constitutional amendments following the 2022 Dobbs Supreme Court decision.

title: Maryland ballot drop boxes installed as vote-by-mail deadlines approach
summary: Maryland has installed 286 ballot drop boxes ahead of the general election, reflecting the state's continued shift toward mail-in voting, which gained popularity during the pandemic. Voters can expect mail-in ballots to arrive as early as September 23, with a final registration deadline for mail voters on October 15.

title: Justice Department sues ship companies for $100M in Baltimore’s Key Bridge cleanup
summary: The U.S. Justice Department sued the owner and operator of the container ship Dali for over $100 million to cover cleanup costs after it crashed into Baltimore’s Key Bridge, causing six deaths and major infrastructure disruption.

title: Nail-driving ceremony marks start of construction on Capitol inauguration platform
summary: The Joint Congressional Committee on Inaugural Ceremonies marked the start of construction for the 60th presidential inauguration platform with a ceremonial "first nail" event at the U.S. Capitol.

title: Hogan and Alsobrooks battle for Jewish voters
summary: Republican Larry Hogan is emphasizing support for Israel and Maryland’s Jewish community in his Senate campaign, aiming to attract Jewish voters who typically lean Democratic. Democratic nominee Angela Alsobrooks faces the challenge of uniting a diverse coalition, including Jewish voters, while Hogan's approach is seen by some as a political wedge strategy.

title: Maryland Rep. Andy Harris to lead House Freedom Caucus
summary: Rep. Andy Harris, R-Maryland, has been elected chairman of the House Freedom Caucus, a right-wing group known for challenging Republican leadership and advocating for limited government spending.

title: Maryland’s Cardin to join US delegation at UN
summary: Maryland Sen. Ben Cardin will represent the U.S.

title: Voter scam in Maryland: Top election official warns about fraudulent texts
summary: Scammers in Maryland are sending fraudulent text messages to voters, falsely claiming they are not registered and urging them to click on deceptive links. Election officials warn these scams could spread disinformation and undermine trust in the 2024 election process.

title: Larry Hogan’s record on LGBTQ+ issues criticized by Maryland legislators
summary: Maryland legislators from the state's LGBTQ+ Caucus have criticized former Gov. Larry Hogan for not adequately supporting LGBTQ+ rights, citing his refusal to sign key protective legislation.

title: Retiring Maryland Rep. Sarbanes says he will continue fighting for election reform
summary: Rep. John Sarbanes, D-Maryland, is retiring from Congress but remains committed to advancing election reform through legislation like the Freedom to Vote Act, which seeks to expand voting access and campaign finance transparency.

title: Maryland’s Van Hollen and environmental groups want polluters pay for climate damage
summary: Maryland Sen. Chris Van Hollen and environmental groups introduced the Polluters Pay Climate Fund Act, which would impose fees on major fossil fuel companies to fund climate resilience and recovery efforts.

title: Black women winemakers break ground in Maryland
summary: Black women winemakers in Maryland are breaking barriers and building community as they navigate the state's historically white-dominated wine industry. Despite being a small fraction of the market, these entrepreneurs are opening new wineries, gaining retail distribution, and aiming to create generational wealth through their ventures.

title: Gov. Moore calls for ending the racial wealth gap in Maryland and beyond
summary: Gov. Wes Moore pledged to end the racial wealth gap in Maryland, emphasizing that it is essential for economic justice and the nation’s prosperity.

title: Maryland small businesses get $10 million grant
summary: Maryland small businesses will receive $10 million in federal funding to support legal, financial, and accounting services through the American Small Business Opportunity Program. The grant aims to help disadvantaged startups grow by providing resources and access to talent through the Maryland Technology Development Corporation.

title: In Africa, NBA’s investment and ambition far outstrip other US pro leagues
summary: The NBA has established a comprehensive basketball program across Africa, outpacing other U.S. professional leagues in investment and reach.

title: White House OKs Maryland wind energy project to be built about 10 miles off Ocean City
summary: The Biden administration has approved a Maryland offshore wind energy project 10 miles off Ocean City, expected to power over 718,000 homes and create thousands of union jobs. The project, the 10th of its kind approved by the administration, aims to contribute significantly to Biden’s goal of generating 30 gigawatts of offshore wind energy by 2030.

title: Harris promises ‘new way forward’ in accepting nomination for president
summary: Vice President Kamala Harris accepted the Democratic nomination for president, vowing to lead the country toward unity and warning of the dangers of a second Trump presidency. She emphasized her historic candidacy and the opportunity to move beyond political divisions in the upcoming election.

title: Vice President Kamala Harris accepts the presidential nomination
summary: Vice President Kamala Harris accepted the Democratic presidential nomination on the final day of the Democratic National Convention. The event was covered by CNS-TV’s Ava Thompson, highlighting the Maryland delegation's activities.

title: Democrats – including Maryland’s Moore – take on GOP proposals to cut vets’ programs
summary: Democrats, including Maryland Gov. Wes Moore, are criticizing Republican plans in Project 2025 to reduce funding for veterans' programs.

title: The Maryland race for the Senate heats up at the DNC
summary: The Maryland Senate race dominated discussions on day four of the Democratic National Convention. CNS-TV's Daniel Stein interviewed delegates to get their perspectives on the contest.

title: Democrats see abortion issue as defining – and winning – issue in fall election
summary: Democrats are positioning abortion rights as a key – and winning – issue in the upcoming fall elections, highlighting recent ballot measure successes in multiple states. This year, several states, including Maryland, will vote on constitutional amendments to protect reproductive rights, reflecting broad public support for legal abortion.

title: Democratic Convention Notebook: Raskin’s mustard, Colbert in town, Demobrats
summary: Rep. Jamie Raskin brought a unique touch to the Democratic National Convention with custom "Strong & Sweet Democracy Mustard," produced in collaboration with his cousins who run the National Mustard Museum.

title: Maryland delegates ended Day 3 at the DNC with a rousing speech by Maryland’s Wes Moore
summary: Maryland's delegation highlighted Senate candidate Angela Alsobrooks on Day 3 of the DNC. The day concluded with a powerful speech by Maryland Governor Wes Moore.

title: Walz formally accepts vice presidential nomination, tells Democrats election is about freedom
summary: Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz formally accepted the Democratic nomination for vice president, framing the election as a battle over the meaning of freedom and criticizing Republican policies as harmful to individual rights and public safety.

title: At Democratic convention, Maryland’s Moore invokes Key Bridge recovery as ‘story of America’
summary: Maryland Gov. Wes Moore highlighted the swift recovery from the Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse as a testament to American resilience in his speech at the Democratic National Convention.

title: Democratic Convention Notebook: Earl the Muskrat, river cruise, walk up songs
summary: Earl the Muskrat, a mascot for Maryland’s delegation at the Democratic National Convention, gained attention for his presence during Barack Obama’s speech and at a delegation breakfast. Former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi made a surprise appearance at the event, highlighting Maryland's role in the upcoming elections.

title: Democrats cruise the Chicago River on Day 3 of their convention
summary: Maryland delegates attended a boat tour on the Chicago River as part of the Democratic National Convention's Day 3 activities. The event offered a scenic break before the convention continued.

title: Maryland lawmakers say Biden legacy secured by decision to step aside
summary: Maryland lawmakers praised Joe Biden's decision to step aside from his reelection bid, calling it a defining moment that secures his legacy as a principled and transformative leader. They highlighted his contributions to civil rights, environmental progress, and LGBTQ+ and women's rights, while emphasizing his impact as one of the most productive presidencies in modern history.

title: Day 2 at the DNC started with a visit from Hoyer, ended with Alsobrooks speech
summary: The second day of the Democratic National Convention began with a visit from Rep. Steny Hoyer and concluded with a speech by Senate candidate Angela Alsobrooks.

title: Women at the Democratic Convention focus on history
summary: Women at the Democratic National Convention highlighted historical milestones as Kamala Harris accepted the presidential nomination. The event underscored the significance of her achievement as the first Black and South Asian woman on a major party's presidential ticket.

title: At the convention, Maryland’s Alsobrooks offers tribute to Harris as friend, mentor, role model
summary: Maryland Senate candidate Angela Alsobrooks praised Vice President Kamala Harris as a mentor and role model in her keynote speech at the Democratic National Convention, highlighting Harris' influence on her career and policies. Alsobrooks emphasized Harris' impact on justice reform and her role in inspiring hope amid political division.

title: Harris inspires new group of young Democratic leaders
summary: The Democratic National Convention in Chicago is highlighting a new wave of young Democratic leaders inspired by Vice President Kamala Harris. Party officials emphasize the depth of emerging talent within the Democratic ranks.

title: Democratic Convention Notebook: Maryland roll call, Baltimore’s Simba and Swiftie bracelets
summary: During the Democratic National Convention, Maryland Governor Wes Moore passionately highlighted the state's historical significance and cast the state's votes for Kamala Harris, while Baltimore Mayor Brandon Scott introduced his infant son, Charm, to the delegation in a "Lion King" tribute. A Mississippi delegate also made a political statement by referencing Taylor Swift and distributing "Swiftie Voter" bracelets.

title: Hoyer doesn’t let a stroke keep him from joining his fellow Maryland Democrats in Chicago
summary: Rep. Steny Hoyer, D-Maryland, attended the Maryland delegation breakfast at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago just nine days after suffering a minor stroke.

title: The Maryland Delegation’s Busy First Day at the DNC
summary: The Maryland Delegation had a busy first day at the Democratic National Convention, beginning with a surprise visit from Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer. The day concluded with a speech by President Joe Biden.

title: Protesters march on the DNC
summary: Protesters demanding a ceasefire gathered in Chicago to demonstrate during the Democratic National Convention. CNS-TV’s Leila Cox interviewed the protestors to learn more about their goals.

title: At Democratic convention, Raskin recalls Jan. 6 and warns of Trump’s threat to democracy
summary: Maryland Rep. Jamie Raskin warned at the Democratic National Convention that former President Donald Trump remains a threat to democracy, accusing him of inciting insurrection and being supported by "Banana Republicans." Raskin highlighted the dangers of Trump's influence, contrasted him with Vice President Kamala Harris and Gov.

title: Angela Alsobrooks enters national stage
summary: Democratic delegates at the DNC showed strong support for Angela Alsobrooks, the Maryland Senate candidate. Capital News Service reporter Ava Thompson covered the event and highlighted the enthusiasm on the campaign trail.

title: Democratic Convention Notebook: Crab mallets, snowplows, and union scabs
summary: The Democratic National Convention in Chicago featured union-themed protests, including "Trump is a Scab" t-shirts and threats of strikes by the United Auto Workers over stalled plant reopenments. Meanwhile, Vice Presidential nominee Tim Walz made surprise appearances at Black and LGBTQ+ Caucus meetings, energizing attendees with calls to make a "generational difference."

title: Schumer crashes Maryland delegation breakfast, touts Alsobrooks candidacy
summary: Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer surprised the Maryland delegation at a breakfast in Chicago, endorsing Angela Alsobrooks' Senate campaign and criticizing Larry Hogan's potential impact on democracy and reproductive rights. Schumer also blamed Republicans for delays in funding the reconstruction of Baltimore’s Francis Scott Key Bridge.

title: Maryland Democrats discuss plans for the DNC
summary: Maryland Democrats at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago shared their expectations for the week with Capital News Service. Delegates and representatives discussed their hopes and plans during the convention.

title: Maryland organizer joined pro-Palestine march at Democratic convention
summary: Ahlam Dahood, a 23-year-old Palestinian American from Maryland, joined pro-Palestine protests at the Democratic National Convention in Chicago, calling for Vice President Kamala Harris to end U.S. military aid to Israel.

title: Mix of Maryland political superstars, newcomers at the Democratic convention
summary: Maryland's political leaders and delegates, including Gov. Wes Moore and U.S.

title: From D.C. to Dakar, basketball connections stretch over the Atlantic
summary: The Basketball Africa League, led by former University of the District of Columbia standout Amadou Gallo Fall, highlights the strong ties between African basketball and the DMV region. Numerous key figures in African basketball, including coaches and administrators, have roots in D.C.

title: Walz, Harris’s VP pick, draws plaudits from Maryland Democrats, scorn from most Republicans
summary: Vice President Kamala Harris selected Minnesota Gov. Tim Walz as her running mate, earning praise from Maryland Democrats for his experience and leadership style.

title: Maryland Democrats praise Biden’s withdrawal, Republicans blast Harris over border
summary: Maryland Democrats, including Gov. Wes Moore and Rep.

title: Accepting nomination in third bid for the White House, Trump reprises familiar themes

His speech, framed as a message of unity, included promises to address crime, inflation, and illegal immigration, despite facing multiple legal challenges, including felony convictions.

Attendees also saw Vivek Ramaswamy actively campaigning and expressing support for Trump and his running mate, J.D.

summary: Michael Morin, brother of Rachel Morin, a Maryland mother murdered in 2023, addressed the Republican National Convention, blaming open borders for allowing violent criminals into the U.S. The suspect, Victor Antonio Martinez-Hernandez, illegally entered the U.S.

Over 4,000 law enforcement officers from 24 states and the District of Columbia are assisting local authorities during the GOP convention, including personnel from the U.S.

title: On child care, a fitful search for local solutions to a national problem
summary: Local efforts to address the U.S. child care crisis, such as in North Carolina, Colorado, and Iowa, have had limited success, highlighting the need for broader solutions.

title: Republican delegates hail Vance as right Trump veep pick
summary: Republican National Convention delegates overwhelmingly endorsed J.D. Vance as Donald Trump’s vice presidential pick, with strong support from state delegations and prominent GOP figures.

title: Maryland Republican National Convention delegates a mix of political pros and newcomers
summary: Maryland’s Republican National Convention delegation in 2024 includes a mix of experienced political figures and newcomers, all of whom supported Donald Trump’s nomination. The delegation is led by Nicole Beus Harris, the state GOP chair and wife of Rep.

title: After Trump rally shooting, Maryland politicians across spectrum decry violence
summary: Maryland politicians across the political spectrum condemned the shooting at a Donald Trump campaign rally in Pennsylvania, which left one attendee and a gunman dead and Trump injured. Officials expressed support for victims and denounced political violence, while the Republican National Convention is set to begin in Milwaukee amid heightened security concerns.

title: Maryland’s pre-K expansion plan proves to be unpopular with child care providers
summary: Maryland's plan to expand pre-K through a mixed delivery system has faced resistance from many private child care providers, with nearly 40% of surveyed providers saying they will not participate. Concerns include staff shortages, additional education requirements, and increased oversight by the state education department.

title: Dealing with diabetes: African prospect balances condition with NBA dreams
summary: Seifeldin Hendawy, an NBA Academy Africa standout with type 1 diabetes, manages his condition while pursuing his basketball dreams, often adjusting practice and meals to maintain his health. Despite the challenges, he remains committed, earning support from teammates and coaches who recognize his dedication.

title: NBA Academy Africa stresses fundamentals in developing talent
summary: NBA Academy Africa focuses on teaching elite young players from across the continent the fundamentals and defensive strategies needed to succeed in basketball. Through patience, repetition, and a strong emphasis on Basketball IQ, the Academy aims to prepare students for college and professional careers.

title: Finding child care in Maryland is hard. Finding the right child care is even harder.
summary: Finding child care in Maryland is difficult, and finding a suitable and affordable option is even more challenging for many families. Despite available resources like a state rating system and scholarship program, parents and providers face significant obstacles, often leading to reliance on unregulated care.

title: Child care is scarce in Maryland and the nation — and the pandemic made matters worse
summary: Child care shortages in Maryland and across the U.S. have worsened since the start of the pandemic, with many families struggling to secure slots as providers and available spaces have declined significantly.

title: Child care in Baltimore County
summary: Baltimore County saw an 18.16% decline in child care providers and a 5.95% drop in child care slots between 2020 and 2024. Despite this, the number of top-rated facilities increased, and providers cite stricter regulations as a reason for the reduced availability of infant care.

title: Child care in Washington County
summary: Child care providers and slots in Washington County declined significantly between 2020 and 2024, with the county experiencing the fifth and eighth largest drops in the state, respectively. Despite this, the number of top-rated child care facilities increased, though providers like Karen Gideon cite rising costs and regulations as challenges.

title: Child care in Prince George’s County
summary: Child care providers and slots in Prince George’s County decreased significantly between 2020 and 2024, with the county experiencing one of the largest drops in the state. Despite this, the number of top-rated facilities increased, though staffing challenges persist due to a post-pandemic shortage of qualified early childhood educators.

title: Child care in Baltimore City
summary: Child care providers and slots in Baltimore City have significantly decreased between 2020 and 2024, with providers down 15.64% and slots down 11.19%. Child care providers face challenges including financial strain, high parental expectations, staff retention, and frequent family relocations, making it difficult to maintain quality care.

title: Child care in Frederick County
summary: Frederick County saw an 8.38% decline in child care slots and a 10.09% drop in providers between 2020 and 2024, ranking among the smallest decreases in the state. Despite an increase in top-rated facilities, child care directors like Bambi Blackwell report significant challenges in finding qualified teachers.

title: Child care in Montgomery County
summary: Montgomery County saw a 9.21% decline in child care providers and a 0.39% drop in child care slots between 2020 and 2024, the smallest decrease in the state. Despite a slight increase in top-rated facilities, concerns remain about infant and toddler care shortages that could worsen without careful monitoring and expansion.

title: Child Care in Worcester County
summary: Worcester County saw a 7.5% decline in child care providers and a 9.84% decrease in child care slots between 2020 and 2024, though it had the smallest provider drop in the state. Despite the decline, the number of top-rated facilities increased from seven to nine during the same period.

title: Child care in Somerset County
summary: Somerset County saw a modest 3.85% increase in child care providers between 2020 and 2024, the only rise in the state, but the total remains well below the 2017 level. Despite a slight decline in child care slots and a reduction in top-rated facilities, officials describe the county as a "child care desert" with limited options.

title: Child care in Calvert County
summary: Calvert County saw a significant decline in child care providers and slots between 2020 and 2024, ranking among the top 10 largest decreases in the state. Child care providers, like Brenda Tyrrell, criticize state regulators for imposing excessive rules without sufficient communication or field expertise.

title: Child care in Allegany County
summary: Allegany County experienced a 21.74% decline in child care providers and a 13.93% drop in child care slots between 2020 and 2024, ranking among the largest decreases in the state. However, the number of top-rated child care facilities doubled during the same period.

title: Child care in Anne Arundel County
summary: Child care providers in Anne Arundel County declined by 19.04% from 2020 to 2024, resulting in a 5.07% drop in available child care slots. Despite high demand, especially for infants, many families struggle to find available spaces, as reported by local daycare owner Laurie Donohue.

title: Child care in Wicomico County
summary: Child care providers and slots in Wicomico County have significantly decreased since 2020, with the county experiencing the third-largest drop in child care capacity in the state. Local providers report long waitlists, highlighting a growing shortage of available care options.

title: Child care in St. Mary’s County
summary: St. Mary's County has experienced the largest decline in child care providers and the fourth-largest drop in child care slots in the state since 2020.

title: Child care in Kent County
summary: Kent County maintained the same number of child care providers from 2020 to 2024, while the number of child care slots increased by 12.83%, the only increase in the state. However, the number of top-rated facilities dropped from two to one, and long waitlists for infant care continue to reflect a broader child care crisis in Maryland.

title: Child care in Cecil County
summary: Cecil County experienced a 10.81% decrease in child care providers and a 9.92% drop in child care slots between 2020 and 2024, ranking among the worst declines in the state. No providers in the county received the highest child care rating during that period, and many have cited stress and difficulty as reasons for closing.

title: Child care in Charles County
summary: Child care providers in Charles County declined by 16.03% between 2020 and 2024, with a slight drop in child care slots, while the number of top-rated facilities fell sharply. Daycare providers report reduced personal interaction with children and rising tuition costs that strain parents' budgets.

title: Child care in Queen Anne’s County
summary: Child care providers in Queen Anne’s County declined by 19.32% between 2020 and 2024, the fourth largest drop in the state, while the number of child care slots fell by 13.17%. Despite this, the county maintained five top-rated facilities, and providers expressed frustration over the lack of recognition for their multifaceted roles.

title: Child care in Caroline County
summary: Child care providers and slots in Caroline County have significantly decreased, with the largest drop in child care slots and the second-largest drop in providers in the state. The shortage has led to the rise of unlicensed providers, making it harder for licensed day cares to fill their spots.

title: Child care in Dorchester County
summary: Dorchester County maintained the same number of child care providers from 2020 to 2024, despite pandemic-related closures, while the number of child care slots saw a slight decline. The county also experienced a reduction in top-rated facilities, with daycare providers citing economic and social changes as challenges to the industry.

title: Child care in Garrett County
summary: Garrett County saw a 17.86% decline in child care providers and a 22.22% drop in child care slots between 2020 and 2024, marking the second-largest slot decrease in the state. Local officials attribute the decline to an aging population and a corresponding decrease in the number of young children.

title: Child care in Howard County
summary: The number of child care providers and slots in Howard County declined by 10.88% and 9.61%, respectively, between 2020 and 2024. Local experts warn that the shortage makes it increasingly difficult for young families to secure child care, urging them to start searching as soon as possible.

title: Child care in Talbot County
summary: Talbot County experienced a 16.39% decrease in child care providers and a 2.35% decline in child care slots between 2020 and 2024, with the number of top-rated facilities also dropping significantly. Child care providers cite reasons such as retirement, strict regulations, changing family dynamics, and competition from schools and unlicensed care as contributing to the industry's decline.

title: Child care in Carroll County
summary: Child care providers in Carroll County decreased by 9.55% between 2020 and 2024, the third smallest drop in the state, while child care slots fell just 1.83%, the fifth smallest decline. Despite challenges during the pandemic, top-rated facilities remained steady, and slot numbers increased slightly from 2022 to 2024.

title: Child care in Harford County
summary: Harford County saw a 16.71% decline in child care providers between 2020 and 2024, the 11th largest drop in the state, while child care slots decreased by 4.51%. Despite this, the number of top-rated facilities rose from 15 to 29, and local preschool director Maryanne Shulman called for incentives to attract more professionals to the child care field.

title: Child care: Missing in Maryland?
summary: Maryland is facing a growing child care crisis, with many families struggling to find affordable and accessible options. Experts warn that the shortage could hinder both parental employment and children's early development.

title: At NBA Academy Africa, academics prepare students for life beyond basketball
summary: The NBA Academy Africa provides top young basketball players with rigorous academic training alongside their sports development, preparing them for potential careers in college or the NBA. Students study core subjects and English proficiency through an American curriculum, aiming to equip them for life beyond the basketball court.

title: Baltimore’s Backbone
summary: Baltimore's Inner Harbor has long been the city's economic and cultural heart, driving tourism and development. Efforts to revitalize surrounding neighborhoods aim to expand the harbor's positive impact throughout the city.

title: How NBA Academy Africa fuels the future of basketball
summary: NBA Academy Africa is developing the continent's top young basketball talent by providing specialized training, education, and nutrition. The academy ensures athletes are properly fueled with three structured meal options and supplements, helping them grow stronger and perform at higher levels.

title: NBA Academy Africa newcomers find common ground in unfamiliar world
summary: NBA Academy Africa brings together young basketball players from across the continent, many facing challenges like language barriers and loneliness when they first arrive. Through team activities, shared interests, and language learning, they gradually bond and build connections both on and off the court.

title: Five things to know about the NBA Academy Africa
summary: The NBA Academy Africa, located in Saly, Senegal, opened in 2018 to train top basketball talent for collegiate or professional careers. The academy highlights its training facilities and notable alumni in its five key facts.

title: At NBA Academy Africa, a commitment to supporting the youngest players
summary: NBA Academy Africa supports young basketball talents from across the continent, providing them with training and development from as young as 15 until they pursue college or professional careers. Players like Seifeldin Hendawy, who moved from Egypt at 16, receive both athletic and personal guidance to help them adapt and excel in the sport.

title: African basketball’s changing of the guard
summary: The NBA Academy Africa is nurturing a new generation of skilled African basketball players, including guards, who are breaking away from the traditional focus on towering centers. While many young Africans still look up to American stars, the Academy aims to develop local talent capable of excelling at the sport's highest levels.

title: BAL Championship: Playing with pride
summary: Solo Diabate and Carlos Morais, two top African basketball players, shared their reflections after the BAL Championship Game. They both emphasized that playing for the BAL is about representing Africa with pride.

title: NBA Finals inspire players at NBA Academy Africa
summary: NBA Academy Africa players watched Game One of the NBA Finals and were inspired by the world's top basketball talent. The academy adjusted its schedule to allow them time to observe and learn from the high-level competition.

title: Club Rafiki: Where basketball dreams flourish
summary: Club Rafiki in Kigali offers free basketball access to children, fostering their passion for the sport. Established in 2022, two courts serve as both a training ground and a community gathering space.

title: Watch an NBA Finals Game with Africa’s top basketball prospects
summary: NBA Academy Africa's top basketball prospects from seven countries gathered to watch Game One of the NBA Finals, analyzing strategies and drawing inspiration from Celtics' performance. The event highlighted the players' deep passion for the game and their aspirations to one day compete at the professional level.

title: Baltimore native doesn’t let disappointments stand in the way of his basketball career
summary: Nick Faust, a Baltimore native, overcame setbacks in his basketball journey through perseverance and hard work. He recently won the Basketball Africa League Season Four Championship, proving his talent on a professional stage.

title: African-born NBA players focus on advancing the game
summary: African-born NBA players continue to make significant contributions to the league, with 19 on rosters at the start of the 2024 season and a growing number of prospects emerging from the continent. Initiatives like the Basketball Africa League, supported by former NBA players and executives, aim to develop talent and expand the game's reach across Africa.

title: Basketball is booming in Africa, but court access lags
summary: Basketball is growing rapidly in popularity across Africa, highlighted by events like the Basketball Africa League, but access to courts remains limited. Club Rafiki in Rwanda, a free and accessible court built by Giants of Africa, is a rare example of the infrastructure needed to support the sport’s expansion.

title: BAL Championship: A long time coming
summary: Petro de Luanda finally won the Basketball Africa League championship after years of competing without success, defeating Al Ahly Ly 107-94. This victory marked a long-awaited triumph for team captain Carlos Morais and his teammates.

title: From drums to dancing, BAL fans bring passion to finals
summary: Rwanda's BK Arena came alive with drums, dancing, and chanting as passionate fans infused the Basketball Africa League finals with vibrant African music and culture. The crowd's energy blended tradition and sports enthusiasm throughout the championship game.

title: Five things to know about the Basketball Africa League
summary: The Basketball Africa League (BAL), launched in 2021, is now the top basketball competition on the continent. It features a pathway to the finals, a women’s program, and aims to promote basketball and female success across Africa.

title: Basketball in Africa
summary: Basketball is rapidly growing in popularity across Africa, with increasing participation and investment in the sport. The success of African players in international leagues has inspired a new generation and boosted the game's profile on the continent.

title: Five Things to Know About Sports in Rwanda
summary: Rwanda is leveraging sports, particularly soccer, as a tool for national healing and unity. The country is also set to host the Road Cycling World Championships in 2025, highlighting its growing role in international sports.

title: Five Things to Know About Kigali
summary: Kigali is known for its widespread use of motorbikes and traffic-light countdowns at intersections. This article highlights five key things newcomers should know about the city.

title: Baltimore to Angola: Nick Faust’s Basketball Journey
summary: Nick Faust, a former high school basketball star from Baltimore, led Angola’s Petro de Luanda to a historic Basketball Africa League championship with a standout performance. After a journey that took him through college, multiple countries, and away from the NBA dream, Faust earned his first professional title at age 31.

title: For elite youth basketball players, leaving Africa isn’t the only option anymore
summary: NBA Academy Africa is providing elite youth basketball players an alternative to moving to the U.S., offering top coaching and education near home. The academy has helped players like Ugonna Onyenso and Aziz Bandaogo transition to Division I college programs in the United States.

title: About ‘Child care: Missing in Maryland?’
summary: Khushboo Rathore, a recent graduate of the Philip Merrill College of Journalism, led the investigative project "Child care: Missing in Maryland?" which revealed a decline in child care providers and slots across most Maryland counties using state data obtained through the Maryland Public Information Act. The project was coordinated by Jerry Zremski and involved multiple faculty and students who contributed to its research, editing, and data visualization.

title: Amid controversy, Supreme Court shows surprising unanimity in most rulings – so far
summary: The Supreme Court has shown historic unanimity in most of its rulings this term, with nearly 75% of decisions being unanimous so far. However, pending high-profile cases on issues like abortion and presidential immunity are expected to reduce that consensus as the term concludes.

title: Statehood activists push for Puerto Rico status vote
summary: Statehood activists are urging Congress to pass the Puerto Rico Status Act, which would establish a binding 2025 referendum for Puerto Ricans to choose between statehood, independence, or sovereignty in free association with the U.S. The bill, backed by bipartisan support in the House, now faces a divided Senate as Puerto Rico seeks greater political representation and equality.

title: Months after costly civil lawsuit settlement, Baltimore City’s rivers still polluting
summary: Baltimore crabber Luke McFadden highlighted ongoing pollution in the Chesapeake Bay, showing raw sewage and trash washing in after rain, despite a recent $4.75 million lawsuit settlement over wastewater plant violations. While experts clarify that the sewage is often partially treated during heavy rain, residents and environmental groups remain concerned about the water quality and city management.

title: Georgia requires less basic training for new police officers than any state but Hawaii
summary: Georgia requires the shortest basic training period for new police officers of any state except Hawaii. This has raised concerns about the adequacy of preparation for law enforcement duties.

title: Georgia mandated training for police on stun gun use, but hasn’t funded it
summary: Georgia requires police to undergo training on stun gun use, but the state has not provided funding for the program. As a result, departments are left to cover the costs or delay implementation.

title: A look at Black-owned startups in Prince George’s County: PerVista aims to prevent active shooters
summary: Vennard Wright, a Prince George’s County native and cybersecurity specialist, founded PerVista, a Black-owned startup that uses AI to detect firearms in surveillance footage and alert law enforcement. The company aims to enhance public safety in schools, malls, and other venues while addressing gun violence in the community.

title: A look at Black-owned startups in Prince George’s County: Tetragram helps cannabis users keep track of products
summary: Otha Smith III founded Tetragram, a mobile app that helps cannabis users track product effectiveness and consumption details, addressing a lack of consumer data in the industry. Based in Prince George’s County, Smith's startup is part of a growing trend of Black-owned businesses in the cannabis sector.

title: Prince George’s has more new businesses than any Maryland county. What’s behind the surge?
summary: Prince George’s County is experiencing a surge in new businesses, particularly in high-tech, cybersecurity, and minority-owned ventures, driven in part by support from local universities and immigrant entrepreneurship. Business formation rates have risen steadily for nearly a decade, outpacing many other Maryland counties.

title: Will Maryland’s Blueprint for education work? An oversight board — and district officials — will be watching
summary: Maryland has launched a $16.6 billion initiative through 2029 to transform public education under the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future, with a seven-member oversight board monitoring progress and ensuring accountability. While educators support the goals, they face challenges including tight deadlines, limited guidance, and the complexities of pandemic recovery.

title: Beau Brade stays home after going undrafted in NFL Draft
summary: Beau Brade, an undrafted Maryland safety, has chosen to play for his hometown team, the Baltimore Ravens. His decision to stay in Baltimore reflects a pattern of commitment to his local community.

title: Reduced bus trips and different start and dismissal times for Prince George’s County Public Schools
summary: Prince George’s County Public Schools will implement three start times and six dismissal times next year, down from 13 and 17 respectively. The changes aim to streamline school schedules and improve efficiency.

title: Prince George’s Co. playgrounds get makeovers
summary: Prince George’s County is partnering with Kaboom! to renovate playgrounds, providing new play spaces for kids this summer. The initiative aims to promote playspace equity across the community.

title: Some Maryland households face disconnect from federal discount internet program
summary: Over 287,000 Maryland households could lose access to discounted high-speed internet at the end of the month unless Congress extends the Affordable Connectivity Program. The Biden administration and bipartisan lawmakers are urging support for a $6 billion funding extension to prevent the loss and maintain internet affordability for millions of Americans.

title: It’s police recruitment season, but filling vacancies is a struggle statewide
summary: Maryland's low unemployment is contributing to a severe police officer shortage, prompting departments to offer higher salaries and bonuses to attract recruits. The crisis is especially acute in Baltimore, where hundreds of officer positions remain unfilled despite increased pay, while smaller cities struggle to compete for applicants.

title: House passes bill to exclude non-citizen representation, add citizenship question to census
summary: The Republican-led House passed a bill to add a citizenship question to the census and exclude non-citizens from the population count used for federal representation, but the bill faces little chance of advancing in the Democratic-controlled Senate. Democrats argue the proposal would harm immigrant communities and skew political representation, while Republicans claim it aligns with constitutional principles of electoral fairness.

title: How ‘Maryland’ are you? Take this quiz and find out
summary: A quiz challenges readers to determine how "Maryland" they really are, testing their knowledge on state symbols and culture. The article encourages staying updated through Capital News Service across multiple platforms.

title: Fat is back: Why dairy farmers are curdling more cheese
summary: Palmyra Farms, a Maryland dairy operation, is expanding into cheese production and retail to adapt as traditional milk sales decline and more consumers opt for plant-based alternatives. Many small dairy farms in Maryland have closed in recent decades due to economic pressures and shifting consumer preferences.

title: Chestertown, Md., mayor wants tax rebate from county, Kent officials aren’t moved
summary: Chestertown Mayor David Foster is urging Kent County to provide a tax rebate to the city, arguing residents are unfairly double-taxed compared to unincorporated areas. He claims the lack of a tax set-off creates inequities, hampers economic development, and disproportionately affects lower-income residents.

title: Small Businesses in Baltimore: ‘Our Own Little, Bitty Town’
summary: Baltimore's small businesses form a close-knit, resilient community that thrives despite city regulations and competition from big box stores and online shopping. A collaborative reporting project revealed how these businesses strengthen the city's social fabric through strong local connections.

title: Influx of millions boosts hope for Mondawmin small businesses owners
summary: An influx of new development and federal funding is bringing hope to small business owners in Baltimore's Mondawmin neighborhood, which has long struggled with violence and economic decline. Despite ongoing challenges, longtime businesses like Gera Variety Discount Liquors remain as anchors in the community.

title: Printing and battle-rapping: How two Baltimore businesses connect and prosper
summary: Two Baltimore business owners, Shaka Pitts and Daryell Mack, have built a successful partnership by combining rap battles with custom printing services, supporting local artists and small businesses. Their collaboration highlights how creativity and community networking can drive positive social impact in West Baltimore.

title: Belair-Edison merchants aim to forge bonds, invigorate neighborhood
summary: Merchants in Baltimore's Belair-Edison neighborhood are working to strengthen community ties and boost local business. Despite challenges like poverty and past economic upheaval, the area's historic charm and dense population offer potential for commercial growth.

title: Nurturing health, mind and community in Belair-Edison
summary: The Flemming family credits UmojaFit, a holistic wellness program led by Ore-Ofe Iluyomade-John, with helping their son Amaree develop confidence, leadership, and a strong sense of community. The program combines fitness with life skills and partners with Iluyomade-John’s husband’s nonprofit to support youth and expand wellness access in Belair-Edison.

title: Mothers of Baltimore: Local women try to overcome lack of child care
summary: In Baltimore, neighborhood-based child care centers are vital in supporting single parents, many of whom face economic hardship and family instability. Operators like Yvonne Turner and LaKesha Solomon provide not only care for children but also emotional and financial support, often relying on community networks to help families access essential services like childcare vouchers.

title: Bakery reinvigorates Druid Heights with sweet rolls and art
summary: James Hamlin opened The Avenue Bakery in West Baltimore in 2011 as part of a broader community revitalization effort to honor the area's cultural heritage and support youth development. While the neighborhood has seen some economic growth, the number of small businesses has declined, and Hamlin continues to focus on attracting tourism and preserving the historic character of Druid Heights.

title: She works four jobs, and thrives
summary: Nailah Queen, a 46-year-old Baltimore entrepreneur, balances four jobs including running two businesses and working full-time for the Department of Juvenile Services. Despite pandemic challenges, she maintained customer trust through consistent communication and built her brands using social media and community support.

title: House votes to consider bill to add citizenship question to census
summary: The U.S. House voted to consider a bill that would add a citizenship question to the decennial census and use only citizen counts for congressional apportionment, following a previous failed attempt by President Trump.

title: Van Hollen, other Maryland Democrats and teachers slam Tennessee law arming educators
summary: Maryland Democrats and education leaders are criticizing Tennessee’s new law allowing teachers to carry firearms in schools, calling it a dangerous and misguided approach to school safety. Maryland law currently prohibits firearms in K-12 and higher education institutions, and officials are confident similar legislation won’t pass in their state.

title: Maryland sees improvement in fatal overdose rates despite nationwide opioid epidemic
summary: Fatal overdose rates in Maryland decreased by 3% in 2023, continuing a downward trend in contrast to the rising national opioid crisis in the U.S., which saw over 112,000 deaths. While fentanyl remains a major contributor to overdoses nationwide, Maryland has seen an 11% decline since the peak of the pandemic-era surge.

title: Maryland’s NAEP scores reflect trends of nationwide learning loss
summary: Maryland's 2022 NAEP results showed declining reading and math scores for fourth and eighth graders, reflecting a broader national trend worsened by the pandemic. The largest declines were seen among Hispanic, Black, and low-income students, with school closures and disruptions cited as contributing factors.

title: 5 unique mini-golf spots in and around Maryland
summary: Maryland and Delaware offer several unique mini-golf experiences, including East Potomac's historic course and Rocky Gorge's longest 19th hole. Other standout spots include Shell We Golf's beach-themed course and Puttshack's tech-enhanced game in Baltimore.

title: From “Red Solo Cup” to Cowboy Carter: How country music has morphed in the mainstream

title: Jackson Holliday’s early MLB struggles were historic among top draft picks

title: NIL allows elite gymnasts to balance Olympic dreams and college

This rule change eliminates the previous need for gymnasts to choose between professional earnings and NCAA eligibility, offering new opportunities for those without established pro leagues.

summary: A bipartisan Senate bill aims to hold individuals and platforms accountable for unauthorized AI-generated replicas of people's voices and images, but concerns about free speech and First Amendment rights remain. While lawmakers like Sen.

summary: Angela Alsobrooks, Prince George’s County Executive and Democratic Senate candidate, aims to bring a fresh perspective to the U.S. Senate by leveraging her local leadership experience and commitment to community-driven solutions.

summary: Maryland volunteers are growing millions of oysters through a gardening process to help restore the Chesapeake Bay's population ahead of the 2025 recovery deadline. Oysters play a vital role by filtering the Bay and supporting thousands of species in the region.

title: Two Maryland coaches bring knowledge and love for their alma mater to their program
