summary: Ukraine activists are urging Congress to maintain and increase U.S. support for the country's war efforts.

title: DC Council cracks down on speeding with new ‘Steer Act’
summary: The DC Council passed the Steer Act to combat speeding by assigning vehicle points to drivers who exceed the speed limit by more than 10 mph. The initiative aims to reduce traffic-related deaths, which hit a 15-year high in 2023.

title: Howard County wants to save more people from sudden cardiac arrest
summary: Howard County is partnering with SaveStation to install outdoor AED enclosures in public areas to improve survival rates from sudden cardiac arrest. The first of seventeen SaveStation AEDs was installed at Meadowbrook Park on Feb.

title: EPA tightens air quality standard for the first time in 12 years
summary: The EPA has updated the air quality standard for the first time in 12 years to reduce harmful soot pollution. The new rule aims to prevent up to 4,500 premature deaths and 800,000 asthma cases by targeting emissions from vehicles and construction sites.

title: Virginia state budget bill will not include funding for Monumental’s proposed arena and entertainment district
summary: Virginia’s state budget bill will not include funding for the proposed Monumental Sports arena and entertainment district in Alexandria. The decision raises questions about the future of the Washington Wizards and Capitals if a new venue is not secured.

title: Montgomery County Police fear staff shortage could lead to crisis as crime rates rise
summary: Montgomery County, Md., is experiencing a rise in crime rates since the start of 2024. Police officials warn that a severe staff shortage may prevent them from effectively responding to calls and could lead to further increases in crime.

title: Proposed bill to legalize online gambling in Maryland
summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering a bill to legalize online gambling, allowing residents to play casino games from home. Critics argue the move could threaten the revenue and viability of existing brick-and-mortar casinos.

title: Children with disabilities benefit from a program that focuses on building athletic and social skills
summary: A non-profit group in the DMV provides children with disabilities the chance to engage in recreational and athletic activities. The program offers 54 monthly sessions and serves 500 participants, giving them access to fun activities they might otherwise miss.

title: Father of Pava LaPere pushes for legislation he says could have prevented her murder
summary: Frank LaPere's father is pushing for legislation to ban "diminution credits" for violent sexual offenders, arguing that such credits contributed to his daughter's death by allowing the accused killer to be released early from prison. While some lawmakers support the bill, public defenders argue that removing these incentives could harm rehabilitation efforts and not necessarily increase public safety.

title: Opioid deaths spur push for kids to carry naloxone
summary: A Maryland high school student advocates for allowing all students to carry and administer naloxone to reverse opioid overdoses, highlighting the growing crisis among teens. A proposed bill, HB 1268, seeks to establish statewide standards permitting students to possess and use naloxone in schools, amid inconsistent district policies and rising adolescent opioid deaths.

title: 567 días y contando: Un renombrado periodista guatemalteco sigue tras las rejas
summary: José Rubén Zamora, un reconocido periodista guatemalteco, ha estado detenido durante 567 días acusado de lavado de dinero, un caso que organizaciones internacionales consideran una represión contra la libertad de prensa. Su arresto ocurrió tras una violenta redada en su casa en 2022, en medio de críticas por la supuesta aplicación política de la justicia.

title: Maryland’s education ‘Blueprint’ struggles to expand pre-K
summary: Maryland's Blueprint for Future Education aims to expand free pre-K access for 3- and 4-year-olds but faces challenges in recruiting private providers and securing space in public schools. While the initiative is praised for its potential long-term benefits, its mixed delivery system is proving difficult to implement effectively.

title: Maryland lawmakers urge Congress to spend more on Chesapeake Bay restoration
summary: Maryland lawmakers are urging Congress to increase funding for the Chesapeake Bay restoration program, citing measurable environmental improvements such as reduced dead zones and recovering oyster populations. The Choose Clean Water Coalition, representing over 290 organizations, emphasizes bipartisan support for the program due to its visible benefits in local communities.

title: The Port of Baltimore’s public terminals are booming. Here’s why.
summary: The Port of Baltimore's public terminals have seen significant growth in cargo volume over the past 25 years, with container, automotive, and roll-on/roll-off cargo all experiencing substantial increases. This growth is attributed to the port’s strategic location and business plan, which leverages its logistical advantages and diverse cargo portfolio.

title: NTSB: Plane door incident probe hindered by lack of Boeing documents
summary: The NTSB investigation into the Boeing 737-MAX 9 door plug incident has been delayed due to Boeing's failure to provide key documents, including the names of employees involved in door assembly. Lawmakers expressed frustration over the lack of cooperation, emphasizing the need for full transparency to ensure aviation safety.

title: Proposed bill in Montgomery County, Maryland aims to limit police searches
summary: A proposed bill in Montgomery County, Maryland, called the “Freedom to Leave Act,” would prohibit police from searching vehicles even with verbal consent from drivers. The legislation aims to curb racial profiling and prevent coercive tactics during traffic stops.

title: Proposed Maryland bill to criminalize distribution of heroin and fentanyl
summary: A proposed Maryland bill, known as Victoria & Scottie’s Law, seeks to criminalize the unauthorized distribution of heroin and fentanyl. The legislation would impose up to 20 years in prison for those convicted of selling these drugs if they cause serious injury or death.

title: Lawmakers work toward solution on juvenile justice
summary: Lawmakers in Maryland are working to reconcile differences between House and Senate bills aimed at reforming the juvenile justice system for children ages 10 to 12, focusing on rehabilitation and public safety. The key disagreement centers on whether children should enter diversion programs outside the Department of Juvenile Services or go through a court-based process.

title: Lawmakers may derail dreams of high-speed transit
summary: Maryland lawmakers are divided over whether the state should fund the Northeast Maglev high-speed rail project, with some, like Del. Nicole Williams, actively opposing any state involvement.

title: Map: How the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future’s will impact your district
summary: The Blueprint for Maryland’s Future outlines significant changes to public education, including school redistricting and increased funding for low-income students. This plan aims to improve equity and academic outcomes across the state.

title: Behind the Blueprint
summary: Architects and engineers are collaborating to design more sustainable urban buildings using advanced digital modeling. This innovative approach aims to reduce environmental impact while enhancing energy efficiency in city infrastructure.

title: Blueprint or budget-breaker? No one knows how to pay for Maryland’s massive education reform
summary: Maryland’s Blueprint for Future Education, aimed at transforming public schools with billions in funding, is straining state finances and projected to create a massive budget shortfall by 2029. With no clear long-term funding plan in place, both Democrats and Republicans are warning of financial risks, but no solutions have been proposed to address the looming crisis.

title: ‘Behind the Blueprint’: A Local News Network project detailing Maryland’s education reform plan
summary: "Behind the Blueprint," a Local News Network project by the University of Maryland’s Capital News Service, explores Maryland’s multi-billion dollar education reform plan aimed at overhauling public schools through five pillars: expanding early childhood education, improving teacher recruitment and retention, enhancing college and career readiness, increasing per-pupil funding, and reforming governance and accountability. The initiative will be analyzed through district-by-district reporting and in-depth coverage of each pillar’s goals and challenges.

title: Lawmakers reached a tentative funding agreement but now face a countdown to avoid a shutdown
summary: Lawmakers reached a tentative funding agreement to avoid a government shutdown, but they now face a tight deadline to pass the bill through both chambers by Friday midnight. The House is set to vote on a stop-gap measure to extend the government’s funding.

title: Reproductive rights advocates urge Congress to recognize women’s economic burdens
summary: Reproductive rights advocates are urging Congress to recognize the economic challenges women face in accessing reproductive healthcare, especially in restrictive states, as highlighted by personal stories and bipartisan discussion during a Senate hearing. The debate intensified following an Alabama court ruling limiting IVF access and prompting legislative action.

title: ‘It’s certainly over’ for aid-in-dying bill this year
summary: A bill legalizing medical aid in dying for terminally ill Maryland residents has been tabled this year due to insufficient support in the Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee. Democratic leaders acknowledged the deeply personal nature of the issue and confirmed no further efforts would be made to push the End-of-Life Option Act forward in the current legislative session.

title: Following lockdown, Md. lawmakers express worry over Capitol’s emergency alert system
summary: Lawmakers in Annapolis praised law enforcement's swift response after a threat prompted a two-hour lockdown at the Maryland State House, but raised concerns about the effectiveness of the emergency alert system. While officials acknowledged the need to avoid over-alarming people, they highlighted the importance of timely internal communication during security incidents.

title: Maryland’s Ruppersberger reflects on over two decades in Congress ahead of retirement
summary: Rep. Dutch Ruppersberger, D-Maryland, reflects on his 40-year political career, including over two decades in Congress, as he prepares for retirement due to family commitments.

title: Retirement crisis threatens current workers, experts tell Congress
summary: Experts warn that the U.S. retirement crisis is putting both current workers and seniors at risk of financial instability, with many lacking sufficient savings to maintain their lifestyle after retirement.

title: House bill advances, allowing for redevelopment of RFK Stadium
summary: The U.S. House of Representatives passed a bill to facilitate the redevelopment of RFK Stadium in Washington, D.C.

title: Lockdown stalls state Capitol on busy session day
summary: A lockdown at Maryland's State House complex lasted nearly two hours after an anonymous threat prompted emergency responders to secure the area. Lawmakers and staff sheltered in place, disrupting session activities until authorities declared the buildings safe.

title: This Baltimore vegan restaurant owner is a fierce advocate for higher wages for tipped workers
summary: Tia Hamilton, co-owner of a Baltimore vegan restaurant, is advocating for higher wages for tipped workers and supporting formerly incarcerated people through various community initiatives. She pays her staff a livable wage, believes in fair treatment, and runs multiple ventures aimed at criminal justice reform and reentry support.

title: Senators condemn “mismanagement” at federal prisons for high suicide rates
summary: A Senate Judiciary Committee hearing condemned mismanagement in federal prisons, citing over 300 suicides, homicides, and accidents from 2014 to 2021, with many linked to solitary confinement and poor conditions. The hearing highlighted a DOJ report showing that nearly half of suicide victims were in restrictive housing, prompting calls for reform and legislation to limit its use.

title: The Ravens’ fourth-quarter turnover rate soars in the playoffs
summary: The Baltimore Ravens have struggled with a higher fourth-quarter turnover rate in playoff games compared to the regular season under head coach John Harbaugh, contributing to their postseason disappointments. Despite overall postseason turnovers being slightly higher, the team's late-game giveaways increase by 98% in the playoffs, significantly impacting their success.

title: Lawmakers propose task force to probe long-term inequities facing Black women
summary: A group of House members has introduced the "Protect Black Women and Girls Act," which would establish a federal task force to address systemic inequities in areas such as education, healthcare, and economic development. Led by the Departments of Health and Human Services and Justice, the task force would assess existing policies and recommend changes to promote equality for Black women and girls.

title: Proposed bill to prohibit universities from considering legacy admissions
summary: A proposed bill in Maryland would ban universities from considering a student’s legacy status in admissions, applying to institutions that receive state funding. Lawmakers aim to enforce this policy across all higher education institutions to promote fairness and diversity in college admissions.

title: Mother of Pava LaPere appeals to Maryland state senators for a grant in her daughter’s name
summary: Caroline LaPere is advocating before Maryland state senators for the Pava LaPere Initiative Acceleration Grant Program. The program aims to boost entrepreneurial innovation by offering grants to tech startups founded by students in Baltimore.

title: New plan to stop youth violence and crime in Prince George’s County, Maryland
summary: Prince George’s County Council member Calvin Hawkins is collaborating with Young Mindz Inc, a non-profit, to combat youth violence and crime through a community-focused initiative. The program targets at-risk youth and returning citizens with a four-prong approach aimed at helping them build stable lives.

title: Miller brothers close bond with head coach Alex Clemsen has made all the difference
summary: Kal and Ethen Miller, wrestlers at the University of Maryland, have developed a strong bond with their head coach, Alex Clemsen, whom they've known since childhood. Their relationship has flourished at UMD, with Clemsen even helping the brothers launch their own NIL clothing brand.

title: Maryland Attorney General announces takedown of organization responsible for a series of crimes in Baltimore City and County
summary: Maryland Attorney General Anthony Brown announced indictments against a criminal organization linked to violent crimes and carjackings in Baltimore City and County. The takedown marks a significant law enforcement action targeting ongoing criminal activity in the region.

title: Taylor Swift, the Super Bowl, and celebrity private jet emissions: A closer look
summary: The 2024 Super Bowl in Las Vegas saw a record number of private jet arrivals, raising concerns about celebrity travel and its environmental impact, with Taylor Swift notably linked to high emissions from a long-haul flight. Despite past top rankings in private jet emissions, Swift did not appear in Myclimate’s 2023 top 30 due to legal restrictions on tracking her flights.

title: US components still found in Russian weapons against Ukraine, experts tell Congress
summary: American-made components, including semiconductors from companies like Intel and Texas Instruments, have been found in Russian weapons used against Ukraine despite U.S. sanctions.

title: Top pro-Israel group boosted political spending after Oct. 7 Hamas attacks
summary: The American Israel Public Affairs Committee (AIPAC) nearly tripled its political spending in the months following Hamas’ Oct. 7 attacks, according to FEC filings, as it aimed to strengthen congressional support for Israel.

title: As resale ticket prices climb, the live music industry looks for solutions
summary: Resale ticket prices for live music events are soaring, with some tickets selling for thousands more than face value, even for smaller venues and unsold-out shows. The practice is drawing attention from lawmakers and industry leaders, who argue it harms artists, venues, and fans.

title: Exploring Black history in and around Maryland: 5 places to visit
summary: Maryland offers several key sites for exploring Black history, including the Frederick Douglass Driving Tour, the Harriet Tubman Underground Railroad Visitor Center, and the Smithsonian National Museum of African American History and Culture. These locations highlight the resilience, culture, and contributions of African Americans through historical landmarks, exhibits, and artifacts.

title: State lawmakers hope to protect judges’ privacy
summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering the Judge Andrew F. Wilkinson Judicial Security Act to enhance judges' safety by removing their personal information from the internet, following a deadly attack on a local judge.

title: Silencing Truth: The Persecution of Russian Journalist Ivan Safronov
summary: Ivan Safronov, a former respected Russian military journalist, was convicted of treason in 2022 and sentenced to 22 years in prison for allegedly leaking secrets to Czech intelligence. His case has been seen as a warning to journalists, signaling that even non-political reporting is no longer safe in Russia.

title: Maryland’s Moore blasts Alabama IVF ruling as “out of step” with the country
summary: Maryland Gov. Wes Moore criticized an Alabama Supreme Court ruling that grants frozen embryos the same legal rights as children, calling it "out of step" with national views and emphasizing the importance of elected officials in shaping judicial appointments.

title: Maryland Democrats close in on refined juvenile justice bill
summary: Maryland Democratic leaders are nearing agreement on revisions to their juvenile justice bill, which would limit delinquency jurisdiction for children ages 10 to 12 to specific offenses like firearms violations and third-degree sex crimes. They also aim to formalize the process for referring youth to rehabilitation services through a court-based "Child in Need of Supervision" system.

title: Income tax hike unlikely in Maryland this year
summary: Maryland lawmakers are pushing for income tax hikes to address a projected state budget deficit, but the proposals are unlikely to pass this year due to political and business concerns. While supporters aim to shift the tax burden to high-income earners and corporations, most officials, including Governor Wes Moore, are avoiding tax increases ahead of the 2024 election.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Anne Arundel County
summary: Anne Arundel County Public Schools received the second-largest increase in state per-pupil funding among Maryland districts between fiscal 2019 and 2024. While the district's Blueprint Implementation Plan highlights strong efforts in early education, teacher diversity, and curriculum integration, it still needs to improve in areas like private provider collaboration, utilization of certified teachers, and comprehensive literacy and math programs.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Baltimore County
summary: Baltimore County Public Schools received a 35% increase in state per-pupil funding between fiscal 2019 and 2024, ranking 11th smallest among Maryland districts. While the district is making strides in pre-K programs, teacher training, and career education, it needs to improve teacher leadership, professional development, and ensure its college readiness plan aligns with Blueprint goals.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Allegany County
summary: Allegany Public Schools saw the smallest per-pupil funding increase among Maryland districts, rising 18.2% from fiscal 2019 to 2024. While the district is expanding early childhood education and promoting diversity, it needs to improve teacher certification, offer vocational apprenticeships, and better engage stakeholders in its Blueprint plan.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Frederick County
summary: Frederick County Public Schools received an 8th smallest 33.3% increase in state per-pupil funding from fiscal 2019 to 2024, with future funding levels still uncertain. While the district has strengths like strong partnerships and expanding educational programs, it faces challenges such as limited pre-K providers and a teacher shortage.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Dorchester County
summary: Dorchester Public Schools is set to receive a 36.9% increase in state per-pupil funding by fiscal 2024, ranking tenth among Maryland districts. While the district is making progress in early childhood education and teacher diversity, it faces challenges in teacher certification, staffing shortages, and needs to refine its literacy and math plans to meet Blueprint requirements.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Cecil County
summary: Cecil County Public Schools received a 30.9% increase in state per-pupil funding between fiscal 2019 and 2024, the third smallest among Maryland districts. While the district has strengths in college readiness and literacy, it faces challenges including teacher shortages, limited in-school tutoring support, and a need for culturally inclusive materials and teacher retention strategies.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Worcester County
summary: Worcester County Public Schools experienced the fourth-largest increase in state per-pupil funding among Maryland districts between fiscal 2019 and 2024, despite still having the lowest funding level in the state. The district's Blueprint Implementation Plan received praise for its pre-K and teacher development initiatives but was urged to improve in areas such as math planning and support for English language learners.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Caroline County
summary: Caroline County Public Schools received the fifth-largest per-pupil funding increase in Maryland between fiscal 2019 and 2024. While the district's Blueprint implementation plan was praised for its strong early childhood and curriculum initiatives, it needs to improve educator recruitment diversity, teacher career development, and the ambition of its literacy timeline.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Howard County
summary: Howard County Public Schools received a 35.9% increase in state per-pupil funding between fiscal 2019 and 2024, the 12th smallest increase among Maryland's 24 school districts. The district's Blueprint Implementation Plan was praised for its strong teacher preparation programs, college and career readiness initiatives, and support for underserved students, though areas for improvement were also noted.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Charles County
summary: Charles County Public Schools received the eighth-largest per-pupil funding increase in Maryland between fiscal 2019 and 2024, but improvements are needed in areas like Pre-K planning, teacher recruitment, and evaluating teacher training effectiveness. The district's Blueprint Implementation Plan was praised for its literacy and career programs but faces recommendations to strengthen family outreach and support systems for educators.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Garrett County
summary: Garrett County Public Schools received a 32% increase in state per-pupil funding between fiscal 2019 and 2024, the fifth smallest among Maryland districts. While the district has strengths in teacher preparation and certification, it needs to improve stakeholder involvement, address the teacher shortage, and finalize key educational plans.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Kent County
summary: Kent County Public Schools saw a relatively modest 33.8% increase in state per-pupil funding between fiscal 2019 and 2024, ranking ninth among Maryland districts. While the district has strengths in early childhood education and teacher support, it needs to improve its math and literacy plans and expand its educator career development framework.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Carroll County
summary: Carroll County Public Schools saw a modest 32.8% increase in state per-pupil funding between fiscal 2019 and 2024, ranking among the lowest in Maryland. While the district's Blueprint implementation plan shows strengths in professional learning and student support, it needs to improve math and literacy strategies, teacher recruitment, and curriculum consistency to better prepare students for college and career readiness.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Montgomery County
summary: Montgomery County Public Schools received a relatively modest 32.8% increase in state per-pupil funding between fiscal 2019 and 2024, the sixth smallest among Maryland districts. While the district's Blueprint Implementation Plan highlights strong initiatives in early education, English learner support, and restorative justice, it also identifies areas needing improvement, such as expediting a common registration platform and enhancing math and college readiness strategies.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Wicomico County
summary: Wicomico County Public Schools received a 31.8% increase in state per-pupil funding between fiscal 2019 and 2024, the fourth smallest among Maryland districts. While the district's Blueprint plan highlights strong partnerships and initiatives to improve teacher diversity and student support, it needs to better address family engagement and provide more training for National Board Certification facilitators.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Harford County
summary: Harford County Public Schools received the third-largest increase in state per-pupil funding among Maryland districts, rising 41.6% from fiscal 2019 to 2024. The district’s Blueprint Implementation Plan highlights strengths in teacher recruitment, equity-focused initiatives, and partnerships, though it still needs to improve pre-K program capacity.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Prince George’s County
summary: Prince George’s County Public Schools received the 11th largest per-pupil funding increase in Maryland between fiscal 2019 and 2024, but some instructional materials and student support strategies still need improvement. While the district has strengths in literacy, professional development, and culturally responsive teaching, it must address teacher shortages and align its curriculum with Blueprint standards.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Queen Anne’s County
summary: Queen Anne’s Public Schools received the second smallest per-pupil funding increase in Maryland between fiscal 2019 and 2024. While the district has implemented strong programs in dual enrollment and career education, it faces challenges in meeting salary increase requirements and addressing teacher staffing shortages.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Washington County
summary: Washington County Public Schools received the ninth largest per-pupil funding increase in Maryland between fiscal 2019 and 2024, yet it remains uncertain how funding will evolve under the Blueprint. While the district's Blueprint Implementation Plan highlights strengths in early childhood education and career training, it also identifies areas needing improvement, including support for pre-K English learners and teacher diversity.

title: Behind the Blueprint: St. Mary’s County
summary: St. Mary’s County Public Schools experienced a 38.4% increase in state per-pupil funding between fiscal 2019 and 2024, the seventh highest in Maryland.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Talbot County
summary: Talbot County Public Schools received the largest per-pupil funding increase in Maryland between fiscal 2019 and 2024, growing by 49%. While its Blueprint implementation plan shows strengths in teacher recruitment and student support, the district needs to address challenges such as expanding early education, improving academic plans, and better serving underserved student groups.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Somerset County
summary: Somerset County Public Schools received a 36.1% increase in state per-pupil funding between fiscal 2019 and 2024, ranking 12th highest among Maryland districts. The district's Blueprint plan emphasizes early childhood education expansion, teacher recruitment and development, and college readiness, though it faces challenges in diversifying its workforce and expanding pre-K access.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Baltimore City
summary: Baltimore City Public Schools received a 34.6% increase in state per-pupil funding between fiscal 2019 and 2024, the tenth smallest among Maryland districts. While the district has strengths like expanding Pre-K and addressing teacher shortages, it needs to improve centralized enrollment systems and private provider engagement for its Pre-K program.

title: Behind the Blueprint: Calvert County
summary: Calvert County Public Schools received the sixth-largest per-pupil funding increase in Maryland between fiscal 2019 and 2024, rising by 38.9%. While the district is making progress in early childhood education and student readiness, it needs to improve in recruiting diverse staff, enhancing teacher leadership, and accelerating its tutoring system implementation.

title: Behind the Blueprint credits
summary: The Local News Network at the Philip Merrill College of Journalism spent six months developing the project "Behind the Blueprint," with contributions from numerous faculty, staff, and student journalists. The collaborative effort involved editors, designers, social media strategists, and student reporters who worked on enterprise stories and district summaries.

title: Potential restrictions on ticket scalping spur controversy in Maryland capital
summary: Maryland legislators are debating an anti-scalping bill that aims to limit excessive ticket resale prices, drawing opposition from season-ticket holders who argue it infringes on their ability to recoup costs. The bill would cap resale prices based on current market rates for comparable seats, with supporters claiming it targets unfair price gouging.

title: States, industry urge Supreme Court to dump air pollution rule
summary: Supreme Court justices appeared divided on whether to suspend federal air pollution regulations pending a lower court's decision, with upwind states and industries arguing the rules impose excessive costs and risks of energy shortages. Downwind states and their legal representatives countered that the regulations are necessary to address harmful pollution and ensure public health.

title: Despite efforts to remove them, Confederates and segregationists live on in Capitol statues
summary: Despite efforts to remove them, statues of Confederate leaders and segregationists still occupy prominent spaces in the U.S. Capitol, standing alongside civil rights icons.

title: Biden administration readies new sanctions against Russia, urges House to pass Ukraine aid
summary: The Biden administration is set to announce new sanctions against Russia on Friday, targeting its actions in Ukraine and the death of Alexei Navalny. The administration is also urging Congress to pass a $60+ billion aid package for Ukraine, which faces opposition in the House despite Senate approval.

title: As Assange faces extradition to US, experts see threats to press freedom
summary: Julian Assange faces extradition to the U.S. over Espionage Act charges, raising concerns among press freedom advocates who fear it could threaten journalists' First Amendment rights.

title: These bikers try (and try) to gut a state helmet law
summary: A group of Maryland motorcyclists, A Brotherhood Against Totalitarian Enactments (ABATE), continues its decades-long effort to repeal the state's mandatory helmet law, arguing it infringes on personal freedom. Despite repeated legislative attempts since 1992, the law remains in place, though the group persists with grassroots advocacy and support from like-minded riders.

title: The Nightmare before New Year’s: The Story of Bahaa Eldin Ibrahim
summary: Al Jazeera journalist Bahaa Eldin Ibrahim was detained by Egyptian authorities in 2018 after being separated from his family at Cairo International Airport and later prohibited from leaving the country. Charged with crimes related to his journalism, he has been held in a prison with a poor human rights record for nearly six years without a trial, while his wife reports he endured abuse during detention.

title: Moore puts extra pot of cash toward green projects
summary: Maryland Governor Wes Moore has allocated $90 million from an unexpected fund to support green initiatives, including decarbonizing community buildings, expanding electric vehicle charging stations, and introducing electric school buses. While the move advances the state's climate goals, officials acknowledge the need for creative funding solutions as future costs rise and financial challenges persist.

title: 567 days and counting: Renowned Guatemalan journalist still behind bars
summary: Renowned Guatemalan journalist José Rubén Zamora remains imprisoned nearly 567 days after being convicted of money laundering, which he and press freedom advocates claim is a politically motivated charge meant to silence him. While an appeals court overturned his sentence, he continues to face accusations and warnings from authorities for his investigative journalism and anti-corruption reporting.

title: Hogan’s Senate run puzzles former peers in Annapolis
summary: Former Maryland Governor Larry Hogan's decision to run for U.S. Senate has surprised many state lawmakers, particularly Democrats who viewed him as uncooperative during his tenure.

title: Maryland’s House Democrats press Republicans to pass Ukraine aid
summary: Maryland's House Democrats are urging Speaker Mike Johnson to allow a vote on the Senate-passed $95 billion aid package for Ukraine, Israel, Gaza, and Taiwan, accusing him of withholding support and endangering lives. Johnson refuses to bring the bill to the House floor without accompanying border security measures, despite a bipartisan Senate compromise and strong Democratic backing for the aid.

title: Anti-war protesters confront House hearing on Houthi threat
summary: Anti-war protesters from Code Pink disrupted a House hearing on U.S. military involvement in the Middle East, urging an end to the conflict in Gaza and condemning Houthi attacks on Red Sea shipping.

title: The Fearless Reporting of Elahe Mohammadi
summary: Elahe Mohammadi, an Iranian journalist, was arrested and sentenced to 12 years in prison for reporting on the death of Mahsa Amini, a woman who died in police custody, and for allegedly acting against national security. Her coverage of Amini's funeral sparked widespread protests in Iran under the "Women, Life, Freedom" movement.

title: Van Hollen, Democrats plan push for stronger policy protecting civilians from American weapons used by allies
summary: Sen. Chris Van Hollen and Democrats are advocating for stronger U.S.

title: Sparks fly as Democrats try to cap event ticket prices
summary: Maryland lawmakers are pushing a bill to curb ticket scalping and unfair pricing, arguing that event tickets should prioritize fans over resellers. Critics, however, warn the legislation could limit consumer choice and reduce market competition.

title: Supreme Court will decide if cities can punish homelessness while a record number of people sleep on the street
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court will decide whether local governments can enforce laws punishing homeless individuals for sleeping or camping outdoors when shelter beds are unavailable, potentially violating the Eighth Amendment.

title: House committee passes bill streamlining US arms sales
summary: The House Foreign Affairs Committee passed a bill to increase reporting thresholds for U.S. arms exports and streamline the approval process, aiming to reduce bureaucratic delays.

title: Mahomes, Chiefs outlast 49ers to claim back-to-back Super Bowls
summary: The Kansas City Chiefs claimed their second consecutive Super Bowl title with a 25-22 overtime victory over the San Francisco 49ers, led by Patrick Mahomes' clutch performance. The win made the Chiefs the first team since the 2003-04 New England Patriots to defend their Super Bowl crown.

title: Maryland’s Hogan makes surprise entry into GOP race for US Senate
summary: Former Maryland Governor Larry Hogan has announced his candidacy for the U.S. Senate, entering the race just days before the deadline and positioning himself as the leading Republican hope for the seat.

title: Annual Smithsonian orchid exhibit highlights plant conservation and protection
summary: The Smithsonian’s annual orchid exhibit, themed "The Future of Orchids: Conservation and Collaboration," showcases around 350 live orchids and artwork to highlight global conservation efforts. Artist Phaan Howng’s 3D-printed orchids and installations emphasize the diversity and fragility of wild orchid species.

title: Senators grill pharmaceutical CEOs on the high cost of prescription drugs in the U.S.
summary: U.S. senators confronted pharmaceutical CEOs over the high cost of prescription drugs, with Merck and Johnson & Johnson initially refusing to testify before agreeing to appear voluntarily.

title: Officer fights to deter drivers like one who harmed him
summary: Sergeant Patrick Kepp, a Montgomery County police officer who lost his legs stopping a reckless driver, is advocating for new legislation to punish negligent drivers in Maryland. Alongside local officials, he supports bills aimed at increasing penalties for repeat offenders and curbing dangerous driving behaviors.

title: Cardin and Van Hollen back new foreign aid bill after bipartisan immigration deal dies
summary: Sens. Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen supported a new Senate vote to advance a $118 billion foreign aid package for Ukraine and Israel after bipartisan immigration talks collapsed.

title: ‘The law is clear’: Crowd urges Supreme Court to rule against Trump in ballot case
summary: Protesters gathered outside the Supreme Court as justices considered whether to remove Donald Trump from the Colorado primary ballot under the 14th Amendment, citing his role in the Jan. 6 insurrection.

title: Supreme Court justices appear skeptical of Colorado’s effort to ban Trump from the ballot
summary: Supreme Court justices expressed skepticism about Colorado's attempt to bar former President Donald Trump from the ballot, questioning whether a state should have the authority to disqualify a presidential candidate. Legal experts anticipate the court will likely overturn the Colorado ruling, potentially deferring the issue to Congress.

title: Dems and Reps clash over private election administration funding at ‘Zuckerbucks’ hearing
summary: House Republicans are pushing for a federal law to ban private funding for state and local election administration, arguing that such support—like Mark Zuckerberg’s $350 million donation to the Center for Tech and Civic Life—may have unduly benefited Democrats in the 2020 election. Critics claim the funding led to increased Democratic voter turnout and potentially violated state laws against partisan election practices.

title: Moore calls for ‘partnership’ to fight state problems
summary: In his first State of the State address, Gov. Wes Moore emphasized collaboration with the legislature to address challenges like public safety and housing, praising the Democratic-led General Assembly for working together.

title: Senators question loyalty of US consultants withholding subpoenaed information on Saudi work
summary: Senators Richard Blumenthal and Maggie Hassan criticized four major U.S. consulting firms for not fully complying with a congressional subpoena related to their work with Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund.

title: Youth Tackle Football: Balancing risks and rewards depends on race and place
summary: Youth tackle football participation is declining due to concerns over brain injuries and behavioral issues, yet many parents still see it as a valuable opportunity. Decisions about whether children should play often depend on race and geographic location, reflecting differing perceptions of risk and reward.

title: When families’ love of the game conflicts with the science
summary: Families face a growing dilemma as the risks of youth tackle football, including potential brain injuries, clash with its perceived benefits like scholarships and career opportunities, leading to declining participation in many areas. However, in communities of color, the sport remains popular due to its seen potential for upward mobility, despite growing concerns about long-term health risks.

title: Poll: Black, Hispanic parents nearly twice as likely as white parents to see youth football as a path to college scholarships, NFL
summary: Black and Hispanic parents are nearly twice as likely as white parents to view youth football as a path to college scholarships and the NFL, despite shared recognition of the sport's health risks. While all groups value teamwork and fitness, Black and Hispanic parents are more attuned to the financial opportunities in youth sports.

title: With few other options, football is hope for families in rural Mississippi
summary: Football serves as a vital source of hope and opportunity for families in rural, impoverished Lexington, Mississippi, offering kids discipline, structure, and a potential path to college and a better life. Despite the sport's risks, the town has one of the highest per capita rates of players on elite college football teams in the nation.

title: As health concerns rise, safety efforts focus on improving helmets, detecting head injury
summary: Efforts to reduce head injury risks in youth tackle football are focusing on new helmet standards and improved safety measures, with NOCSAE proposing lighter, more tailored helmets for children ages 5-13. Experts like Dr.

title: In an Atlanta suburb, youth football is a way of life
summary: In Buford, Georgia, youth football is a cherished tradition, with hundreds of children and volunteer coaches participating in the Gwinnett Football League despite growing concerns about the risks of head injuries. Parents and coaches believe the benefits and opportunities the sport provides outweigh the dangers, ensuring its continued legacy in the community.

title: Some ex-NFL players are cautious about starting their children in tackle football
summary: Former NFL players like Domonique Foxworth and Muhammad Oliver are increasingly cautious about letting their children play tackle football at a young age, opting instead for flag football to minimize risks and learn fundamentals. Many believe the sport's dangers outweigh early benefits and would delay tackle football until high school or later.

title: Video: Why Lexington, Mississippi embraces youth tackle football
summary: Lexington, Mississippi, a small town in the nation's poorest state, produces a high number of college football players per capita despite its economic challenges. The community sees youth tackle football as a vital source of pride and opportunity.

title: About this project
summary: A University of Maryland student journalism project explores how parents make decisions about their children playing tackle football, revealing that perceptions of risk and opportunity vary by race and community. The investigation includes interviews and a national poll showing the sport's complex role in youth development despite concerns about brain injuries.

title: As Maryland considers medical aid in dying, here’s how it’s playing out in D.C.

summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering updates to youth justice reforms after seeing increases in youth-related crimes such as auto theft and carjackings. summary: Republicans in Maryland are pushing to repeal a law that prevents police from pulling over drivers based solely on the smell of marijuana, arguing it hinders law enforcement efforts. summary: Lawmakers in Maryland may revisit a controversial law that prevents police from using the smell of marijuana as probable cause to stop drivers, following public concerns and incidents like one involving Rev. Robert L.

While the line connects to key destinations like Dulles Airport and new suburban developments, many commuters still prefer driving or other modes of transport.

summary: HBCU advocates are calling for increased security funding following recent shootings at Morgan State and Bowie State Universities during homecoming events. Rep.

summary: Gov. Wes Moore is using positive messaging and a focus on service to counter political polarization, emphasizing that "service will save us" as a unifying mantra.

summary: Transgender patients in Maryland face significant geographic and availability barriers to gender-affirming care, often requiring long-distance travel to access competent medical professionals. While urban areas like Baltimore and D.C.

The program, unique for its pre-charge approach, now aims to strengthen partnerships and broaden its support for at-risk youth, primarily aged 13 to 18 and largely African American.

title: Maryland’s Cardin vows to halt military aid to Egypt over human rights abuses
summary: Sen. Ben Cardin has vowed to block U.S.

title: Antisemitic incidents reported in the U.S. hit record high according to ADL data
summary: Antisemitic incidents in the U.S. reached a record high in 2022, with over 3,500 incidents reported, according to the Anti-Defamation League's annual audit.

title: COVID-19 numbers in Maryland and region surge amid decline in preventive measures
summary: Maryland is experiencing a surge in COVID-19 cases, with the highest rate recorded in September at 6.64 cases per 100,000 people, despite a gradual decline afterward. Experts warn that reduced preventive measures and lower testing rates may lead to underreported cases as the region enters respiratory disease season.

title: Speaker fight fallout: Pelosi, Maryland’s Hoyer lose Capitol hideaways
summary: Rep. Steny Hoyer and former House Speaker Nancy Pelosi were evicted from their Capitol hideaway offices by interim Speaker Patrick McHenry following the ousting of Kevin McCarthy.

title: Maryland’s 2023 traffic fatalities may top 2007’s grim death toll
summary: Maryland is on track to have its highest number of traffic fatalities since 2007, with 456 deaths as of October 4, 2023. Factors such as increased holiday traffic and changes in driving behavior since the pandemic are contributing to the rising toll, prompting new safety funding and enforcement efforts.

title: Distractions in the classroom: School districts sue social media giants over mental health crisis
summary: School districts in Maryland, including Charles County, are suing major social media companies like Google, Meta, and Snap Inc., accusing them of contributing to a mental health crisis by designing addictive platforms that distract students and hinder learning. Educators report that excessive social media use in classrooms leads to behavioral issues and a lack of self-regulation among students.

title: Washington’s World Culture Festival focused on peace and community
summary: Washington's fourth World Culture Festival celebrated global unity, peace, and community through diverse cultural performances, meditation, and activities on the National Mall. Organized by the Art of Living Foundation, the event featured thousands of artists and world leaders, highlighting shared human values across cultures.

title: Maryland’s push to phase out gas-powered car sales by 2035
summary: Maryland is implementing regulations to phase out gas-powered car sales by 2035, mirroring California's approach and aiming to significantly increase electric vehicle (EV) adoption. While EV registrations have surged, the state faces challenges in developing sufficient charging infrastructure to support the growing demand.

title: Washington’s Art Museum of the Americas features transgender and nonbinary works
summary: The Art Museum of the Americas in Washington is showcasing the “As We Are” exhibit, featuring 10 works by transgender and nonbinary artists from Latin America, highlighting the challenges they face. The exhibit, developed in collaboration with PUICA and funded by Synergia, includes a winning video piece that presents testimonials of transgender individuals across the continent.

title: Judge blocks parts of new Maryland gun law
summary: A federal judge blocked parts of Maryland's new Gun Safety Act, preventing enforcement of provisions that would have restricted firearms in areas such as bars, near demonstrations, and on private property without permission. The ruling temporarily reinstates previous laws, allowing gun owners more leeway as the lawsuit continues.

title: State’s top financial officials blast congressional budget inaction
summary: Maryland’s financial officials and Governor Wes Moore condemned congressional budget inaction, warning that a federal government shutdown would severely harm the state’s economy by delaying paychecks and disrupting essential services. The administration is preparing emergency measures, including support for food banks and temporary loans, to mitigate the impacts on Maryland residents.

title: Food banks, feeding programs gird for federal shutdown’s impact
summary: Food banks and feeding programs in Maryland are preparing for increased demand if a federal government shutdown occurs, as federal workers face furloughs and nutrition programs may be disrupted. While some programs would continue with state funding, benefits like WIC could see immediate reductions without federal support.

title: Raskin leads effort to recognize Banned Books Week
summary: Rep. Jamie Raskin and Sen.

title: With no breakthroughs as government faces shutdown Saturday, impacts would be widespread
summary: A federal government shutdown looms as House Republicans remain deadlocked over spending bills, border security, and aid to Ukraine, with no resolution in sight before midnight Saturday. Lawmakers warn of widespread harm, with Senate leaders urging bipartisan action to avoid disrupting critical services and rolling back key policy progress.

title: Van Hollen urges Menendez to resign; Cardin says let legal process ‘move forward’
summary: Maryland Sen. Chris Van Hollen joined 28 Senate Democrats in urging New Jersey Sen.

title: Heartbroken parents warn of the dangers of subway surfing, an online trend
summary: A 15-year-old Maryland student died after falling from a moving train while participating in subway surfing, a dangerous trend linked to urban exploration shared on social media. His parents warn that online platforms expose young people to risky behavior, echoing concerns raised by health officials about the influence of harmful internet content.

title: Foliage hot spots to hit this fall
summary: Western Maryland is an ideal spot for viewing fall foliage, with leaf color changes starting in mountainous regions like Garrett and Allegany counties and lasting through early November in areas like the Eastern Shore. The Maryland Department of Natural Resources predicts peak foliage in inland areas between October 12 and 28, with coastal regions peaking later, and reports suggest some brown leaf edges due to drought stress, though vibrant fall colors are still expected.

title: In Washington, Zelenskyy makes pleas to Congress and the White House for more aid
summary: Ukraine’s President Volodymyr Zelenskyy urged U.S. Congress and President Joe Biden for more military and humanitarian aid during a visit to Washington, where he faced opposition from some Republican lawmakers.

title: Maryland lawmakers push to designate the Chesapeake Bay as a national recreation area
summary: Maryland lawmakers have introduced legislation to designate the Chesapeake Bay as a National Recreation Area, aiming to protect and highlight its environmental and historical significance. The bill, supported by a bipartisan coalition, seeks to expand the National Park Service's role in the watershed through voluntary land contributions and public-private partnerships.

title: Vivek Ramaswamy’s debut on Republican debate stage leads to increased online popularity
summary: Vivek Ramaswamy experienced an 18% increase in X followers following the first Republican presidential debate, gaining the highest percentage of new followers among GOP candidates. While Donald Trump gained the most followers in raw numbers, his growth was minimal due to his massive existing following, and Mike Pence actually lost followers in the same period.

title: Moore apologizes to wrongfully convicted Baltimore man
summary: Gov. Wes Moore publicly apologized to Demetrius Smith, a Baltimore man wrongfully convicted of murder, as he received $340,802 in compensation from the state.

title: Cannabis administration receives pushback on licensing timeline
summary: Cannabis businesses in Maryland are criticizing the Maryland Cannabis Administration for a tight licensing timeline, with applications opening on Nov. 13 and distribution set to begin just six weeks later.

title: Hellish tree of heaven weeds out native plants
summary: The tree of heaven, an invasive species from China, is rapidly spreading across the U.S., outcompeting native plants and supporting the growth of the spotted lanternfly. Known for its aggressive growth and distinctive foul odor, it poses a significant threat to ecosystems and infrastructure.

title: Seeing spotted lanternfly eggs? Scrape, smash, report them
summary: The spotted lanternfly, an invasive insect damaging crops and plants, is laying eggs in Maryland, particularly in northern areas and the Eastern Shore, and officials urge the public to scrape, smash, and report them. These pests feed on fruits and trees, causing wilting, sap oozing, and sooty mold, and are especially prevalent on the invasive tree of heaven.

title: Capitals evaluate prospects, look to the future at rookie camp
summary: The Washington Capitals held a rookie camp in Annapolis, giving top prospects a chance to showcase their skills ahead of training camp and the preseason. The event featured intense drills and practices led by the Hershey Bears coach, with future-focused players like Hendrix Lapierre and Vincent Iorio in attendance.

title: About The Howard Center
summary: The Howard Center for Investigative Journalism, established in 2019 at the University of Maryland, trains journalism students through hands-on investigative projects in partnership with news organizations nationwide. Funded by a $6 million grant from the Scripps Howard Foundation, the center honors Roy W.

title: About The Local News Network
summary: The Local News Network at the University of Maryland supports Maryland news outlets by producing localized content with student reporters and offering internships funded by the Klingenstein Family Fund. It aims to strengthen local journalism while giving students hands-on reporting experience.

title: About The Povich Center
summary: The Shirley Povich Center for Sports Journalism trains students to become leaders in sports media through an experiential curriculum. It promotes discussions on race, gender, and politics, continuing the legacy of Shirley Povich's impactful journalism.

title: Saturday is National Dance Day, with a focus on hip-hop’s 50th anniversary
summary: National Dance Day, celebrated on Saturday, highlights hip-hop's 50th anniversary with events across Washington, including performances, dance classes, and DJ sets. The day also marks the debut of breaking as an Olympic sport and underscores hip-hop's evolution from street culture to global recognition.

title: Capitals to hold rookie camp at McMullen Arena in Annapolis
summary: The Washington Capitals will hold their 2023 Rookie Camp at McMullen Arena in Annapolis from Sunday to Tuesday, marking the first time the team has been in the city since 2018. With a new head coach and a focus on younger players, the team aims to identify potential roster additions while navigating salary cap constraints.

title: Legal aid, community groups begin outreach on free eviction counsel
summary: Legal aid and community groups are reaching out to tenants in Annapolis to inform them of their rights and offer free legal help under a 2021 Maryland law. The initiative aims to empower low-income residents facing eviction and improve their ability to challenge landlords over housing issues.

title: In Maryland, Biden touts economic successes, blasts GOP policies as ‘extreme’
summary: President Joe Biden highlighted his economic achievements in Maryland, including job growth and low unemployment, while criticizing Republican policies as fiscally irresponsible and harmful to social programs. Despite his claims of economic progress, a recent poll shows widespread public concern over rising costs and a worsening economy.

title: Moore tells interviewer he has no interest in higher office; talks economy, public safety
summary: Governor Wes Moore stated he has no interest in running for higher office and emphasized his non-traditional political background during a recent interview. He focused on revitalizing Maryland's economy through targeted investments and data-driven policies to address economic stagnation and disparities.

title: Contracted out: How Maryland school districts do business
summary: Maryland school districts increasingly rely on private contractors to manage services such as transportation, food service, and maintenance. This outsourcing has raised questions about accountability, cost-effectiveness, and the impact on educational quality.

title: Audits show trouble lurking in school contracts
summary: Auditors in Maryland have uncovered significant issues with school district contracting, including a case where a former transportation official stole over $320,000 through misuse of purchasing cards and contract mismanagement. Despite frequent audits and investigations, many districts continue to ignore recommendations to address recurring financial problems.

title: An unprecedented look at Maryland public school spending
summary: The Local News Network at the University of Maryland has launched a searchable database, "Contracted Out," offering an unprecedented look at school district vendor payments across Maryland's 24 public school districts from 2018 to 2022. While the database provides transparency on over $25,000 vendor payments, it covers only a small portion of total school spending, which is largely composed of teacher and staff salaries.

title: Health care, construction, tech among biggest school expenses
summary: Maryland's public school districts spent $21.1 billion between 2019 and 2022 on non-salary expenses, with health care, construction, and technology being major costs. The data, compiled in "Contracted Out," highlights significant spending on vendor contracts, particularly for employee health insurance, amid a surge in pandemic relief funding.

title: Baltimore County leads state in transparency of school expenditures
summary: Baltimore County Public Schools is the only district in Maryland required to provide the purpose for each contract payment over $25,000, due to an amendment added during legislation in 2011. While most school districts must report such expenditures, only Baltimore County includes detailed explanations and tracks minority business involvement.

title: Some school expenses, big and small, remain a mystery
summary: Maryland school districts, including Anne Arundel and Howard Counties, have spent millions on expenses that lack clear explanations, such as an unnamed "Electronic Funds Transf Program" and large insurance payments. While some districts provided vague justifications for smaller, unusual purchases, others, like Anne Arundel, refused to explain their largest expenditures.

title: About the project
summary: “Contracted Out” was a collaborative journalism project led by University of Maryland faculty and students, involving data analysis, multimedia reporting, and web design to examine vendor payments in Maryland school districts. The project was coordinated by multiple faculty members and featured contributions from dozens of students across various journalism courses.

title: About the data
summary: The data in “Contracted Out” includes payments of $25,000 or more made by Maryland school districts to vendors, as required by Chapter 541 of the Acts of 2019. Students from the University of Maryland helped obtain and standardize the missing data after it was incomplete on the state’s Open Data Portal.

title: Board of Education Race 2022 Coverage
summary: The 2022 Board of Education race saw high voter turnout and intense competition among candidates. Key issues included school funding, curriculum reforms, and pandemic recovery plans.

title: Board of Education Voter Guide
summary: The Board of Education Voter Guide provides information to help voters make informed decisions in school board elections. It outlines candidates' positions, key issues, and the impact of local education policies.

title: Bringing Back Baseball
summary: Efforts are underway to revive baseball in the city through community programs and youth outreach. Local leaders and former players aim to increase participation and rebuild interest in the sport.

title: Hagerstown’s new ballpark: Picnic areas, walking paths and high expectations
summary: Hagerstown is set to open a new 3,000-capacity ballpark in downtown by 2024, replacing the old Municipal Stadium and bringing professional baseball back to the city after a three-year hiatus. The new Atlantic League team, whose name will be announced on July 20, will compete against regional rivals in Maryland and Pennsylvania.

title: Baseball stadium aims to revitalize city center
summary: Hagerstown is building a $70 million ballpark to revitalize its struggling downtown and attract new economic investment. While local leaders hope the stadium will spark a renaissance, economists and officials remain divided on its ability to significantly boost the city's economy.

title: Neighbors remain skeptical of ballpark in their backyard
summary: Hagerstown residents are divided over the construction of a new $70 million minor league ballpark, with some city officials and business owners excited about its potential to revitalize the downtown area. However, nearby residents express concerns over traffic, noise, and the stadium's impact on the neighborhood, with some calling it "totally unneeded" and "completely unwanted."

title: For Black community, ties to city’s baseball traditions are complicated
summary: Hagerstown's Black community has long felt disconnected from the city's baseball traditions, rooted in racial segregation and exclusion, including the treatment of icons like Willie Mays during his 1950 minor league debut. As a new ballpark opens near the historically Black Jonathan Street neighborhood in 2024, city leaders aim to rebuild trust and forge a stronger, more inclusive relationship between baseball and the community.

title: Could new baseball team bring Little League spirit back to Hagerstown?
summary: Hagerstown, once a Little League powerhouse, has seen a decline in youth baseball participation and lost its professional team in 2020, leading to a waning community connection to the sport. A new Atlantic League team is seen as a potential catalyst to revive local interest, mirroring past efforts by the Suns to engage with youth leagues and inspire the next generation of players.

title: Big dreams for small-town baseball: Owners of new team have deep roots in Hagerstown
summary: The new Hagerstown baseball team is owned by long-time local residents committed to revitalizing the city and ensuring baseball stays in the community. With a focus on community connection and local ownership, the group aims to follow the successful model of other long-standing minor league teams.

title: Atlantic League founder brings Hagerstown into his baseball ‘Petri dish’
summary: Frank Boulton, founder of the Atlantic League of Professional Baseball, is bringing a new independent baseball team to Hagerstown, 37 years after initially passing on a chance to invest in the city's former team. With no local experience in running a team, Hagerstown partners rely on Boulton's expertise as he continues to expand his influence in independent baseball across the U.S.

title: Inside the numbers: What changed the last time Maryland built a minor-league ballpark
summary: The Regency Furniture Stadium in Waldorf, Maryland, opened in 2008 with hopes of boosting the local economy, leading to significant population and tax revenue growth but mixed results in income and housing values. The experience offers insights for Hagerstown, where a new $70-million stadium aims to revitalize the downtown area, though outcomes may vary.

title: The Preakness was under the spotlight after deaths at Churchill Downs earlier this month
summary: Protesters highlighted the dangers of horse racing before the Preakness as a horse was euthanized due to a severe injury during the event. The incident reignited concerns over equine welfare, following multiple horse deaths at Churchill Downs earlier in the month.

title: Charting the Elite Statistical Performances of the 2023 NCAA Lacrosse Season
summary: The 2023 NCAA lacrosse season saw significant changes from the previous year, with all four Final Four teams eliminated and greater parity among teams. A new statistical database created by a journalism project allows for in-depth analysis of individual player performances, highlighting standout athletes and offering a customizable tool for fans and analysts.

title: Congress, health officials look to improve federal response to the next crisis
summary: Congress is re-evaluating federal laws governing public health crises to improve the U.S. response to future emergencies, as the 2006 law set to expire has shown shortcomings during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Cardin reintroduces bipartisan bill to authorize coastal watershed habitat conservation program
summary: Sens. Ben Cardin and Lindsey Graham have reintroduced the Coastal Habitat Conservation Act to provide funding and statutory authority for the U.S.

title: Outdoors could be key to improving post-pandemic learning
summary: Outdoor education is being highlighted as a potential solution to post-pandemic learning challenges, with educators like Tom Ackerman advocating for more classroom time outside. The No Child Left Inside Act, reintroduced in Congress, aims to fund environmental education initiatives to enhance student learning and development.

title: Independent reporters on social media report DC crime to large audiences
summary: Independent reporters in the Washington, D.C. area are using social media to cover crime and breaking news, often gaining large followings due to their real-time updates and community-focused approach.

title: University of Maryland, PointsBet part company in wake of betting controversies
summary: The University of Maryland has ended its marketing deal with PointsBet, one of several prominent universities to discontinue similar sports betting partnerships amid growing controversy. The agreement was managed through a third-party firm, Maryland Sports Properties, and details of the contract remain undisclosed by both the university and the sports book.

title: Endometriosis affects 200 million worldwide but many suffer in silence
summary: Endometriosis, a whole-body disease impacting women, transgender, and non-binary individuals, affects an estimated 200 million people worldwide. Many sufferers remain silent due to the lack of guaranteed treatment or non-surgical diagnostic methods, despite efforts by organizations like EndoMarch to raise awareness.

title: Contradicting federal court rulings on abortion pills have jeopardized states’ access to it
summary: Contradicting federal court rulings in Texas and Washington have created uncertainty about states' access to medical abortion. The Maryland Attorney General, along with 17 others, is working to ensure Washington's ruling protects access to the FDA-approved abortion pill Mifepristone.

title: Rescued horses help veterans on their path to healing
summary: Lifeline Horse Rescue and Rehabilitation uses rescued and rehabilitated horses to provide therapy for veterans and service members dealing with PTSD and depression. The program helps both the animals and the individuals on their paths to healing and adoption.

title: Years later a victim and her family still suffer after Las Vegas mass shooting
summary: Mary Moreland and her daughter Tina Frost continue to struggle with the long-term effects of the Las Vegas mass shooting years after the tragedy. Their story reflects the lasting impact of gun violence on victims and their families across the United States.

title: Early voting starts for special mayoral election
summary: Early voting has begun for the May 6th special mayoral election following former Mayor Patrick Wojahn's resignation due to child pornography charges.

title: High school cosmetology students open one-day fundraising salon
summary: Thomas Edison High School of Technology allows students to gain hands-on experience in their chosen fields. Cosmetology students recently opened a one-day fundraising salon to support peers competing in the SkillsUSA competitions.

title: High schoolers in Montgomery County learn to refurbish cars and sell them
summary: Thomas Edison High School of Technology in Montgomery County offers students a hands-on learning experience through a program that teaches them to refurbish cars. As part of a countywide initiative, students also learn how to sell the restored vehicles.

title: Child care prices account for more of median family incomes in Somerset and Baltimore City, data shows
summary: Child care costs consume a larger share of median family income in Baltimore City and Somerset County compared to other parts of Maryland, with prices rising significantly since 2018. In Central Maryland, higher incomes somewhat offset the costs, but families in lower-income areas struggle as child care takes up a larger portion of their earnings.

title: Orioles’ international scouting strategy initiates shifts in team characteristics
summary: The Baltimore Orioles have shifted their scouting strategy under General Manager Mike Elias, leading to an increase in non-American players within their minor league system. This change, marked by the hiring of international scouting director Koby Perez, aims to build a strong talent pipeline from the minors to the major league roster.

title: Hogan’s environment agency was underfunded and underperformed, experts say
summary: Experts say the Maryland Department of the Environment was underfunded and understaffed during Hogan’s tenure, leading to weakened enforcement and a decline in Chesapeake Bay water quality. While the administration defended its efforts, critics argue the cuts sent a message to polluters that violations would go unchecked.

title: Coaching turnover has increased in MLS, some top European leagues
summary: Coaching turnover has increased in Major League Soccer and three of Europe’s top five leagues since 1996, driven by rising pressure on clubs and managers. While La Liga and Serie A have had the highest turnover rates, the Premier League, Bundesliga, and Ligue 1 have also seen significant coaching changes in recent years.

title: The “multiverse” of music genres is warping into a sea of vibes
summary: Streaming services like Spotify have transformed music consumption and genre classification, using algorithms to analyze and categorize songs based on psychoacoustic attributes, resulting in an expansive and fluid genre map. While rock once dominated, its influence has waned in recent years, with emerging sub-genres like alt-z and the growing presence of hip-hop reshaping the musical landscape.

title: Maryland’s top invasive plant species import harm to natives
summary: Invasive plant species are causing significant harm to Maryland's environment by outcompeting native plants and disrupting ecosystems. The state is taking measures to control these species, including legislation targeting plants like running bamboo and bush honeysuckle.

title: Smithsonian’s ‘1898’ exhibit explores complex history behind U.S. expansionism
summary: The Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery has unveiled its first major exhibition, “1898: U.S. Imperial Visions and Revisions,” marking the 125th anniversary of key events in U.S.

title: Paul Monteiro set to make Moore’s vision for youth service year a reality in Maryland
summary: Paul Monteiro, newly appointed head of Maryland’s Department of Civic and Service Innovation, is working to launch Governor Wes Moore’s youth service year program, the SERVE Act, with the goal of enrolling 250 participants by October and scaling up to 2,000 by the fourth year. The program offers recent high school graduates paid service roles, mentorship, and job training as an alternative to college or direct employment.

title: Several Maryland Democrats expected to vie to replace Cardin
summary: Several Maryland Democrats, including Montgomery County Councilmember Will Jawando, Reps. Jamie Raskin and David Trone, and local leaders Angela Alsobrooks and Johnny Olszewski, are expected to compete in a 2024 primary to replace retiring Sen.

title: Historically successful UCLA gymnastics faces challenges in move to Big Ten
summary: UCLA's historically successful women's gymnastics team will face new challenges as it moves to the Big Ten in 2025, shifting from competitive Pac-12 rivals to a conference with a weaker gymnastics tradition. Head coach Janelle McDonald embraces the change, believing it will provide student-athletes with continued opportunities and excitement.

title: Debt ceiling fight leads Van Hollen, Democrats to revive proposal to eliminate the debt ceiling
summary: Democrats, led by Sens. Chris Van Hollen and Brian Schatz, have reintroduced a bill to eliminate the national debt ceiling to prevent economic disruptions caused by recurring debt limit disputes.

title: Biden infrastructure program so far has sent $2.6 billion to Maryland
summary: President Joe Biden’s infrastructure program has allocated $2.6 billion to Maryland over the past two years for projects including roads, public transit, and water safety. The funding, part of the Bipartisan Infrastructure Law, aims to modernize infrastructure, create jobs, and address past harmful infrastructure decisions.

title: Cardin gives racial and religious profiling bill another chance
summary: Sen. Ben Cardin has reintroduced the End Racial and Religious Profiling Act of 2023, aiming to ban profiling by law enforcement and mandate training and data reporting, following renewed attention to police violence after Tyre Nichols' death.

title: D.C. community organizes African ceremony to heal violent crime trauma
summary: The Love-More Movement in Washington, D.C., organized an African-inspired ceremony to help victims of violent crime process and heal from their trauma. The event aims to provide emotional support in a community frequently affected by violence.

title: Former Terrapin Taylor Cummings is a color commentator for Maryland women’s lacrosse
summary: Taylor Cummings, a former Maryland Terrapin and top-ranked player, now serves as a color commentator for the Maryland women’s lacrosse team on The Big Ten Network. Her expertise enhances game coverage with insights from her playing and coaching background.

title: Paws to Read helps children boost their confidence when reading aloud
summary: Paws to Read is a program where children read aloud to trained dogs to help build their confidence in a relaxed, distraction-free environment. The initiative provides a judgment-free zone that makes some kids feel more comfortable practicing their reading skills.

title: The early spring brings in one of the worst pollen seasons yet
summary: Early spring, brought on by warmer weather, has caused trees to bloom earlier and produced one of the worst pollen seasons yet. Many people are experiencing worse allergies than usual as a result.

title: Maryland pitcher Courtney Wyche started her own pitching camp where she coaches young girls
summary: Courtney Wyche started her own pitching camp in Maryland with her father, coaching high school girls alongside her teammates. Inspired by her self-taught pitching journey since age 10, she now focuses on teaching and mentoring young female athletes.

title: UberEats delivery guy builds up his own brand by documenting his deliveries
summary: Josh Cavalero has been gaining recognition by sharing his UberEats delivery experiences on Instagram since August 2022. His content has helped him build a personal brand, which he aims to expand into in-depth restaurant reviews.

title: D.C. Mayor announces community policing project as Chief Contee retires to join FBI
summary: D.C. Mayor Muriel Bowser announced a community policing initiative to address the city's shrinking police force as summer approaches.

title: Cardin’s effort to push ERA forward falls short in the Senate
summary: A Senate resolution to recognize the Equal Rights Amendment as the 28th U.S. Constitution amendment failed to meet the 60-vote threshold needed to overcome a filibuster.

title: His chemotherapy over, Maryland’s Raskin says his cancer is ‘in remission’
summary: Maryland Rep. Jamie Raskin announced that his cancer is in remission after completing chemotherapy, with a 90% chance it will not return.

title: New MLB rules lead to shorter games and more stolen bases
summary: The 2023 MLB season introduced new rules including a pitch clock, larger bases, and shift restrictions, leading to shorter games and more stolen bases. The pitch clock has already caused 33 violations in the first 35 games, with an average game time now at two hours and thirty-eight minutes.

title: Maryland’s Ivey wants federal law raising age to 21 for semiautomatic rifle and shotgun buys
summary: Rep. Glenn Ivey of Maryland introduced a bill to raise the minimum age to purchase semiautomatic rifles and shotguns to 21, aligning with the current age requirement for buying handguns.

title: US, South Korea announce plans for expanded space partnerships
summary: The United States and South Korea have agreed to expand their space partnership, focusing on areas such as lunar exploration, space communications, and climate monitoring. The collaboration includes joint efforts on NASA’s Artemis mission and shared satellite technology to track environmental changes globally.

title: Senate will vote on Cardin’s Equal Rights Amendment resolution this week
summary: The Senate is set to vote this week on a bipartisan resolution to recognize the Equal Rights Amendment as the 28th Amendment, despite its 1982 ratification deadline having passed. While the resolution has broad support with 52 co-sponsors, it faces potential opposition and must overcome a filibuster to pass.

title: Maryland Public defender opposes Baltimore youth curfew, residents weary of crime wave
