summary: Lawmakers criticized Metro for concealing safety issues with new-model Kawasaki 7000-series rail cars for years, raising concerns about public safety and trust. Mechanical defects, including wheel failures linked to a 2021 derailment, led to the removal of all such cars from service.

title: Maryland Democratic lawmakers renew effort to push landmark climate change legislation through the General Assembly
summary: Maryland’s Democratic lawmakers are pushing for aggressive climate change legislation aimed at achieving net zero carbon emissions by 2045, with key provisions targeting emissions reductions, building standards, and methane regulation. The proposed bills would require major emission cuts, set strict timelines for transitioning to clean energy, and mandate the state’s vehicle fleet to switch to zero-emission models by 2033.

title: Maryland Gov. Hogan announces he will not run for U.S. Senate
summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan announced he will not run for the U.S.

title: Maryland bill aims to reform a law that can trigger deportation for immigrants
summary: A Maryland bill seeks to reform the Probation Before Judgment law to prevent immigrants from facing deportation or citizenship barriers due to pleading guilty for minor offenses. The legislation aims to allow judges to grant probation without requiring a guilty plea, ensuring equal treatment under state law for both citizens and noncitizens.

title: In Maryland, Biden signs order affecting 200,000 workers in federal building contracts
summary: President Joe Biden signed an executive order in Maryland requiring federal construction contracts over $35 million to use project labor agreements, affecting around 200,000 workers and aiming to improve job quality and project efficiency. The move, backed by local and national leaders, makes such agreements mandatory, building on a policy first encouraged under President Barack Obama.

title: Washington team owner battles with new allegations, and lawmakers debate whether Congress has oversight role
summary: Tiffani Johnston, a former Washington Commanders employee, testified before Congress about alleged inappropriate conduct by team owner Daniel Snyder, including unwanted physical contact during a dinner and a forced attempt to place her in a limo. Snyder denied the allegations, calling them "outright lies," while lawmakers and NFL officials continue to scrutinize the team's workplace culture.

title: Memorials to lynching victims challenge who writes nation’s history
summary: Memorials to lynching victims are reshaping the national narrative by bringing attention to a long-ignored chapter of American history. These tributes challenge traditional historical accounts and highlight the ongoing struggle for racial justice.

title: Confederate monument stands at site of 1922 Arkansas lynching
summary: A Confederate monument remains standing at the site of a 1922 lynching in Arkansas. The presence of the monument has sparked debate over historical memory and racial justice.

title: A lynching countenanced by the white press and church
summary: The article discusses a historical lynching that was supported or ignored by white newspapers and churches, highlighting the complicity of mainstream institutions in racial violence. It underscores the deep-seated racism and lack of justice faced by Black individuals during that era.

title: Some Protestant churches welcomed revival of the Ku Klux Klan
summary: Some Protestant churches in the early 20th century welcomed the revival of the Ku Klux Klan, viewing its members as upholding moral and religious values. This support reflected a broader acceptance of the Klan's influence within certain religious communities at the time.

title: Robert Vann’s Pittsburgh Courier set a pattern for what the Black press could do
summary: Robert Vann's Pittsburgh Courier demonstrated the power of the Black press in advocating for civil rights and amplifying the voices of African Americans. His leadership set a lasting example for future generations of Black journalists and editors.

title: Freedom’s Journal marked the beginning of the Black press
summary: *Freedom’s Journal*, founded in 1827, was the first African American-owned newspaper in the United States and played a key role in advocating for Black rights and challenging racial injustice. It marked the beginning of a powerful tradition in the Black press that continues to amplify marginalized voices.

title: Simeon Booker among Black chroniclers of civil rights-era atrocities
summary: Simeon Booker was a pioneering Black journalist who documented civil rights-era atrocities, bringing national attention to the struggles and injustices faced by African Americans. His work, along with other Black chroniclers, played a crucial role in shaping public awareness and the historical record of the civil rights movement.

title: Black journalist Alexander M. Rivera, who covered Willie Earle lynching trial, recalls tension, fear
summary: Black journalist Alexander M. Rivera, who reported on the 1952 Willie Earle lynching trial in South Carolina, recalled the intense racial tension and fear he experienced while covering the case.

title: NAACP head Walter White was a pioneering Black journalist
summary: Walter White, the head of the NAACP, was a pioneering Black journalist known for his investigative reporting on race-related issues in the United States. His work helped shed light on racial injustice and contributed to the civil rights movement.

title: Frederick Douglass founded newspapers to allow Black writers to tell their own stories
summary: Frederick Douglass founded newspapers to give Black writers a platform to share their own narratives. His efforts aimed to challenge racial stereotypes and promote self-representation within the African American community.

title: James Weldon Johnson gave voice to Black people’s dignity and creativity
summary: James Weldon Johnson was a prominent figure who championed the dignity and creativity of Black people through his work in literature and civil rights. His contributions, including the poem "Lift Every Voice and Sing," became powerful symbols of African American resilience and identity.

title: Ida B. Wells exposed the economic truths behind lynchings
summary: Ida B. Wells revealed that lynchings in the post-Reconstruction South were often driven by economic competition rather than the moral justifications given at the time.

title: A timeline of post-Civil War racial terror and federal legislative efforts to stop It
summary: The article outlines a history of racial terror in the U.S. following the Civil War, including lynching and systemic discrimination.

title: Explore the Printing Hate lynching coverage database
summary: The Printing Hate lynching coverage database compiles news articles and media reports on lynching incidents in India. It aims to document and analyze the portrayal of such violence in the press to raise awareness and promote responsible journalism.

title: Billie Holiday v. The White Press
summary: Billie Holiday faced significant racial bias and hostility from the white press during her career, which often distorted her public image and downplayed her artistic achievements. Despite her immense talent and influence on jazz, she was frequently subjected to discriminatory coverage that reflected the broader racism of the time.

title: National Underground Railroad Network to Freedom adds four Maryland sites
summary: The National Underground Railroad Network to Freedom has added four new sites in Maryland, highlighting the state's significant role in the history of the Underground Railroad. Maryland now has over 90 recognized sites, reflecting its long history of aiding freedom seekers and its connection to figures like Harriet Tubman.

title: Our new database expands the scope of ‘Printing Hate’
summary: Our new database significantly broadens the scope of the “Printing Hate” project by including a more extensive range of hate-filled printed materials. This expansion allows for deeper analysis of how hate speech is disseminated through print media.

title: Diversity among Big Ten head coaches
summary: The Big Ten conference is making progress in promoting diversity among its head coaches, as highlighted by Black coaches Mike Locksley and Marisa Moseley. Commissioner Kevin Warren provided insights on the conference's current standing in diversity efforts.

title: Opening up University of Maryland police logs
summary: The University of Maryland is making its police logs publicly available for the first time, following calls for greater transparency. The move comes amid ongoing national discussions about campus policing and accountability.

title: The horrors of lynching photographs and postcards
summary: Lynching photographs and postcards from the early 20th century served as grim mementos of racial violence in the United States. These disturbing images not only dehumanized victims but also perpetuated a culture of terror and racial oppression.

title: Greenbelt passes a referendum to study possible reparations for Black and Native American residents
summary: Greenbelt, Maryland, has passed a referendum to establish a 21-person commission to study reparations for African American and Native American residents. The initiative, approved by residents, aims to explore potential reparative measures for historical injustices.

title: ‘Streeteries’ in Montgomery County will remain at least through March
summary: Montgomery County's shared street initiative, known as "Streeteries," will continue through at least March. The extension aims to provide a safe outdoor space for dining and recreation amid the ongoing pandemic.

title: Montgomery county business managers conflicted as the mask mandate lift is extended
summary: Montgomery County extended the suspension of its indoor mask mandate, but the decision could be reversed if COVID case numbers rise. Masks may be required again starting November 9 if case averages increase by Friday.

title: Sugar skulls, pictures and orange flowers: Mexican Catholics celebrate Day of the Dead
summary: Mexican Catholics in Baltimore celebrate the Day of the Dead with vibrant altars featuring photos, candles, orange flowers, and decorated skulls. The tradition, rooted in Mexico, honors deceased loved ones and is increasingly observed in U.S.

title: Victory for tenants: Montgomery County Council passes rent stabilization bill
summary: Montgomery County Council passed a rent stabilization bill to protect tenants from steep rent hikes and late fees for six months. The measure, praised by local advocates, aims to support residents still recovering from the pandemic's economic impact.

title: Spacecraft Lucy launches to space on a mission to discover
summary: Lucy, a NASA mission led by NASA Goddard, has launched to explore Jupiter’s Trojan asteroids to gain insights into the formation of our solar system. The spacecraft will travel 4 billion miles and study eight asteroids during its journey.

title: D.C. Council introduces a bill that would require all eligible students to be vaccinated
summary: A new bill introduced in the D.C. Council would require all eligible students to be fully vaccinated against COVID-19 by December 15.

title: Activists call for change in how police respond to mental health crisis incidents in Montgomery County
summary: Activists and Ryan Leroux's family are calling for changes in how Montgomery County police handle mental health crises following his fatal shooting in July. They argue that his death could have been avoided if officers had provided appropriate mental health support instead of using force.

title: Anti-Asian Hate Crimes Increase 73% in 2020, FBI Data Shows
summary: Anti-Asian hate crimes rose by 73% in 2020, according to FBI data, with experts linking the surge to hate rhetoric during the pandemic. The reported numbers may be lower than the actual incidents, as many victims do not report the crimes to authorities.

title: RSV cases spike, as parents worry about their children’s safety
summary: Doctors are reporting an unexpected surge in RSV cases nationwide, typically peaking in winter. Parents are growing concerned about protecting their children amid the rise and ongoing COVID-19 threats.

title: Howard University students stage sit-in protest, enter day 2
summary: Howard University students, led by the Live Movement, are staging a sit-in protest at the Blackburn University Student Center for a second day to demand improved housing conditions. The demonstrators have vowed to continue until their demands are addressed.

title: D.C. LGBTQ+ shelter struggling to stay open after losing government funding
summary: A D.C. LGBTQ+ nonprofit, Casa Ruby, is forced to close its 50-bed emergency shelter after losing an $850,000 government grant.

title: TPS holders continue to fight for a pathway to citizenship
summary: TPS holders are advocating for a permanent pathway to citizenship. They continue to push for a long-term legal solution to their status in the U.S.

title: Capital Gazette shooter sentenced after being found criminally responsible
summary: Jarrod Ramos was sentenced for the 2018 murder of five Capital Gazette workers. Victims' family members and survivors testified at the sentencing hearing.

title: Organization helping Afghan refugees overwhelmed with donations
summary: The Adventist Community Services of Greater Washington is assisting Afghan refugees with overwhelming community support. The organization has temporarily stopped accepting donations due to storage capacity limits.

title: DC making moves to tackle food insecurity among low income residents
summary: DC Health has partnered with FRESHFARM to expand access to fresh produce for low-income residents through the Produce Plus program. Starting this summer, FRESHFARM will oversee the initiative to connect local farmers with underserved communities facing food insecurity.

title: Montgomery county voters demand council to strengthen mental health resources
summary: Montgomery County voters are urging local officials and candidates to prioritize mental health by implementing stronger policies. The call comes amid rising concerns about the community's mental health needs.

title: Vehicles for Change: A non-profit transforming lives one car at a time
summary: Vehicles for Change is a Baltimore-based nonprofit that helps former prisoners reenter society by training them as auto mechanics through an internship program. They repair donated cars, which are then sold to low-income families in need of transportation.

title: University of Maryland’s therapy dog ready for finals week stress
summary: As finals week approaches and student stress rises, the University of Maryland Police Department has introduced their therapy dog, Teddy, to help ease anxiety. Teddy is available to provide comfort and support to students during this challenging time.

title: The Arkansas racial massacre almost no one remembers
summary: In 1919, a white mob in Elaine, Arkansas, killed hundreds of Black people in what is now recognized as one of the deadliest racial massacres in U.S. history.

title: A hall-of-fame Maryland editor ‘published racist viewpoints with pride’
summary: A renowned Maryland editor, celebrated for his journalism career, is now facing scrutiny for having published racist viewpoints with pride throughout his tenure. His legacy is being reevaluated in light of these revelations.

title: Maryland General Assembly elects Davis state treasurer
summary: The Maryland General Assembly elected Delegate Dereck Davis as the state's new treasurer, with nearly all lawmakers supporting him in a joint vote. A longtime legislator and first African-American from Prince George’s County to chair a House committee, Davis expressed his commitment to safeguarding Maryland’s finances during his new role.

title: Asked about late mail, postmaster general will give late response
summary: The Maryland congressional delegation is awaiting a delayed response from Postmaster General Louis DeJoy regarding the USPS's readiness for the holiday mail delivery season. Critics continue to push for DeJoy’s removal, citing a pattern of late responses and ongoing service issues despite recent improvements in on-time delivery rates.

title: Temporary legal protections leave uncertainty for Afghan evacuees resettling in the U.S.
summary: Afghan evacuees resettling in the U.S. face uncertainty due to temporary legal protections that limit their ability to plan for the future.

title: Hogan’s congressional map veto overridden by legislature
summary: The Maryland General Assembly overrode Gov. Larry Hogan’s veto to pass a congressional redistricting plan that is expected to favor Democrats, creating seven likely Democratic seats and one competitive district.

title: Historic Amtrak funding aims to alleviate delays and replace nearly 50-year-old rail cars
summary: Amtrak is set to receive a historic $66 billion in funding through President Biden’s infrastructure bill to modernize its aging rail system, reduce delays, and replace outdated infrastructure. The investment aims to improve reliability and passenger experience, particularly along the busy Northeast Corridor, where decades-old infrastructure has contributed to frequent delays.

title: Baltimore police reform pilot program diverts 911 calls
summary: Baltimore's 911 diversion pilot program, which redirects behavioral health and substance use crisis calls to trained personnel instead of police, is being hailed as a success by city officials and law enforcement. The Crisis Response Team, composed of police and a social worker, has been dispatched over 300 times since its launch, providing a specialized response during daytime hours.

title: Aggregated data masks Asian disparities in Maryland and US
summary: Aggregated race data obscures significant health and educational disparities among Asian American subgroups in Maryland and across the U.S., as larger groups like Chinese and Indian Americans overshadow smaller, more vulnerable communities. Experts emphasize the need for disaggregated data to ensure equitable resource allocation and legislative attention to these disparities.

title: In move to electric vehicles, Maryland is doing better than most
summary: Maryland ranks seventh in the U.S. for electric vehicle (EV) preparedness, with 40,587 registered EVs and a growing network of public chargers.

title: Dem-favored redistricting plan advances in the Senate
summary: A Democratic-backed congressional redistricting plan advanced in the Maryland Senate after an amendment to replace it with a map preferred by Gov. Larry Hogan was rejected.

title: Former homeless veteran gives shelter to others who struggle
summary: Michael Strong, a former homeless Air Force veteran who struggled with addiction and life on the streets, now helps other homeless veterans find shelter in Washington, D.C. After decades of personal battles and setbacks, he works to support those facing similar challenges through the Chesapeake Health and Education Program.

title: Maryland TikTok creators share their side of the story
summary: Maryland TikTok creators are gaining recognition despite a limited local community, using the platform to showcase talents ranging from parkour to bartending while earning income through brand partnerships and TikTok's Creator Fund. Though opportunities are growing, many creators express frustration over the lack of regional collaboration and visibility.

title: Pandemic financially devastated minority-led nonprofits
summary: Minority-led nonprofits in Maryland, particularly in Prince George’s County, were financially devastated by the pandemic due to limited funding and multiple income losses. Advocates are urging state officials to allocate $1 billion from Maryland’s budget surplus to support these struggling organizations, with half distributed immediately and half reserved for future needs.

title: House rejects amendment to swap redistricting maps
summary: The Maryland House of Delegates rejected an amendment to replace the legislative redistricting map with one proposed by the governor's citizen commission, allowing the original plan to move forward. Republicans criticized the legislative map as partisan and unfair, while Democrats defended its legality and focus on communities of interest.

title: Maryland cities surpass national average of mail-in ballots in local elections
summary: Maryland cities saw a significant increase in mail-in voting during local elections, surpassing the national average, with some areas like Frederick reporting over 88% of votes cast by mail. This shift reflects a broader trend toward expanded mail-in voting, with many cities experiencing dramatic rises compared to previous elections.

title: House committee recommends legislative redistricting map
summary: A House committee in Maryland recommended a congressional redistricting map proposed by the Legislative Redistricting Advisory Commission, while the Senate voted to override several vetoes on the first day of the 2021 special session. The recommended map faces competition from an alternative plan supported by Republican Governor Larry Hogan and a citizen commission that claims to offer a more transparent and public-focused redistricting process.

title: News coverage of lynchings of Mexicans, Asians and Native Americans followed established patterns
summary: News coverage of lynchings involving Mexicans, Asians, and Native Americans often mirrored existing racial stereotypes and justified the violence through dehumanizing narratives. Media portrayal typically reinforced dominant social hierarchies rather than challenging the injustices depicted.

title: Maryland residents submit most telemarketing call, robocall complaints to FTC per capita
summary: Maryland had the highest number of telemarketing and robocall complaints per capita in the 2021 fiscal year, with 2,028 complaints per 100,000 residents, followed closely by Delaware. Most complaints involved robocalls and imposter government agency scams, despite the availability of the FTC's Do Not Call Registry.

title: Legislature plans special session on redistricting, vetoes
summary: The Maryland General Assembly is set to hold a special session to address congressional redistricting and consider maps from two commissions, with political party lines expected to heavily influence the process. The proposed maps differ significantly from the current one, and approval would require legislative passage and potential gubernatorial approval.

title: Somerset County Public School has seen “alarming” total positive COVID-19 cases since the start of the school year
summary: Somerset County Public Schools have seen alarming rates of student and staff COVID-19 cases, with some schools reporting over 9% positivity rates since August 2021. The county's low vaccination rate, at 46%, contrasts with Maryland’s 67% average, as efforts continue to vaccinate children ages 5 to 11.

title: Hogan announces COVID measures in face of omicron variant
summary: Maryland is expanding its efforts to track the omicron variant through enhanced surveillance and testing, as confirmed cases emerge in the U.S. Governor Larry Hogan urged calm and emphasized the importance of testing, while noting the state has one of the strongest variant surveillance systems in the nation.

title: Supreme Court weighs Mississippi abortion law, future of Roe v. Wade
summary: The Supreme Court considered a Mississippi law banning abortions after 15 weeks, challenging the precedent set by Roe v. Wade and raising concerns about the potential impact on the court's legitimacy.

title: Bike infrastructure will help prevent crashes and fatalities, advocates and researchers say
summary: Baltimore and other Maryland cities have limited bike infrastructure, leading to a majority of crashes occurring on roads without dedicated bike lanes. Advocates stress the importance of protected bike infrastructure to reduce injuries and fatalities, though funding remains a challenge for local governments.

title: Supreme Court to hear arguments over Mississippi law banning abortions after 15 weeks
summary: The Supreme Court will hear arguments in *Dobbs v. Jackson Women’s Health Organization* regarding Mississippi’s 15-week abortion ban, which could overturn the precedent set by *Roe v.

title: AP spread racist Jim Crow-era coverage to a national audience
summary: The Associated Press (AP) contributed to the national spread of racist stereotypes by disseminating Jim Crow-era news coverage that reinforced white supremacy. This practice exposed a broader audience to prejudiced narratives that dehumanized Black Americans.

title: Maryland counties vaccinate youngest schoolchildren
summary: Maryland has expanded vaccine eligibility to 5- to 11-year-olds, with local school and health systems facilitating clinics and vaccination rates rising across the state. Montgomery County has led the effort, significantly increasing its vaccination rate by hosting school-based clinics accessible to underserved communities.

title: The Congressional Black Caucus: Building a legacy for half a century
summary: The Congressional Black Caucus, founded in 1971, celebrates its 50th anniversary and continues to lead efforts in advancing civil and voting rights. With 57 members, the caucus has played a key role in recent legislative achievements, including the passage of President Biden’s bipartisan infrastructure bill.

title: Maryland State House dome, grounds slated for repairs
summary: The Maryland State House dome and surrounding grounds will undergo a two-phase restoration project funded by $619,620, focusing on structural repairs, historical preservation, and accessibility improvements. The project, led by MCWB Architects, is expected to extend beyond its funding period until late 2024.

title: Maryland turkey farmers have high sales and high costs
summary: Maryland turkey farmers are experiencing strong sales ahead of Thanksgiving but are grappling with rising costs for feed, fuel, and electricity. While some farmers have raised prices slightly, others are absorbing the expenses to remain competitive and retain customers.

title: Marylanders say they are feeling the pinch of inflation
summary: Marylanders are struggling with rising inflation, which has led to higher costs for essentials like groceries and gas, prompting changes in household budgets. Experts attribute the inflation to increased government spending, pandemic-related stimulus, and supply chain disruptions.

title: Data shows Maryland General Assembly is becoming more representative of state
summary: The 2018 Maryland General Assembly elections led to the most diverse and representative legislature in the state's history, though disparities still remain. While significant progress has been made in gender and racial representation, experts emphasize that continued efforts are needed to fully reflect Maryland’s population.

title: The lynching of Willie Earle prompted a trial, but no convictions
summary: Willie Earle, a Black man, was lynched in 1947 by a white mob in Greenville, South Carolina, following his arrest for the murder of a local grocer. Despite a subsequent trial, no members of the mob were convicted.

title: Tracking air travel: See how many people are flying this Thanksgiving
summary: Air travel for Thanksgiving is expected to return to pre-pandemic levels, with Washington, D.C. area airports already experiencing increased passenger traffic.

title: Silver Spring salon stays open with little relief, lots of resolve
summary: Alchemy Hair Salon in Silver Spring remained open during the pandemic despite three months of closure and limited government support, with owner Roxie determined to keep her 23 employees employed. More than a year and a half later, the salon continues to face challenges, as staff and clients navigate the ongoing effects of the crisis.

title: Environmental lessons for Maryland in wake of COVID-19
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic in Maryland highlighted both environmental inequities and a renewed public appreciation for nature, with a 45% increase in state park visitors in 2020. At the same time, the crisis led to a surge in medical waste, including disposable masks, posing new environmental challenges.

title: Billing errors plague health providers in Maryland
summary: Behavioral health providers in Maryland are disputing the state's claim that they were overpaid by over $359 million through Medicaid and state programs, arguing that insufficient documentation has been provided. The issue began in early 2020 when UnitedHealth Group/Optum failed to process claims after taking over billing, prompting the state to issue weekly estimated payments based on historical data.

title: Never mind the honeybee: Maryland researchers want more buzz over saving native bee species
summary: Maryland researchers argue that the focus on saving honeybees diverts attention from critically endangered native bee species. While honeybees are not classified as endangered and their populations remain stable, many native species face real threats and require urgent conservation efforts.

title: How a 1919 massacre tore Elaine, Arkansas, apart
summary: A 1919 massacre in Elaine, Arkansas, left dozens of Black residents dead after a dispute turned into a violent confrontation with white mobs and law enforcement. The event, rooted in racial tensions and labor unrest, remains a tragic chapter in the town's history and a symbol of broader civil rights struggles.

title: History focuses on men, but Black women were lynched, too
summary: Black women were also victims of lynching, though history has largely overlooked their experiences in favor of focusing on men. This underreported aspect highlights the need for a more inclusive and accurate historical narrative.

title: A pregnant woman’s lynching resonates through generations
summary: A pregnant woman was brutally lynched, an act of violence that has left a lasting scar on her community. The incident continues to echo through generations, symbolizing deep-seated injustice and unresolved trauma.

title: Federal lawmakers in both parties seek to redress veteran homelessness
summary: Bipartisan lawmakers introduced the Improving Housing Outcomes for Veterans Act to address ongoing homelessness among veterans by enhancing coordination between federal agencies and local providers. The legislation aims to implement recommendations from a 2020 GAO report and ensure better support for veterans at risk of or experiencing homelessness.

title: At Baltimore’s port, Biden touts ‘once-in-a-generation’ infrastructure investments
summary: President Biden highlighted the $1.2 trillion infrastructure bill as a transformative investment during a visit to the Port of Baltimore, which will receive significant funding to modernize and improve supply chain efficiency. The legislation, set to be signed into law, includes a historic $17 billion for ports nationwide and is part of broader efforts to stimulate economic recovery and create jobs.

title: Legislative redistricting group releases draft congressional maps
summary: Maryland's Legislative Redistricting Advisory Commission released four draft congressional maps, drawing criticism for potential gerrymandering, while the state's bipartisan citizens commission presented its own maps to the governor. Both sets of maps will be considered during a special legislative session starting Dec.

title: Candidates declare for 2022 statewide races in Maryland
summary: Candidates from both major parties have announced their campaigns for Maryland's 2022 statewide races, including governor, attorney general, and comptroller, with primaries set for June. The Democratic gubernatorial primary features a diverse field including prominent politicians, business leaders, and former government officials.

title: Ahead of Veterans Day, Biden administration focuses on veteran suicides
summary: The Biden administration has launched new initiatives aimed at reducing veteran suicides by coordinating efforts across federal agencies to improve mental health care, limit access to lethal means, and enhance suicide risk identification. Despite a slight decline in veteran suicides in 2019, veterans still die by suicide at nearly twice the rate of civilians, highlighting an ongoing public health crisis.

title: Maryland, nation brace for Thanksgiving travel surge
summary: This Thanksgiving, 53.4 million Americans are expected to travel, a 13% increase from last year and the highest since 2005, driven by reopened borders and improved public health conditions. While air travel is nearly doubling compared to 2020, most travelers will still opt for road trips, with driving accounting for the majority of holiday travel.

title: New congressional maps could impact incumbents
summary: New congressional maps proposed by Maryland’s Citizens Redistricting Commission could force some current representatives out of their districts, as two new districts would not include the homes of any sitting incumbents. The final map includes a Western Maryland district along the northern border and a new district combining Anne Arundel and Howard counties, neither of which currently house the representatives who serve them.

title: Massive infrastructure bill cleared by House includes nearly $8 billion for Maryland
summary: The House has passed a $1.2 trillion infrastructure bill that includes nearly $8 billion in funding for Maryland's transportation, broadband, and port projects. The bipartisan legislation, awaiting President Biden’s signature, is expected to create hundreds of thousands of jobs in the state.

title: Newspapers falsely reported Slocum Massacre as a race revolt
summary: Newspapers incorrectly reported the Slocum Massacre as a race revolt, distorting the event's true nature. This misleading coverage contributed to the erasure of the massacre's historical significance and the suffering of Black Texans.

title: Annapolis confronts a legacy of lynchings and racial terror
summary: Annapolis is addressing its troubled past by confronting a legacy of lynchings and racial terror. Local efforts aim to acknowledge historical injustices and promote racial healing.

title: Goucher Poll results are in. Take our quiz to see where you stand.
summary: The Goucher Poll has released its results, offering insights into public opinion on key issues. Readers are encouraged to take an online quiz to compare their views with the poll's findings.

title: Cybersecurity concerns grow in hospitals across Maryland
summary: Maryland hospitals are experiencing a surge in ransomware and cybersecurity threats, with federal investigators examining multiple breaches among healthcare providers in the state. Cyberattacks are becoming more frequent and dangerous, prompting new legislation to protect critical healthcare systems and patient data.

title: Atlanta newspapers’ white supremacy fueled 1906 race massacre
summary: The Atlanta newspapers fueled racial tensions in 1906 by publishing false claims that Black men were assaulting white women, inciting a white supremacist-led massacre that killed dozens of Black residents. This coverage played a central role in justifying and escalating the violence against the city’s Black community.

title: Hoyer proposes $9 billion trust fund to help reverse global deforestation
summary: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer introduced a $9 billion trust fund proposal to help developing countries combat deforestation, aligning with President Biden’s climate goals. The initiative, called AMAZON21, aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by preserving and restoring global forests ahead of a 2030 deforestation elimination target.

title: Legal sports betting further delayed in Maryland
summary: Maryland's Sports Wagering Applicant Review Commission delayed voting on sports betting licenses for five casinos, citing the need for more information. Governor Larry Hogan has repeatedly urged the commission to expedite the process to launch the state's legal sports betting industry.

title: New virtual reality course lowers stress at recovery centers
summary: Two Maryland recovery centers are using a new virtual reality program to help patients reduce stress through mindfulness and immersive, calming environments. Developed by BehaVR and Johns Hopkins, the six-session CenteredVR experience guides users with expert narration and 3D visuals to rewire stress responses and promote mental well-being.

title: Proposed Chesapeake Bay funds aim to curb pollution
summary: Up to $737 million in proposed funding from a congressional budget reconciliation package aims to reduce pollution in the Chesapeake Bay watershed by supporting agricultural conservation efforts such as planting forest buffers and improving livestock grazing practices. The funding push, backed by six Democratic senators, seeks to address urgent water quality issues, including nitrogen pollution and waste management problems at poultry operations.

title: Newspapers called Tallahassee lynching victims animals, insane
summary: Newspapers in Tallahassee in 1940 used dehumanizing language to describe lynching victims, referring to them as animals or insane. This racist rhetoric reflected the broader societal justification for racial violence during the era.

title: Kentucky newspapers often blamed Black victims for lynchings
summary: Kentucky newspapers historically frequently blamed Black victims for their own lynchings, perpetuating racial injustice. This pattern of reporting ignored the broader systemic racism and violence faced by African Americans in the state.

title: Van Hollen, Cardin push pilot program to curb military vehicle rollover deaths
summary: Sens. Chris Van Hollen and Ben Cardin have introduced legislation named after 1st Lt.

title: Supreme Court hears arguments on Texas abortion law Monday
summary: The Supreme Court is set to hear arguments on the Texas Heartbeat Act, a law that allows private citizens to enforce a near-total abortion ban by suing those who assist in abortions after a fetal heartbeat is detected. The case challenges the precedent of Roe v.

title: Annapolis downtown floods as high water expected to last the weekend
summary: Annapolis is experiencing severe flooding, with water levels expected to reach the third-highest ever recorded and remain high through Sunday. Coastal areas are dealing with high winds, heavy rain, and rising tides, prompting school closures and business disruptions.

title: Maryland labor secretary hears unemployment app concerns
summary: Maryland legislators criticized the state's unemployment mobile app for lacking essential functionality, such as submitting claims or uploading documents, during a recent meeting with Labor Secretary Tiffany Robinson. They highlighted the struggles of constituents who rely solely on mobile devices and urged improvements to make the app more accessible and effective.

title: As millions quit jobs for new opportunities, ‘Great Resignation’ shows no signs of waning
summary: Millions of workers continue to leave their jobs across various sectors, with August seeing 4.3 million resignations—43% higher than the previous year—showing the Great Resignation remains strong. Experts suggest the trend reflects a broader awakening as employees seek better satisfaction and opportunities beyond their current roles.

title: Anti-abortion crisis pregnancy centers outnumber abortion providers in Maryland 2 to 1
summary: In Maryland, crisis pregnancy centers (CPCs) outnumber abortion clinics two to one and are strategically located in areas with high poverty and limited access to abortion services. These faith-based centers often mislead women by advertising abortion-related services while providing incomplete or inaccurate information, potentially delaying or preventing access to abortion.

title: Questions and answers about the upcoming climate summit in Scotland
summary: President Joe Biden will attend the COP26 climate summit in Glasgow, Scotland, to demonstrate the U.S.'s renewed commitment to addressing climate change after rejoining the Paris Agreement. The conference, held from October 31 to November 12, is critical for nations to set updated emissions targets and reinforce global climate action efforts.

title: Abortion bans disproportionately impact marginalized communities, activists say
summary: Abortion bans are disproportionately affecting marginalized communities, including people of color and LGBTQ individuals, according to activists. With multiple restrictive laws in place or pending in 21 states, advocates argue these policies reflect broader systemic oppression beyond just being a women's issue.

title: New Immigrant Affairs office to connect resource centers
summary: Maryland has established a new Governor’s Office for Immigrant Affairs to connect immigrant advocacy resources and assist foreign-born residents with services like English programs and naturalization. Appointed director Lorena Rivera aims to launch a website and multilingual hotline before potentially stepping down in 15 months.

title: Horse rescue will operate new facility with grant from state
summary: Days End Farm Horse Rescue in Woodbine, Maryland, will use a $100,000 state grant as a down payment to purchase a nearby firehouse for facility expansion. The rescue rehabilitates abused and neglected horses and assists in animal abuse investigations.

title: Day of the Dead celebration honors Maryland COVID-19 victims
summary: A Day of the Dead celebration in Maryland honored victims of the COVID-19 pandemic, offering a moment of remembrance and reflection. The event featured altars, art, and community gatherings to pay tribute to those who lost their lives.

title: Day of the Dead celebration honors Maryland COVID-19 victims
summary: Maryland residents are celebrating Day of the Dead to honor loved ones lost during the pandemic, combining Mexican traditions with local observances. The event, distinct from Halloween, involves gatherings at cemeteries and festivals with food, music, and marigolds, offering a meaningful way to remember the deceased.

title: 988 suicide line on its way, but states might not be ready
summary: The 988 suicide hotline, set to launch in July, aims to improve access to mental health crisis services, but concerns remain about whether states have sufficient funding and capacity to handle increased demand. While some states like Maryland are preparing with federal funding and draft plans, only 20 states have proposed legislation to support the new system.

title: Maryland needs more marijuana data, experts say
summary: Experts recommend that Maryland collect comprehensive data on cannabis use before potential legalization to better assess future impacts, particularly in areas like youth use and impaired driving. Current data on cannabis-related issues, such as motor vehicle accidents involving THC, is incomplete and may lead to misleading conclusions if not addressed.

title: Columbus, Mississippi, newspapers were not innocent bystanders to racist violence
summary: Columbus, Mississippi, newspapers actively documented and, in some cases, perpetuated racist violence rather than remaining neutral observers. Their coverage often reflected and reinforced the racial tensions and injustices of the time.

title: Yazoo City’s newspaper provided a forum for its pro-lynching readership
summary: Yazoo City’s newspaper historically served as a platform for its readers' support of lynching, reflecting and amplifying the community's racist attitudes. The publication's coverage contributed to the normalization of racial violence in the region.

title: P.G. County Police resist release of misconduct records, despite law change
summary: Prince George’s County Police Department has refused to release police misconduct records, claiming they are investigative and not subject to public disclosure, despite a new Maryland law intended to increase transparency. Lawmakers and advocates argue the department's refusal contradicts the law's purpose, which was passed to make such records publicly accessible.

title: Against backdrop of instability in Haiti, Cardin and Rubio press for more U.S. engagement
summary: Senators Ben Cardin and Marco Rubio have pushed for greater U.S. engagement in Haiti through bipartisan legislation aimed at combating corruption, violence, and human rights abuses while strengthening civil society.

title: With holidays ahead, small businesses struggle with supply chain disruptions
summary: Small businesses are struggling with supply chain disruptions as international shipping delays and rising costs threaten holiday preparations. While the White House and Congress address the issue, experts highlight a lack of coordination in transportation and logistics as a key problem, though the Port of Baltimore remains an exception to the widespread bottlenecks.

title: Massive public lynchings of Black men were nurtured by Waco, Texas, newspapers
summary: Waco, Texas newspapers in the early 20th century played a role in inciting massive public lynchings of Black men by publishing inflammatory rhetoric and sensationalized stories that dehumanized Black individuals and fueled racial violence. These media practices contributed to a climate of terror that supported systemic racism and mob violence in the region.

title: Anti-lynching laws have not passed Congress in 130 years
summary: Anti-lynching laws have failed to pass in Congress for over 130 years, despite numerous attempts. Efforts to criminalize lynching at the federal level continue to face political and legislative challenges.

title: Maryland will pay wrongfully convicted man
summary: Maryland has agreed to pay Leslie Vass over $500,000 in compensation for being wrongfully convicted of armed robbery in 1975. The payment reflects a new law tying compensation to the state's median income and highlights calls for criminal justice reform.

title: Washington Metrorail Safety Commission removes 60% of trains from service
summary: The Washington Metrorail Safety Commission has removed all 7000-series railcars from service, which account for 60% of the fleet. As a result, only 40 trains remain in operation, reducing service frequency to about every 30 minutes.

title: ‘Critters in crisis’: Pollution is reducing wildlife populations in Montgomery County streams
summary: Insects, fish, and amphibians in Montgomery County streams are at risk due to pollution, according to local environmental officials. Residents are urged to take action to help prevent further contamination and protect wildlife.

title: Initiatives take on the challenge of cleaning the Baltimore Harbor, but problems run deep
summary: Baltimore has launched various initiatives to clean the Baltimore Harbor since the 1972 Clean Water Act, but industrial contamination and ongoing trash issues persist. While trash wheels have collected millions of pounds of debris, much of the material is too contaminated for recycling, hindering cleanup efforts.

title: Maryland needs to do more to enforce anti-lead laws, advocates say
summary: Maryland advocates are urging the state to increase funding and improve enforcement of lead reduction laws, as the state was excluded from a recent EPA lead prevention initiative. Despite ongoing efforts under the Maryland Healthy Children Act, which lowered the blood lead level threshold for intervention, more resources are seen as needed to address lead hazards, particularly in low-income communities.

title: More non-prescription meds are coming to vending machines
summary: Maryland now allows over-the-counter medications to be sold in vending machines under a new state law, removing a decades-old ban. The change aims to improve access to health products, especially in areas with limited pharmacy availability.

title: Newspapers printed hate for scores of years, leading to racist violence
summary: Newspapers historically published racist content for decades, contributing to a climate of hatred. This incitement was linked to outbreaks of racist violence.

title: In the 1880s, election fraud and a massacre stopped Black progress
summary: In the 1880s, Black Americans faced significant setbacks due to widespread election fraud and violent massacres aimed at suppressing their political influence. These events halted the progress made during Reconstruction and deepened racial divisions in the United States.

title: Printing Hate: How white-owned newspapers incited racial terror in America
summary: White-owned newspapers in America historically fueled racial terror by publishing inflammatory content that incited violence against Black communities. These publications played a key role in spreading hate and justifying systemic racism through biased reporting and dehumanizing rhetoric.

title: Printing Hate – How white-owned newspapers incited racial terror in America
summary: White-owned newspapers in America historically fueled racial terror by publishing inflammatory content that incited violence against Black communities. This media coverage helped normalize and justify systemic racism, particularly during the era of lynching and segregation.

title: Democrats in Congress press Biden to extend COVID-related prisoner releases
summary: Democrats in Congress are urging President Biden to reverse a Justice Department policy that could reincarcerate thousands of prisoners released to home confinement during the pandemic. They argue that recalling these individuals, some of whom are elderly or have served long sentences for non-violent crimes, would be harmful and contrary to the public interest.

title: Hogan proposes $150 million for increased Maryland police funding
summary: Gov. Larry Hogan proposed a $150 million "Re-Fund the Police Initiative" to boost police staffing, training, and technology, drawing criticism from Democratic lawmakers and Baltimore’s mayor.

title: Facebook needs regulation, experts say, but they see roadblocks
summary: Experts argue that Congress needs to regulate Facebook to curb harmful practices, but they doubt lawmakers can act quickly enough given the fast-evolving technology. While there is growing bipartisan support for oversight, especially after recent whistleblower revelations, regulatory efforts face challenges due to Congress's limited technical expertise and legislative inertia.

title: Maryland is seeing an increase in precipitation, sea level and flooding
summary: Maryland has experienced increased precipitation, flooding, and rising sea levels over the past two decades, with coastal areas receiving the most rainfall. Experts attribute these trends to climate change, projecting continued heavy precipitation and significant sea level rise in the region.

title: Media Watch: The Gabby Petito Disappearance
summary: Student media reporters in College Park, Maryland, are examining how news networks covered the disappearance of Gabby Petito. Their analysis focuses on the portrayal of the case and the influence of media attention on public perception.

title: CNS TV Newscast 10/12/2021
summary: CNS TV Newscast covered key local and national updates on October 12, 2021, from College Park, MD. The broadcast highlighted ongoing developments in education, public safety, and regional politics.

title: DC council making moves to legalize selling marijuana
summary: Washington, D.C. Council members are advancing legislation to tax and regulate cannabis sales.

summary: The Anne Arundel County School Board of Education plans to raise school bus driver wages by $5 per hour. The increase is accompanied by incentives aimed at retaining current drivers and attracting new ones.

summary: Frances Haugen, a former Facebook employee, testified before the Senate, offering insights into the company's internal operations. She discussed Facebook's daily routines and answered questions from lawmakers.

title: Netflix donates over $5 million to fund a memorial scholarship in honor of Chadwick Boseman at his alma mater.
summary: Netflix has donated more than $5 million to establish a memorial scholarship at Chadwick Boseman's alma mater. The scholarship honors the late actor and aims to support future students.

title: Animals at the Maryland Zoo are getting the animal-friendly COVID vaccine
summary: The Maryland Zoo in Baltimore will begin vaccinating 34 animals against COVID-19 starting in October. The vaccines, provided free of charge by Zoetis, are designed to be safe and effective for animals.

title: A local small business is rewarding teachers for their hard work
summary: A local Rockville business, FlanCake by Gaby, is giving free flan cakes to teachers as a gesture of appreciation. The gesture recognizes their hard work and dedication during the COVID-19 pandemic.

title: Maryland holds game in honor of mental health awareness
summary: Maryland football honored mental health awareness by wearing green ribbons during their game against Iowa. The gesture highlighted the importance of mental health advocacy in sports and beyond.

title: Maryland hiring new superintendent for juvenile facilities
summary: Maryland is conducting a national search for a new superintendent to oversee education in its juvenile treatment facilities, aiming to address challenges like teacher retention and curriculum development. The appointed superintendent will work to improve educational quality and advocate for better conditions, though they will not have the authority to directly raise teacher wages.

title: Thousands of Marylanders face animal bites and rabies exposure each year
summary: Each year, thousands of Marylanders experience animal bites and rabies exposure, with domestic animals like cats being among the most frequently identified rabid animals. The Maryland health department has issued corrections regarding previous reporting errors on rabies transmission, treatment, and financial assistance for post-exposure prophylaxis.

title: Steny Hoyer and Democrats press Senate to remove Confederate statues
summary: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer and a group of Democrats are urging the Senate to remove statues of Confederates and white supremacists from the U.S. Capitol, following a House vote to do so.

summary: Gov. Larry Hogan announced a five-point budget framework to allocate Maryland’s $2.5 billion surplus, including boosting the rainy-day fund, offering tax relief for retirees and residents, supporting underserved communities, and enhancing state employee compensation.

title: Redistricting groups faced with uneven population growth
summary: Maryland's redistricting commissions are working to create new congressional and legislative maps amid uneven population growth, with central areas gaining residents while western and Eastern Shore counties lost population. While congressional districts must be nearly equal in population, legislative districts allow for up to a 5% variance, leading to debates over fairness and partisan impacts.

title: Takeaways from the 2020 census for Maryland, in 5 charts
summary: Maryland's population grew by 7% to 6.18 million between 2010 and 2020, becoming more racially diverse with a decline in the white population and significant increases in Black, Hispanic, and multiracial residents. The state also saw a notable rise in people identifying as "other races" and those belonging to two or more racial groups, especially among younger populations.

summary: American companies are seeking to hire Afghan refugees to address labor shortages, recognizing their valuable skills and contributions to the economy. However, child care remains a major challenge, especially for refugee families, as the U.S.

summary: A new study shows that marijuana use among college students in the U.S. has increased from 38% in 2015 to 44% in 2020, while alcohol and binge-drinking rates have declined.

The legislation would allocate $97.5 million specifically for tribal-led conservation efforts, addressing long-standing resource gaps as Indigenous communities face increasing wildlife challenges.

summary: A broad coalition of political, religious, and business leaders, along with companies and advocacy groups, has launched Welcome.US to assist in resettling Afghan refugees across the United States. Maryland Gov.

summary: U.S. state legislatures have passed a record number of voting laws, with 18 states enacting restrictive measures and 25 expanding access, according to the Brennan Center for Justice.

summary: The U.S. Marine Band premiered "These Lights, Which Shine," a new composition by Maj.

summary: Caroline County Circuit Court Judge Jonathan G. Newell died by apparent suicide after federal agents attempted to arrest him at his Maryland home on charges of sexual exploitation of a child.

summary: Maryland has expanded eligibility for COVID-19 booster shots to include individuals 65 and older living in nursing homes and other congregate care facilities. summary: The Annapolis Latinos League, founded in 2018 by Kleber Llivichuzca, offers the Latino community a safe environment for gathering. The league promotes inclusivity by avoiding drugs, alcohol, and inappropriate language.

summary: Over 250 anti-LGBTQ bills have been introduced in U.S. state legislatures this year, with 17 already signed into law, including Arkansas’ ban on gender-affirming medical care for transgender youth.

However, the CDC still advises against travel to several popular international destinations, including France, Italy, and Spain, while the U.S.

title: Bipartisan legislation aims to strengthen U.S. competitive position against China
summary: Bipartisan Senate legislation seeks to bolster U.S. competitiveness against China by increasing investment in technology, strengthening supply chains, and promoting American leadership in global affairs.

title: Essential and Exposed
summary: Essential workers remain on the front lines during the pandemic, facing increased risks while maintaining critical services. Their exposure highlights ongoing vulnerabilities in public health and workplace safety.

title: US deems migrant seafood workers ‘essential’ but limits their COVID-19 protections
summary: Migrant seafood workers in the U.S., classified as essential under the H-2B visa program, face significant risks during the pandemic due to lack of required COVID-19 protections during travel and housing. Despite their essential status, federal and state authorities have not mandated safety measures, leaving thousands vulnerable to outbreaks in communal work and living conditions.

title: Podcast: Airport workers faced COVID risks as airlines advertised passenger safety measures
summary: Airport workers faced significant COVID risks during the pandemic, often overlooked in conversations about air travel safety. The Howard Center's podcast *In The Air* highlights their experiences and the broader implications for community safety.

summary: Massachusetts local health boards, many with minimal staff, were forced to take on workplace safety enforcement during the pandemic, leading to overwhelming challenges and even a health crisis for one official. The situation exposed weaknesses in the state's labor safety system, compounded by the federal OSHA's reduced role and the under-resourced Massachusetts Department of Labor Standards.

title: Baltimore reimbursement program leaves residents burdened with sewage backup costs
summary: Baltimore residents frequently face sewage backups in their homes, often incurring significant cleanup and repair costs. Despite a city reimbursement program, few residents receive payments due to strict eligibility requirements that lead to most applications being rejected.

summary: Montgomery County faces challenges in addressing mental health crises, with police responding to an average of 19 incidents daily due to limited in-person resources. Efforts are underway to expand crisis services, including additional funding for a mobile team of mental health professionals.

summary: Emergency medical responders like Megan O’Brien have faced heightened risks during the pandemic, with studies showing they are more likely to die from COVID-19 than many other healthcare workers. title: Prisoners in solitary confinement live in cells the size of an elevator

While solitary confinement has generally decreased nationwide, it remains prevalent in some states, with the United Nations labeling prolonged isolation as a form of torture due to its severe psychological effects.

title: Sanders and Ocasio-Cortez want $172 billion to overhaul public housing
summary: Sen. Bernie Sanders and Rep.

title: A timeline of COVID-19 cases during phased reopening in Maryland
summary: Maryland experienced fluctuating COVID-19 case numbers as it moved through phases of reopening in 2020. The state saw a rise in cases following the relaxation of restrictions, prompting renewed public health measures.

title: The numbers behind the US men’s national soccer team in Europe’s top five leagues
summary: The USMNT has struggled to advance deep in major tournaments, with its last quarterfinal appearance in the 2002 World Cup and a recent failure to qualify for the 2018 World Cup. Twenty current or soon-to-be USMNT players are in Europe’s top five leagues, with a combined transfer value of $261.25 million, led by Christian Pulisic and Giovanni Reyna.

title: “The case was done”: The testimony that solidified the Chauvin trial
summary: Dr. Martin Tobin's testimony during Derek Chauvin’s trial provided a clear, scientific explanation of how George Floyd died, emphasizing that his death resulted from a lack of oxygen due to Chauvin's knee on his neck.

title: How the evening news showed graphic content during the Chauvin trial
summary: During the Derek Chauvin trial, CBS, ABC, and NBC faced difficult decisions in covering graphic content, with CBS showing Floyd’s death after a warning while ABC aired distressing photos. The networks' varied approaches highlighted the challenge of balancing authentic coverage with the potential harm of disturbing visuals.

title: How the evening news is covering Black Lives Matter protests
summary: In the wake of the George Floyd and Daunte Wright killings, ABC, NBC, and CBS offered differing coverage of the Black Lives Matter protests, with CBS emphasizing property damage and labeling demonstrations as "riots," while ABC and NBC provided more balanced summaries. Critics argue that CBS's focus on violence without protester context risks overshadowing the movement's core message against police brutality.

title: The struggle of blurring evidence in trial coverage: When is doing so appropriate?
summary: CBS selectively unblurred graphic footage during the Derek Chauvin trial to provide necessary context, such as showing Chauvin’s knee on Floyd’s neck, but faced criticism for not consistently warning viewers beforehand. In contrast, other networks avoided showing the most traumatic content, opting for a more viewer-sensitive approach.

title: ‘A difficult call’: How networks handled graphic images of George Floyd’s death
summary: Networks faced a difficult choice during the trial of Derek Chauvin in balancing the public's right to know with the psychological harm caused by repeated exposure to graphic images of George Floyd's death. Experts like Bruce Shapiro and Roxane Silver emphasized the need to weigh the journalistic value of such images against their potential to spread trauma.

title: Coverage holes and the perception of bias
summary: The article highlights how news coverage, particularly during the Derek Chauvin trial, can create perceptions of bias through selective use of footage and omitted details. ABC's heavy focus on courtroom testimony led to significant reporting gaps, such as failing to mention a key witness's Fifth Amendment plea.

title: Lester Holt: The voice of reason
summary: Lester Holt's coverage of the Derek Chauvin trial emphasized George Floyd's story and the impact of his death, focusing on racial justice rather than the defendant. His impartial reporting and sensitive handling of the footage engaged viewers and highlighted the trial's significance in the fight for social change.

title: To clarify, not confuse, is a journalist’s duty
summary: CBS and NBC presented differing accounts of an interview with Lisa Christensen, an alternate juror in the Derek Chauvin trial, with both networks highlighting her conviction of Chauvin's guilt but diverging in how they addressed the influence of external events. While CBS left questions about the jury's impartiality unresolved, NBC concluded with a more definitive portrayal that the jurors followed the judge's instructions.

title: “Believe your own eyes”: The impact of the traumatic visuals George Floyd’s death on news coverage
summary: The graphic image of Derek Chauvin kneeling on George Floyd’s neck became a defining visual of the trial, with ABC repeatedly using it to emphasize the prosecution's message that Floyd’s death was murder. The heavy reliance on traumatic visuals in trial coverage raises concerns about desensitization and may influence future news coverage of police violence.

title: Framing the future on the day of the Derek Chauvin verdicts

While CBS devoted significant time to discussing legislative solutions and long-term change, ABC and NBC focused more on the verdict's immediate implications and political responses.

summary: Prince George’s Community College is offering free classes through its culinary program to help residents adopt healthier lifestyles. The initiative is a partnership with the American Heart Association.

summary: More Americans are traveling again, with the European Union planning to allow U.S. travelers this summer.

title: Student hosts covid donations drive to bring essential items to local charity
summary: A 16-year-old student in Silver Spring, MD, organized a donation drive to support those impacted by the coronavirus pandemic. The initiative aimed to provide essential items to local charities addressing rising domestic violence and homelessness.

title: UMD’s CARE to Stop the Violence team hosts healing session for sexual violence awareness
summary: The University of Maryland's CARE to Stop Violence team hosted a healing session at La Plata Beach as part of Take Back the Night 2021 to raise awareness about sexual violence. The event featured creative self-care activities such as healing arts and crafts for survivors, supporters, and the community.

title: Maryland lifts outdoor mask mandate and outdoor dining restrictions
summary: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan has lifted the statewide outdoor mask mandate and outdoor dining restrictions, though some counties like Howard and Montgomery continue to enforce outdoor masking. Masks remain required indoors, at large venues, and on public transportation.

title: Fidos for Freedom at UMD has continued to raise service dogs amidst the pandemic
summary: Fidos for Freedom at the University of Maryland has continued to meet in person and raise service dogs during the pandemic. The group remains committed to training dogs that will eventually assist individuals in need.

title: A Montgomery County aid group raises over $100,000 to help local community
summary: A Montgomery County aid group has raised over $100,000 to assist local residents with essentials like food and diapers. Since its formation last year, the group has supported more than 3,000 people in the community.

title: One year later: What happened to Maryland’s Korean COVID-19 tests?
summary: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan was praised in 2020 for acquiring 500,000 Korean-made coronavirus tests, credited to his wife’s involvement and dubbed “Operation Enduring Friendship.” However, a year later, many of the tests were found to be flawed and largely unused.

title: NASA’s Goddard Space Flight Center set to launch next-gen telescope in October
summary: NASA’s James Webb Space Telescope, developed by the Goddard Space Flight Center, is set to launch on October 31 after years of delays and rising costs, with testing now complete and no major holdups expected. The telescope will replace the Hubble and offer unprecedented capabilities to observe distant regions of the universe.

title: Biden: ‘America is on the move again’; wants $2 trillion to aid families
summary: President Joe Biden called for Congress to approve a nearly $2 trillion plan to support American families, including expanded education, affordable childcare, and paid family leave, during his first major address to a joint session of Congress. The proposal would be funded by raising the top tax rate for the wealthiest earners to 39.6%, reversing a cut made under former President Donald Trump.

title: Listeria outbreak in Mexican-style soft cheese prompts recall
summary: A listeria outbreak linked to Mexican-style soft cheese from El Abuelito Cheese Inc. has sickened at least four people and caused one death, prompting a recall of several cheese products.

title: Cardin seeks to extend relief payments to farmers, ranchers and self-employed
summary: Sen. Ben Cardin and bipartisan colleagues have introduced legislation to allow farmers, ranchers, and sole proprietors to retroactively apply for increased PPP loan amounts based on gross income rather than net income.

title: Desperate for Diapers
summary: The Tyler Heights Resource Fair offers essential items like diapers and feminine care products to those in need. Maryland Delegate Dana Jones introduced a bill allowing tax deductions for diaper donations to encourage community support.

title: Crystals in Commemoration
summary: Brookside Gardens in Maryland has installed over 1,450 crystals as part of the "Facets of Hope" memorial, each symbolizing a local life lost to COVID-19. The installation continues to grow as new crystals are added weekly.

title: Maryand is trying to limit bear-human conflict
summary: Maryland is urging residents to secure food and garbage to prevent attracting black bears as they emerge from hibernation and seek food before natural sources become available. The Wildlife and Heritage Service reports a growing bear population and increasing human-bear conflicts, with efforts underway to monitor the population and provide financial assistance to affected farmers.

title: Opioid use, fentanyl deaths spike amid pandemic
summary: Preliminary 2020 data shows a sharp rise in opioid-related deaths in Maryland, with fentanyl involved in most cases, as health officials link the surge to pandemic-related stress and disrupted treatment access. Experts note that restrictions on in-person care and psychosocial support have worsened outcomes for individuals struggling with addiction.

title: Addressing a new wave of anti-Asian hate in Maryland
summary: Anti-Asian hate crimes in Maryland have more than doubled since 2018, prompting calls for improved reporting and law enforcement response. Corinna Shen, a Rockville community leader, has experienced repeated vandalism she believes are hate crimes, highlighting the need for greater trust between victims and authorities to effectively address the issue.

title: adam test post
summary: No content provided to summarize.

title: Helping the homeless: How Maryland is attempting to vaccinate one of its most vulnerable communities
summary: Maryland is working to vaccinate its homeless population, a particularly vulnerable group at higher risk for severe illness from COVID-19 due to living conditions and underlying health issues. As the state moves toward broader vaccine eligibility, efforts continue to ensure those without stable housing can access life-saving immunizations.

title: Maryland is at the forefront of youth cricket in the U.S.
summary: Maryland has become a leader in youth cricket in the U.S., thanks to the efforts of Sham Chotoo, who launched a successful program through schools and community centers. By adapting the game for younger players and promoting it as a fun alternative sport, he helped establish the first elementary school cricket league in the nation.

title: Maryland schools experience COVID-19 outbreaks while slowly bringing students back to classrooms
summary: Maryland schools are experiencing multiple COVID-19 outbreaks as they gradually bring students back to in-person learning, with 43 schools currently listed as having outbreaks. Baltimore County has the highest number of cases and affected schools, with private schools reporting a slightly lower average of cases compared to public schools.

title: DOTS is giving away parking spots so artists can display their work after virtual classes brought less cars to campus
summary: The University of Maryland's Department of Transportation is offering free parking spots for artists to display their work. This initiative comes as fewer cars come to campus due to remote learning, allowing creative expression in underused spaces.

title: The University of Maryland announces its plans to reopen campus for the Fall 2021 semester
summary: The University of Maryland announced plans to reopen its campus for the Fall 2021 semester, coordinating with Prince George’s County on lifting restrictions. Vaccines will be highly recommended but not required under the university's reopening plan.

title: Montgomery County is working to reimagine police authority in the aftermath of encounter
summary: Montgomery County is taking steps to reduce police involvement in school affairs following an incident in January 2020 involving a young Black student and local officers. The County Council and Board of Education are working together to reimagine the role of police in schools.

title: Dr. Darryl J. Pines makes history as the University of Maryland’s first Black president
summary: Darryl J. Pines was inaugurated as the 34th president of the University of Maryland.

title: The University of Maryland has received 5400 vaccine doses to be administered on campus
summary: The University of Maryland has received a total of 5400 vaccine doses to distribute on campus, following its decision to reopen in the fall. University officials emphasize the importance of vaccination to ensure safety during the semester.

title: Senate approves bill aimed at combating hate crimes against Asian Americans
summary: The U.S. Senate has passed the COVID-19 Hate Crimes Act with overwhelming bipartisan support, aimed at accelerating federal investigations of hate crimes against Asian Americans.

title: Maryland begins statewide effort to lessen digital divide
summary: Maryland is addressing the digital divide through the Digital Connectivity Act, aiming to provide affordable, high-quality broadband access and necessary tools for all residents. The initiative seeks to close longstanding gaps in internet access that were exacerbated by the pandemic's shift to online work, education, and healthcare.

title: House passes DC statehood, Senate prospects dim
summary: House Democrats passed a bill granting statehood to Washington, D.C., but it faces an uncertain future in the Senate due to insufficient bipartisan support. The legislation aims to give D.C.

title: Number of civilian gun applications approved in Md. increases
summary: The number of approved civilian firearm applications in Maryland more than doubled from 2019 to 2020, rising from 47,093 to 95,502. Applications increased across all 24 jurisdictions, with Baltimore County approving the most in 2020.

title: Chesapeake Bay fate depends on many states
summary: The health of the Chesapeake Bay relies on cooperation among six states and the District of Columbia, but pollution challenges persist due to insufficient accountability from upstream states like New York and Pennsylvania. Recent reports show declining water quality and underwater grasses, despite some improvements in crab and oyster populations.

title: National Cherry Blossom Festival’s new art exhibit still blooming in DC area
summary: The National Cherry Blossom Festival's "Art in Bloom" exhibit, featuring 26 oversized cherry blossom sculptures painted by selected artists, continues to be displayed throughout the DC area through Memorial Day. Artists created vibrant, symbolic sculptures to bring joy and hope, with some pieces potentially staying on display permanently.

title: Maryland college students seek mental health help amid COVID-19 pandemic
summary: Maryland college students have faced increased mental health challenges during the COVID-19 pandemic, yet university counseling center usage has declined, partly due to students living off-campus. Despite rising needs, several Maryland universities have reduced counseling budgets, spending less per student compared to other institutions.

title: Md. Justice Commission plans to increase data access
summary: The Maryland Access to Justice Commission is working to improve access to the civil justice system by increasing legal assistance, encouraging pro bono work, and eliminating barriers to legal help, despite the lack of funding for recent legislation. The commission also aims to enhance public access to critical legal information and justice data to better serve Maryland residents.

title: Board of Public Works approves compensation for man wrongfully convicted
summary: Melvin Thomas, who spent 19 years in prison for a wrongful attempted murder conviction, will receive over $1.6 million in compensation from Maryland over seven years. The Board of Public Works approved the payment after the conviction was overturned due to the victim's recanted testimony and new evidence.

title: Maryland music venues struggle to stay afloat
summary: Independent music venues in Maryland, like Baltimore's Ottobar, have faced severe financial challenges due to the pandemic, with some losing up to 95% of their revenue. While state and community support has provided some relief, many venues continue to struggle to fully recover and remain operational.

title: Anti-abortion bills on the rise among state legislatures
summary: Republican state legislators are introducing over 500 anti-abortion bills this year, aiming to challenge Roe v. Wade through a conservative-majority Supreme Court.

title: Lawmakers want to expand role of hospitals in preventing violence
summary: Maryland and Illinois lawmakers are proposing a bipartisan bill to expand federal funding for hospital-based programs that help victims of violent injuries avoid becoming repeat victims or perpetrators. The legislation, inspired by a successful model in Baltimore, aims to break the cycle of violence through counseling, job training, and other support services.

title: In Washington, Chauvin guilty verdict is call to pass police reform measures
summary: The guilty verdict of former officer Derek Chauvin in the death of George Floyd has galvanized U.S. leaders to push for comprehensive police reform.

title: Food truck vendor thrives during pandemic shutdowns and challenges
summary: Chris Van Jura launched Catalyst Hot Dogs in December 2020 as a mobile food truck to earn income after being furloughed due to the pandemic. His eight-square-foot shop has thrived despite the challenges of shutdowns and economic uncertainty.

title: The return of the March Madness has buoyed chicken wing sales
summary: The absence of the 2020 NCAA Men’s Basketball tournament led to a chicken wing surplus and lower prices. The return of March Madness has now driven record chicken wing sales, helping restaurants recover.

title: Community organization helps vaccinate stray cats to avoid euthanization
