summary: Beltsville Community Cats is vaccinating stray cats to ensure they receive necessary medical care. This effort aims to prevent their euthanization and improve their chances of finding homes.

title: Filling your garden with native Maryland plants could save you time, money and the environment
summary: Using native Maryland plants in your garden can save time and money while requiring less maintenance and no special fertilizers. These plants also offer environmental benefits, making them a smart choice as spring approaches.

title: Metro PD advises civilians on how to keep safe from increased homicides and car jackings
summary: Metro PD warns of rising homicides and carjackings in the DMV area and urges residents to take precautions. The department is providing safety tips to help protect individuals and communities during the summer.

title: Student athletes and coaches reflect on how great it feels to have fans back in the stands
summary: Student athletes and coaches at the University of Maryland are celebrating the return of fans to the stands after more than a year of empty seats. They say the presence of supporters has restored a sense of normalcy and improved the overall game-day atmosphere.

title: Maryland schools continue comparatively slow reopening plan
summary: Maryland public schools have among the lowest rates of in-person instruction in the U.S., despite the state's moderate COVID-19 case levels. Experts argue that research shows schools can reopen safely without increasing community spread, but decisions have not fully reflected this evidence.

title: Chesapeake Bay, southern Maryland could see new federal park, heritage designations
summary: Maryland lawmakers are pushing for federal legislation to establish a Chesapeake National Recreation Area, aiming to protect and promote the region's natural, cultural, and historical resources. The initiative seeks to expand the concept of national recreation areas to highlight the Bay’s significance and boost tourism and conservation efforts.

title: Maryland lawmakers wrap up 2021 session with pandemic aid; reforms to police, betting
summary: Maryland lawmakers concluded the 2021 session by passing major measures including a multi-billion-dollar pandemic relief plan, police reforms, and the legalization of sports betting, all amid a limited in-person legislative process due to pandemic safety protocols. The session also saw bipartisan cooperation on a $52.4 billion budget funded in part by federal aid, as well as emergency unemployment assistance to address pandemic-related job losses.

title: House committee passes DC statehood bill
summary: The House Oversight and Reform Committee passed a bill to make Washington, D.C., the 51st state, naming it the Douglass Commonwealth and granting it full congressional representation. The bill faces a full House vote and has drawn sharp partisan debate over constitutional concerns and voting rights.

title: Biden to withdraw troops from Afghanistan starting May 1, ending by Sept. 11
summary: President Joe Biden announced the start of the U.S. troop withdrawal from Afghanistan on May 1, with a full exit planned by Sept.

title: Pandemic upends usual procedures in adoptions and foster care
summary: The pandemic disrupted traditional in-person visits between foster children and their biological families, replacing them with online meetings and restricted in-person interactions that made emotional connections difficult. In response, Congress allocated $400 million in relief funding for foster care programs, extending support for former foster youth up to age 27.

title: Biden administration takes aim at improving Black maternal health care
summary: The Biden administration is increasing federal efforts to address the Black maternal health crisis by allocating significant funding for initiatives like implicit bias training, maternal care programs, and nutrition support. Vice President Kamala Harris highlighted systemic racial inequities as key contributors to the disproportionately high maternal mortality rates among Black women.

title: A look at a family’s journey of adopting amid a pandemic
summary: Dillion Hopson Allen and his parents, Zina and Michael Brown, are working to adopt Rosa, their foster daughter with autism and epilepsy, but the process has been delayed due to the pandemic. What typically takes six to nine months now takes up to a year, with slower court proceedings and other pandemic-related challenges affecting foster care and adoptions.

title: About  Essential and Exposed
summary: The Howard Center for Investigative Journalism at the University of Maryland collaborated with journalists from multiple universities to produce investigative stories, podcasts, and digital content as part of its mission to train future journalists. Funded by the Scripps Howard Foundation, the center's work was led by faculty and students across reporting, data analysis, design, and audience engagement teams.

title: Bias training bill passes in Maryland Legislature
summary: A Maryland bill requiring healthcare professionals to undergo implicit bias training every two years has passed the legislature and awaits Governor Larry Hogan's signature. The legislation aims to address racial disparities in healthcare, particularly highlighted by the disproportionate impact of the pandemic on Black and brown communities.

title: Bill for gun rights Medical cannabis users gun rights bill stalls in House
summary: A Maryland bill aimed at protecting firearms rights for medical cannabis users stalled in the House of Delegates after amendments were added to align state law with federal restrictions on firearm possession by marijuana users. Despite initial Senate support and advocacy for veterans using medical marijuana, the revised bill faces opposition from some lawmakers who argue it unfairly limits patient rights.

title: Equity Task Force to help COVID-19 vaccine distribution among minorities
summary: Maryland is addressing racial disparities in its COVID-19 vaccination rollout through a Vaccine Equity Task Force, which aims to improve access for underserved communities, particularly Black and Latino residents. The initiative includes mobile clinics and partnerships with local organizations to increase vaccine distribution in hard-to-reach areas.

title: Cicadas will soon invade the state of Maryland
summary: Brood X, a 17-year-periodical cicada species, is set to emerge in Maryland and 15 other eastern U.S. states, with billions of red-eyed cicadas expected to appear as early as late April.

title: Biden takes actions aimed at curbing gun violence ‘epidemic’
summary: President Joe Biden announced several measures to combat gun violence, including nominating a gun-control advocate to lead the ATF and addressing the issue of untraceable "ghost guns." These actions come amid stalled congressional efforts and in response to recent mass shootings.

title: Balloon releases to end in Maryland under bill
summary: Maryland is set to ban intentional balloon releases under House Bill 391, which has passed both legislative chambers and is now awaiting the governor’s approval. The law aims to reduce environmental hazards and wildlife harm, as balloons often end up in waterways, are mistaken for food by marine life, and can cause injury or death.

title: COVID-19 forces new ways of administering hospice care
summary: Hospice providers in Maryland had to rapidly adapt their care delivery methods during the COVID-19 pandemic due to heightened risks and restrictions. They implemented creative solutions like window visits and expanded telehealth to continue supporting vulnerable patients while minimizing in-person contact.

title: Maryland governor would lose parole veto powers under bill
summary: A Maryland bill aims to remove the governor's veto power over parole decisions and extend the minimum time served for life-sentence inmates before parole eligibility, but differences between legislative chambers complicate its passage. While advocacy groups support the reform, some state officials argue the governor's oversight remains a necessary safeguard.

title: Biden faces pressure to address May 1 Afghanistan withdrawal deadline
summary: President Joe Biden is under pressure to decide whether to meet the May 1 deadline for withdrawing U.S. troops from Afghanistan, a timeline set by the Trump administration's 2020 Doha agreement with the Taliban.

title: Maryland bill would repeal some jury disqualifications
summary: A Maryland bill seeks to repeal jury disqualification for individuals with past felony convictions or pending charges, aiming to promote re-enfranchisement and restorative justice. Proponents argue the change is critical to addressing racial disparities in the justice system and aligns with the state's history of leading re-enfranchisement efforts.

title: Legislature votes to bolster unemployment insurance system
summary: Maryland's legislature has passed emergency measures to increase unemployment benefits for claimants and reduce the financial burden on businesses, awaiting Gov. Hogan's signature.

title: Maryland bills aim to make it easier to vote
summary: Maryland lawmakers are advancing multiple bills aimed at expanding voting access, including increasing early voting sites, ensuring accessible voting for marginalized groups, and preserving ballot drop boxes. These efforts contrast with restrictive voting laws in some Republican-led states and reflect a broader push to make voting more convenient and inclusive.

title: Maryland law would promote unusual sports
summary: A Maryland bill seeks to expand access to non-traditional sports like skateboarding, pickleball, and cricket in Prince George’s County by improving facilities and infrastructure. Lawmakers aim to provide diverse recreational opportunities for residents and support growing sports that are currently underrepresented in the area.

title: Some fans wary of return to live baseball, Povich Center-CDCE-Post poll finds
summary: A national poll conducted by the Povich Center and others found that while many sports fans are hesitant to return to live events during the pandemic, a majority feel more comfortable attending outdoor games like baseball than indoor events. Safety measures such as mask mandates, health screenings, and lower stadium capacities were seen as factors that could ease fans' concerns about returning.

title: Washington Bullpen podcast: D.C. explores how to set up marijuana sales
summary: Marijuana is legal in the District of Columbia, but no law currently exists to regulate its legal sale. Reporter Rayonna Burton-Jernigan examines the issue in the "Washington Bullpen" podcast.

title: Fans in the Stands:  Despite COVID-19 protocols, many not ready to return to live sports
summary: Despite ongoing efforts to resume live sports events, many fans remain hesitant to return to stadiums due to lingering concerns over the pandemic. Attendance has been lower than expected, reflecting a cautious public still wary of large gatherings.

title: Motorsports in Maryland set for a restart after tough 2020
summary: Motorsports in Maryland were significantly impacted by the 2020 pandemic shutdown, with events like Monster Jam and the Frank Sagi tribute race canceled and racing facilities forced to halt operations. Now, as restrictions ease, local tracks like Hagerstown Speedway are preparing to restart the racing season and welcome fans back to the stands.

title: ‘He saved my life’: The story of Nancy Heil and racehorse Karan’s Notion
summary: Nancy Heil, a 78-year-old horse breeder and trainer, achieved a milestone in 2020 when her homebred Karan’s Notion won the Maryland Million Sprint. The unexpected victory not only made history but also saved Heil's farm.

title: Why Capital News Service created its own COVID-19 vaccine dashboard
summary: Capital News Service created a Maryland Vaccine Dashboard to simplify access to information on vaccine eligibility and locations, addressing disparities in vaccination rates and consolidating data from multiple sources into one easy-to-navigate site. The tool focuses on Baltimore and the state’s most populous counties, which have significant African-American populations with lower vaccination rates.

title: Maryland launches mobile vaccination program to give shots to those in underserved communities
summary: Maryland has launched a mobile vaccination program to reach underserved communities with limited access to vaccine sites. The 32-foot units will target minority, migrant, and eastern Maryland populations who face transportation barriers.

title: The Baltimore Police Department is working to prevent department misconduct
summary: The Baltimore Police Department has launched a new initiative called “EPIC” aimed at preventing misconduct and reducing errors. The program also seeks to strengthen the department's relationship with the local community.

title: Catholic Terps helps students celebrate throughout Holy Week
summary: Catholic Terps is organizing socially distanced in-person events for students in College Park to celebrate Holy Week this Easter. The initiative allows students to stay connected to their faith while adhering to safety guidelines.

title: Montgomery County theaters losing money under orders to halt food sales
summary: Movie theaters in Montgomery County, Maryland, continue to struggle financially as they are prohibited from selling food and beverages while mask mandates remain in effect. Despite some pandemic restrictions being lifted, the lack of concession sales is hindering their recovery.

title: Montgomery County Alcohol Beverage Service encourages responsible drinking with alcohol-to-go orders
summary: Montgomery County's Alcohol Beverage Service launched the 'Pause Program' to promote responsible drinking by encouraging customers to consume alcohol-to-go beverages at home rather than while driving. The initiative comes as restaurants and bars continue offering take-home alcoholic drinks since the start of the pandemic.

title: Voter restrictions are being proposed in 47 states, report says
summary: State legislators in 47 states have introduced 361 bills this year to restrict voting, according to a Brennan Center report, with many targeting absentee voting and voter ID requirements. In response, Democrats in Congress are pushing the For the People Act to expand voting rights, while Republicans criticize it as a partisan power grab.

title: Md. mental health facilities will have to report sexual abuse
summary: A new Maryland bill requires mental health facilities to report sexual abuse and harassment complaints to state agencies within 24 hours. Advocates say this is needed because people with developmental disabilities are especially vulnerable and underreported.

title: Maryland expands vaccine rollout as variants increase
summary: Maryland is accelerating its vaccine rollout by opening pre-registration for everyone 16 and older as concerns grow over rapidly spreading coronavirus variants. The state has identified 677 variant cases, mostly from the UK, and has administered over 2.7 million vaccines to date.

title: Democrats in Congress pressure Biden to address student loan debt crisis
summary: Democrats in Congress have introduced bills urging President Biden to forgive student loan debt, arguing it would reduce racial and gender wealth gaps and boost the economy. Biden has ruled out supporting the proposed levels of debt cancellation but is reviewing his legal options for forgiving some student debt.

title: Democrats in Congress search for a compromise on minimum wage
summary: Democrats in Congress are seeking a compromise on raising the federal minimum wage after failed attempts to include a $15 per hour proposal in recent legislation. With reconciliation as a potential strategy, lawmakers continue to push for an increase from the current $7.25 rate set in 2009.

title: More individuals in Maryland are now eligible for the COVID vaccine as phase 2B begins
summary: More individuals in Maryland are becoming eligible for the COVID vaccine as Phase 2B begins, though the state's full adult eligibility phase is delayed until April 27. Meanwhile, Maryland recorded its highest positivity rate since February 9, at 5.24%.

title: Three time cancer survivor creates business and provides hope for patients
summary: Sonia Su, a three-time cancer survivor, founded Kits to Heart to hand deliver care kits to patients. Her business aims to bring comfort and hope to those facing cancer during difficult times.

title: New facility in Baltimore aims to help urban communities grieve family loss
summary: Roberta’s House is a new 22,000-square-foot facility in Baltimore designed to support urban families in grieving the loss of a loved one. It offers unique amenities like a theater, arts space, and quiet rooms, making it the first center of its kind in the U.S.

title: The Maryland gymnastics team bounces back and secures a spot in NCAA regionals
summary: The Maryland gymnastics team overcame the challenges of the 2020 postseason cancellation due to Covid-19 and spent months rebuilding. Their efforts paid off as they secured a bid to the NCAA tournament and a spot in the regionals.

title: Cameras on school buses catch drivers who illegally pass stopped buses
summary: Prince George’s County public schools have partnered with BusPatrol to install cameras on all school buses to monitor and catch drivers who illegally pass stopped buses. The initiative began on April 8th, aiming to improve safety around school transportation.

title: Prince George’s County looks to return to normal with re-openings
summary: Prince George’s County is returning to normal as nature centers and attractions reopen. Residents are embracing the change by resuming visits to their favorite local spots.

title: Expansive COVID-19 bill advancing in Maryland Legislature
summary: Maryland's legislature is advancing a $152.5 million bill aimed at strengthening the state's two-year COVID-19 recovery plan through expanded testing, contact tracing, and vaccination efforts. The bill also promotes equitable access to testing, removes insurance coverage exemptions for certain tests, and creates job opportunities through a public health workforce initiative.

title: Hogan announces $3.9 billion in Rescue Act funding
summary: Governor Larry Hogan announced the allocation of $3.9 billion in American Rescue Plan funding to support Maryland's Unemployment Insurance, broadband infrastructure, schools, small businesses, and transportation projects. State leaders emphasized the investment's role in addressing pandemic challenges and creating a stronger economic future.

title: Lawmakers renew effort to study slavery reparations
summary: Lawmakers have reintroduced legislation to establish a commission aimed at studying the legacy of slavery and systemic racism, potentially leading to reparations for African American descendants. Sponsored by Sen.

title: Bill alters gun storage requirements for unsupervised minors
summary: Maryland legislators have introduced Jaelynn’s Law, a bill aimed at preventing unsupervised minors from accessing firearms, following a 2018 school shooting that killed 16-year-old Jaelynn Willey. The bill has stalled in committee as police reform measures dominate the legislative session, despite continued advocacy from supporters.

title: Bill to repeal spousal defense for sexual crimes moves to House of Delegates
summary: A Maryland bill to repeal the legal protection preventing prosecution of certain sexual crimes committed by a spouse has advanced to the House of Delegates after passing unanimously in the Senate. The bipartisan legislation, supported by lawmakers and experts, aims to eliminate an outdated legal exemption rooted in 18th-century common law that has been shown to enable marital sexual violence.

title: Maryland law would ban hate symbols in public schools
summary: A new Maryland bill, HB0418, aims to ban hate symbols like swastikas, Confederate flags, and nooses in public schools, effective July 1, to create a safer learning environment. The legislation, inspired by student advocacy, allows school districts to define additional prohibited symbols that could disrupt the school environment.

title: Baltimore City residents press for tax sale relief
summary: Low-income homeowners in Baltimore, including those in African-American communities and older adults, are facing the risk of losing their homes due to the city's tax sale system and financial hardships worsened by the pandemic. Many, like Raymond Thompson, struggle with lost paperwork, accumulated interest, and limited job opportunities, making it difficult to meet tax obligations despite eligibility for relief programs.

title: Bill adding mental health callback services advances in Md. amid COVID-19 pandemic
summary: Maryland is advancing a bill to create a mental health callback program through 2-1-1 Maryland, aiming to help residents struggling with mental health during the pandemic. Named the Thomas Bloom Raskin Act, the program will begin in July and is part of broader efforts to address a national mental health crisis.

title: Bill would limit use of DNA databases to solve crimes in Maryland
summary: Maryland's House has passed a first-in-the-nation bill to limit law enforcement use of consumer DNA databases for solving crimes, requiring consent and judicial approval. The legislation aims to balance public safety with privacy rights by restricting genetic genealogy investigations to specific serious crimes.

title: Bill to expand protections for LGBTQ Americans faces hurdles in the Senate
summary: The Senate is considering the Equality Act, which would expand federal protections for LGBTQ Americans against discrimination in employment, housing, and public services, but faces significant challenges due to partisan divisions. The bill, which has passed the House twice, aims to amend the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to include protections based on sexual orientation and gender identity, with President Biden pledging to sign it if it reaches his desk.

title: Del. Jheanelle K. Wilkins (MD) proposes an emergency bill to get doulas back in the delivery room
summary: Del. Jheanelle K.

title: Group pushing to reopen Montgomery County Public Schools asks Governor Larry Hogan to intervene
summary: TogetherAgainMCPS is urging Governor Larry Hogan to assist in reopening Montgomery County Public Schools following updated CDC guidelines that allow for three feet of distancing in elementary schools. The group aims to safely and quickly return students to in-person learning.

title: The death of Sarah Everard spurs movement to stop violence against women
summary: The murder of Sarah Everard has sparked widespread outrage and discussions about violence against women, especially among young women. Social media is highlighting a U.N.

title: Montgomery County high schools Red Cross Clubs host virtual blood drive
summary: Students at four Montgomery County high schools are hosting a virtual blood drive through the American Red Cross 'Sleeves Up' platform. The effort aims to address the critical need for blood and platelet donors amid the pandemic and other emergencies.

title: Increasing salt runoff is impacting Montgomery County residents’ water supply
summary: Excess road salt use in Montgomery County is contaminating the local water supply. The Department of Environmental Protection is taking action through regulation and public forums to address the issue.

title: University of Maryland students hold candlelight vigil to call attention to anti-Asian hate crimes
summary: University of Maryland students held a candlelight vigil in response to the Atlanta shootings to raise awareness about anti-Asian hate crimes. UMD President Darryll Pines attended, and organizers urged him to take greater action to support AAPI students.

title: The Department of Homeland Security makes $20 million available to fight domestic terrorism
summary: The Biden administration has allocated $20 million to address domestic terrorism, particularly white supremacist violence and online radicalization. The funding comes in response to the January 6 Capitol insurrection and aims to prevent future acts of domestic extremism.

title: A Georgetown student group helps moms in Guatemala earn a living
summary: A Georgetown student group, Project Olas, started a Spanish learning program a year ago to help Guatemalan moms earn extra income. In return, students improve their Spanish skills through weekly one-hour conversations with their assigned "olas mom."

title: Judges and experts say judiciary needs greater racial and gender diversity
summary: Judges and legal experts testified before Congress that the U.S. judiciary lacks sufficient racial and gender diversity, which undermines fairness and public trust.

title: Van Hollen, other lawmakers want to block permanent U.S. Capitol fencing
summary: Lawmakers including Sen. Chris Van Hollen and Sen.

title: Md. bill would publicize monetary settlement with police
summary: A new Maryland bill, HB1248, sponsored by Del. Alonzo T.

title: Pandemic forces struggling hotels to convert to apartments
summary: The Georgetown Suites Hotel in Washington, D.C., is being converted into luxury apartments due to pandemic-driven declines in hotel demand. Across the U.S., struggling hotel owners are repurposing properties for residential use to adapt to a weakened hospitality market and capitalize on strong rental demand.

title: DACA advocates urge U.S. Senate to vote for path of citizenship
summary: DACA advocates are urging the U.S. Senate to support a pathway to citizenship for recipients like them.

title: New vaccination site opens in Hyattsville as Prince George’s County vaccination rates reach state low
summary: Prince George’s County has opened a new Covid-19 vaccination site in Hyattsville to boost immunization efforts. With just under 7.5% of residents fully vaccinated, the county remains the least vaccinated in Maryland.

title: Maryland begins new Covid vaccine phase, residents 60 and over now eligible
summary: Maryland has begun a new phase of its Covid vaccine distribution, making residents 60 and older eligible for vaccination. Additionally, individuals with disabilities are now included in phase 2B, with six more mass vaccination sites set to open by the end of April.

title: Maryland Delegates argue passionately over ‘Juneteenth’ bill
summary: Maryland delegates passionately debated HB448, a bill to make Juneteenth a paid state holiday, with supporters emphasizing its historical significance and opponents raising concerns about costs. If passed, the bill would recognize June 19 as Juneteenth National Freedom Day, commemorating the day in 1865 when Union soldiers announced the end of slavery in Texas.

title: Feed Anne Arundel: Helping Tyler Heights
summary: Feed Anne Arundel is a nonprofit initiative that supports restaurants and families in need in Anne Arundel County by providing food and essential resources. Tyler Heights Elementary School in Annapolis is a key recipient, hosting a bi-weekly food pantry and resource fair for the community.

title: Maryland’s COVID-fighting complex
summary: Novavax, a Maryland-based biotech firm, is nearing completion of its highly effective COVID-19 vaccine, bringing attention to the state's expanding biohealth industry. With over 40 companies involved in the pandemic response, Maryland has become a hub for collaboration and innovation in coronavirus-related research and production.

title: House clears two gun safety bills, but Senate may be roadblock
summary: The House passed two gun safety bills, including universal background checks and a longer waiting period to close the "Charleston loophole," but both face potential hurdles in the Senate. The legislation aims to prevent gun violence by expanding checks on private sales and increasing the time required to complete firearm purchases.

title: Legislators aim for better voter accessibility in Maryland
summary: Maryland lawmakers are pushing for legislation to improve voting accessibility for disabled voters by requiring a uniformly accessible voting device for all. The bill aims to address concerns that the current system compromises voting privacy and equality by using different methods for disabled and non-disabled voters.

title: Bill would replace Columbus Day with Indigenous Peoples’ Day
summary: A proposed bill in Maryland would replace Columbus Day with Indigenous Peoples’ Day, aiming to honor Native American contributions and shift historical recognition. Supporters argue it corrects historical erasure, while opponents claim it disregards Italian American heritage and achievements.

title: Senate gets landmark voting legislation, but partisanship poses steep challenges
summary: The For the People Act, a major voting and campaign finance reform bill passed by the House, faces uncertain prospects in the Senate due to deep partisan divisions. The legislation aims to expand voting access, increase election security, and reduce the influence of special-interest money in politics.

title: Bill to repeal Maryland state song advancing in Legislature
summary: A bill to repeal Maryland’s state song “Maryland, My Maryland!” is moving through the Legislature due to its offensive and outdated language, with supporters arguing it aligns with broader efforts to remove Confederate-era symbols. Opponents, however, warn it erases an important part of the state’s history and sets a troubling precedent.

title: Md. bill reimbursing business property taxes would be costly
summary: A Maryland lawmaker is pushing for a bill to reimburse personal property taxes for businesses affected by the pandemic, which could cost the state up to $365 million from the rainy day fund. However, the proposal faces criticism from state officials and other legislators who argue it is too costly, complex, and lacks clear eligibility criteria.

title: Maryland bill would curb police use of military surplus equipment
summary: A Maryland bill passed by the state Senate would restrict law enforcement agencies from acquiring military-style equipment such as weaponized drones, grenade launchers, and destructive devices through federal surplus programs. The legislation, part of the broader Maryland Police Accountability Act of 2021, aims to prevent local police from using gear typically reserved for military operations.

title: Hogan eases COVID-19 capacity restrictions
summary: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan announced the removal of indoor and outdoor capacity restrictions for dining, retail, and recreational activities, citing improved pandemic metrics and increased vaccination rates. While social distancing and mask mandates remain in place, local governments will decide whether to adopt the updated guidelines.

title: Maryland bill would ban firearms at election sites
summary: A Maryland bill aiming to ban firearms within 100 feet of polling sites is moving through the state Legislature, with proponents arguing it is essential to prevent voter intimidation. The legislation, which would take effect in October 2021, includes exemptions for law enforcement and imposes civil penalties for violations.

title: Bill would lessen punishment for some teen sexting
summary: A Maryland bill passed in the House that reduces penalties for some juvenile sexting cases, ensuring teens are not automatically treated as sex offenders unless under extraordinary circumstances. The legislation clarifies sexting is not child pornography in certain cases, such as consensual exchanges between peers with no coercion or significant age difference.

title: Democrats want total ban on members carrying guns in the U.S. Capitol
summary: Democrats are pushing to ban members of Congress from carrying guns in the U.S. Capitol, citing security risks and the need to close a loophole in current regulations.

title: Biden administration attempts to revive Iran nuclear talks, but tensions persist
summary: The Biden administration is seeking to revive nuclear negotiations with Iran by easing some sanctions and engaging in EU-brokered talks, but progress is hindered by unresolved issues including human rights concerns, unresolved hostage situations, and Iranian nuclear advancements. Iran has signaled a tentative openness to talks but remains reluctant due to ongoing U.S.

title: A bill set to legalize marijuana in Maryland aims to give back to the community
summary: A bill introduced by Delegate Jazz Lewis aims to legalize and regulate recreational marijuana in Maryland. Sixty-three percent of the tax revenue from the law would be directed to HBCUs and communities impacted by poverty and racism.

title: Baltimore Mayor Brandon Scott announces partnership to create a database to track guns in the city
summary: Baltimore Mayor Brandon Scott has announced a partnership with Everytown for Gun Safety to create a database aimed at tracking guns in the city. The initiative is intended to reduce gun violence by helping law enforcement remove firearms from the streets and make more arrests.

title: Morgan State University alumnus donates $20 million
summary: Morgan State University received a $20 million donation from an alumnus, marking the largest gift from a graduate in the university's history. The donation will fund scholarships for students with financial need.

title: Student Organization fights to provide free feminine hygiene products on campus
summary: Get Ovary It, a student organization at the University of Maryland, aims to provide free feminine hygiene products in campus bathrooms. After losing university funding, the Student Government Association took over to support the initiative.

title: Governor Hogan announces three new mass vaccination sites in Maryland
summary: Governor Hogan announced three new mass vaccination sites in Maryland, located at Blue Crabs Stadium, Wicomico Youth & Civic Center, and Hagerstown Premium Outlets. The move aims to increase vaccination efforts as the state reaches a daily record of 35,730 shots administered.

title: The University of Maryland’s School of Theatre, Dance and Performance Studies receives a $9 million gift
summary: The University of Maryland’s School of Theatre, Dance and Performance Studies received a $9 million donation from the Brin Family. The gift aims to provide students with improved technology to support their performing arts education, especially following the shift to online learning during the pandemic.

title: Maryland Athletics launches Momentum
summary: The University of Maryland has partnered with Opendorse to launch a program that helps student-athletes build their personal brands. The initiative, called Momentum, comes as more professional athletes use their platforms to advocate for personal causes.

title: Maryland lawmakers are close to adding HBCU funding
summary: Maryland lawmakers are close to passing a bill that would allocate nearly $600 million to the state's four historically Black colleges and universities (HBCUs) to address long-standing funding disparities. The move follows a 2006 court ruling in favor of the HBCUs, but a settlement has remained unresolved for over a decade.

title: Maryland bill would refine environmental justice commission
summary: A Maryland bill aims to reform the Commission on Environmental Justice and Sustainable Communities to better serve vulnerable and marginalized communities disproportionately affected by environmental hazards. The proposed changes include increasing diversity among members, requiring regular meetings, and providing tailored orientation for new members from heavily impacted areas.

title: Legislation for control of the Baltimore Police moves to the House
summary: A comprehensive police reform package, including a bill to transfer control of the Baltimore Police Department to the city, has passed the Maryland Senate with bipartisan support and now moves to the House of Delegates. The package includes measures for increased accountability, such as body camera mandates, restrictions on military equipment, and independent investigations in fatal police incidents, though some Republican opposition cited concerns over the scope of the reforms.

title: Bill to rebuild trust between immigrants and law enforcement
summary: A Maryland bill aims to prohibit law enforcement from inquiring about immigration status and end cooperation with ICE to build trust between police and immigrant communities. Opponents, including some local law enforcement, argue the bill could compromise public safety by limiting information sharing.

title: Consumer groups ask for more targeted poultry inspections to curb contamination
summary: Four consumer advocacy groups are calling for stricter and more targeted USDA poultry inspections to reduce salmonella and campylobacter contamination, which remain leading causes of foodborne illness. They argue current measures are ineffective and propose harsher penalties, greater accountability for poultry companies, and improved enforcement to better protect public health.

title: Biden and congressional Democrats try 180-degree turn on immigration
summary: The Biden administration is implementing executive actions and proposing new legislation to reverse Trump-era immigration policies, aiming to create a more humane and orderly system, including an eight-year path to citizenship for undocumented immigrants. While congressional Democrats largely support the plan, internal party disagreements and Republican opposition could delay its passage.

title: College athletes could be paid for endorsements under Maryland bill
summary: A Maryland bill aims to let college athletes profit from their name, image, and likeness while enhancing their protections, as part of a national movement to address their economic and well-being concerns. Named after Maryland football player Jordan McNair, the legislation seeks to end what advocates call the exploitation of student athletes and align with similar laws passed in other states.

title: Sports betting debate heats up in Annapolis
summary: Maryland legislators are working to regulate the state's newly legalized sports betting market, with a focus on equitable license distribution and generating funds for education. The bill proposes three licensing tiers and aims to ensure Maryland keeps pace with neighboring states that have already launched similar programs.

title: Montgomery County athletics back in person after almost 12 months online
summary: Montgomery County Public Schools resumed in-person athletic practices for fall sports on March 1, marking the first time in nearly 12 months that students have engaged in physical training. The return includes conditioning and skill-based activities as part of the gradual restart of school athletics.

title: Maryland Department of Education approves standardized testing to start in the spring
summary: The Maryland State Department of Education has approved standardized testing to begin in the spring, focusing on mathematics and English language arts. The shortened test will be required for both in-person and virtual students.

title: Baltimore organizations work to get COVID relief money to underserved residents
summary: Baltimore Mayor Brandon Scott has relaunched a $6 million emergency COVID relief program, set to begin on March 1. The initiative will provide $400 debit cards to up to 15,000 households, prioritizing underserved and marginalized communities.

title: Fraudulent unemployment claims present concerns in Maryland
summary: Maryland has seen a significant rise in fraudulent unemployment claims, with 65% of claims filed since January 2021 flagged for fraud, of which 87% were confirmed as fraudulent. The surge in claims overwhelmed the state’s underprepared labor department, and officials, including Lt.

title: Maryland General Assembly targets suicide prevention
summary: Maryland lawmakers are addressing rising suicide rates with legislation to remove financial barriers to mental health treatment and provide law enforcement with specialized training. The proposed measures come amid concerns over increased suicides, particularly among veterans, and potential unintended impacts on health insurance plans.

title: Bill would grant Maryland high school seniors added year of eligibility
summary: A proposed Maryland bill would allow high school seniors who graduated in 2021 to play sports during the 2021-2022 school year, providing them another season due to pandemic-related disruptions. The legislation seeks to waive eligibility requirements such as academic progress and age restrictions for these athletes.

title: Vaccine Hunters take control of appointment search
summary: A Facebook group called Maryland Vaccine Hunters has grown to nearly 55,000 members by helping residents book hard-to-find COVID-19 vaccine appointments. Created to reduce wasted doses, the group now serves as an information hub and matchmaking service for eligible individuals and those who can assist in securing appointments.

title: Lawmakers launch new effort at tightening background checks on gun sales
summary: Lawmakers in the Senate and House have introduced bipartisan legislation to expand background checks for all gun purchases, aiming to close the "gun show loophole" and prevent firearms from falling into the hands of ineligible buyers. The bills, supported by a majority of Americans according to public polling, face opposition from the National Rifle Association but could be voted on soon in the House.

title: Biden’s COVID relief plan includes $130 billion to help schools reopen
summary: President Joe Biden’s $1.9 trillion American Rescue Plan includes $130 billion to help schools reopen safely with measures like testing, ventilation, and personal protective equipment. While Democrats aim to pass the bill using reconciliation, Republicans criticize it as poorly targeted and overly costly.

title: D.C. statehood backers mobilize behind legislation that faces tough odds
summary: Advocates for District of Columbia statehood have gained record support in Congress, with a House bill passing and Senate efforts led by Sen. Tom Carper facing significant Republican opposition.

title: A Maryland House bill is working to help patients with medical debt
summary: A Maryland House bill is being proposed to prevent patients from losing income or housing due to unpaid medical bills, many of which are under $1,000. Between 2009 and 2018, Maryland hospitals sued patients over 145,000 times for such debts.

title: Maryland bill would combat menstrual inequities
summary: A Maryland bill, HB757, aims to combat menstrual inequities by requiring health departments and social service agencies to provide free menstrual products to low-income households and women in Medicaid. The legislation, supported by youth activist Saara Khan and Del.

title: Pandemic could change the oyster industry for good
summary: The pandemic has significantly impacted Maryland's oyster industry, leading to a 25% drop in sales and forcing farmers to shift from restaurant sales to direct public sales. To adapt, organizations like the Oyster Recovery Partnership are helping farmers connect with consumers and teaching people how to prepare oysters at home.

title: Hogan touts new vaccine during stadium site visit
summary: Governor Larry Hogan highlighted Maryland's new M&T Bank Stadium vaccination site and expressed optimism about the potential FDA authorization of Johnson & Johnson’s single-dose vaccine, which could significantly increase vaccination capacity. The site aims to administer up to 10,000 doses daily and has already seen high demand with thousands of appointments booked.

title: Many Maryland schools set to reopen Monday
summary: Many Maryland school districts are reopening for in-person instruction starting Monday, following Governor Larry Hogan’s push to resume classes by March 1, with varying schedules and safety measures in place. While some teachers have protested or criticized the reopening plans, early data suggests in-person learning has not significantly increased coronavirus spread.

title: Maryland bill would charge companies for carbon pollution
summary: Maryland lawmakers propose a bill to charge fees on fossil fuels and high-emission vehicles to reduce carbon emissions and fund schools with the first $350 million annually. The legislation aims for a 60% reduction in emissions by 2030 and net zero by 2045, facing opposition over potential cost increases for consumers.

title: Legislators hope to sweeten lemonade stand restrictions
summary: Maryland legislators are pushing a bill to prevent local governments from restricting or regulating children's lemonade stands on private property, arguing such common activities should not require excessive permits. Proponents say the current system imposes unnecessary bureaucracy on harmless, small-scale ventures like selling nonalcoholic drinks.

title: New bill would change police procedure during traffic stops
summary: A new Maryland bill, the Know Your Rights Act, would require police to explicitly state individuals' rights during traffic stops, display identification, and inform passengers of their right to refuse to identify themselves. While supporters argue it promotes transparency and prevents coercion, opponents like Howard County State’s Attorney Richard Gibson claim it could hinder law enforcement and pose safety risks.

title: Biden taps three for Postal Service board; signals possible move on DeJoy
summary: President Joe Biden has nominated three individuals to fill vacancies on the U.S. Postal Service Board of Governors, a move that could influence the future of Postmaster General Louis DeJoy.

title: Marijuana legalization proposed in Maryland Legislature
summary: Maryland legislators are considering a bill to legalize recreational cannabis use for adults 21 and older, aiming to promote social equity, create jobs, and generate significant tax revenue. The proposal would also allow for expungement of past cannabis convictions and establish a regulated market, though initial costs for implementation and oversight are expected to be high.

title: Bills seek to limit implicit bias in Maryland judicial system
summary: Maryland legislators introduced two bills requiring implicit bias training for judges, police officers, public defenders, and state attorneys to address potential biases that could affect their decisions. The proposed legislation aims to reduce systemic disparities, particularly in sentencing, by helping judicial system members recognize and counteract unconscious biases.

title: Pushed too far: Overexertion has claimed lives of 22 Division I football players since 2000
summary: Overexertion during training has led to the deaths of 22 Division I football players since 2000. The tragic incidents have sparked concerns about the safety and intensity of athletic conditioning programs.

title: What’s next for the struggling U.S. Postal Service?
summary: The U.S. Postal Service continues to face severe delays, budget problems, and public criticism, with Postmaster General Louis DeJoy defending his leadership amid calls for his removal.

title: Opioid-related deaths increase amid COVID-19 pandemic
summary: Opioid-related deaths in Maryland increased by 12.1% between January and September 2020 compared to the same period in 2019, with minority communities experiencing some of the highest rises. In response, the state launched the Maryland COVID-19 Inter-Agency Overdose Action Plan to expand access to treatment, telehealth, and naloxone.

title: Franchot expects Marylanders to see relief as early as Friday
summary: Maryland Comptroller Peter Franchot anticipates that 98% of relief payments under the RELIEF Act will be processed by Friday, with electronic and paper payments beginning Tuesday. The bipartisan legislation provides over $1 billion in tax relief and stimulus to more than 422,000 eligible residents, including stimulus checks, unemployment tax relief, and aid for small businesses.

title: Pandemic-inspired Maryland bill would redirect student funds toward school of choice
summary: A Maryland Republican lawmaker has introduced a bill that would allow parents to reallocate public school funds toward an alternative school if their district fails to offer in-person instruction by fall. The proposal, inspired by concerns over the impact of virtual learning, mirrors similar pandemic-driven school choice legislation seen in other states.

title: Maryland taxes may be offset by diaper, feminine hygiene donation
summary: A new Maryland bill allows up to a $1,000 state income tax deduction for donations of diapers or feminine hygiene products to qualified charities, aiming to address increased demand due to the pandemic. The initiative, supported by lawmakers and advocates, seeks to raise awareness and support for families and women facing hygiene inequity.

title: Bill allows for more local restrictions on tobacco products in Maryland
summary: Maryland legislators have introduced a bill allowing local jurisdictions to impose stricter restrictions on the sale and distribution of tobacco products, including setting higher age limits and limiting certain products like flavored vapes. However, the bill does not affect licensing or taxation, which will remain under state oversight.

title: Senate acquits Trump of inciting Capitol attack, though bipartisan majority finds him guilty
summary: A bipartisan Senate majority found former President Donald Trump guilty of inciting the Jan. 6 Capitol attack, but fell short of the two-thirds vote needed for conviction, leading to his acquittal.

title: Trump’s defense opens and closes; Senate may vote on conviction Saturday
summary: Trump's defense team argued his speech was protected by the First Amendment and accused the impeachment process of being politically motivated, citing similar rhetoric used by Democratic leaders. They presented a video highlighting examples of political and celebrity figures using comparable language, warning that a conviction could threaten free political speech.

title: Maryland bill would provide voting info to the incarcerated
summary: A new Maryland bill, the Value My Vote Act, would require state agencies to provide incarcerated individuals with voter registration applications and information about restored voting rights upon release. Advocacy groups are pushing for the legislation, arguing that more needs to be done to inform formerly incarcerated people of their voting rights.

title: Taskforce will study college students’ mental healthcare access
summary: A Maryland bill proposes a task force to study barriers college students face in accessing mental healthcare, as pandemic-related stress and isolation have worsened mental health issues among this population. Experts note that late adolescence is a vulnerable time for mental illness, and the pandemic has intensified academic and emotional challenges for students.

title: Juvenile reform bill to prohibit life without parole
summary: Maryland is considering the Juvenile Restoration Act, which would prohibit life without parole for minors and allow sentence reductions for those who have served at least 20 years for crimes committed as teenagers. Advocates argue the bill is essential to address racial disparities in the state’s prison system, where the majority of affected inmates are Black.

title: Kirwan education veto expected to be overturned this week
summary: Maryland's legislature is expected to override Gov. Larry Hogan’s veto of the Blueprint for Maryland’s Future education bill, which includes a 10-year plan to boost teacher pay and school resources with $15 billion in funding.

title: Senators warned a Trump acquittal would embolden future challenges to democracy
summary: House impeachment managers argued that acquitting Donald Trump would embolden him or future leaders to challenge democracy through violent means, citing his pattern of incendiary rhetoric and lack of remorse. They emphasized that his January 6 speech directly incited the Capitol attack, with evidence showing supporters believed they were following his orders.

title: Bill establishes Maryland police use of force requirements
summary: Maryland legislators introduced a bill to revise police use of force requirements, aiming to increase accountability and limit lethal force to situations involving imminent threats of death or serious injury. The legislation responds to national calls for police reform following high-profile incidents of police violence.

title: Taxes on digital ads, cigarettes among Maryland House veto overrides
summary: The Maryland House of Delegates overrode Governor Larry Hogan’s veto of a bill imposing a digital advertising tax and raising tobacco taxes, aiming to fund education reform and pandemic-related expenses. Critics argued the measures would burden small businesses and fail to curb smoking, while supporters emphasized public health and long-term investment.

title: Senators hear evidence tying Trump to Capitol attack and mob hunt for Pence, Pelosi
summary: New evidence presented during former President Donald Trump's impeachment trial shows rioters on January 6 came dangerously close to Vice President Mike Pence and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi, with some chanting for Pence's execution. House managers argue Trump's rhetoric directly incited the mob, including references to Pence that were repeated by rioters through bullhorns and used to justify their violent actions.

title: ICE detention centers could leave Maryland for good
summary: Maryland lawmakers are debating the Dignity Not Detention Act, which aims to prevent the state from renewing contracts with ICE and private prison companies and to stop the construction of new detention centers. Opponents argue the bill undermines public safety efforts, while supporters highlight concerns over unsafe and inhumane conditions in current facilities.

title: Maryland bill would require therapy dogs to be allowed in public schools
summary: A proposed Maryland bill would require public schools to allow certified therapy dogs to provide emotional and academic support to students, with implementation details left to local school boards. Supporters highlight the positive impact of therapy dogs in reducing student anxiety and improving learning outcomes, particularly among young readers.

title: On bipartisan vote, Senate declares Trump trial constitutional; arguments start Wednesday
summary: The U.S. Senate voted 56-44 to allow the impeachment trial of former President Donald Trump for inciting the Jan.

title: Some struggle with new bill testimony system in Maryland
summary: The shift to an online system for submitting testimony in Maryland's General Assembly has made it harder for some individuals, particularly those with disabilities or limited daytime availability, to participate in bill hearings. Additionally, strict sign-up timeframes and limits on oral testimony have raised concerns about restricted public input, especially for contentious issues.

title: Maryland Senate overrides vetoes on gun restrictions, funding
summary: The Maryland Senate overrode four vetoes from Gov. Larry Hogan, including measures on firearm transactions and juvenile record privacy.

title: Maryland may ban plastic carryout bags at retail shops
summary: Maryland may ban plastic carryout bags at retail shops to reduce pollution and promote reusable alternatives, with advocates highlighting the environmental and long-term benefits. Current plastic bag fees in some counties have already significantly reduced single-use plastic consumption.

title: Settlement in Idaho case strengthens homeless protections
summary: A court settlement in Idaho has strengthened legal protections for homeless individuals by limiting how they can be cited for sleeping in public. The agreement aims to address unfair enforcement of anti-homeless laws.

title: Maryland delegates consider rolling back protections for law enforcement
summary: Maryland delegates are considering a bill to repeal the Law Enforcement Officers Bill of Rights, a law that provides significant protections for officers under investigation. The proposed repeal aims to increase civilian oversight and address calls for police reform following years of criticism over the law's impact on accountability.

title: Bill could make Maryland police discipline records public
summary: Maryland legislators have introduced a bill, HB0120 or Anton’s Law, aimed at making police disciplinary records public to increase transparency and accountability in police misconduct investigations. Named after Anton Black, who died in police custody in 2018, the bill is part of broader police reform efforts supported by advocacy groups like the ACLU of Maryland.

title: Maryland lawmakers push for minimum wage for inmates
summary: Maryland lawmakers are pushing to raise the stipend for inmate work to near minimum wage, arguing that the current pay—sometimes as low as $0.17 per hour—resembles exploitative labor practices. Supporters claim higher wages would reduce reliance on family support or illegal activities within prisons and better prepare inmates for reentry into society.

title: Hogan’s RELIEF Act advancing in Maryland General Assembly
summary: Governor Larry Hogan's $1 billion RELIEF Act of 2021 advanced in the Maryland Senate and is now under review in the House Ways and Means Committee, with supporters highlighting its focus on pandemic economic relief for residents and struggling industries. The bill includes tax breaks, funding for hard-hit sectors like tourism and restaurants, and adjustments to unemployment insurance calculations to provide financial relief to businesses.

title: Proposed Maryland legislation would expand hate crime law
summary: Proposed Maryland legislation would expand hate crime laws by allowing judges to mandate anti-bias education programs for offenders and adding gender expression to the list of protected categories. The bills, sponsored by state senators and delegates, aim to reduce recidivism and have drawn support from advocates who highlight the success of similar programs.

title: State lawmakers seek to lock in transit repair funding
summary: Maryland lawmakers are advancing a bill to provide guaranteed annual funding for the state's transit system to improve safety and reliability, as the state led the nation in transit breakdowns in 2019. While advocates support the effort to modernize aging infrastructure and reduce emissions, the state transportation department opposes it, arguing it limits flexibility in response to financial or operational crises.

title: Maryland bill would grant mental health days off for students
summary: A proposed Maryland bill would allow students one excused absence per quarter for mental health reasons without requiring a doctor’s note, aiming to address rising anxiety, depression, and stress among students. Sponsored by Del.

title: State lawmakers look to plug in disconnected Marylanders
summary: Maryland lawmakers are pushing to address broadband internet inequities, proposing legislation to treat high-speed internet as a utility and establish a statewide office to monitor access and combat digital redlining. Despite efforts, challenges remain, as two-thirds of residents without broadband live in urban areas, and provider costs and infrastructure gaps continue to hinder access.

title: Bill adds canine support for veterans in treatment courts
summary: Maryland legislators are introducing a bill to allow therapy and facility dogs to support veterans in Veterans Treatment Courts, helping reduce stress and anxiety during legal proceedings. The initiative aims to expand rehabilitation pathways for veterans by providing emotional assistance through trained canines in participating counties.

title: Police, lawmaker differ over potential Maryland school officer restrictions
summary: A proposed Maryland bill would restrict school resource officers to entering schools only during emergencies or for routine needs, aiming to make minority students feel safer, though police groups argue it could compromise school safety. The bill also requires officers to wear civilian clothing and conceal firearms unless necessary, facing opposition from law enforcement organizations.

title: Maryland Senate adds $520 million to Hogan’s pandemic relief bill
summary: Maryland Senate leaders introduced a $520 million amendment to Gov. Hogan’s $700 million pandemic relief bill, focusing on targeted support for small businesses, nonprofits, and underserved communities.

title: Board of Public Works approves settlement for McNair family
summary: The Board of Public Works approved a $3.5 million settlement for the family of Jordan McNair, a University of Maryland football player who died of heatstroke in 2018 due to failures by university medical staff. The settlement concludes a two-year process, and the McNair family has established a foundation focused on preventing heat-related illnesses, with the university implementing reforms to improve athlete safety.

title: Maryland to open state-run COVID-19 vaccination centers
summary: Maryland is opening six state-run mass vaccination sites and expanding eligibility to include residents 65 and older and essential workers, despite ongoing challenges with vaccine distribution and access. Concerns remain about limited vaccine availability, as new groups are added, making it harder for earlier priority groups like teachers to secure doses.

title: Hogan establishes redistricting reform commission
summary: Governor Larry Hogan has established the Maryland Citizens Redistricting Commission to address gerrymandering by creating a nine-member panel with balanced party representation to redraw legislative maps. The commission, led by three co-chairs from different political backgrounds, will develop maps based on population and geography, aiming to provide a more impartial redistricting process.

title: Maryland mourns late Senate President Emeritus Mike Miller
summary: Maryland honored the late Senate President Emeritus Mike Miller with a multi-day memorial, including a public visitation at the State House and a ceremony attended by prominent political figures who paid tribute to his legacy. Leaders remembered Miller for his decades of service, political influence, and personal impact, noting that his passing leaves a void in Maryland politics and the lives of those who knew him.

title: Recovery, health funding highlight fiscal year 2022 budget
summary: Governor Larry Hogan's fiscal year 2022 budget proposal emphasizes economic recovery and increased healthcare funding to combat the ongoing effects of the pandemic, with a $1 billion reduction in planned spending to $49 billion. The budget includes $700 million for economic relief and aims to reduce the tax burden on residents while expanding healthcare support.

title: Maryland legislation would help school children with seizures
summary: Maryland lawmakers are pushing "Brynleigh’s Act," a bill that would require schools to train staff in seizure response and ensure medical readiness for students with epilepsy or seizure disorders. The legislation aims to provide consistent protections and remove civil liability for responders through a Good Samaritan clause.

title: Gambling risks for youth may be taught in Md. high schools
summary: Maryland may require high schools to teach a curriculum on the dangers of gambling, as proposed in Senate Bill 243, aiming to educate students before they develop gambling addictions. The bill, supported by gambling addiction treatment funding, seeks to address rising risks among young people, particularly those in lower socioeconomic groups who start gambling early.

title: Protecting the mental health of Maryland police officers
summary: Maryland legislators are advancing a bill to provide confidential mental health support for police officers, including counseling and peer support, to address stressors such as protests and personal crises. The initiative aims to expand access to employee assistance programs across all law enforcement agencies in the state, ensuring confidentiality and support regardless of department size.

title: Governor Hogan calls Maryland spending proposal an ‘economic recovery budget’
summary: Governor Larry Hogan unveiled a balanced "economic recovery budget" for Maryland that avoids tax increases, layoffs, or service cuts, featuring a $1 billion stimulus package to aid residents and small businesses affected by the pandemic. The budget includes significant funding boosts for education, health services, and unemployment tax relief, supported by frozen non-COVID spending and emergency fiscal measures.

title: Joe Biden takes oath as 46th president, declares ‘democracy has prevailed’
summary: Joe Biden was sworn in as the 46th U.S. president, vowing to unite a divided nation amid ongoing challenges like the pandemic, racial tensions, and political polarization.

title: Wall Street investors pricing Americans out of last bastion of affordable housing
summary: Wall Street investors are driving up housing costs by buying up homes in the last affordable markets, pushing middle-class Americans out. This trend threatens to eliminate the last opportunities for Americans to purchase homes at reasonable prices.

title: Legislative efforts to protect trailer park residents from eviction show mixed results
summary: Legislative efforts to protect trailer park residents from sudden evictions have had mixed success, with some states passing strong protections while others have seen limited progress. Advocates continue to push for stronger, more consistent laws to ensure stable housing for vulnerable residents.

title: Trump impeached for inciting Capitol assault, faces uncertain Senate verdict
summary: President Donald Trump was impeached for a second time by the House of Representatives, accused of inciting the Capitol assault by urging supporters to “show strength” after falsely claiming the election was stolen. The Senate trial is expected to begin after Trump leaves office, with Majority Leader Mitch McConnell stating it would not conclude before President-elect Joe Biden is sworn in.

title: COVID on Campus: Student experiences in quarantine
summary: In 2020, the spread of COVID-19 dramatically altered college life in the U.S., reshaping both education and social interactions. Students across the country shared their quarantine experiences during the Fall 2020 term through a video featuring their stories.

title: COVID pandemic leaves fishing industry casting for customers
summary: The COVID-19 pandemic has hurt Maryland’s seafood industry as consumers avoid cooking seafood at home due to difficulty, odor concerns, and fear of foodborne illness. With restaurants closed or operating at reduced capacity, demand for seafood has dropped sharply, though pre-cooked items like crabs have seen some resilience.

title: Maryland immigrants await Biden moves on immigration policy promises
summary: DACA recipient Yoslin Amaya Hernandez and other undocumented immigrants in Maryland await concrete action from President-elect Joe Biden on his campaign promises to reverse Trump-era immigration policies. Despite DACA allowing her to study and work, she remains anxious about potential deportation and uncertain about the new administration's ability to provide lasting legal security.

title: Public housing, the last refuge for the poor, threatens to kick out tenants for small debts
summary: Public housing, often the last refuge for the poor, is increasingly threatening to evict tenants over minor debts. This trend raises concerns about the stability and accessibility of affordable housing for vulnerable populations.

title: Volunteers are working harder as COVID heightens the need for food
summary: As the pandemic worsens food insecurity in Baltimore, volunteers and local organizations are working harder to distribute thousands of meals and pounds of food each week. With a sharp rise in demand, food banks and pantries have significantly increased their efforts, supported by both community initiatives and expanded city services.

title: As the pandemic drags on, Baltimore communities work to keep neighbor’s spirits up
summary: As the pandemic continues, Baltimore communities are coming together to combat rising stress and anxiety through initiatives like meditation sessions, outdoor events, and mutual support. Mental health hotlines in the area report a significant increase in calls, highlighting growing concerns over isolation, depression, and pandemic-related distress.

title: COVID means many more responsibilities for the oldest child
summary: Katherine Banegas-Bonilla, a 17-year-old high school student in Baltimore, has taken on numerous household and caregiving responsibilities during the pandemic, including helping her younger siblings with school and managing the home while her parents work. Experts note that many older siblings in similar situations are shouldering increased domestic duties, highlighting the need for emotional and academic support for these teens.

title: Maryland hopeful for Biden’s environmental impact
summary: Maryland officials and environmental groups are optimistic that the Biden administration will advance climate action and restore environmental protections, particularly for the Chesapeake Bay. However, success will depend on Biden's ability to navigate a divided Congress and reverse Trump-era policies through legislation or executive action.

title: Court ruling on DACA a relief for Marylanders ‘in limbo’
summary: A recent court ruling has restored the Obama-era policies of the Deferred Action for Childhood Arrivals (DACA) program, allowing new applications and two-year work permits after the Trump administration halted them in 2017. The decision brings relief to Maryland's DACA recipients and students, who can now benefit from reinstated protections, educational opportunities, and legal support initiatives.

title: Maryland examining wastewater for coronavirus
summary: Maryland is expanding its use of wastewater testing to detect coronavirus, particularly in vulnerable communities, using funding secured by Gov. Larry Hogan.

title: Maryland lawmakers ‘disappointed’ by witness at hearing
summary: A former Maryland Environmental Service official invoked his right against self-incrimination over 100 times during a legislative hearing, frustrating lawmakers investigating a controversial severance payout. The hearing revealed questionable spending on travel and other expenses during his tenure but provided no new information about whether Gov.

title: Few incidents of voter intimidation and harassment reported
summary: Maryland's attorney general's office received 27 complaints of voter intimidation or harassment during the 2020 election, including reports of suspicious flyers, confrontational behavior at polling places, and threatening letters. Despite these incidents, the number of reported cases remained low, and responses from law enforcement were limited.

title: For area libraries and patrons, pandemic has meant a whole new story
summary: During the pandemic, libraries in Washington, D.C., and Maryland have adapted to limited operations while continuing to serve as essential community resources. Despite closures and restrictions, they remain a vital social safety net, offering access to information, technology, and educational support.

title: Maryland plans phased COVID-19 vaccine distribution next week
summary: Maryland is set to receive its first shipment of COVID-19 vaccines next week, with initial doses prioritized for healthcare workers, long-term care facility residents and staff, and first responders. The state plans a phased distribution based on CDC recommendations, starting with high-risk groups, while addressing vaccine hesitancy remains a key challenge.

title: Blue precincts in Republican counties helped boost Biden to victory in Maryland
summary: Biden's victory in Maryland was aided by strong Democratic performance in urban "blue precincts" within otherwise Republican-leaning counties. These areas, concentrated in cities, provided enough support to tip the state's electoral outcome in his favor.

title: The legislative legacies of the George Floyd and Breonna Taylor protests
summary: The deaths of George Floyd and Breonna Taylor in 2020 sparked widespread protests against police violence, with the Black Lives Matter movement advocating for systemic reform and the slogan "Defund the Police" calling for reallocation of police funds to social programs. While some argue the movement has lost focus with polarizing rhetoric, others, like Rep.

title: Telling the Uncomfortable Truth
summary: As media outlets promote vaccine developments as "good news," they often fail to critically evaluate the data or disclose that pharmaceutical companies, not independent experts, confirm the vaccines' safety and efficacy. This lack of scrutiny misleads the public, downplaying concerns about the scientific process and federal influence.

title: Maryland looks into statewide mandate on police body cameras
summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering a statewide mandate for police body cameras by 2025, but concerns remain about the financial burden of equipment and storage costs on local departments. A legislative task force is evaluating how to implement the policy in a fiscally feasible way, particularly for smaller counties.

title: How to Deal with Trump’s Lies
summary: The article criticizes NBC, ABC, and CBS for repeatedly broadcasting President Trump's false claims about the election and voter fraud, arguing that fact-checking is insufficient when the media amplifies disinformation. Experts suggest the media should focus on reporting the truth without giving a platform to baseless statements.

title: How Trump Changed Political Journalism
summary: President Donald Trump transformed political journalism by forcing media to shift focus from policy to his personal conduct, with coverage dominated by his tweets, press events, and erratic behavior. Critics argue that the press's adherence to "both-sides" reporting allowed Trump to gain undue attention for his falsehoods and misconduct, undermining objective journalism and democratic norms.

title: A Year for the History Books
summary: 2020 was a tumultuous year marked by the impeachment of President Donald Trump, a global pandemic that caused widespread death and economic disruption, and nationwide protests following the death of George Floyd. The year also saw the deaths of prominent figures like Ruth Bader Ginsburg and John Lewis, record voter turnout in a highly contested election, and Trump's refusal to concede despite losing the electoral vote.

title: Election Security in 2020
summary: The 2020 U.S. election was declared the most secure in American history due to improved infrastructure, widespread use of paper ballots, and enhanced cybersecurity measures.

title: Fact Checking under the Trump Administration
summary: During the Trump administration, social media platforms like Twitter and news networks extensively fact-checked misleading information related to the pandemic and the 2020 election. Trump's claims about immunity to the virus and election fraud were repeatedly flagged as false or misleading by Twitter and verified by state officials and news outlets.

title: Why Clinton Failed and Biden Prevailed
summary: Joe Biden defeated Donald Trump in the 2020 election largely because Trump's attacks on Biden were overshadowed by the pandemic, whereas in 2016, Trump's attacks on Hillary Clinton over her email scandal proved effective. While both campaigns targeted family controversies and trade policies, Biden's campaign resonated more with voters' immediate concerns in 2020 compared to Clinton's in 2016.

title: Jonathan Karl, the Model for Covering Trump’s Post Presidency
summary: Jonathan Karl has emerged as a leading model for post-presidency Trump coverage, consistently calling out the former president's and his allies' tactics with insightful, critical reporting. As Trump remains influential in the Republican Party, journalists like Karl play a crucial role in highlighting the risks his brand of politics poses, even if it draws criticism from his supporters.

title: Coverage of Essential Workers in Pandemic Shows Their Value
summary: Media coverage during the pandemic highlighted the critical roles of essential workers, especially healthcare and grocery employees, revealing the challenges they faced. While increased visibility led to wage raises for some, attention shifted to healthcare workers as the crisis evolved.

title: How Maryland public schools have responded to COVID-19
summary: Maryland public schools initially allowed hybrid learning as cases rose, but most have now shifted to fully virtual instruction due to high infection rates. While some districts returned students to classrooms as early as September, parents have expressed concerns over the pace and equity of the reopening efforts.

title: Allegany County experiencing surge in COVID-19 cases
summary: Allegany County in Maryland is experiencing a significant surge in COVID-19 cases, with a positivity rate over four times the statewide average as of November 20. In response, Governor Larry Hogan implemented new restrictions, including restaurant and bar closures, reduced retail capacity, and suspended hospital visitations.

title: Metro budget cuts would hurt workers and residents
summary: Metro's proposed budget cuts threaten widespread job losses, station closures, and reduced service, drawing sharp criticism from transit workers and advocates who warn of severe impacts on essential workers and the regional economy. Similar financial struggles are being seen in transit systems across the U.S., including New York and Los Angeles.

title: Maryland works to fix racial disparities in juvenile centers
summary: Maryland's juvenile detention centers have seen a significant drop in admissions over the past decade, with many children being diverted to alternative programs. However, Black children continue to be disproportionately represented, making up 77% of admissions despite being only 31.6% of the youth population in the state.

title: The integration of sports and politics went to the next level in 2020
summary: In 2020, major sports franchises across the U.S. opened their venues as voting centers, boosting voter turnout and safety during the pandemic.

title: Live music venues struggle to survive as the COVID-19 pandemic rages on
summary: Live music venues in Washington, D.C., are struggling to survive due to the ongoing impact of the COVID-19 pandemic, with many forced to close or operate at limited capacity. Despite a city pilot program allowing some venues to host events, business owners like Pie Shop’s Sandra Basanti continue to face severe financial challenges.

title: Board of Public Works approves natural gas pipeline permit
summary: The Maryland Board of Public Works approved a permit for a natural gas pipeline under the Wicomico River to meet rising energy demand on the Eastern Shore. Environmental and racial justice groups opposed the project, citing ecological concerns, but the approval signals diminishing legal avenues to block it.

title: Revised citizenship test is harder, more conservative and may worsen backlogs, experts say
