summary: The "Glendening Effect" refers to the significant impact former Maryland Governor Parris Glendening had on shaping environmental policies in the state. His initiatives led to lasting conservation efforts and inspired similar programs across the U.S.

title: ‘Life and death crisis’ in Baltimore leads Hogan to push crime bills
summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan declared a "life and death crisis" over rising violence in Baltimore and announced his violent crime legislation as emergency bills to fast-track their passage.

title: Trump’s proposed Chesapeake Bay cleanup cuts draw fire
summary: President Donald Trump's proposed 91% funding cut for the Chesapeake Bay cleanup program has faced strong opposition from Congress, state officials, and environmental groups. Despite previous congressional efforts to increase funding, Trump continues to push for drastic reductions, though lawmakers hope to block the cuts through bipartisan support.

title: Hoyer says aid is delayed to Puerto Rico following 2017 hurricanes and earthquakes
summary: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer stated that Puerto Rico is experiencing delays in receiving $44 billion in allocated federal aid for recovery from the 2017 hurricanes and recent earthquakes. Lawmakers are working with federal agencies and local officials to address challenges in accessing funds needed to begin recovery projects and secure FEMA reimbursements.

title: Cardin and Van Hollen aim for net-zero greenhouse gases by 2050
summary: Sens. Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen have introduced the Clean Economy Act, aiming to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions in the U.S.

title: Bill looks to make single-occupant restrooms gender-neutral
summary: A proposed Maryland bill would require single-occupant restrooms in public buildings to use gender-neutral signage, aiming to improve accessibility for women, people with disabilities, caregivers, and transgender individuals. The bipartisan legislation allows localities to set fines up to $250 and has garnered support from parents, advocacy groups, and lawmakers.

title: Maryland bill would ban plastic carryout bags from stores
summary: A Maryland bill proposes banning plastic carryout bags at the point of sale starting in July 2024, imposing a 10-cent fee on durable bags like paper, and encouraging reusable alternatives. The legislation excludes certain types of bags used for food packaging and other specific purposes.

title: Bill would cover pets under Maryland’s black bear damage fund
summary: A new Maryland bill proposes expanding the Black Bear Damage Reimbursement Fund to cover pet-related damages caused by black bears. Currently funded by conservation stamps and hunting lottery donations, the fund typically reimburses losses to crops and livestock, with limited annual resources.

title: Bill would expand Maryland in vitro insurance to cover unwed women
summary: A new Maryland bill seeks to expand in vitro fertilization (IVF) insurance coverage to include unwed women, removing the current marital status requirement that excludes them from state-mandated fertility treatment benefits. The legislation, backed by the Women’s Law Center of Maryland, also aims to reduce the waiting period for insurance coverage from two to one year of unsuccessful attempts to conceive.

title: House votes to end deadline for states to ratify the ERA
summary: The U.S. House voted to remove the deadline for states to ratify the Equal Rights Amendment, with Democrats and five Republicans supporting the measure.

title: Flu warnings after 25 people die in Maryland
summary: At least 25 people have died from the flu in Maryland, where over 4,200 cases have been reported. Health officials are urging residents to take precautions to stay healthy and avoid illness.

title: Visit these hidden historical gems this Presidents Day weekend
summary: Presidents Day offers a chance to honor U.S. presidents and explore historical sites beyond the National Mall.

title: D.C.’s new XFL team gets rave reviews after first game
summary: D.C.'s new XFL team, the Defenders, received enthusiastic fan support after a 31-19 comeback win over the Seattle Dragons in their debut game at Audi Field. Many local fans and influencers praised the team's energy and performance, even drawing favorable comparisons to the struggling Washington NFL franchise.

title: Maryland bill would restrict what foods may be labeled ‘meat,’ as artificial substitutes become more common
summary: A Maryland bill, sponsored by a Republican senator, would prohibit labeling plant-based, lab-grown, or insect-based foods as "meat," aiming to ensure "truth in advertising." Supporters argue it prevents misleading labels, while opponents claim it stifles innovation and that existing guidelines are sufficient.

title: Legislation would carve exemptions for teen ‘sexting’ in Maryland
summary: Maryland legislators are considering bills to exempt teenagers from child pornography laws in cases involving consensual "sexting," following a state court's call for legislative action. The proposals aim to address the complexities of criminalizing teen behavior while protecting minors from exploitation.

title: In wake of his Senate acquittal, Trump angrily lashes out at Democrats and other critics
summary: President Donald Trump angrily celebrated his Senate acquittal, blaming Democrats, the FBI, and others for a "corrupt" and "evil" impeachment process. In remarks at the National Prayer Breakfast and the White House, he criticized political opponents, including Speaker Nancy Pelosi and Senator Mitt Romney, accusing them of prioritizing their agenda over the country's well-being.

title: Maryland Senate passes legislation that would provide support dogs to child witnesses in court
summary: The Maryland Senate passed legislation to expand a program providing therapy dogs to help calm child witnesses in courtrooms across the state. The initiative, inspired by successful local pilot programs, aims to reduce anxiety for children testifying in circuit court proceedings.

title: Senate acquits Trump of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress
summary: The U.S. Senate acquitted President Donald Trump of charges related to abuse of power and obstruction of Congress, ending his impeachment trial with votes largely along party lines and only one Republican, Sen.

title: In shadow of impeachment, Trump says state of the Union “is stronger than ever”
summary: President Donald Trump delivered a highly partisan State of the Union address, asserting that the nation is stronger than ever with economic and military successes, while rejecting a handshake from Speaker Nancy Pelosi amid ongoing impeachment proceedings. His speech highlighted record-low unemployment rates for minority groups and emphasized his administration's achievements, drawing sharp contrasts between Republican support and Democratic disapproval.

title: Mfume wins Democratic primary to succeed Cummings; Klacik gets GOP nod
summary: Former Rep. Kweisi Mfume won the Democratic primary to succeed late Rep.

title: Senators make their final cases ahead of Wednesday’s impeachment vote
summary: Senators finalized their positions ahead of the impeachment vote, with most Republicans supporting acquittal and only a few Democrats pushing for conviction. While some Republicans, like Susan Collins, acknowledged Trump's wrongdoing, they did not believe the evidence met the high constitutional standard for conviction.

title: Cybersecurity bill aims to create a base level of defense for local agencies
summary: A new Maryland bill, Senate Bill 120, proposes that the state’s Department of Information Technology develop a baseline cybersecurity strategy to help local agencies, such as counties and school districts, better defend against cyber attacks. The legislation, which draws comparisons to a 2019 North Dakota law, aims to provide guidance rather than mandate spending, with supporters emphasizing proactive preparation to avoid costly digital crises.

title: Md. bill would make helmets optional for most motorcyclists
summary: A Maryland bill would allow most experienced motorcyclists aged 21 or older to ride without helmets if they have two years of riding experience and have completed a safety course. While supported by some lawmakers and the American Motorcycle Association, the bill has faced consistent opposition from public health and safety groups and has failed to advance in previous legislative sessions.

title: ‘Magic Mahomes’ leads Kansas City Chiefs to first Super Bowl win in 50 years
summary: Patrick Mahomes led the Kansas City Chiefs to a stunning 31-20 comeback victory over the San Francisco 49ers in Super Bowl LIV, securing the team's first title in 50 years. At just 24 years old, Mahomes became the youngest quarterback in NFL history to win both a Super Bowl and a Super Bowl MVP award.

title: Super Bowl LIV preview: San Francisco 49ers vs. Kansas City Chiefs
summary: The San Francisco 49ers and Kansas City Chiefs will face off in Super Bowl LIV at Hard Rock Stadium in Miami, with the Chiefs boasting a high-powered offense led by Patrick Mahomes and the 49ers featuring a dominant defense and a strong running game. The game will highlight key matchups, including top tight ends Travis Kelce and George Kittle, and will determine the champion of the NFL’s 100th season.

title: Kansas City QB Patrick Mahomes surprises defenses with never-ending bag of tricks
summary: Kansas City Chiefs quarterback Patrick Mahomes continues to amaze with his unpredictable, creative plays, including no-look passes and off-balance throws that leave defenders and teammates in awe. His unique skill set, honed through years of baseball and instinctive playmaking, makes every game against him a challenging and memorable experience.

title: San Francisco’s Raheem Mostert rides wave of momentum into Super Bowl LIV
summary: Raheem Mostert's standout performance in the NFC Championship game, highlighted by a 220-yard, four-touchdown game, showcased his momentum as the San Francisco 49ers head into Super Bowl LIV. Known for his surfing-inspired celebration and background in the sport, Mostert credits surfing with helping him overcome challenges in football and life, impressing teammates with his athletic versatility.

title: Senate rejects calling witnesses to impeachment trial, will vote on articles next week
summary: The Senate rejected calls to bring witnesses in President Trump's impeachment trial, moving the process toward a final vote next week on the two articles of impeachment. Republican senators, largely opposing additional evidence, are expected to acquit Trump, with the final decision set for the day after his State of the Union address.

title: Maryland bills aim to restrict kratom
summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering a bill to classify kratom as a highly dangerous controlled substance, citing concerns over its opioid-like effects and potential for abuse. Advocates argue for regulation rather than prohibition, claiming kratom can safely help manage pain and opioid withdrawal when used properly.

title: Maryland’s Delaney drops out of presidential race days before Iowa caucus
summary: Former Maryland Rep. John Delaney has dropped out of the 2020 presidential race just days before the Iowa caucuses, citing insufficient support and a desire not to split the moderate vote.

title: Senators wrap up impeachment trial questioning ahead of key vote on witnesses
summary: Senators concluded two days of impeachment trial questioning, focusing on whether presidential actions aimed at re-election are impeachable and whether obtaining political information from a foreign country is illegal, ahead of a key vote on calling witnesses. Despite House Democrats arguing their case had been proven, Republican senators, including Lamar Alexander, indicated they would not support witnesses or conviction, making a quick acquittal likely.

title: Maryland lawmakers override several bills Hogan vetoed last year
summary: Maryland lawmakers overrode Governor Larry Hogan's vetoes on five bills, including measures on criminal record disclosure and in-state tuition for undocumented students, but failed to pass a bill requiring minimum crew sizes on freight trains. The defeat was attributed to concerns over jeopardizing a major economic development project involving the Howard Street Tunnel expansion and support from CSX Transportation.

title: Former Good Counsel teammates live out Super Bowl dream with Kansas City
summary: Former high school teammates Kendall Fuller and Dorian O’Daniel from Good Counsel are living their Super Bowl dream together as Kansas City Chiefs players. Once rivals on the varsity team, they now stand united on the NFL's biggest stage.

title: Super Bowl notebook: Goodell on minority coaches, a London franchise and more
summary: NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell acknowledged the league's lack of minority head coaches and pledged to make changes, emphasizing the need for diversity in leadership. The league currently has only four minority head coaches, despite 70% of players being Black, and will hold a serious meeting to address the issue.

title: Senators’ questions in impeachment trial spur debate on witnesses
summary: Senators debated the need for new witnesses in President Trump’s impeachment trial, with Democrats pushing to hear from John Bolton and others while the White House opposed the move. A motion was proposed to give Chief Justice John Roberts authority to rule on witness and evidence requests, aiming to ensure a fair trial process.

title: Bill allows motorists to keep driving past Real ID deadline
summary: Maryland drivers whose licenses are confiscated due to Real ID non-compliance will have 90 days to submit required documentation under new legislation. The law would protect them from being charged for not having a license during this period if stopped for another violation.

title: Trump’s defense team wraps up; questions — and a key vote on witnesses — to come
summary: Trump's defense team concluded its Senate impeachment trial arguments, asserting that removing a president over policy disagreements sets a dangerous precedent. A key vote on whether to call witnesses may occur as early as Friday, with Republicans struggling to secure enough support to override Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell's opposition.

title: Lawmakers look to repeal state’s ‘archaic’ sex laws
summary: Maryland lawmakers are pushing to repeal outdated laws that allow marriage as a defense in some spousal sex crime cases and criminalize sodomy. They aim to modernize sexual assault laws by eliminating loopholes and treating marital rape as a serious crime.

title: Bolton revelations overshadow Trump impeachment defense, may shift GOP witness stance
summary: John Bolton's upcoming book reveals that President Trump allegedly withheld military aid from Ukraine until it announced investigations into the 2016 election and the Bidens, undermining Trump's defense in his Senate impeachment trial. The revelations have sparked debate among Republican senators about whether to call new witnesses and could influence future votes on evidence.

title: In brief impeachment trial opening, Trump lawyers insist president did nothing wrong
summary: President Trump’s defense team opened their impeachment trial by denying any wrongdoing and accusing House Democrats of omitting evidence and attempting to remove him from the 2020 ballot. They argued the case is politically motivated and not based on actual presidential misconduct.

title: Trump Ukraine obstruction continues, House Democrats tell Senate impeachment trial
summary: House Democrats argue that President Trump endangered national security by pressuring Ukraine and obstructing Congress, asserting he remains a threat to democracy. They urge Senate Republicans to support witnesses and documents in the impeachment trial to fully examine his conduct.

title: Still no GOP movement on key question in impeachment trial: Will there be witnesses?
summary: Republicans in the Senate largely oppose calling new witnesses in the impeachment trial, claiming existing evidence is sufficient, while Democrats argue additional testimony is crucial given the gravity of the proceedings. A recent poll shows majority public support for subpoenaing new witnesses, though the country remains divided on whether to remove the president from office.

title: In impeachment trial, House Democrats use Trump allies’ words against them
summary: House Democrats in President Trump's impeachment trial argued that abuse of power, betrayal of national interests, and corruption qualify as impeachable offenses under the Constitution, citing historical and legal precedents. They also used past statements from Trump's allies, including Alan Dershowitz and Sen.

title: Without witnesses, House Democrats open arguments in Trump impeachment trial
summary: House Democrats began their opening arguments in the Senate impeachment trial without introducing new witnesses or evidence, focusing on allegations that President Trump abused his power and obstructed an investigation into his conduct. Republican senators and Trump’s legal team dismissed the case as politically motivated, emphasizing the lack of explicit "quid pro quo" evidence in the impeachment articles.

title: Among bills for Maryland small business, big lemonade stands out
summary: A Maryland bill aims to protect children's lemonade stands from local permit enforcement, inspired by a national movement supported by Country Time Lemonade. The legislation, backed by bipartisan lawmakers, seeks to support young entrepreneurs and prevent incidents like the $500 fines imposed on children in Montgomery County.

title: Senate impeachment trial opens with fight over rules, but GOP prevails
summary: The Senate impeachment trial of President Donald Trump began with a partisan battle over trial rules, with Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell and Republicans securing their desired procedures, blocking Democratic efforts to subpoena additional witnesses and evidence. Trump faces charges of abuse of power and obstruction of Congress, but conviction requires a two-thirds Senate vote, which appears unlikely given Republican control of the chamber.

title: Proposed rule could limit the number of bills Maryland senators can file
summary: A proposed rule in Maryland aims to limit the number of bills a senator can file during the annual legislative session, with Sen. Michael Hough advocating for a cap of 20 to improve efficiency.

title: Bill would make possession of ransomware a crime in Maryland
summary: A new bill in Maryland seeks to criminalize the possession of ransomware with malicious intent, imposing penalties of up to 10 years in prison and $10,000 in fines, though researchers would be exempt. Sponsored by Senator Susan Lee, the legislation aims to deter cybercriminals and align Maryland with other states that have already enacted similar laws.

title: Maryland lawmakers consider new rifle and shotgun regulations
summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering a bill that would require background checks and licensed dealer involvement for transfers of rifles and shotguns, aiming to close a current regulatory gap. Opponents argue the bill could criminalize common rural practices and complicate gun purchases, while supporters say it aims to ensure all gun sales are properly vetted.

title: Housing, guns bills priority of new Maryland Senate committee chairman
summary: Sen. William "Will" Smith Jr.

title: Hogan: Fighting Baltimore crime a priority in new Maryland budget
summary: Governor Larry Hogan's 2021 Maryland budget prioritizes fighting violent crime in Baltimore with significant funding for law enforcement, crime prevention, and legal initiatives, while also emphasizing record education funding. The proposed $47.9 billion "Accountability Budget" includes no new taxes and aims to address public safety and educational improvements outlined by the Kirwan Commission.

title: ‘Wrong’ Md. crime data highlights inconsistent statistics
summary: Maryland's crime statistics, particularly for rape, show significant inconsistencies between reports from the FBI, state police, and local law enforcement, with some agencies reporting vastly different numbers for the same crimes in the same time periods. The Prince George’s County Police Department disputed the FBI’s reported data, claiming the numbers were "wrong" and further highlighting the lack of clarity and reliability in the state's crime statistics.

title: Capital Gazette shooter was concerned about sanity
summary: Jarrod Ramos, the Capital Gazette shooter, has long been fixated on the newspaper due to a 2011 column he believed portrayed him as insane. Now, his legal team is arguing his insanity to avoid prison, echoing his 2012 lawsuit claiming the article defamed him by implying he was mentally unstable.

title: Maryland’s suburbs saw a large influx of prescription opioids
summary: Between 2006 and 2012, Maryland's suburbs received more prescription opioids per person than urban or rural areas, with Cecil and Kent counties on the Eastern Shore having some of the highest numbers in the state. While Maryland had fewer pills per person overall compared to the national average, urban areas in the state saw the lowest opioid distribution, unlike the national trend.

title: Harpers Ferry rock climbers worry closures could set precedent for future access
summary: Rock climbers in Harpers Ferry National Historical Park are concerned that the National Park Service's 2017 decision to ban climbing in parts of the park without public input could set a troubling precedent for future access. Climbing groups argue that the closure was unexpected and are continuing efforts to regain access to the area's historically significant climbing routes.

title: Sea levels are rising, and so are risks to the Port of Baltimore
summary: The Port of Baltimore is facing increasing risks from rising sea levels and severe weather due to climate change, prompting officials to develop a climate resilience strategy focused on preventing flooding and protecting cargo. While the port has policies to manage heat, its main climate-related concerns center on water-related threats rather than extreme temperatures.

title: Sustainability and climate change emerge in architecture schools across the country
summary: Architecture schools across the country are increasingly emphasizing sustainability and climate change in their curricula, with courses focused on designing eco-friendly systems and reducing carbon emissions. Experts stress the interconnected nature of climate challenges and the need for collaboration across disciplines to address them effectively.

title: More domed stadiums, fewer ski resorts: Expect climate change to affect sports around the world
summary: Climate change is increasingly affecting sports worldwide, with leagues like Major League Baseball facing more weather-related disruptions and financial costs. As extreme weather becomes more common, teams are exploring solutions like domed stadiums, while sports such as skiing and soccer also face significant challenges.

title: Baltimore Lags Behind Other Cities In Adoption Of Cool Roofing
summary: Baltimore residents are using cool roofs to combat rising summer temperatures, but the city lags behind others in implementing policies to promote their widespread adoption. While some cities have mandated cool roofs, Baltimore has not, despite efforts by advocates and research highlighting their role in reducing urban heat disparities.

title: Planting trees to fight climate change
summary: Kwamel Couther of the Baltimore Tree Trust works to increase the city's tree canopy to 40% by planting and maintaining trees in neighborhoods like McElderry Park. Trees help reduce urban heat, clean the air, lower energy costs, and mitigate the effects of climate change.

title: A plastic bag ban, green agriculture and zero waste: legislators’ climate plans for the 2020 session
summary: Maryland legislators plan to address climate change in the 2020 session with proposals including a plastic bag ban, studies on reducing single-use plastics, and efforts to combat urban heat islands through tree planting. Del.

title: Rising temperatures mean bigger worries for pregnant women and children
summary: Rising temperatures linked to climate change pose serious risks for pregnant women and their fetuses, including dehydration, preterm labor, and low birth weight. Studies show extreme heat can lead to early births and congenital heart defects in infants, particularly during the first trimester.

title: Across Maryland, counties and universities boost revenue through ICE contracts
summary: Maryland counties and universities are boosting local revenue through contracts with ICE, including 287(g) agreements that train local officers to enforce immigration laws and Intergovernmental Service Agreements that provide detention space. Despite activist opposition, officials argue the financial benefits for public services outweigh ethical concerns.

title: Washington Bullpen podcast: “I had to stand up” – Politics and sports in the nation’s capital
summary: Ray Schoenke, a former Washington NFL player, risked his career in 1971 by refusing to take a picture with President Richard Nixon in protest of the Vietnam War. His experience highlights the complex relationship between politics and sports, a dynamic he feels has become more damaging for athletes over time.

title: Cold weather? Hot weather?  New blend of grasses keeps sports fields lush no matter the season
summary: A new grass blend called bluemuda combines bermudagrass and bluegrass to thrive in both hot and cold weather, offering a solution for athletic fields in unpredictable climate zones. Developed after past failed attempts, it is now being used successfully at locations like the Rose Bowl and could help fields adapt to climate change.

title: Equal Rights Amendment may be near ratification, but must overcome old deadline
summary: The Equal Rights Amendment may be close to ratification after Virginia lawmakers proposed removing the 1982 deadline, needing just one more state to reach the 38 required for adoption. However, the amendment still faces a potential legal challenge due to the expired deadline not being officially rescinded by Congress.

title: Prices for construction projects spike, likely due to labor shortages
summary: Construction projects in Maryland, including those at the University of Maryland, have seen significant cost increases due to labor shortages and a lack of skilled tradespeople. The rising costs, attributed to higher wages, rebidding trade packages, and contractor exits, have added tens of millions to the price of major developments.

title: Election Guide: Meet field of 32 candidates seeking Rep. Elijah Cummings’ seat
summary: Thirty-two candidates, including Elijah Cummings' widow and former staff, are competing to fill the late congressman's congressional seat in Maryland's 7th District. The race features a record number of credible Democratic contenders, with key figures like Maya Rockeymoore Cummings, Harry Spikes, and Kweisi Mfume vying to continue Cummings' legacy.

title: Volunteers march in third annual Annapolis Women’s Unity March
summary: Eve Hurwitz, President of March on Maryland, led the third annual Annapolis Women’s Unity March on March 1, 2019. Volunteers like Meera Lynn Devotta and Sumayyah Mordecai shared inspiring stories with the crowd during the event.

title: Md. lawmakers expect education to dominate 2020 session
summary: Maryland lawmakers anticipate education reform, school construction, and funding for HBCUs to be key issues during the 2020 General Assembly session. The session will also feature new leadership in both the Senate and House, marking a generational shift in state politics.

title: Steny Hoyer sees experience as his advantage
summary: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer, D-Maryland, feels confident about his reelection bid, citing his 38 years of service and deep experience in Congress as key advantages. Despite primary challenges from younger candidates, Hoyer remains active and focused on legislative priorities like voting rights and redistricting reform.

title: Colder temperatures projected for Maryland later in winter
summary: Wisp Ski Resort in Maryland began making snow in early November, the earliest in five years, as unseasonably cold weather arrived ahead of winter. While some models predict colder conditions through Christmas, others suggest a milder winter, with the Climate Prediction Center forecasting a warmer, wetter than average season for the Mid-Atlantic.

title: How Md. uses surveillance, data to track motorists, traffic
summary: Maryland uses hundreds of automatic license plate readers and other surveillance methods to track motorists for law enforcement and traffic planning, collecting both anonymous and identifiable data. Privacy advocates warn that the long-term tracking and storage of this information raise significant civil liberties concerns.

title: Joint effort aims at addressing Langley Park housing ills
summary: A new report by CASA and the University of Maryland highlights severe housing issues in Langley Park, including overcrowding, poor maintenance, and health hazards, disproportionately affecting Latino immigrant residents. The report calls for collaboration among community members, government agencies, and property owners to improve living conditions and residents' well-being.

title: In Maryland, advocates educate immigrants about the census
summary: In Maryland, CASA de Maryland is actively educating immigrant communities about the importance of participating in the 2020 census to ensure fair political representation and resource allocation. The organization's efforts are part of a broader state initiative to boost census participation among hard-to-reach populations.

title: Md. youths needing psychiatric care find long waits, drives
summary: Children and adolescents in rural Maryland needing inpatient psychiatric care often face long waits and lengthy drives due to a severe shortage of local facilities. Only a handful of hospitals in the state offer acute care for young patients, forcing families to travel long distances for treatment.

title: It’s all happening at the zoo – at night during the holidays
summary: The Smithsonian National Zoo transforms into a glowing winter wonderland each holiday season with millions of LED lights, animal-shaped lanterns, laser shows, and interactive art installations. The annual ZooLights event, now in its 13th year, attracts visitors with its festive atmosphere and creative displays designed to boost off-season attendance.

title: As pilot episode for ‘The President is Missing’ readies to film in Maryland, there’s hope of a sizable economic impact
summary: Maryland is set to begin filming a pilot episode for the potential SHOWTIME series *The President is Missing* in early 2020, with hopes it will generate a significant economic impact similar to that of *House of Cards*. State officials are optimistic the production will create jobs and boost local businesses, thanks in part to Maryland’s film incentives and versatile locations.

title: UMD flights help the state understand air quality
summary: The University of Maryland's RAMMPP team has been helping the Maryland Department of the Environment improve air quality since 1999 by tracking smog-forming pollutants from upwind states and local sources. Despite their research and efforts to reduce ground-level ozone, Maryland continues to violate federal ozone standards as the EPA has continually lowered acceptable levels.

title: Graduates of the adult drug court in Montgomery County celebrate and reflect
summary: Graduates of Montgomery County's adult drug court celebrated completing a program that combines legal oversight with treatment and therapy. The initiative aims to help individuals struggling with drug addiction achieve recovery and stability.

title: Maryland teen runs her own nonprofit clothing line for people with disabilities
summary: Leah Howard, a 14-year-old from Maryland, founded the nonprofit "Adaptive Style," which creates clothing designed for people with disabilities. Her organization aims to provide functional and fashionable apparel tailored to the needs of individuals with various physical challenges.

title: Farm families face high suicide rates as they struggle to make ends meet
summary: Farm families like the Vaughans, who own Daily Crisis Farm in Maryland, are struggling financially as rising expenses threaten their livelihoods. This financial strain is contributing to a national rise in farmer suicides, casting a shadow over the future of small farms across the U.S.

title: Girl sleeps in a land-locked boat to protest inaction on climate change
summary: A 17-year-old high school student in Maryland slept on a land-locked boat for four nights to protest government inaction on climate change. The protest took place in support of Greta Thunberg’s global climate strike on December 6.

title: ‘Resiliency Hubs’ Forming Around Baltimore
summary: Baltimore is establishing "resiliency hubs" to help residents cope with extreme weather and power outages. These community centers aim to provide essential services like electricity, water, and shelter during emergencies.

title: Smithsonian’s chief says more museums must wait, maintenance is top priority
summary: Smithsonian Secretary Lonnie Bunch III says addressing a $1 billion maintenance backlog is his top priority before considering new museums. While open to future expansions, he emphasizes the need for thorough planning, adequate resources, and a long-term commitment, estimating new museums could take at least a decade to realize.

title: One local artist is ditching the canvas for bathroom stalls
summary: A local artist is transforming school bathrooms into vibrant works of art, aiming to brighten and improve the environment for students. Her creative project at Langley Elementary School is intended to leave a lasting positive impact beyond traditional canvases.

title: Widow of Capital Gazette journalist finishes his book
summary: The widow of a journalist killed in the 2018 Capital Gazette shooting completed the book he was working on, calling it a 300-page love letter. The project symbolizes her dedication to preserving his legacy and their relationship.

title: Newsrooms reviewed security after Capital Gazette shooting
summary: Newsrooms across the U.S. have enhanced security measures following the 2018 Capital Gazette shooting, which killed five journalists.

title: This year’s White House ornament marks first presidential helicopter ride
summary: The 2024 White House Christmas ornament honors President Dwight D. Eisenhower as the first U.S.

title: House Judiciary Committee opens next impeachment phase with rancor, legal debate
summary: Three Democratic constitutional experts testified before the House Judiciary Committee that President Trump's actions toward Ukraine constituted high crimes and misdemeanors, while Republican witness Jonathan Turley criticized the impeachment process as rushed and lacking sufficient evidence. The debate centered on whether Trump's conduct met the constitutional threshold for impeachment, with Democrats asserting abuse of power and Turley arguing the case was based on a weak factual record.

title: Trained to serve: Maryland’s Natural Resources Police K-9 Unit
summary: Maryland’s Natural Resources Police K-9 Unit uses specially trained dogs like Rider, a hound-terrier mix, to perform critical tasks such as tracking, detecting poached wildlife, and searching for missing persons. The program prioritizes dogs with high energy and strong toy drive, combining determination with intelligence to effectively carry out law enforcement duties in natural resource protection.

title: Maryland water systems found to contain worrying levels of nitrate, arsenic and other chemicals, according to Environmental Working Group
summary: A 2019 Environmental Working Group (EWG) report found that most Maryland water systems contain contaminants like nitrates, arsenic, and trihalomethanes at levels exceeding health guidelines. The EPA tracks compliance violations but not specific contaminant levels, and smaller systems, including mobile home parks, are more likely to have water quality issues due to limited resources.

title: With student loan debt at an all-time high, some students worry about post-grad life with loans
summary: Student loan debt in the U.S. has reached $1.48 trillion as of June 2019, with federal loans making up the majority and offering lower, fixed interest rates compared to often higher, variable rates on private loans.

title: Maryland continues funding for protective crop plantings
summary: Maryland has not fully utilized its allocated funds for a cover crop program aimed at reducing pollution in the Chesapeake Bay. Despite progress in reducing phosphorus and nitrogen levels, the state still needs to cut nitrogen runoff further to meet its 2025 water quality goals.

title: What we learned from 5 days of impeachment hearings
summary: Democrats are moving forward with the next stage of the impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump after five days of public hearings featuring 12 witnesses. Key evidence includes Trump allegedly pressuring Ukraine to investigate Joe Biden and withholding military aid, with multiple officials calling the actions improper.

title: Hogan issues first paroles for juvenile lifers in decades
summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan has approved the first paroles for juvenile lifers in 24 years, marking a significant shift in state policy.

title: Maryland bill would ban balloon releases
summary: A proposed Maryland bill would impose a $250 fine for intentionally releasing balloons, aiming to reduce environmental waste and raise awareness about proper balloon disposal. The bipartisan legislation, inspired by a Queen Anne’s County law, seeks to protect wildlife and rural lands from the harmful effects of balloon debris.

title: Former Baltimore mayor pleads guilty to four counts
summary: Former Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh pleaded guilty to four counts, including conspiracy to defraud the United States and tax evasion, related to fraudulent sales of her "Healthy Holly" children's books. She admitted to double-selling books, failing to deliver them, and using the proceeds for personal and political expenses, while underreporting her income to pay less in taxes.

title: Former adviser tells impeachment inquiry Trump envoy was on ‘domestic political errand’
summary: Former White House adviser Fiona Hill testified that Trump's ambassador to the EU was engaged in a "domestic political errand" in Ukraine, linking aid and a White House meeting to investigations into Biden and the 2016 election. Hill and diplomat David Holmes also challenged claims of Ukrainian election interference, warning that Russia is actively working to influence the 2020 election.

title: Congress awaits inspector general’s report on cancellation of FBI headquarters move
summary: Congress is awaiting an inspector general's report to determine if the Trump administration's decision to cancel the FBI's planned relocation was justified. The review examines the decision to retain the aging J.

title: After Trump hotel subpoena, House panel OKs bill seeking audits of federal property
summary: The House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee approved a bill requiring the General Services Administration to audit federal properties leased to private parties, following a subpoena related to President Trump’s Washington hotel. The legislation aims to ensure transparency and compliance with lease agreements, as Democrats allege the Trump lease may violate the Constitution’s emoluments clause.

title: Officials warn Pentagon cuts could force closing of Bethesda military medical university
summary: The Pentagon is considering significant budget cuts to the Uniformed Services University of the Health Sciences in Bethesda, which could lead to its closure. Officials and Maryland Senator Chris Van Hollen are urging Defense Secretary Mark Esper to reconsider, emphasizing the university's critical role in the military health system.

title: Sondland confirms quid pro quo in “seminal” fourth impeachment hearing
summary: Gordon Sondland, the U.S. ambassador to the EU, testified that President Trump and senior officials sought a quid pro quo with Ukraine, linking military aid to investigations into Joe Biden and others.

title: Former Baltimore mayor indicted on federal fraud charges
summary: Former Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh has been indicted on 11 federal charges, including wire fraud, conspiracy, and tax evasion, related to a scheme involving the sale of her children's books. The indictment alleges she defrauded buyers, enriched herself, and used the funds to support her political career, while underreporting her income on tax returns.

title: Franchot announces largest tobacco bust in agency history
summary: Maryland Comptroller Peter Franchot announced the largest tobacco bust in agency history, seizing over $450,000 worth of untaxed tobacco products and arresting two individuals. The investigation revealed that the suspects smuggled the products from a state with lower tobacco taxes and distributed them through retail stores in Prince George’s County.

title: Officials detail ‘unusual’ call between Trump and Ukraine leader
summary: White House officials testified that President Trump's July call to Ukraine's leader, in which he linked military aid to a Biden investigation, was improper and unusual. The testimony supports impeachment efforts alleging Trump abused his power by conditioning aid on a politically motivated probe.

title: Take a walk through Centreville’s opioid haunted house
summary: A group in Centreville, Maryland, created the Haunted Trap House to raise awareness about the opioid epidemic. Each room in the haunted house depicts a different stage in the life of someone struggling with drug addiction.

title: Amidst “intimidating” tweets from Trump, envoy tells impeachment probe of ‘smear campaign’
summary: Marie Yovanovitch testified before the House Intelligence Committee about being ousted as U.S. ambassador to Ukraine amid what she described as a "public smear campaign" by Trump and his lawyer, while the president criticized her on Twitter, which lawmakers called witness intimidation.

title: State comptroller promotes local business owners
summary: The state comptroller is encouraging residents in Prince George’s County, Maryland, to support local businesses during the holiday season. The push aims to reinvest money back into local communities through increased shopping.

title: Van Hollen, Beyer propose surtax on millionaires
summary: Sen. Chris Van Hollen and Rep.

title: Immigrants, led by Jamaicans, slow Baltimore population loss
summary: Immigrants, particularly Jamaicans, are helping to slow Baltimore's population decline, with nearly 2,000 newcomers moving to the city in 2018 despite an overall population drop. This trend is part of a national pattern where immigrants have helped post-industrial cities like Baltimore avoid or reduce population loss.

title: Key witnesses impugn Trump in first impeachment public hearing
summary: The first public hearing in President Donald Trump's impeachment inquiry featured testimony from key witnesses who criticized his actions. The hearing highlighted a partisan split among lawmakers regarding Trump’s conduct.

title: In first public impeachment hearing, revelations of new Trump Ukraine call
summary: Acting U.S. Ambassador to Ukraine William Taylor testified that a July 26 phone call revealed Donald Trump discussing "the investigations" with Ambassador to the EU Gordon Sondland, one day after Trump's controversial call with Ukraine's president.

title: Deadline nears for Maryland uninsured-motorist debt amnesty
summary: Maryland's FineFix program offers uninsured motorists until December 31 to enroll and have 80% of their pre-2017 uninsured-driving debts forgiven, with the remaining 20% to be paid over time. The initiative, aimed at getting drivers back on the road legally, requires proof of insurance and settled fines for vehicle registration.

title: Immigrant advocates rally in Baltimore before crucial Supreme Court case
summary: Immigrant advocates rallied in Baltimore on Nov. 8, 2019, as part of a nationwide march from the Statue of Liberty to the Supreme Court ahead of a key hearing on the future of DACA and TPS.

title: Divided Supreme Court hears arguments over young immigrants program
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court heard arguments on whether the Trump administration's 2017 termination of the DACA program was lawful, with the government claiming it was a reasonable enforcement decision and opponents arguing it caused widespread harm without proper justification.

title: Has climate news coverage turned a corner?
summary: A record 323 news outlets from 47 countries collaborated in September for the most extensive climate change coverage to date, significantly boosting public awareness and engagement. Organized by Covering Climate Now, the initiative reached over 1 billion people through 3,640 stories and extensive social media sharing.

title: Trump presidency brings unprecedented attention to the Constitution’s emoluments clauses
summary: The Trump presidency has brought unprecedented attention to the Constitution’s emoluments clauses, leading to multiple lawsuits alleging violations related to the president's business dealings with foreign entities. These clauses, designed by the Founding Fathers to prevent foreign corruption, are now under intense legal and public scrutiny due to Trump’s extensive global business interests.

title: Briana Urbina’s pitch to Maryland’s 5th Congressional District: go younger
summary: Briana Urbina, a 35-year-old civil rights attorney and former teacher, is campaigning for Maryland’s 5th Congressional District, emphasizing issues like affordable housing and Medicare for all while advocating for generational change. She challenges long-time incumbent Steny Hoyer, citing the need for new leadership and motivated by her students’ disappointment after the 2016 presidential election.

title: Black bear hunt numbers up with growing population
summary: Maryland's black bear population has grown significantly, prompting an increase in hunting permits and resulting in the harvest of 145 bears this year, 10 more than last year. The population has expanded eastward, and with an annual growth rate of about 12 percent, the state anticipates continued expansion into new territories.

title: New trial date set, records made public in Capital Gazette trial
summary: The trial to determine criminal responsibility for Jarrod Ramos, who pleaded guilty to killing five Capital Gazette journalists in 2018, has been rescheduled for March 4. Court documents related to the case, including DNA testing and Ramos's veterinary history, have now been made public.

title: NCAA rules help UMD, others inflate football attendance figures
summary: The NCAA allows schools like the University of Maryland to report inflated football attendance figures by counting distributed tickets rather than actual scanned entries, masking declining fan interest. This practice has helped mask falling scanned attendance numbers across many Big Ten schools, with Maryland showing a 56.3% gap between announced and actual attendance in 2018.

title: Relieving D.C.’s food insecurity issue
summary: Food insecurity affects millions of U.S. households, with Washington D.C.’s Wards 7 and 8 particularly underserved by just two grocery stores for 34,000 residents.

title: Workers tackle strange substance that has dirtied Jefferson Memorial
summary: Workers are using lasers to remove a stubborn dark biofilm from the Jefferson Memorial's dome as part of a 15-month renovation project. The effort, which also involves roof and stone repairs, aims to preserve the historic site while avoiding chemical pollution of the Tidal Basin.

title: Md. lawmakers announce $2.2 billion school construction plan
summary: Maryland lawmakers announced a $2.2 billion school construction and renovation plan, to be funded through bonds and casino revenue, with annual payments of about $125 million. The initiative, called the Built to Learn Act, aims to elevate Maryland’s education system and will be a top priority during the 2020 legislative session.

title: 45 years ago, another presidential impeachment involved another Sarbanes
summary: In 1974, Maryland Rep. Paul Sarbanes introduced the first article of impeachment against President Richard Nixon during the Watergate scandal, which ultimately led to Nixon's resignation.

title: Funding for historically black colleges remains held up in Senate
summary: Historically Black Colleges and Universities in Maryland risk losing over $4 million in federal funding due to congressional inaction, as the FUTURE Act renewing support has stalled in the Senate. Senate leaders have instead focused on a broader Higher Education Act reauthorization, delaying critical, time-sensitive funding for HBCUs.

title: High court to weigh Trump’s ending of program for young, undocumented immigrants
summary: The Supreme Court is set to hear arguments on whether President Trump's decision to end the DACA program, which protects young undocumented immigrants, is constitutional. Lawmakers, universities, businesses, and religious groups have urged the court to preserve the program, emphasizing the contributions and potential of Dreamers.

title: Six things riders might like to know from Metro’s update to Congress
summary: Metro is prioritizing safety over service as it addresses aging infrastructure and maintenance issues, following a recent train collision incident. During a congressional hearing, leaders acknowledged progress but emphasized that significant work remains to ensure a reliable and safe transit system for commuters.

title: Kate Kennedy, a voting advocate, seeking second term on College Park City Council
summary: Kate Kennedy, a vocal advocate for non-citizen voting rights, is running unopposed for re-election to the College Park City Council. Her commitment to civic engagement and leadership stems from a lifelong involvement in community service and a passion for women's empowerment.

title: “Flower Man” has blossoming business on Annapolis street
summary: "Flower Man" runs a thriving flower business on Annapolis street, continuing his work even on rainy days. His dedication has helped his business grow and attract attention locally.

title: A natural hair bill is being welcomed in Montgomery County
summary: A natural hair bill is being supported in Montgomery County to address discrimination based on hair texture. Advocates, including lawmakers and career advisers, argue it is time to end such biases in the workplace.

title: Maryland women’s soccer makes Big Ten Tournament for first time in history
summary: Maryland's women’s soccer team has made history by qualifying for the Big Ten Tournament for the first time since joining the conference in 2014.

title: A divided House approves path to possible Trump impeachment
summary: The U.S. House of Representatives approved a resolution to advance the impeachment inquiry against President Donald Trump, calling for public hearings and transparency in the investigation into his dealings with Ukraine.

title: At Brookings talk, Van Hollen calls for “quiet diplomacy,” strategic partnerships
summary: Sen. Chris Van Hollen criticized the Trump administration's isolationist foreign policy at a Brookings Institution event, advocating for stronger alliances and diplomacy in response to growing influence from Russia and China.

title: By the numbers: Washington Nationals win the World Series
summary: The Washington Nationals overcame the Houston Astros in a hard-fought World Series, clinching their first-ever title with a 6-2 Game 7 victory on the road. Their improbable run to the championship was fueled by timely hitting and strong pitching throughout the series.

title: Nationals #FinishedTheFight, now it’s time for the parade
summary: The Washington Nationals will celebrate their first World Series championship with a parade in downtown Washington on Saturday, following their historic seven-game victory over the Houston Astros. The team made history by winning all four road games in the series, marking the first time a team has done so to claim the title.

title: BARCS holds a pet-friendly festival to promote pet adoption
summary: BARCS is hosting its 15th annual BARCStoberfest in Baltimore to promote pet adoption and raise awareness for abused and abandoned animals. The pet-friendly festival aims to help the shelter find homes for thousands of animals each year.

title: Capital Gazette shooting trial postponed
summary: The trial for the Capital Gazette shooting was postponed after the defense requested more time to review new mental health evidence provided by the prosecution, which they argued was submitted too late. Judge Laura Ripken ruled the prosecution was not in violation of discovery rules, but the trial's start was delayed until further notice.

title: Board approves $9 million for five wrongly convicted men
summary: The Maryland Board of Public Works approved nearly $9 million in compensation for five men who were wrongly convicted and later exonerated, with payments based on the number of years each spent in prison. The compensation, intended to reflect lost income and housing, will be distributed in multiple installments through 2025.

title: Consumer Financial Protection Bureau holds stance against added payday borrower protections
summary: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau has maintained its decision to remove additional payday lending protections, arguing there was insufficient evidence and legal support for the requirements. While some lawmakers have criticized the move and urged compliance with original rules, the agency continues to redefine what constitutes abusive lending practices.

title: At symposium, Van Hollen stresses support for scientists, seriousness of climate change
summary: At a symposium in Maryland, Sen. Chris Van Hollen emphasized the importance of addressing climate change and criticized Trump administration efforts to suppress the term as "all nonsense." He praised scientists and vowed to support their work, calling for continued federal engagement in combating climate-related disasters like extreme flooding.

title: Md. lawmakers, officials, union meet on staffing shortages
summary: Maryland lawmakers, state officials, and union members convened in Annapolis to address staffing shortages in state agencies, which employees say are causing safety issues and injuries. Union leaders criticized the Hogan administration for delays in filling vacancies and called for immediate action.

title: Orioles, Ravens groundskeepers challenged by climate change
summary: Baltimore Orioles and Ravens groundskeepers are facing increasing challenges due to extreme and erratic weather caused by climate change, prompting them to adapt with new strategies and resilient turf solutions. Rising temperatures, unpredictable precipitation, and more frequent heatwaves are forcing stadium staff to rethink field maintenance and prepare for long-term environmental shifts.

title: Shooter in Capital Gazette pleads guilty to murder, other counts
summary: Jarrod Ramos, the gunman in the 2018 Capital Gazette shooting, pleaded guilty to five counts of murder and other charges, admitting to targeting journalists and staff in the newsroom. The court hearing, marked by emotional reactions from victims' families and colleagues, concluded with Ramos acknowledging his guilt without expressing remorse.

title: In Baltimore, presidents, family and friends bid Cummings a final farewell
summary: Elijah Cummings was honored with a moving funeral in Baltimore, attended by two former presidents, family, friends, and colleagues who celebrated his legacy of integrity, justice, and public service. His widow, Maya Rockeymoore Cummings, powerfully defended his character and reflected on his final moments, emphasizing his lifelong commitment to his community and democracy.

title: A not-so happy Halloween for Maryland’s struggling bat population
summary: Maryland's bat population is facing a severe decline due to white-nose syndrome, a cold-loving fungus that disrupts hibernation and leads to starvation. Since its arrival in the state around 2009–2010, the disease has caused a 90–99% drop in some bat species.

title: More than 4,000 attend funeral service for U.S. Rep. Elijah Cummings
summary: More than 4,000 people attended the funeral service for U.S. Rep.

title: Congress pays tribute to Elijah Cummings at U.S. Capitol
summary: Rep. Elijah Cummings became the first Black elected official to lie in state at the U.S.

title: By the numbers: Washington Nationals in the World Series
summary: The Washington Nationals, leading the World Series 2-0 against the Houston Astros, are one step away from their first-ever title. Despite entering as underdogs, they've scored 17 runs in the first two games, overcoming Houston’s strong pitching.

title: Md. Senate President Miller to step down as chamber leader
summary: Maryland Senate President Thomas V. "Mike" Miller Jr.

A private developer may build apartments on Knox Road in College Park, Maryland, potentially replacing some of the area's popular eateries. The decision was discussed at the recent College Park Council meeting.

title: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg discusses new cryptocurrency Libra before House Financial Committee
summary: Mark Zuckerberg testified before the House Financial Committee about Facebook's planned cryptocurrency, Libra, which is set to launch next year. The hearing quickly expanded beyond cryptocurrency, with lawmakers raising broader concerns during the session.

title: The Washington Nationals stimulate $6.5 million economic boon in World Series
summary: The Washington Nationals' World Series appearance is expected to generate a $6.5 million economic boost for the D.C. area.

title: U.S. Rep. Elijah Cummings’ life is celebrated at services at Morgan State University
summary: A special service honoring Rep. Elijah Cummings was held at Morgan State University on Wednesday night.

title: D.C. artist converts old police and fire call boxes to art to celebrate women
summary: A D.C. artist is transforming old police and fire call boxes into public art.

title: Baltimore says goodbye to a beloved leader, friend at Morgan State University tribute
summary: Baltimore honored the late Rep. Elijah Cummings with a tribute at Morgan State University, where he served on the Board of Regents for 19 years and left a lasting legacy through education and advocacy.

title: House slows impeachment probe amidst Cummings commemorations
summary: The House impeachment inquiry slowed slightly as Washington and Baltimore honored the late Rep. Elijah Cummings, though investigators vowed to continue his work.

title: Congress looks to remove ‘illegal alien’ from federal use
summary: Congress is considering removing the term "illegal alien" from federal use, following a past effort that successfully eliminated offensive language like "oriental" and "negro." The push comes as President Trump's frequent use of the term has sparked concern over its divisive and harmful impact on immigrant communities.

title: 274,000 pounds of food (and counting) recovered
summary: The College Park chapter of the Food Recovery Network has recovered over 274,000 pounds of food waste to date, donating it to local organizations like Christian Life Center. With chapters nationwide and strict food safety guidelines, the nonprofit continues expanding efforts, including recovering food from campus dining halls and sports events.

title: UMD continues to make sustainable strides with the Cool Food Pledge
summary: The University of Maryland has become the first university to join the Cool Food Pledge, committing to reduce food-related greenhouse gas emissions by 25% by 2030 through changes in sourcing and food service. The university has a history of sustainable dining, having exceeded its 2020 goal of sourcing 20% of food from sustainable vendors, with some produce coming from its own Terp Farm.

title: Baltimore community remembers U.S. Rep. Elijah Cummings
summary: Baltimore community members remembered U.S. Rep.

title: Politicians react to death of U.S. Rep. Elijah Cummings
summary: Politicians across the country expressed grief over the death of U.S. Rep.

title: Smithsonian’s Anacostia Museum reopens
summary: The Anacostia Community Museum has reopened after $4.5 million in renovations. The museum, an important part of DMV history, was recently visited by CNS-TV’s Cam Hasbrouck.

title: Maryland maltsters optimistic industry can grow
summary: Maryland's small malting industry, with only three companies, is being nurtured by optimistic maltsters who believe it has growth potential. Despite challenges in transitioning from traditional farming, some farmers are exploring malting as a viable and sustainable alternative to livestock feed production.

title: Malted barley’s additional uses
summary: Malted barley, traditionally used in beer, is also a key ingredient in malt liquor and various non-alcoholic products like malted milk balls and shakes. Its versatility extends from fermented beverages to sweets, with malted milk powder being widely available today.

title: “Washington Bullpen” podcast: The legacy of Rep. Elijah Cummings
summary: Rep. Elijah Cummings, a prominent advocate for civil rights and healthcare reform, passed away at 68 after long-standing health issues.

title: Baltimore remembers Elijah Cummings for his faith, friendship
summary: Baltimore mourns the death of Rep. Elijah Cummings, a civil rights leader and 22-year congressman remembered for his leadership, faith, and dedication to his community.

title: ​Judge limits notes from psychiatric evaluation in Capital Gazette shooting case
summary: A judge in the Capital Gazette shooting case ruled that defense mental health experts will not provide their detailed notes to the prosecution, limiting access for cross-examination purposes. Jarrod Ramos, who is charged with five counts of first-degree murder, has pleaded not guilty and not criminally responsible, leading to a separate trial if he is found guilty.

title: Veteran Baltimore congressman and Trump era protagonist Elijah Cummings dies at 68
summary: Rep. Elijah Cummings, a prominent Democratic congressman and key figure in the impeachment inquiry of President Donald Trump, died at 68 due to long-standing health issues.

title: ‘Our North Star’: Congress mourns loss of Cummings
summary: Congress mourned the death of Rep. Elijah Cummings, remembering him as a steadfast leader and civil rights advocate who served Baltimore for over three decades.

title: Former Md. delegate pleads guilty to wire fraud charge
summary: Former Maryland Delegate Tawanna Gaines has pleaded guilty to a federal wire fraud charge for using an undisclosed PayPal account to collect and misappropriate approximately $22,000 in campaign donations over three years. She agreed to repay the funds and faces a recommended prison sentence of 8-14 months, with sentencing scheduled for January 3.

title: Timeline: Congressman Elijah Cummings life and career highlights
summary: Congressman Elijah Cummings was a prominent Maryland politician and civil rights advocate, serving in the U.S. House of Representatives for over two decades.

title: Photo Gallery: Rep. Elijah Cummings on Capitol Hill
summary: The article features a photo gallery showcasing Rep. Elijah Cummings on Capitol Hill.

title: E-scooters on college campuses look like they have a bumpy road ahead
summary: Electric scooters are becoming a popular transportation option on college campuses, but concerns over accidents, poor implementation, and safety have risen. While some schools have introduced regulations to address these issues, others face criticism for hasty rollouts and user compliance problems.

title: Annapolis remembers Cummings as ‘giant of a man with a gentle soul’
summary: Elijah Cummings, a prominent Democratic leader in Congress and civil rights advocate, is being remembered in Annapolis as a dedicated public servant with a lasting legacy. Officials from both parties praised his decades of service to Maryland and his commitment to improving lives, especially in Baltimore.

title: Election to fill congressional seat expected for next year
summary: Maryland is expected to hold a special election next year to fill the congressional seat left vacant by the death of Elijah Cummings. Governor Larry Hogan has 10 days to set the election dates, with the primary and general elections each occurring at least 65 days apart.

title: Hogan orders traffic solutions for ongoing Bay Bridge fixes
summary: Gov. Larry Hogan expressed frustration over traffic backups caused by the Bay Bridge resurfacing project and emphasized the need to proceed with the work to ensure long-term bridge safety.

title: Charges against Md. delegate add to state corruption history
summary: Former Maryland Delegate Tawanna Gaines faces a federal wire fraud charge for allegedly using an undisclosed PayPal account to collect campaign donations, failing to report over $22,000 in funds for at least three years. The case adds to a growing list of Maryland lawmakers accused of corruption or ethical violations, with experts noting the state's concerning prevalence of "legal corruption."

title: House condemns Trump’s Syria policy
summary: The U.S. House of Representatives passed a bipartisan resolution condemning President Trump's decision to withdraw troops from northern Syria, which has left Kurdish allies vulnerable to Turkish attacks.

title: Supreme Court hears arguments on convicted sniper’s life sentences
summary: The Supreme Court heard arguments on whether Lee Boyd Malvo's juvenile life sentences without parole in Virginia violate the Eighth Amendment, following a 2012 ruling that such sentences are unconstitutional for minors unless they demonstrate permanent incorrigibility. Virginia argues Malvo’s case is exempt because his sentencing was discretionary, not mandatory.

title: Hogan directs wrongfully convicted to be paid; post office renovations approved
summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan announced that payments to five men wrongfully convicted will be approved at the next Board of Public Works meeting in two weeks.

title: One man dead after officer-involved shooting in Hyattsville
summary: A man is dead following an officer-involved shooting in Hyattsville, Maryland. The incident was reported by CNS-TV’s Cam Hasbrouck.

title: Judge orders mental evaluation remain private in criminal phase of Capital Gazette trial
summary: A judge ruled that the mental health evaluation of Jarrod Ramos will not be discussed during the guilt or innocence phase of the Capital Gazette trial, which is part of a bifurcated legal process. Ramos, who has pleaded not guilty and not criminally responsible, faces multiple charges for the 2018 shooting that killed five people at the newspaper's offices.

title: GOP Gov. Hogan affirms support for Trump impeachment inquiry
summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan has expressed support for the Congressional impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump, calling the allegations "troubling and disturbing" and emphasizing the need to uncover the facts.

title: Supreme Court to weigh Virginia life sentences in Washington sniper case
summary: The Supreme Court will decide whether Virginia's life without parole sentence for Lee Boyd Malvo, who committed murders as a minor in the 2002 Washington sniper attacks, violates the Eighth Amendment. Malvo's legal team argues the 2012 ruling against mandatory life sentences for juveniles should apply to his case, while Virginia contends its discretionary sentencing system makes him exempt.

title: Van Hollen and Graham seek sanctions against Turkey for attack on Kurds
summary: Senators Chris Van Hollen and Lindsey Graham plan to introduce a bipartisan bill imposing sanctions on Turkey for its military operation against Kurdish forces in Syria, which has resulted in significant casualties and displacement. The move comes in response to President Trump's decision to withdraw U.S.

title: Maryland, Delaware, Pennsylvania fight clean water rollback
summary: Maryland, Delaware, and Pennsylvania are challenging the Trump Administration's repeal of the 2015 Clean Water Rule, which expanded federal protections for waterways and faced opposition from farming groups. The revoked rule, which clarified federal jurisdiction over water bodies, was criticized as an overreach by the EPA but praised by states for safeguarding natural resources like the Chesapeake Bay.

title: Undersized crab possession dominates Maryland crab violations
summary: Maryland's Department of Natural Resources reported that undersized crab possession was the most common crab-related violation, accounting for nearly half of 2,341 infractions from 2013 to 2018. Officers typically return live undersized crabs to the water or donate them, while violations are often resolved like speeding tickets, with most violators pre-paying citations.

title: New gun range preaches safety in town of school shooting
summary: A new indoor gun range, Flat Broke Shooters Range, opened in Lexington Park, Maryland, aiming to provide a safe, year-round shooting environment for the community. The facility, built by competitive shooters Steve and Cindi Thomas, includes safety features like ballistic rubber and steel ceiling baffles to prevent accidental discharges.

title: As popularity of ride-sharing grows, safety concerns rise
summary: A Uber driver and his passenger were fatally shot in Maryland, leading to the indictment of the suspect on multiple charges, including two counts of murder. The incident has intensified scrutiny on ride-sharing safety, with companies like Uber and Lyft emphasizing their background checks and ongoing efforts to enhance safety measures.

title: National Institutes of Health Bethesda facility needs $1.5 billion for repairs
summary: The National Institutes of Health faces a $1.5 billion repair backlog at its Bethesda facility, with 72% of buildings over 20 years old and many in poor condition. Maryland lawmakers are urging Congress to provide additional funding to address critical maintenance needs and prevent risks to research and patient care.

title: Railroad’s rusting Potomac River span facing overhaul – and maybe more
summary: Plans are underway to overhaul the 115-year-old Long Bridge, a key rail link between Washington, D.C., and northern Virginia, to increase capacity and address bottlenecks by 2040. The proposed $1.9 billion project includes adding a second two-track bridge and possibly a dedicated bike and pedestrian crossing.

title: Safety procedures, video monitoring increase in Maryland public schools
summary: Maryland public schools are enhancing safety measures by installing security cameras and conducting active shooter drills, with a focus on phasing in cameras at elementary schools. These efforts come in response to increasing school shooting incidents nationwide and include strict guidelines for the use and sharing of security footage.

title: Maryland synagogues receive grant funds for security
summary: Maryland synagogues and other religious institutions received over $1.7 million in federal grants for security improvements, with most recipients being Jewish organizations. The funding, part of an annual program, aims to enhance physical security for religious sites considered high risk due to their nature.

title: Short films and screenplays highlighted District film festival’s 16th year
summary: The 16th annual DC Shorts International Short Film Festival and Screenplay Competition celebrated the craft of short filmmaking with screenings, workshops, and a screenplay competition that featured over 80 entries. "Life in the Pen," written by Jason Forbach, won the screenplay competition, which was one of the festival's closing events.

title: Renovations get major role in 2019 Folger Shakespeare season
summary: The Folger Shakespeare Library will close in March 2020 for a $38 million, two-year renovation to modernize its facilities, including adding a new pavilion and exhibition halls. During the renovation, performances will move to St.

title: One year after Khashoggi’s murder, vigil outside Saudi embassy demands justice
summary: A candlelight vigil was held outside the Saudi Embassy in Washington and the Saudi consulate in Istanbul to mark one year since journalist Jamal Khashoggi's murder. Attendees called for justice, as no significant consequences have been imposed on Saudi leadership, and international pressure remains low despite widespread condemnation of the killing.

title: Judge denies defense motion to limit crime-scene video in Capital Gazette case
summary: A judge in Maryland denied a defense motion to exclude crime-scene video from the 2018 Capital Gazette mass shooting. The video, which shows the shooter's entry, the attack, and victims trying to escape, will be used in the trial of Jarrod Ramos, who is charged with multiple counts of murder and assault.

title: Record-breaking heat representative of overall hot autumn
summary: Maryland experienced record-breaking heat in early October, with temperatures far exceeding historical averages and contributing to an unusually warm autumn. The heat, fueled by high-pressure patterns and dry conditions, affected daily life and agriculture, though some farmers were able to mitigate impacts due to earlier crop maturity.

title: A look into Major League Baseball’s massive home run surge in 2019
summary: In 2019, Major League Baseball shattered its single-season home run record with 6,776 total, as four teams, including the Minnesota Twins, far exceeded historical marks. While no definitive cause has been confirmed, players and analysts have speculated that changes in pitching strategies or baseball composition may have contributed to the surge in power hitting.

title: Attorneys argue over crime-scene video, other motions, at Capital Gazette hearing
summary: Prosecutors and defense attorneys in the Capital Gazette shooting case disputed during a hearing over whether crime-scene videos should be admitted as evidence, with the defense arguing they are unduly graphic and unnecessary. The videos, which capture the shooter entering the newsroom and victims attempting to escape, are described by prosecutors as crucial to showing the crime’s progression and the defendant’s intent.

title: A roundup of Maryland laws taking effect Oct. 1
summary: On October 1, Maryland implemented numerous new laws covering criminal justice, health, and consumer regulations, including banning bump stocks, decriminalizing gambling, and raising the tobacco purchasing age to 21. Additional changes include stricter penalties for hate crimes, opioid screening in jails, and reforms to the Medical Cannabis Commission.

title: Maryland groups condemn federal refugee admissions reduction
summary: Maryland organizations condemned the Trump Administration’s decision to set the lowest-ever refugee admissions cap at 18,000 for fiscal 2020, calling it a cynical and astounding betrayal of U.S. humanitarian values.

title: With the REACH, the Kennedy Center expands its mission
summary: The Kennedy Center's new $250 million expansion, the REACH, aims to strengthen community engagement through free and ticketed events, interactive spaces, and artistic collaboration. Featuring modern design and a bridge connecting to the National Mall, the REACH marks the first major expansion since the center opened in 1971.

title: “Washington Bullpen” podcast: Inside the District’s climate march
summary: Thousands of people of all ages marched in Washington, D.C., on Sept. 20 to participate in a climate strike, missing school or work to protest on Capitol Hill.

title: Therapy puppies help teens in Maryland juvenile centers
summary: Therapy puppies Clay and Bayr are providing emotional support and comfort to teens at two juvenile detention centers in Maryland through a pilot program. Animal-assisted therapy has been shown to reduce symptoms of anxiety and depression, helping residents cope and bond.

title: White House Ukraine call summary “damning,” Hoyer, other Democrats, say
summary: Democratic lawmakers called the White House's summary of President Trump's July 25 call with Ukrainian President Zelensky "damning," alleging Trump pressured Ukraine to investigate Joe Biden. House leaders, including Steny Hoyer, framed the exchange as evidence of the president attempting to interfere in the 2020 election and endorsed the ongoing impeachment inquiry.

title: Senators criticize recent Central American agreements to address border crisis
summary: Democratic senators criticized the Trump administration for withholding details of new "safe third country" agreements with Guatemala, Honduras, and El Salvador, which would divert asylum seekers to those nations despite concerns over violence and instability. While some senators expressed alarm, the committee’s Republican chairman praised the administration’s efforts in addressing the border crisis.

title: Pelosi sets formal impeachment inquiry into Trump; Maryland Democrats concur
summary: Congress has launched a formal impeachment inquiry into President Donald Trump, with House Speaker Nancy Pelosi citing his alleged abuse of power and betrayal of national security. The inquiry follows allegations that Trump pressured Ukraine to investigate political rival Joe Biden, and comes as some House Democrats shifted their stance in recent days.

title: Senators want answers on Trump administration shutdown of women’s health helpline
summary: Democratic senators, including Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen, are demanding answers from the Trump administration after a long-standing women’s health helpline was abruptly shut down without notice this summer. The senators argue the service is critical for underserved communities and have requested a response by September 30.

title: Thousands urge Washington and the world to take action on climate change
summary: Thousands of people in Washington, D.C., joined a global youth strike for climate change, led by activist Greta Thunberg, demanding urgent action through marches and protests. Participants, ranging from students to older allies, emphasized the importance of cross-generational support to address the climate crisis.

title: Md. Revenue Estimates board updates tax projections
summary: Maryland's Revenue Estimates Board increased the state's revenue projection for the current fiscal year by nearly $130 million, attributing the rise to a strong 2018 tax year rather than long-term growth. Officials expressed concerns about slowing wage growth, contracting key industries, and uncertain future revenue trends despite the state's prolonged economic expansion.

title: Meet one of Hoyer’s Democratic primary challengers: McKayla Wilkes
summary: McKayla Wilkes, a 29-year-old Waldorf resident, is challenging House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer in Maryland’s 5th Congressional District Democratic primary.
