Wilkes, who has faced personal struggles and systemic barriers, aims to represent working-class constituents and emulate the grassroots success of Rep.

title: Washington Bullpen: Inside the District’s fight for voting representation in Congress
summary: Residents of Washington, D.C., continue to protest their lack of voting representation in Congress despite paying the highest federal taxes per capita and having a population over 600,000. Historians note the Founding Fathers debated the issue but never resolved it, and modern activists are now pursuing new strategies to secure D.C.'s Congressional rights.

title: Despite DNA evidence of innocence, W. Va. man who pled guilty remains locked up
summary: A West Virginia man who pled guilty to a crime remains incarcerated despite DNA evidence suggesting his innocence. Authorities have not released him, leaving questions about the justice system's reliance on confessions and forensic science.

title: Separated migrant children likely to face lifelong trauma, Congress told
summary: Migrant children separated from their parents under the Trump administration's zero-tolerance policy are likely to suffer lifelong trauma, according to a federal official testifying before Congress. A recent report found that these children experienced heightened anxiety, abandonment fears, and even suicidal thoughts, exacerbated by inadequate care and prolonged stays in government facilities.

title: Washington Monument to reopen after three-year closure
summary: The Washington Monument has reopened after a three-year closure for elevator and security upgrades, allowing visitors to once again ascend to its observation deck. The renovations include a reliable elevator, enhanced security, and improved climate control, ensuring a smoother and safer experience for tourists.

title: Cardin, Brown say Andrews military families are paying for Trump’s wall
summary: Congress redirected $13 million intended for a new child care center at Joint Base Andrews to fund President Trump’s border wall, leaving military families without adequate care options. Sen.

title: Summit highlights racial disparities in maternal care
summary: A national summit highlighted the persistent racial disparities in maternal care, with Black women in the U.S. experiencing pregnancy-related death rates four to five times higher than white women.

title: Annual cocaine overdose deaths on rise in Maryland
summary: Cocaine-related overdose deaths have risen sharply in Maryland since 2015, with most involving fentanyl and concentrated in Baltimore. While 2019's first quarter saw a decline in some areas due to initiatives like naloxone distribution and Safe Stations, it remains unclear if the trend will continue.

title: Md. lawmakers, AG question DeVos on loan forgiveness program
summary: Maryland officials and lawmakers are pressing U.S. Education Secretary Betsy DeVos for explanations after the Public Service Loan Forgiveness program denied nearly all applications, despite borrowers meeting eligibility requirements.

title: FDA readying ban on flavored e-cigarettes amidst health scare
summary: The Trump administration is preparing to ban flavored e-cigarettes in response to a surge in vaping-related lung illnesses and concerns over youth nicotine addiction. The FDA has identified Vitamin E acetate in cannabis vaping products as a potential cause, as 450 people across 33 states have been hospitalized and six have died from the illness.

title: Maryland’s Hoyer contradicts Judiciary’s Nadler, then reverses course
summary: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer initially stated the House is not conducting a formal impeachment inquiry but later reversed his stance, clarifying he was referring only to the full House's consideration of articles. He affirmed support for Judiciary Committee Chairman Jerry Nadler’s ongoing investigation into potential impeachment.

title: House pushes four bills to improve maternal health
summary: House Democrats are advancing four bills to address the U.S.'s rising maternal mortality rate, which has more than doubled since 1987 and remains among the worst in the developed world. The proposed legislation includes extending Medicaid coverage for one year postpartum and addressing racial disparities, with bipartisan support and states already implementing similar initiatives.

title: Federal funds aimed at boosting Chesapeake Bay oyster population
summary: Federal funding of $800,000 has been allocated to restore oyster habitats in key Chesapeake Bay tributaries, supporting efforts to boost the oyster population and improve bay health. The funding complements a state plan to reduce oyster harvesting by 30% in hopes of achieving a sustainable oyster supply within eight to ten years.

title: Raskin decries administration as Cummings launches new probe into Pence, emoluments
summary: Democrats are investigating Vice President Mike Pence's stay at a Trump-owned Irish resort, which they claim may violate the Constitution's emoluments clause. Rep.

title: Maryland eyes Dorian for coastal flooding, rip current risks
summary: Maryland officials are monitoring Hurricane Dorian for potential coastal flooding and rip current threats as it moves up the mid-Atlantic coast. While the storm caused significant damage in the Bahamas and North Carolina, emergency managers are also coordinating with regional teams for recovery and preparation efforts.

title: Maryland communities and D.C. receive youth homelessness grants
summary: Baltimore, Prince George’s County, and the District of Columbia are among 23 communities receiving $75 million in federal grants to address youth homelessness through HUD’s expanded Youth Homelessness Demonstration Program. The funding emphasizes collaboration with homeless youth and aims to improve local programs by following community-developed plans.

title: Van Hollen blasts McConnell over Senate inaction on gun bill
summary: Sen. Chris Van Hollen criticized Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell for refusing to bring gun control legislation to a vote without President Trump's support, calling it irresponsible.

title: Code Red: Baltimore’s Climate Divide
summary: Baltimore faces a growing climate divide, with low-income and minority communities disproportionately affected by extreme heat and environmental hazards. City officials are under pressure to implement equitable climate resilience strategies to address these disparities.

title: In urban heat islands, climate crisis hits harder
summary: Urban heat islands experience the effects of the climate crisis more intensely, with higher temperatures worsening living conditions for city residents. This phenomenon highlights the need for targeted climate adaptation strategies in densely populated areas.

title: Health risks rise with the temperature
summary: Higher temperatures are linked to an increased risk of various health issues, including heat-related illnesses and cardiovascular problems. As global temperatures continue to rise, public health systems face growing challenges in protecting vulnerable populations.

title: No trees, no shade, no relief as climate heats up
summary: Rising temperatures and deforestation are reducing natural shade, leaving communities with less relief from the intensifying heat. The lack of tree cover is worsening the impacts of climate change, particularly in urban and vulnerable areas.

title: Global warming will be costly and neighborhoods must do more
summary: Global warming is expected to cause significant financial and environmental costs, urging communities to take stronger action. Neighborhoods must enhance preparedness and implement sustainable measures to mitigate its impacts.

title: A summer in Baltimore’s hottest neighborhoods
summary: Baltimore's hottest neighborhoods are facing extreme summer heat, disproportionately affecting low-income and historically marginalized communities. City officials are working to expand cooling centers and tree canopy coverage to mitigate the impacts of rising temperatures.

title: Despite #MeToo era, most top colleges share little about sexual assaults
summary: Most of the nation’s largest public universities remain largely untransparent about how they handle sexual assault cases, with many failing to provide basic data on reports, investigations, and disciplinary actions. Despite the #MeToo movement's push for accountability, critics argue that colleges are still lacking in competence, awareness, and commitment to addressing campus sexual violence.

title: AP Investigation: Death Behind Bars
summary: An AP investigation reveals that thousands of inmates have died in U.S. prisons in recent years, often under unclear circumstances.

title: The Cost of Freedom in Maryland’s Gig Economy
summary: Maryland lawmakers have passed new regulations requiring gig economy companies to provide basic benefits and protections to independent contractors, marking a significant shift in labor policy. The move aims to balance flexibility for workers with financial security, setting a precedent for other states grappling with similar issues.

title: Opening the curtains: The data behind 90 days in Annapolis
summary: In the 2019 Maryland General Assembly session, only 40 of 188 legislators passed at least half of their introduced bills, with an average success rate of 30.6%. While Governor Larry Hogan has signed several bills and vetoed others, including the $15 minimum wage bill, he still has until May 28 to veto legislation passed later in the session.

title: Md.’s consumer advocates push for new debt collection laws
summary: Maryland consumer advocates are pushing for new debt collection laws after a report revealed that thousands of residents face wage garnishment and hundreds are arrested annually for unpaid debts, often under $5,000. The practice, critics say, reflects a punitive approach that disproportionately affects low-income residents in the state’s most populous areas.

title: Former Md. Dept. of Public Safety and Correctional Services secretary:  No regrets about leaving
summary: Former Maryland Department of Public Safety and Correctional Services Secretary Stephen Moyer has no regrets about leaving his position in March to return to Florida, where he now serves as public safety director for Sarasota Memorial Healthcare System. Moyer, who previously worked in Maryland law enforcement and government, emphasized that his decision was personal, driven by his desire to return to his home state and utilize his experience in the healthcare sector.

title: Baltimore Clean Air law could affect Maryland landfills
summary: Baltimore’s new Clean Air Act imposes stricter emissions standards on incinerators, potentially forcing the closure of the region’s largest trash-burning facility. This could accelerate landfill capacity limits, especially for the nearly full Quarantine Road landfill, by shifting unburned waste to landfills instead of ash.

title: People and Culture of the Caribbean Spotlighted in Evans Thorne Paintings at Takoma Park Exhibit
summary: Evans Thorne, a 70-year-old Caribbean artist, showcased vibrant paintings of Caribbean people and culture at the Women of the World exhibition in Takoma Park, offering a joyful contrast to the show’s heavier themes. His passion for art began in childhood in Trinidad, and he later studied in the U.S., influenced by mentors and inspired by his homeland’s rich traditions and landscapes.

title: Bartlett’s first stint at Md. Statehouse highlights her passion to help the vulnerable
summary: J. Sandy Bartlett's early political involvement with campaigns for Douglas Wilder and Barbara Mikulski inspired her to eventually run for office after encouragement from state Sen.

title: Bad news for gig workers: A crowded labor market is depressing income, census data shows
summary: The gig economy in Maryland is becoming more competitive, leading to lower incomes for many workers as more people and even international freelancers vie for the same jobs. While offering flexibility, the growing number of gig workers—estimated at over 40 million nationwide—is driving down wages across various fields, from ride-sharing to graphic design.

title: Gig workers to clients: ‘Freelancing isn’t free work’
summary: Freelance gig workers like Kai Keefe in Maryland face frequent issues with non-payment or underpayment, even when contracts are in place. As the gig economy grows, workers struggle with inconsistent pay due to the lack of legal protections and oversight.

title: Home-based eateries: The next big thing in the sharing economy?
summary: Chef Malik Anderson uses his home to host extravagant meals for strangers through the meal-sharing platform BonAppetour.com, earning extra income as part of the gig economy. Home-based eateries and similar food services are emerging as a fast-growing segment in the sharing economy, offering unique dining experiences while providing income opportunities for independent chefs.

title: Bitter Cold: Climate Change, Public Health and Baltimore
summary: Baltimore is experiencing extreme cold weather, highlighting the complex and often unpredictable impacts of climate change. Public health officials are urging residents to take precautions as the city deals with the challenges of increasingly severe winter conditions.

title: Housing prices soar in Takoma Park, leaving residents unhappy with options
summary: Housing prices in Takoma Park have significantly increased, with the median home price reaching $350,000 and median rent at $2,600 a month, leading to growing resident concerns over affordability. A recent survey found that only 31% of residents believe quality affordable housing is available, highlighting a decline in satisfaction since 2014.

title: Md. House of Delegates elects Adrienne Jones as new speaker
summary: The Maryland House of Delegates elected Delegate Adrienne A. Jones as the first African American and first woman to serve as Speaker of the House, following a lengthy and unexpected deliberation.

title: National Cherry Blossom Festival generates over $100 million for DC
summary: The National Cherry Blossom Festival is estimated to generate between $100 million to $160 million in economic activity for Washington, D.C., supporting local businesses and tourism. The event, which overlaps with other major attractions, helps boost hotel revenue and offers themed experiences for visitors.

title: Anne Arundel Co. campaign finance bill awaits governor’s signature
summary: A Maryland campaign finance bill, House Bill 993, now awaits Governor Larry Hogan’s signature and would grant Anne Arundel County the authority to regulate campaign contributions from developers during land use or zoning proceedings. The legislation, streamlined from 16 to nearly four pages, was designed to allow the county, rather than the state, to determine how to implement such restrictions.

title: A broken radiator in the beginning of winter
summary: A broken radiator at the start of winter left many residents without heat, causing discomfort and safety concerns. Authorities are working to repair the system and provide temporary heating solutions.

title: Weed warriors repel invaders to protect plants and visitors to a Hyattsville park
summary: Hyattsville's Magruder Park has seen significant progress in removing invasive plant species like Asian bush honeysuckle through a decade-long effort led by Dr. Marc Imlay and volunteers.

title: Young people, like those at Hogan’s New Hampshire visit, may be key 2020 targets
summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan is considering a 2020 Republican primary challenge against Donald Trump and is focusing on engaging young voters, who are increasingly participating in elections.

title: Biased landlords ignore disability rights, uphold segregation, activists say
summary: Landlords are using disability, race, and other factors to discriminate against low-income renters, activists argue, often violating the Fair Housing Act. Tactics like disparate impact and restrictions on how rent is paid disproportionately harm vulnerable communities, despite legal protections in place at the federal and state levels.

title: In New Hampshire, Maryland’s Hogan keeps 2020 door open
summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan indicated he is seriously considering a presidential bid against Donald Trump but emphasized he would only run if he believes there is a viable path to victory.

title: Fresh kicks motivating students in Baltimore
summary: Elementary school students in Baltimore are being motivated to improve their grades and behavior through a program initiated by two local men. As a reward, students receive new sneakers for their academic and behavioral achievements.

title: In honor of Maryland black WWI vet, Van Hollen introduces bill to ‘right historic wrongs’
summary: Sen. Chris Van Hollen introduced bipartisan legislation to posthumously award the Medal of Honor to Army Sgt.

title: The Washington Bullpen: A look at the Mueller report
summary: Host Kate Casey of "The Washington Bullpen" reviews Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s report, which was released to the public on Thursday. The episode provides an analysis of the findings and implications outlined in the report.

title: Hogan heads to high-profile New Hampshire event as experts speculate on potential 2020 run
summary: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan is set to speak at a high-profile New Hampshire event, fueling speculation about a potential 2020 presidential run against Donald Trump. While Hogan has criticized Trump and expressed concerns about the country's political climate, he has also acknowledged the challenges of mounting a primary challenge.

title: Bill would provide protections to student loan borrowers
summary: A new Maryland bill aims to protect student loan borrowers from deceptive and predatory practices by loan servicers, including restrictions on false information and requirements for timely responses to complaints. The legislation, introduced following a report of poor servicing practices, also allows for complaints to be referred to financial regulators for review.

title: Despite tight landfill space, mattress recycling bill failed
summary: A Maryland bill aimed at promoting mattress and box spring recycling to reduce landfill waste and illegal dumping failed to pass in the Senate this session. Despite concerns over limited landfill space and varying local disposal options, the legislation did not become law.

title: Among the flowers, animals or pints of beer, yoga is a draw
summary: Yoga is becoming a popular wellness activity in unexpected outdoor settings like botanical gardens and zoos, offering participants a unique blend of nature and exercise. These pop-up yoga sessions provide physical and mental health benefits and reflect the growing popularity of yoga in the U.S.

title: Local effort aims at tackling the problem of juvenile fire starters
summary: A local initiative in Emmitsburg, Maryland, is addressing the growing concern of juvenile fire setting, an activity traditionally linked to boys but now increasingly involving girls. Experts note a rise in the number of young girls engaging in this dangerous behavior, though precise data remains difficult to track.

title: Spotlight on DMV Hip-Hop: Shy Glizzy
summary: Shy Glizzy, a standout rapper from Washington D.C., has gained national attention with his unique style and contributions to the rising DMV hip-hop scene. His bold tracks, collaborations with other DMV artists, and Beyoncé's endorsement highlight his role in bringing D.C.'s sound into the mainstream.

title: Maryland lawmakers blister Trump acts in Mueller report, stop shy of impeachment call
summary: Maryland's Democratic lawmakers condemned President Trump's conduct as detailed in the Mueller report, criticizing Attorney General William Barr's handling of the report's release but stopping short of calling for impeachment. They pledged to pursue congressional investigations into potential obstruction of justice and Russian interference.

title: Hogan signs bills on hate crimes, cyberbullying
summary: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan signed several bills into law addressing hate crimes, cyberbullying, and human trafficking, including an updated anti-cyberbullying measure named "Grace’s Law 2.0." He also established June 28 as Freedom of the Press Day in honor of the 2018 Capital Gazette shooting victims.

title: Gene therapy company announces acquisition, expansion
summary: Paragon Bioservices, a gene therapy company based in Maryland, announced a $1.2 billion acquisition by Catalent Biologics and a partnership with Sarepta Therapeutics to expand its drug manufacturing capabilities. The company, which benefits from state economic incentives, plans to significantly grow its workforce and continues to be recognized as a key contributor to Maryland’s biotech industry.

title: Maryland will make smoking and vaping age 21
summary: Maryland will raise the minimum age to purchase tobacco and vape products—including those without nicotine—to 21, effective October 1, with exceptions for active-duty military members aged 18 or older. Retailers who violate the law face fines and potential jail time, as lawmakers aim to curb rising teen vaping rates and associated health risks.

title: Black maternal health crisis prompts politicians, providers to act
summary: Black mothers in the U.S. face significantly higher maternal mortality rates, driven by factors including systemic racism and inadequate healthcare access.

title: Caps look to seize momentum in Game 4 after fight
summary: The Washington Capitals used physicality, highlighted by a first-period fight between Alex Ovechkin and Hurricanes' Andrei Svechnikov, in Game 3, which they lost 5-0 but still lead the series 2-1. Svechnikov, who suffered a concussion and will miss Game 4, was taken out of the game on a cart after being dropped by Ovechkin, sparking mixed reactions from both teams and coaches.

title: Maryland officials join opposition to seismic tests in the ocean
summary: Maryland officials, along with attorneys general from nine other Atlantic coastal states, have joined a lawsuit opposing the Trump administration's plan to conduct seismic testing off the East Coast, citing harm to marine life and coastal economies. They argue the testing, which involves loud air gun blasts, prioritizes fossil fuel interests over environmental and economic concerns.

title: The Washington Bullpen: A look at Roger Stone
summary: In this episode of "The Washington Bullpen" podcast, host Kate Casey explores the role of Roger Stone, a former Trump adviser, in the Russia investigation. The Department of Justice is set to release a redacted version of Special Counsel Robert Mueller’s report, which addresses Russian interference and potential presidential obstruction.

title: International student enrollment in United States drops, UMD does not follow trend
summary: International student enrollment in the U.S. has declined for the first time in over a decade, with some attributing the drop to Trump administration policies and others pointing to global competition and rising costs.

title: Local author on the challenges to becoming a children’s book author
summary: Priscilla Cummings, a local children's book author with over 30 years of experience, highlights the challenges of entering the publishing world. She speaks out as the controversy surrounding Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh's book scandal continues.

title: Marylanders mourn loss of Speaker Busch
summary: Maryland mourned the loss of former House Speaker Michael Busch at a solemn funeral in Annapolis, where family, friends, and public officials honored his life and legacy. Those who knew him praised his integrity, compassion, and dedication to serving all Marylanders, with loved ones remembering him as a kind, fair, and devoted father and leader.

title: Ruppersberger presses for digital coastal mapping project
summary: Maryland Rep. Dutch Ruppersberger has introduced a bipartisan bill to fund a $4 million digital mapping project for the entire U.S.

title: Baltimore groups and residents use Twitter to discuss extreme weather
summary: Baltimore residents and community groups are using Twitter to share information and coordinate responses to extreme weather events. The social media platform has become a key tool for real-time communication and support during severe weather conditions.

title: Elephants March still draws supporters even after event is canceled
summary: Despite the cancellation of the Elephants March in Washington due to a missing parade permit, a group of activists still gathered to protest the ivory trade and raise awareness. Demonstrators, including PETA members and animal rights advocates, continued the cause by rallying near the Lincoln Memorial and White House, drawing attention from passersby and tourists.

title: Hundreds gather in Annapolis to honor Michael Busch
summary: Hundreds gathered in Annapolis on Monday to honor the late Maryland House Speaker Michael Busch, with politicians, dignitaries, and the public paying their respects at the State House. Gov.

title: Police-involved shooting reported in College Park
summary: A Prince George’s County police officer fired a single shot at a moving vehicle in a College Park Home Depot parking lot after witnessing two men suspected of stealing power tools and a crowbar. The SUV was later pulled over, the driver was arrested, and the vehicle was taken into police custody.

title: Traditional Chinese puppeteer tours Maryland schools sharing the art of his craft with children
summary: A traditional Chinese puppeteer visited Maryland schools to share his art with students. He concluded his tour at Paint Branch Elementary School in College Park.

title: UMD Observatory provides new images of meteor
summary: The University of Maryland's observatory offers students hands-on experience with telescopes and software through long-term research projects. Its efforts have resulted in capturing unique images of the night sky, including new visuals of a meteor.

title: National Harbor residents, visitors say they won’t let terror threat impact them
summary: Residents and visitors at National Harbor say they will not let the terror threat disrupt their daily lives. A man was arrested for allegedly stealing a rental truck with the intent to attack the area.

title: Sarbanes calls insulin-pricing system “hocus pocus”
summary: Rep. John Sarbanes criticized insulin manufacturers for opaque pricing practices, arguing that transparency would prevent manipulation and better protect patients.

title: DC store’s Go-Go music is turned back on after neighborhood protest
summary: A local store in Washington’s Shaw neighborhood played Go-Go music outdoors for nearly 25 years before neighbors protested and temporarily stopped it. Go-Go fans rallied to have the music restored, and it was soon turned back on.

title: Spotlight on DMV Hip-Hop: Oddisee
summary: Oddisee, a DMV-based rapper of African-American and Sudanese descent, uses his music to address social issues and educate audiences through conscious lyrics and dynamic live performances. With a career rooted in meaningful storytelling and a passion for both hip-hop and photography, his influence continues to grow globally.

title: The Washington Bullpen: A look at Felix Sater
summary: Host Kate Casey examines Felix Sater, a former business associate of Donald Trump with a complicated history, on the "Washington Bullpen" podcast. Sater is highlighted as a significant figure in the investigations related to the Trump administration.

title: Remembering Michael Busch, Maryland’s longtime House Speaker
summary: Michael Busch, Maryland’s longest-serving House Speaker, passed away at 72 after a brief illness. A respected figure in state politics for over three decades, he was known for his bipartisan leadership and mentorship.

title: Maryland lawmakers close out 2019 session, honor Speaker Michael Busch
summary: Maryland lawmakers concluded the 2019 legislative session, passing numerous bills on issues ranging from environmental protection to criminal justice reform. During the final day, they honored Speaker Michael Busch for his leadership and service.

title: Final day of General Assembly filled with sorrow as the legislature wraps up
summary: Maryland lawmakers spent the final day of the General Assembly session addressing pressing state issues while keeping House Speaker Michael Busch on their minds. The legislature wrapped up its work amid a somber tone following his recent passing.

title: Baltimore’s Commission on Sustainability says connection between humans’ actions and climate change had “never been stronger”
summary: Baltimore’s Commission on Sustainability has stated that the link between human activities and climate change is now stronger than ever. The commission emphasized the urgent need for action to address the impacts of climate change in the region.

title: Bill would let Queen Anne’s salons, barbers sell alcohol
summary: A new bill in Queen Anne would allow salons and barbershops to sell alcohol. The proposal aims to boost local businesses by expanding their service offerings.

title: Assembly’s final day tempered by mourning of Speaker Busch
summary: Maryland lawmakers and Governor Larry Hogan paused legislative activity on the final day of the General Assembly to mourn the death of House Speaker Mike Busch, who passed away hours before the session ended. Leaders from both parties praised Busch for his decades of public service and commitment to the state.

title: Success, failure, mourning at close of Md. General Assembly
summary: Maryland's General Assembly wrapped up its session with 864 bills passed and mixed successes across party lines, despite the tragic death of House Speaker Mike Busch. Key legislative achievements included education funding and criminal justice reform, while bills on aid-in-dying and gun checks failed, and lawmakers honored Busch in a final joint session.

title: Twitter users have mixed feelings rising popularity of electric scooters and bikes
summary: Uber and Lyft are expanding their services to include electric scooters and bikes, joining companies like Lime and Bird in offering eco-friendly transportation options across multiple U.S. cities.

title: Local paddling group wins battle with government over Potomac River
summary: The Canoe Cruisers Association successfully challenged a security ban that had prevented paddling on the Potomac River during President Trump's golf outings. They were able to return to the river and celebrated their victory.

title: The return of the Orioles gives Baltimore a chance to celebrate
summary: Amid ongoing controversy surrounding Mayor Catherine Pugh's book deals, Baltimore residents turned to cheering for the Orioles at their home opener. The return of the team offered a moment of unity and celebration for the city.

title: Amtrak to make $90 million in renovations to Baltimore station
summary: Amtrak will invest $90 million to modernize Baltimore’s Penn Station, aiming to enhance transit connections and customer experience. The project, led by Penn Station Partners, will include new amenities, expanded parking, and improved walkability for the station, which serves over a million passengers annually.

title: Halting human trafficking requires public to “see the unseen”
summary: Rebecca McDonald of Women at Risk, International emphasized the need for public awareness to combat human trafficking, urging people to "see the unseen" during a training event in Waldorf, Maryland. The program educated church members on identifying trafficking signs, with the goal of increasing community involvement in addressing this global issue.

title: Nats rallying after Turner injury
summary: The Washington Nationals showed resilience by winning two key games following shortstop Trea Turner's broken finger injury, which he suffered from a pitch he deemed too close to his head. Despite the setback, the team remains aware of the significant impact Turner has had and will continue to have on their season.

title: Washington Bullpen: A look at Michael Cohen
summary: In this week's "Washington Bullpen" podcast, host Kate Casey examines Michael Cohen, Donald Trump's former personal attorney, who is set to go to prison but continues cooperating with prosecutors. The discussion comes as the public awaits insights from the Mueller report, which is under review by Attorney General William Barr.

title: Viral Baltimore Drumming Duo to Perform in D.C. Cherry Blossom Festival Parade
summary: A1 Chops, a drumming duo from Baltimore, will perform at the National Cherry Blossom Festival Parade in Washington, D.C., following their viral rise through social media and appearances on "The Ellen DeGeneres Show." Despite early struggles and skepticism, Timothy Fletcher and Malik Perry have turned their busking roots into a national platform, showcasing their talent at one of the country's largest festivals.

title: Large Maryland public-private projects may face delay
summary: New legislation in Maryland could delay large public-private partnership projects, including Governor Hogan’s $9–$11 billion highway expansion plan, by requiring credit checks, environmental assessments, and committee reviews before approval. The bill aims to ensure financial accountability and state protection in high-cost P3 agreements, affecting projects like the I-270 and I-495 widening efforts.

title: New report on the Chesapeake Bay finds encouraging signs
summary: The latest report on the Chesapeake Bay shows improving conditions for several key environmental indicators. This suggests progress in the long-term efforts to restore the health of the bay and its watershed.

title: HHS initiative aims to prevent new cases of HIV in Maryland and other “trouble spots”
summary: The US Department of Health and Human Services is collaborating with local health departments to diagnose and prevent new HIV cases in Maryland and other high-risk areas. The initiative targets three HIV hot spots in Maryland: Baltimore City, Prince George’s County, and Montgomery County.

title: State Comptroller calls for resignation of Baltimore mayor
summary: Maryland Comptroller Peter Franchot called for Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh’s resignation amid an investigation into a children’s book controversy. He questioned how legislative leaders on the University of Maryland Medical System’s board could have been unaware of potential improprieties.

title: Baltimore businesses brace for possible Preakness move
summary: The Preakness Stakes may move from Pimlico Race Course in Baltimore to Laurel Park in 2021, raising concerns about the economic impact on local businesses and prompting opposition from city officials. Despite legal efforts and political pushback, the relocation appears increasingly likely, threatening one of the city's most profitable annual events for restaurants and bars.

title: After Wow Air closes, critics see flaws in U.S. regulation
summary: The sudden collapse of Wow Air left passengers stranded and sparked criticism of U.S. regulators for allowing a financially unstable foreign airline to operate without ongoing oversight.

title: Franchot condemns consultant firm examining UMMS dealings
summary: Maryland Comptroller Peter Franchot criticized Nygren Consulting for its lack of independence and effectiveness in reviewing University of Maryland Medical System's board dealings, including those involving Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh. Pugh, who received $500,000 for a book deal with the system, has taken a leave of absence amid the controversy.

title: A new way to relax at the Maryland Zoo with yoga and penguins
summary: Yoga enthusiasts can now enjoy a vinyasa-style class at the Maryland Zoo in Baltimore. The unique session offers a relaxing workout with an up-close view of African penguins.

title: Former Terp, Ravens football player continues to provide support to Baltimore residents
summary: Former Terp and Ravens player Torrey Smith hosted his 8th annual charity basketball game in Baltimore to support local youth. The event, part of his Torrey Smith Family Fund, raises money to help students in the city's schools.

title: Continuing the fight for pay equality on Equal Pay Day
summary: Legislators and advocates gathered on Capitol Hill on Equal Pay Day to support the Paycheck Fairness Act, which was recently passed in the House. The bill seeks to address wage disparities by closing existing pay loopholes.

title: In tribute to Henrietta Lacks, Maryland Democrats ask study on cancer trials access
summary: Maryland Democrats have introduced legislation to honor Henrietta Lacks by studying barriers that prevent underrepresented groups from participating in government-funded cancer clinical trials. The bill aims to ensure broader representation in cancer research, addressing disparities highlighted by Lacks' own unrecognized contribution to medical science.

title: Baseball Twitter buzzes about Orioles’ surprising start, Harper being booed
summary: The Baltimore Orioles have surprised fans with a strong 4-1 start to the 2019 season, including a series win over the Yankees. Meanwhile, the Washington Nationals have struggled, winning just one of their first four games at home, and Bryce Harper faced boos during his return to Nationals Park with the Phillies.

title: Springtime “blooming” underway in the nation’s capital
summary: Washington’s cherry blossom trees are in full bloom, drawing visitors from around the world to enjoy this iconic springtime attraction. Gifted to the U.S.

title: Acting Baltimore mayor draws lawmakers’ optimism, support
summary: Acting Baltimore Mayor Bernard "Jack" Young received support from local lawmakers after stepping in following Mayor Catherine Pugh's temporary leave due to health and legal scrutiny over book sales. While Young committed to leading the city through the transition, officials avoided commenting on Pugh's potential return, emphasizing the need for focus on key issues.

title: Hoyer calls April Fools on Trump’s health care reform plan
summary: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer dismissed President Trump's claims of an imminent healthcare reform bill, calling it an April Fools' joke and predicting it will not materialize before the 2020 election. Trump’s renewed push for healthcare legislation has drawn criticism from Republicans and faced resistance in the Senate, where leaders say they will not pursue repeal efforts with a Democratic-controlled House.

title: Annapolis fantasy role-play group seeks new recruits for battle re-enactments
summary: An Annapolis-based group is recruiting new members for Dagorhir, a full-contact fantasy roleplay battle game using foam weapons, inspired by medieval and fantasy themes. The activity, which originated 47 years ago and has grown to over 50 chapters nationwide, offers participants a chance to live out their fantasy battle dreams in a safe, organized environment.

title: Annapolis-based nonprofit seeks funds to make sailing more accessible
summary: An Annapolis-based nonprofit, Chesapeake Region Accessible Boating, is seeking funds to build a new adaptive boating center to better serve people with disabilities, veterans, and at-risk youth. The center would provide more space, accessibility, and improved facilities for sailing lessons and activities.

title: Gypsy jazz fans jam in Takoma Park
summary: In Takoma Park, a monthly Gypsy jazz jam brings together musicians at the VFW, offering an open, improvisational space for fans of jazz Manouche. These events, rooted in the legacy of Django Reinhardt, highlight the town's vibrant music culture and the community's passion for this unique style.

title: BWI-Marshall Airport hit by shutdown of international budget airline
summary: WOW Airlines abruptly went out of business, causing disruptions for passengers at BWI-Marshall Airport and leaving many stranded. A Baltimore woman reported being on what may have been the last WOW flight into the airport.

title: Local Special Olympian’s family worries about possible loss of federal funding
summary: Desiree Holland, a 48-year-old Special Olympics champion from Hyattsville, Maryland, has competed since she was 8. Her mother expresses concern over the potential impact of losing federal funding on the program.

title: House and Senate override Governor’s veto of minimum wage increase
summary: Maryland’s House and Senate quickly overrode Governor Hogan’s veto of a $15 minimum wage bill less than 24 hours after it was rejected. The law will raise the minimum wage to $11 an hour in 2020, with a final increase to $15 by 2026.

title: Washington County senior hand crochets thousands of caps for newborns
summary: Doris Bender, an 80-year-old from Sharpsburg, Maryland, has been crocheting personalized caps for newborns at a local hospital since 2016. Over 2,000 babies have received her handmade hats to take home.

title: Hopeful fans turn out for the start of the Nationals season
summary: Fans gathered at Nationals Park for the start of the season, drawn by the excitement of Opening Day. They enjoyed ballpark classics and a standout pitching matchup.

title: Oldest Living African American B&O employee recalls life on the railroad
summary: Maggie Hudson, the oldest living African American B&O Railroad employee, is set to turn 100 and still remembers her historic role with the company. Her memories highlight an important milestone in the railroad's history and the contributions of African American workers.

title: Supreme Court hears arguments in Maryland gerrymandering case
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court heard arguments in a long-standing gerrymandering case involving Maryland’s Sixth Congressional District.

title: Maryland House votes to reprimand Delegate Jay Jalisi
summary: The Maryland House of Delegates reprimanded Delegate Jay Jalisi following a 16-page ethics report that detailed an ongoing pattern of bullying and abusive workplace behavior. The vote occurred two days after the report was released.

title: Liberians seek extension of program to allow their legal stay in the U.S. to continue
summary: The Deferred Enforced Departure program, allowing Liberians to legally stay in the U.S., is set to expire on March 31. Liberians and supporters are urging President Trump to extend the program.

title: Local non-profit making a difference for many Maryland classrooms
summary: A local non-profit in Maryland is helping families by providing school supplies, easing the burden of choosing between essentials like food and educational materials. They are making a difference one pencil at a time in classrooms across the state.

title: Legislation seeks increase in education funding according to recommendations from the Kirwan Commission
summary: Lawmakers in Maryland are urging the General Assembly to approve a funding plan based on the Kirwan Commission's "Blueprint for Maryland’s Future." The legislation aims to improve the state's school system by providing students with better resources for college and career success.

title: Ex-offenders seek second chance in the workforce
summary: Ex-offenders in Maryland are advocating for changes to job applications by removing questions about criminal history. They gathered in Annapolis on the National Day of Empathy to lobby lawmakers for a fairer chance in the workforce.

title: Supporters say Clean Energy Jobs Act could bring thousands of clean energy jobs to Maryland
summary: Senator Brian Feldman's Clean Energy Jobs Act aims to create up to 20,000 clean energy jobs in Maryland by setting targets for renewable energy. The legislation requires 50% renewable energy by 2030 and 100% by 2040.

title: Star safety calls playing for Washington his “dream”
summary: Washington signed safety Landon Collins to a six-year, $84 million contract, fulfilling his dream of playing for the team while leaving behind the New York Giants, who had previously given him his NFL start. Collins, a three-time Pro Bowler and former Alabama standout, aims to help Washington return to playoff contention.

title: Maryland House votes to approve hike in the minimum wage
summary: The Maryland House has voted to approve a plan to increase the state’s minimum wage to $15 per hour by 2025. The legislation now moves to the next stage of the approval process.

title: Climate change threatens flooding and hurts crabbing in Maryland
summary: Climate change is contributing to severe flooding in Maryland and increasing the acidity of the Chesapeake Bay. These changes threaten both coastal communities and marine life, including the crab population.

title: Maryland House of Delegates overrides Hogan veto of school start date bill
summary: Maryland's House of Delegates voted to override Governor Larry Hogan’s veto of a bill allowing schools to start before Labor Day, joining the Senate in reversing his 2016 executive order. The override marks the third veto override this week, as lawmakers also reversed vetoes on minimum wage and alcohol regulation bills.

title: Doctor assisted suicide bill fails in state senate
summary: A bill allowing terminally ill patients to seek doctor-assisted suicide failed in the Maryland Senate after a tie vote. The legislation had passed the House but was heavily amended in a Senate committee before ultimately being defeated.

title: Discount carrier Wow Air shutters, leaving BWI passengers stranded
summary: Discount airline Wow Air abruptly ceased operations, canceling all flights and leaving passengers stranded at airports in Maryland and other U.S. locations.

title: Md. legislators vote to override Gov. Hogan’s bill vetoes
summary: Maryland legislators overrode Gov. Larry Hogan’s veto of two bills, including one to gradually raise the minimum wage to $15 by 2025 and another to transfer alcohol and tobacco regulation from the state comptroller.

title: Modern 9-1-1 system will increase state and local fees
summary: Maryland legislators passed a bill to modernize the 9-1-1 system by increasing fees to fund cybersecurity, technology upgrades, and staffing, as part of the Next Generation 9-1-1 initiative. Named Carl Henn’s Law, the legislation aims to improve emergency response through text, photo, and video capabilities and address system failures that contributed to past tragedies.

title: Maryland may expand electric vehicle tax credits
summary: Maryland may expand its electric vehicle tax credit to $3,000 per vehicle, applying only to fully electric models and increasing the annual funding cap to $6 million for fiscal year 2020. The proposed Clean Cars Act of 2019 aims to encourage more residents to purchase zero-emission vehicles by combining state and federal incentives.

title: Spotlight on DMV Hip-Hop: O-Slice
summary: O-Slice, a 24-year-old University of Maryland alum, is emerging as one of the most technically gifted MCs in the DMV hip-hop scene. Known for her meticulous approach to music and live performances, she also writes and directs her own music videos, showcasing her multifaceted artistry.

title: Maryland native nominated to be next Marine Corps commandant
summary: Lt. Gen.

title: Delegate Jay Jalisi unanimously reprimanded by House
summary: The Maryland House unanimously reprimanded Delegate Jay Jalisi for allegedly abusive behavior toward staff, including incidents of bullying and yelling, as detailed in a joint ethics committee report. Jalisi denied the allegations, calling the report a "political hit job," and has not completed recommended anger management and civility programs.

title: A beginner’s guide to bubble tea
summary: Bubble tea, originating from Taiwan in the 1980s, has gained widespread popularity for its chewy tapioca pearls and customizable flavors. It is both a cultural connection for many and a social experience, with places like Kung Fu Tea offering a reliable and diverse selection.

title: Maryland’s growing tourism industry gears up for warm season
summary: Maryland's tourism industry is preparing for the warm season as visitation continues to grow, with over 40 million visitors in 2015 generating significant tax revenue for the state. Popular destinations like National Harbor and Eastern Shore are promoting themselves through social media to attract leisure travelers.

title: Baltimore County delegate faces possible reprimand for workplace bullying
summary: A report from the Maryland General Assembly’s Joint Committee on Legislative Ethics recommends reprimanding Baltimore County Delegate Jay Jalisi for abusive workplace behavior. The recommendation follows allegations of workplace bullying.

title: Supreme Court hears arguments on Maryland, North Carolina redistricting
summary: The Supreme Court heard arguments on redistricting cases from Maryland and North Carolina, with questions about whether partisan gerrymandering violates the Constitution and if a manageable standard can be established. The court appeared divided, with liberal justices favoring clearer guidelines and conservative justices emphasizing state control and rejecting mandatory proportional representation.

title: Maryland voters rally to support gerrymandering case
summary: Maryland voters and political leaders gathered at the Supreme Court to support a gerrymandering case challenging the redrawing of the state’s 6th Congressional District. The case, along with a similar one from North Carolina, raises questions about the fairness and constitutionality of partisan and racial gerrymandering.

title: Terps’ loss to LSU one of March Madness’ best games this tournament
summary: In a thrilling 2019 NCAA Tournament game, Maryland made a dramatic second-half comeback against LSU but ultimately lost when LSU's Tremont Waters hit a game-winning layup with 1.6 seconds left. The victory sparked controversy as some observers claimed Waters committed a traveling violation on the play.

title: Reporter took a picture of a resort and ended up in Turkmen prison
summary: A journalist for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, Saparmamed Nepeskuliev, was imprisoned in Turkmenistan for three years after taking photos of a government resort, enduring torture, solitary confinement, and forced sleep deprivation. He is one of five RFE/RL reporters jailed in Turkmenistan in the past four years for their work.

title: Ukraine rebels hold U.S.-funded reporter nearly two years
summary: Ukrainian journalist Stanislav Aseyev, employed by U.S.-funded Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, has been held captive by Russian-backed separatists in Donbas since 2017, with his forced confession broadcast to deter other journalists from reporting in the region. The number of RFE/RL journalists imprisoned, killed, or assaulted has increased, highlighting growing dangers for media workers in the area.

title: Brother was imprisoned in Uzbekistan to silence journalist
summary: Aziz Yusupov, imprisoned in Uzbekistan on fabricated drug charges, was targeted by authorities to pressure his brother, journalist Farruh Yusupov, into ceasing corruption reports from abroad. Despite Uzbekistan's recent release of political prisoners, the case highlights ongoing government efforts to silence dissent, even against those linked to U.S.-funded media outlets like Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty.

title: She digs into corruption as Ukraine targets possible sources
summary: Natalia Sedletska, an award-winning journalist with Radio Free Europe, has exposed high-level corruption in Ukraine, prompting government investigations but also drawing threats and legal actions aimed at intimidating her and her sources. A recent attempt by Ukrainian prosecutors to obtain her cell phone records set a troubling precedent, undermining journalist-source confidentiality and discouraging whistleblowers.

title: U.S.-funded journalist: Each day we kiss our kids goodbye
summary: A suicide bombing in Kabul on April 30, 2018, killed 31 civilians, including 10 journalists, marking the deadliest attack on media in Afghanistan’s history. Three of the victims were from U.S.-funded Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, an outlet once created by the CIA but now independent and crucial to Afghan journalism amid rising threats from the Taliban and Islamic State.

title: It’s hard to learn when classrooms are cold
summary: Cold classrooms make it difficult for students to concentrate and learn effectively. Maintaining a comfortable temperature in schools is essential for supporting student performance and well-being.

title: Baltimore mayor signs new clean air standards
summary: Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh signed a bill to tighten emissions standards at the city's two trash incinerators, aiming to improve air quality in one of the nation's most polluted urban areas. The new regulations could lead to the closure of Wheelabrator Baltimore, the region's largest incinerator, due to its inability to meet the stricter standards, sparking concerns over job losses and economic impact.

title: Cold War’s Radio Free Europe Now Beacon of Independent News: Its Reporters Killed, Assaulted, Imprisoned, Even by U.S. Allies
summary: Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty, originally a CIA-funded Cold War propaganda tool, now serves as a leading source of independent news in Europe and Central Asia. Despite U.S.

title: Maryland may raise smoking age to 21, limit vape marketing
summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering raising the legal age to purchase tobacco and vape products to 21 and banning marketing tactics that target minors, such as cartoon characters and child-friendly packaging. The proposed measures aim to reduce youth vaping and smoking by limiting access and curbing age-specific advertising.

title: Bills would fund HIV prevention, tracking, testing rape kits
summary: Bills in Maryland aim to improve privacy protections for sexual assault victims and extend the reimbursement period for rape kit testing, ensuring more victims can access care beyond the current five-day window. The legislation, backed by a 2017 committee's recommendations, also seeks to streamline the processing of sexual assault evidence kits by law enforcement.

title: Spokesman for Anthony Brown ‘confident’ he will seek re-election
summary: Democratic Rep. Anthony Brown has over $517,000 in campaign funds and is expected to seek re-election in 2020.

title: Maryland redistricting case to be heard in Supreme Court
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court will hear a Maryland congressional redistricting case to determine if the state's 6th District was gerrymandered to benefit Democrats.

title: Democrats seek billions of dollars with small Wall Street tax
summary: Democrats have proposed the Wall Street Tax Act of 2019, which would impose a 0.01% tax on financial transactions to raise over $776 billion over 10 years and curb speculative trading. While supporters argue it would benefit the broader economy, opponents claim it could harm retirement savings and financial markets.

title: Washington Wizards hanging around in battle for eighth seed
summary: The Washington Wizards improved their playoff chances with a 100-90 win over the Orlando Magic, moving them closer to the eighth seed in the Eastern Conference. Key contributions from the bench, including 21 points from Thomas Bryant, helped the Wizards, who now trail the Miami Heat by 3.5 games in the race for the final playoff spot.

title: The Washington Bullpen: A look at Michael Flynn
summary: In this week's "The Washington Bullpen," host Kate Casey examines the role of former national security adviser Michael Flynn in the Trump administration scandals. A recent court filing indicates that Flynn's cooperation with the Mueller investigation has concluded, though he remains available to assist law enforcement.

title: A Conversation With Allison Gost Breitenother
summary: Allison Gost Breitenother discusses her journey in the tech industry, highlighting the importance of mentorship and diversity. She emphasizes the need for inclusive leadership to drive innovation and foster growth in the sector.

title: Climate change is theme of Environmental Film Festival
summary: The 27th annual Environmental Film Festival in Washington, D.C., highlights climate change through over 100 films, including world premieres and award-winning documentaries. This year’s event, partnering with National Geographic, showcases environmental stories of resilience and action in response to urgent global climate challenges.

title: Bills would permit high school voter registration in Maryland
summary: Two bills in Maryland aim to allow high school students and staff to register to vote at their schools, with materials to be submitted to election officials within five days. The legislation, supported by youth advocates, seeks to boost youth voter turnout and civic engagement.

title: Critics hit Trump administration over information backlog, delays
summary: Congressional critics accused the Trump administration of delaying and blocking the release of public information, violating the law's presumption of openness. Despite the 2016 FOIA Improvement Act, agencies have failed to meet response deadlines, leading to a worsening backlog of requests.

title: Enjoy these warm weather activities in Maryland
summary: Maryland offers a variety of affordable spring activities, including hiking the Billy Goat Trail and viewing the Great Falls waterfall in Potomac. The 4.7-mile trail through the Chesapeake & Ohio Canal National Historical Park provides scenic overlooks and challenges for outdoor enthusiasts.

title: New Amur tiger at the Smithsonian’s National Zoo
summary: The Smithsonian National Zoo has welcomed a 6-year-old Amur tiger, Nikita, as part of a conservation effort to increase the critically endangered subspecies' population through breeding. Nikita will be introduced to an existing male Amur tiger, Pavel, in hopes of producing offspring, following recommendations from the AZA's Species Survival Plan.

title: Dining on free pancakes for a good cause
summary: A College Park restaurant participated in National Pancake Day by offering free buttermilk pancakes to dine-in customers. In exchange, guests were encouraged to donate to charities supporting children with serious illnesses.

title: Organ donation could be taught in Md. schools
summary: Maryland legislators are pushing bills to teach high school students about organ donation and provide unpaid leave for living donors. The efforts aim to increase donor registration and awareness to address long transplant waiting lists in the state.

title: House Democrats introduce bill to protect undocumented immigrants
summary: House Democrats introduced the Dream and Promise Act to provide a path to permanent residency for approximately 3.6 million undocumented immigrants, including DREAMers and recipients of temporary protections. The bill aims to counter Trump administration policies ending programs like DACA, TRS, and DED, while halting removal proceedings for affected individuals.

title: Bill would give some Md. students free eyeglasses and exams
summary: A new Maryland bill would provide free eye exams and glasses to public school students who fail vision screenings and lack access to recommended services, aiming to improve learning outcomes by ensuring students can see the classroom clearly. The legislation, sponsored by state lawmakers, would create the Vision for Maryland Program in partnership with Johns Hopkins University and local education and health departments.

title: #ReadAcrossAmerica campaign celebrates reading and literacy
summary: The #ReadAcrossAmerica campaign, held annually around Dr. Seuss' birthday, promotes reading motivation and literacy with participation from schools, celebrities, and organizations worldwide.

title: Maryland’s small but engaged wine industry celebrates third annual wine month
summary: Maryland's wine industry, though smaller than Virginia's, celebrates its rich history and growth with the third annual Maryland Wine Month in March. Wineries across the state are promoting local wines through events and social media under the hashtag #MarylandWineMonth.

title: Critics see toothpaste boxes as threat to environment
summary: Critics argue that toothpaste boxes contribute to environmental harm through deforestation and waste, despite claims that paperboard is sourced sustainably and has high recycling rates. The controversy highlights ongoing issues with recycling contamination and the need for more eco-friendly packaging solutions.

title: Washington trades for another quarterback
summary: Washington has acquired quarterback Case Keenum from the Denver Broncos in a low-risk trade, sending a 2020 sixth-round pick and receiving a seventh-rounder. The move adds depth to Washington's quarterback room while Denver saves $14.5 million in cap space.

title: Maryland House votes to approve assisted suicide legislation
summary: The Maryland House approved assisted suicide legislation for the terminally ill in a 76-64 vote. The bill now moves to the Senate for further consideration.

title: Former offender bakes his way to a new life
summary: Former prisoner Gregory Carpenter has turned his life around by founding 2 AM Bakery in Baltimore. Through his "Eye Can B-More" initiative, he aims to help other formerly incarcerated individuals re-enter the workforce.

title: Prince George’s initiative aims to help men stop domestic violence
summary: Prince George’s County has launched The Men’s Challenge to raise awareness about domestic violence and encourage men to discuss their personal experiences. The initiative aims to prevent violence by fostering open dialogue and promoting positive behavior.

title: Cummings seeks answers on Trump administration’s response to drug crisis
summary: Elijah Cummings, chairman of the House Oversight and Reform Committee, criticized the Trump administration's handling of the drug crisis during a hearing with the head of the Office of National Drug Control Policy. He called for greater accountability and a more effective federal response to the ongoing public health emergency.

title: Nationals fans turn in Bryce Harper shirts for a shot of goodwill
summary: Washington Nationals fans can now exchange their Bryce Harper merchandise at a D.C. business for a chance to support others.

title: Maryland voters maintain high approval of Hogan
summary: Republican Governor Larry Hogan maintains high approval among Maryland voters, according to the latest Gonzales Poll, despite governing in a predominantly Democratic state. The poll also assessed public opinion on issues like a minimum wage increase and President Trump's border wall.

title: Local non-profit sells jewelry to benefit dog rescues
summary: Pearls for Pups, a local Maryland non-profit, sells jewelry with 100% of proceeds going to dog rescue shelters. The group has already raised nearly $60,000, aiming to reach $100,000 in the coming years.

title: County Execs, Baltimore Mayor join in call for drug affordability board
summary: Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh and county executives from Howard, Harford, and Anne Arundel Counties are urging state lawmakers to pass legislation establishing a Prescription Drug Affordability Board. The initiative aims to reduce the cost of prescription drugs and was launched alongside a social media campaign.

title: Peak bloom date set for Washington’s cherry blossoms
summary: The 2024 peak bloom date for Washington’s cherry blossoms has been announced, marking the highlight of the annual festival. Local officials shared the date alongside details of events planned for the celebration.

title: Bill eliminates subjectivity surrounding threats of mass violence
summary: Maryland lawmakers have passed emergency legislation to streamline the prosecution of threats of mass violence, removing the need to identify five individuals in fear of harm. The bill, now advancing in the House, aims to address challenges posed by social media threats by focusing on the potential risk to five or more people if the threat were carried out.

title: Coding classes would count as foreign language under bill
summary: A Maryland bill with bipartisan support would allow students to take computer programming classes to fulfill foreign language requirements, aiming to expand tech education and career opportunities. While supporters highlight benefits for students with diverse learning abilities and the potential for high-paying jobs, opponents argue it could limit cultural understanding and college readiness.

title: Maryland House passes drug-aided death bill
summary: The Maryland House passed a bill allowing terminally ill patients to end their lives with prescribed medication, requiring three consents and excluding euthanasia or coercion. Opponents raised religious, moral, and ethical concerns, while supporters emphasized patient choice and personal experiences with terminal illness.

title: We’re analyzing data to explain connections between temperature, health and neighborhoods in Baltimore
summary: Researchers are examining data to uncover links between temperature, health outcomes, and neighborhood characteristics in Baltimore. The study aims to better understand how environmental factors impact public health across different communities.

title: Maryland legislative leaders announce plans for education funding
summary: Maryland legislators announced "The Blueprint for Maryland’s Future," a bill aiming to boost teacher salaries, improve training, and provide free prekindergarten for low-income children. The plan, backed by a $325 million to $750 million investment over two years, seeks to enhance education outcomes through career readiness standards and early college opportunities.

title: Md. legislators push for increase in renewable energy, jobs
summary: Maryland legislators are pushing to increase the state’s renewable energy standards to 50% by 2030 and 100% by 2040, with a focus on solar and offshore wind energy, while also aiming to boost job creation in the sector. The proposed legislation, Senate Bill 516 and House Bill 1158, has drawn significant public interest and support, despite previous stalled efforts and challenges related to leadership changes in the House.

title: Preparedness is key to mitigating upcoming hurricane damage, experts say
summary: Experts emphasize that effective hurricane forecasts, updated building practices, and individual preparedness are crucial for reducing hurricane damage. Investing in pre-disaster mitigation and promoting green, hazard-resistant construction can significantly lessen both physical and financial impacts.

title: Maryland could allow people to use EBT cards at restaurants
summary: Maryland legislators are considering a bill that would allow certain low-income individuals to use their EBT cards at restaurants, following similar programs in other states. A related bill also passed the House of Delegates to increase oversight of the WIC nutrition program for women and children.

title: Trying to stay warm in Oliver
summary: Residents in Oliver are struggling to stay warm as a severe cold snap grips the area. Authorities urge people to take precautions to avoid frostbite and hypothermia.

title: Hagerstown crossing guard wins national honors
summary: Sara Mason, a Hagerstown crossing guard, has dedicated 50 years to helping schoolchildren cross the street safely. Her efforts earned her a finalist spot for the annual America’s Best Crossing Guard Award.

title: Polynesian dancing helps one woman with overcoming health challenges
summary: A Maryland woman has found physical and emotional healing through years of participating in Polynesian dancing with Meki’s Tamure Polynesian Arts Group. The group provides a tropical escape and supportive community, helping her regain control of her life despite health challenges.

title: Coast Guard lieutenant appears in U.S. federal court on drug, gun charges
summary: Coast Guard Lieutenant Christopher Hasson appeared in U.S. federal court in Maryland on drug and gun charges following his arrest in February 2019.

title: Senate committee hears testimony on regulations for shotguns and rifles
summary: A survivor and widow of the Annapolis Capital-Gazette shooting testified before a Senate committee in support of new regulations on shotgun and rifle sales. The NRA and 2A Maryland opposed the proposal, arguing that long guns are not a major source of crime weapons in the state.

title: Maryland lawmakers looking to increase the age to buy tobacco products
summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering legislation to raise the minimum age for purchasing tobacco products from 18 to 21. If passed, Maryland would join six other states in implementing this age increase.

title: Howard County couple marks a marriage milestone and a first in Columbia
summary: Madelaine and William Lamb celebrated over 50 years of marriage. Their anniversary also marked a historic first for the city of Columbia, as they broke barriers as a pioneering couple.

title: Howard County unveils plan to curb youth suicide
summary: Howard County is launching a comprehensive plan to address youth suicide by increasing awareness, reducing stigma, and focusing on prevention. The initiative was partly inspired by a local mother's personal loss and her subsequent call to action.

title: Calvert County high school helps uncover a piece of Baltimore’s past
summary: Students from Calvert County High School helped uncover a piece of Baltimore's history tied to the post-Civil War era at the site of the current Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond. The discovery links the location to the period when African American slaves were freed.

title: House aiming to mandate funding for Maryland HBCUs
summary: The Maryland House of Delegates is set to hold a hearing on legislation requiring the governor to allocate over $16 million annually to each of the state's four historically Black universities starting in 2021. The move comes amid ongoing legal battles and settlement talks over a 13-year lawsuit alleging systemic underfunding compared to traditionally white institutions.

title: Bills would strip regulatory power and contributions from Franchot
summary: Two bills in Maryland aim to transfer regulatory authority over alcohol, tobacco, and motor fuels from Comptroller Peter Franchot to a new commission and restrict industry donations to him. Franchot opposes the move, calling it a "political stunt," and warns it could jeopardize a $750 million tobacco settlement.

title: Metro’s current hours stand, board plans to address riders’ other concerns instead
summary: The Metro Board of Directors voted to keep current late-night service hours despite pressure to extend them, choosing instead to focus on other rider concerns like fares and rail extensions. Original late-night hours are set to resume in July 2020 without further board action.

title: Maryland lawmakers look to increase the age to buy tobacco products
summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering a bill to raise the minimum age for purchasing tobacco products from 18 to 21. If passed, Maryland would become the seventh state to implement such a change.

title: Supreme Court hears oral arguments for Bladensburg Peace Cross case
summary: The Supreme Court heard oral arguments in a case concerning a 40-foot World War I monument in Bladensburg, which has been at the center of a years-long legal battle over its removal from public property. The lawsuit challenges whether the religious symbol on public land violates the Establishment Clause.

title: Caps win back-to-back games after deadline deals
summary: The Washington Capitals secured a 7-2 victory over the Ottawa Senators, extending their winning streak to two games with strong secondary scoring following key deadline-day acquisitions. Despite a slow start, the team rallied behind contributions from multiple players, including a power-play goal from John Carlson, and showed improved effort under coach Todd Reirden's guidance.

title: Former Trump attorney Michael Cohen testifies before House Oversight Committee
summary: Michael Cohen, former Trump attorney, testified under oath before the House Oversight Committee, discussing the president's alleged involvement in improper activities. He was also scheduled to testify privately the next day before the House Intelligence Committee.

title: Spotlight on DMV Hip-Hop: Rico Nasty
summary: Rico Nasty, a bold and unapologetic artist from Prince George’s County, has signed with Atlantic Records while maintaining her unique style and voice. Her rising success, including a Coachella performance and praise from notable rappers, highlights her impact on the hip-hop scene.

title: High court hears arguments over future of Bladensburg Peace Cross
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court heard arguments over whether a 40-foot Christian cross in Maryland violates the Constitution, with justices appearing divided on whether it is a religious symbol or a secular war memorial.

title: Cohen pulls back curtain on Trump, accuses him of crimes in Oval Office
summary: Michael Cohen, former lawyer to President Donald Trump, accused him of committing crimes during a public hearing before the House Oversight Committee, including prior knowledge of WikiLeaks' release of DNC emails in 2016 and directing payments to Stormy Daniels to ensure her silence before the election. While Cohen denied direct knowledge of Russian collusion, he claimed Trump's eldest son informed him about setting up a meeting with a Russian lawyer during the campaign.

title: Local woman provides help to others dealing with domestic violence
summary: Yaneth Sical, a Prince George’s County resident, opened her own crafts store partly to support women in Guatemala who are victims of domestic violence. Her decision was inspired by a trip to her home country.

title: Maryland resident nears completion of historic National Parks tour
summary: Mikah Meyer, a Maryland resident, is nearing the end of a three-year journey to visit all 418 national parks in the U.S. His mission aims to make history while honoring his late father's memory.

title: Advocates prepare for Supreme Court hearing on Maryland’s Bladensburg Peace Cross
summary: The Bladensburg Peace Cross, a 40-foot Christian symbol on government land in Maryland, is being challenged as a violation of the separation of church and state. The Supreme Court will hear oral arguments on whether the monument is a secular tribute to veterans or an endorsement of Christianity.

title: House Democrats introduce bill to fight voter suppression
summary: House Democrats, led by Majority Leader Steny Hoyer, have introduced a bill aimed at combating voter suppression they claim resulted from a 2013 Supreme Court decision. The legislation seeks to strengthen voting regulations in response to what lawmakers describe as increased discrimination.

title: Maryland lawmakers back sweeping education overhaul plan
summary: Maryland lawmakers support a major education reform plan aimed at improving public schools, addressing issues like underfunding in low-income areas, teacher turnover, and expanding early childhood and career education. The commission behind the plan is seeking $3.8 billion in funding to be implemented over ten years, with legislative action expected in the coming year.

title: House Democrats introduce bill to combat voter suppression
summary: House Democrats introduced a bill to restore federal oversight of voting rights in states with histories of discrimination, in response to the 2013 Supreme Court decision that weakened the Voting Rights Act. The legislation aims to address voter suppression tactics, such as closing polling locations and purging voter rolls, which supporters argue have disproportionately affected minority communities.

title: High court to hear arguments Wednesday on Bladensburg Peace Cross
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court will hear arguments on whether a 40-foot cross in Maryland, erected as a World War I memorial, violates the First Amendment's establishment clause.

title: Md. launches mobile wellness vehicle to combat addictions
summary: Maryland has launched a mobile wellness vehicle to provide accessible treatment and support for individuals struggling with substance use disorders, particularly in Anne Arundel County. The initiative aims to reduce barriers to care by offering clinical services, education, and recovery resources from a specially equipped bus staffed by healthcare professionals.

title: Bill would prevent toll roads without county approval
summary: A proposed Maryland bill would require county approval before toll roads can be built, potentially delaying Gov. Hogan’s $9 billion plan to reduce traffic congestion.

title: $15 minimum wage bills under consideration in legislature
summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering legislation to raise the state's minimum wage to $15 per hour by 2023, with supporters arguing it would help workers afford basic needs and boost productivity. However, opponents, including Governor Larry Hogan, warn it could lead to job losses and higher costs for businesses.

title: Support, concern for Maryland’s 4th try at aid-in-dying bill
summary: A Maryland bill aims to allow terminally ill individuals to end their lives with a lethal dose of prescribed medicine, requiring multiple consents and medical evaluations. Supporters argue it provides dignity and control, while opponents express concerns over public safety, with similar laws already in place in several U.S.

title: Maryland could begin issuing digital driver’s licenses
summary: Maryland is considering legislation to allow the issuance of digital driver’s licenses through a mobile app that provides varying levels of information depending on the requester. While the digital license would not replace physical licenses entirely, concerns remain about compatibility with existing ID scanning technologies used by some businesses.

title: Engaging audiences and connecting with communities through social media
summary: The article discusses how organizations can effectively engage audiences and build stronger community connections through strategic use of social media. It highlights the importance of authentic interaction, timely content, and platform-specific approaches to foster meaningful engagement.

title: Maryland businesses on display at local culinary festival
summary: Maryland businesses showcased their products at a sold-out Chocolate, Wine & Whiskey festival in Washington, D.C., featuring vendors like DMVPopcorn Heaven, Chocolibrium, and Mason’s Lobster Rolls. The event highlighted local and international food and drink offerings, drawing crowds with unlimited tastings and specialty items.

title: First female NAHL president hopes for ‘hometown’ team in Md.
summary: Robyn Remick, the first female president in the North American Hockey League, aims to build the Maryland Black Bears into central Maryland's "hometown" team. With a background in sales and marketing from Disney and ESPN, she focuses on fan engagement and supporting billet families who host players.

title: Medical cannabis is a high priority in Md. legislature
summary: Maryland legislators are advancing multiple bills to expand medical cannabis access, including edible products, inmate treatment, and workplace privacy protections. Sponsored by Sen.

title: Katsucon 2019 created a world of fantastical characters
summary: At Katsucon 2019, thousands of fans gathered in Maryland to celebrate anime and pop culture through elaborate cosplay and art. The event featured immersive character portrayals and vendors showcasing handmade memorabilia, highlighting the community's passion for creative expression.
