title: Coast Guard lieutenant charged with targeting lawmakers, media, held without bail
summary: A Coast Guard lieutenant, Christopher Hasson, has been charged with illegal firearm possession and drug offenses, and is being held without bail amid allegations of planning to attack Democratic politicians and media figures. Federal authorities seized 15 firearms and evidence of drug use from his home, citing a significant threat to public safety.

title: Building sensors to help communities in Baltimore
summary: Baltimore communities are being equipped with new building sensors to monitor environmental conditions and improve safety. The initiative aims to provide real-time data to help residents and officials respond to potential hazards.

title: Maryland lawmakers looking to increase transparency in the USM Board of Regents
summary: Maryland lawmakers are proposing a bill to increase transparency within the University of Maryland System Board of Regents. The bill aims to add members and implement changes to make the board's operations more open.

title: State senate hears testimony on doctor-assisted suicide
summary: The Maryland Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee heard testimony on a bill that would permit physician-assisted suicide under specific conditions. The legislation previously underwent a hearing in a House committee last week.

title: Preparations underway for latest winter storm
summary: The State Highway Administration in Maryland began preparing roads several days ahead of the latest winter storm. Residents also stocked up on snow removal supplies in anticipation of up to six inches of snow.

title: Md. bill seeks to prohibit using DNA databases to solve crime
summary: A Maryland legislator has proposed a bill to prohibit the use of consumer genealogical DNA databases for solving crimes through familial DNA matches, following the arrest of the Golden State Killer using such a technique. Maryland and the District of Columbia are the only jurisdictions in the U.S.

title: Photos, private information to be blocked under 9-1-1 bill
summary: Maryland legislators are pushing bills to block the public release of sensitive information, such as photos of crime scenes and victims' identities, under the state’s Public Information Act. The move aligns with the rollout of a new "Next Generation 9-1-1" system that allows text, photo, and video communication with emergency services by 2021.

title: Anne Arundel teen maintains silent State House protest to support the environment
summary: A 14-year-old Anne Arundel County teen is silently protesting outside the Maryland State House for 90 days to demand environmental protections. She seeks a constitutional amendment ensuring the public’s right to clean air, water, and a healthy environment.

title: Maryland could give minors consent for preventative HIV care
summary: Maryland is considering legislation that would allow minors to consent to preventative HIV treatment, such as Truvada, without parental approval. The bill aims to address rising HIV rates among young people and aligns PrEP with other medical treatments minors can already consent to.

title: Cummings: Presidents need to open books on library fundraising
summary: A new bipartisan bill, the Presidential Library Donation Reform Act of 2019, passed the House and would require presidents to publicly disclose all donations over $200 to their presidential libraries. The legislation aims to increase transparency after past instances of undisclosed and foreign funding for such institutions.

title: Virginia Expresses ‘Profound Regret’ for History of Lynchings
summary: Virginia legislators have unanimously passed resolutions expressing "profound regret" for the state's history of lynching, acknowledging the racial terror that claimed over 80 lives, mostly African-American men, in the decades following the Civil War. The resolutions aim to promote healing and reconciliation by documenting these incidents through online records, historic markers, and educational programming.

title: Senate, House weigh bills changing Board of Regents makeup
summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering bills to expand and make more transparent the University System of Maryland Board of Regents, including adding four members and live-streaming meetings. The proposed changes aim to increase diversity and public accountability following criticism over the board's handling of the Jordan McNair investigation.

title: Bill would mandate teaching about the Holocaust in schools
summary: A survey revealed that nearly one in five people aged 18 to 34 were unfamiliar with the Holocaust. In response, Maryland Senator Ben Kramer is sponsoring a bill to require Holocaust education in all public and private schools.

title: Maryland legislature considers limits on the use of plastic straws in restaurants
summary: The Maryland legislature is considering a bill that would significantly restrict the use of plastic straws in restaurants beginning in 2020. The proposal has drawn both support and opposition during recent committee discussions.

title: Annual Montgomery County program helps with preparing women leaders for the future
summary: The Montgomery County Commission for Women hosted its annual Women’s Legislative Briefing under the theme “Women Igniting and Achieving Change.” The event brought together elected officials, activists, and future leaders to address issues affecting women and girls and to encourage them to drive positive change in their communities and beyond.

title: State’s largest animal shelter gets $250,000 grant for Valentine’s Day
summary: The Petco Foundation presented BARCS, Maryland's largest animal shelter, with a $250,000 grant on Valentine’s Day. BARCS cares for over 12,000 animals annually and was surprised by the donation during a special event in Baltimore.

title: Valentine’s Day’s roots are more than candy and roses
summary: Valentine’s Day originated from the martyrdom of Saint Valentine in A.D. 269, who was known for helping lovers unite.

title: Maryland state senator called to active duty during the legislative session
summary: Maryland State Senator Will Smith, a Navy Reserve lieutenant, is being deployed to Afghanistan. His deployment comes just ten days before the end of the 90-day Maryland General Assembly session.

title: Maryland lawmakers push bill to simplify financial aid for independent students
summary: Maryland lawmakers are pushing the FAFSA Fairness Act of 2019 to simplify financial aid for students who have no contact with their parents due to abuse, abandonment, or incarceration. The bill would allow these students to apply under a "provisionally independent" category, streamlining the aid process and reducing barriers to higher education.

title: Legislation would stiffen penalties for ransomware attacks
summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering legislation to impose stricter penalties for ransomware attacks, including fines up to $100,000 and prison sentences of up to 10 years for attacks causing losses over $1,000. The bill also introduces a new offense for possessing ransomware with intent to use it, excluding researchers.

title: Dr. Sacoby Wilson speaks at Environmental justice event
summary: Dr. Sacoby Wilson addressed an environmental justice event, emphasizing the importance of equitable solutions to pollution and health disparities in marginalized communities.

title: Hoyer slams Trump’s border emergency claims, says there’s no border crisis
summary: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer rejected President Trump's claims of a border emergency, stating there is no crisis and criticizing the threat of another government shutdown over funding for a border wall. While Congress works to pass a compromise bill with less funding than Trump requested, the president remains confident in securing his border security priorities.

title: Baltimore Ravens trade longtime quarterback Joe Flacco to the Denver Broncos
summary: The Baltimore Ravens have agreed in principle to trade quarterback Joe Flacco to the Denver Broncos in exchange for a mid-round draft pick, pending the start of the new NFL league year on March 13. Flacco, a former Super Bowl MVP, is set to leave the team that drafted him in 2008 after a season in which rookie Lamar Jackson emerged as the franchise's new quarterback.

title: Schools may start before Labor Day as Senate bill advances
summary: A Maryland Senate bill passed to undo Gov. Larry Hogan’s executive order requiring schools to start after Labor Day, with Democrats supporting and Republicans opposing it.

title: Maryland Senate votes to return school start dates to local school boards
summary: Maryland senators approved legislation allowing local school boards to set their own school start and end dates, reversing a 2016 state mandate that required schools to start after Labor Day. The bill now moves to the House for further consideration.

title: Extreme heat and cold: CNS is reporting on climate and health
summary: CNS reports on the increasing impact of extreme weather, including heat and cold, on public health. The coverage highlights how climate change is exacerbating health risks across different regions.

title: Grab a slice from one of Maryland’s local pizzerias for #NationalPizzaDay
summary: Maryland celebrates #NationalPizzaDay with a variety of local pizzerias, including Ledo’s Pizza, which began in Adelphi in 1955. An interactive map highlights some of the state’s best pizza spots for fans to explore.

title: Sen. Will Smith to be deployed to Afghanistan in March
summary: Sen. William "Will" Smith Jr.

title: Bill to “ban the box” would end federal employer requests for criminal histories
summary: A bipartisan bill, the Fair Chance Act, has been introduced to "ban the box" by prohibiting federal employers and contractors from inquiring about an applicant's criminal history before making a conditional job offer. The legislation aims to reduce recidivism by giving former felons a fair chance to secure employment, aligning with recent criminal justice reform efforts highlighted by President Trump.

title: Caps coming together as they prepare for playoff push
summary: The Washington Capitals defeated the Colorado Avalanche 4-3 in overtime despite controversial officiating and a high hit, marking their third win in four games after the All-Star break. The victory suggests the defending Stanley Cup champions are overcoming recent struggles and regrouping for a playoff push.

title: Howard County Executive updates Ellicott City flood mitigation efforts
summary: Howard County Executive Calvin Ball announced updates to Ellicott City's flood mitigation efforts, indicating that alternatives to the current plan of demolishing buildings on Main Street are being considered. The town has experienced two deadly floods within two years, prompting ongoing discussions on how best to address the recurring issue.

title: Local officials team up to push for hike in state’s minimum wage
summary: Local officials, including county executives and Baltimore's mayor, are pushing for Maryland's minimum wage to be raised to $15. Governor Larry Hogan remains undecided, citing concerns about potential effects on businesses.

title: White House protest calls on Trump administration to issue report, apply sanctions for the murder of Washington Post journalist
summary: On February 8th, the Trump administration was due to release a report on the murder of journalist Jamal Khashoggi and the U.S. response.

title: Maryland lawmakers have mixed reviews of 2019 State of the Union
summary: Maryland's two Democratic senators praised President Trump's focus on government funding but criticized his comments on ongoing investigations. The state's lone Republican congressman expressed support for the President's priorities, particularly his stance on border security.

title: Hoyer says House will continue Trump investigations, ask for tax returns
summary: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer stated that the House will continue its investigations into Russian interference and potential Trump campaign collusion, emphasizing Congress's constitutional duty to oversee government operations. Meanwhile, Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell urged Democrats to prioritize the public interest over political motives, responding to Trump's bipartisan overtures in his State of the Union address.

title: Maryland legislators disappointed with Trump’s State of the Union address
summary: Maryland’s Democratic lawmakers criticized President Trump’s State of the Union address, calling it divisive and lacking in bipartisan unity or meaningful policy solutions. While some acknowledged specific mentions like women’s representation, they emphasized the need for concrete action on issues such as gender equality and government stability.

title: Legislation would mandate activity for all elementary public school students in Maryland
summary: A proposed bill in Maryland would require more than two hours of weekly physical activity for elementary public school students. The legislation was discussed in a House committee hearing on Thursday.

title: Bills would allow live-stream of Assembly, agency meetings
summary: Bipartisan bills in Maryland aim to live-stream General Assembly and agency meetings to increase transparency and public access, with support from both chambers and the governor. While initial cost estimates are high, some lawmakers argue existing systems could provide a more affordable solution.

title: Legislation would update Justice Reinvestment Act
summary: Maryland's Justice Reinvestment Act, implemented in 2016, has reduced prison and jail populations by prioritizing treatment over incarceration and setting stricter sentencing guidelines. Advocates now seek legislative updates to further prevent recidivism and refine the law's impact.

title: Maryland could be banned from dredging Man O’ War Shoal
summary: Maryland legislators are considering a ban on dredging the Man O’ War Shoal to protect remaining oyster populations, despite efforts by the Department of Natural Resources to use the shells for habitat restoration. Opponents argue that alternative materials, such as granite, may be more effective for oyster bed restoration.

title: Police forces take icy dip to support Special Olympics
summary: Law enforcement officers in Maryland braved icy waters for the 23rd Annual Polar Bear Plunge, raising funds for the Special Olympics. The event, which included Governor Larry Hogan and participation from top fundraising departments like Prince George’s Police, aimed to raise $2.5 million to support over 7,000 athletes with intellectual disabilities.

title: Defense dominates as Patriots top Rams, 13-3, in Super Bowl LIII
summary: The New England Patriots defeated the Los Angeles Rams 13-3 in Super Bowl LIII, with a dominant defensive performance highlighted by Stephon Gilmore’s game-sealing interception. The low-scoring game marked the Patriots' sixth Super Bowl title in 17 years and their largest margin of victory in a championship game.

title: Mothers take on State House to push for additional gun control
summary: Mothers and supporters in Maryland gathered in Annapolis to advocate for stricter gun control measures. They are pushing for a ban on "ghost guns" and 3D printed firearms, as well as mandatory background checks for shotgun and long gun purchases.

title: Senate committee hears testimony on governor’s Judicial Transparency Act
summary: The Senate Judicial Proceedings Committee in Maryland heard divided testimony on Governor Hogan’s Judicial Transparency Act, which would mandate a state Sentencing Commission to publish annual, detailed sentencing data by judge for violent offenders. The bill aims to increase judicial accountability but has sparked debate over its potential impact on judicial independence.

title: Testimony presented defining eSports in Maryland, permitting prizes
summary: Montgomery County Delegate Eric Luedtke highlighted eSports as a multi-billion dollar industry that Maryland needs to regulate. He advocated for legislation to define eSports and permit prize competitions, emphasizing the economic benefits it could bring to the state.

title: House Democrats seek sweeping reforms on ethics, campaigns
summary: House Democrats have introduced the "For the People Act of 2019" to push for major election and ethics reforms, including campaign finance changes and making Election Day a federal holiday. While the bill is expected to pass the House, it faces strong opposition in the Republican-led Senate, where it is seen as a partisan power grab.

title: Maryland’s Super Bowl players competed in different high school landscape
summary: Micah Kiser, a Maryland high school football standout from the early 2010s, is preparing for Super Bowl LIII, having played in a competitive MIAA league that now struggles due to St. Frances Academy's dominance and the departure of key programs.

title: John Johnson put hoop dreams aside to go from Northwestern High to Super Bowl
summary: John Johnson quit high school basketball to focus on football, leading to a successful college and NFL career, where he now plays as a safety for the Los Angeles Rams. Known for his competitiveness and bold personality, Johnson is set to take center stage at Super Bowl LIII.

title: Moms group rallies to push gun-control laws
summary: A Maryland-based group of mothers and advocates rallied in Annapolis to push for stricter gun laws, including bans on ghost guns and 3D printed firearms, and mandatory background checks for long guns. While supporters argue the legislation is a proactive step to close safety loopholes, some lawmakers question its necessity due to a lack of reported crimes involving such weapons in the state.

title: Bill would mandate school time for student physical activity
summary: A Maryland bill would require elementary students to get 150 minutes of physical activity weekly, including 90 minutes of P.E., with additional funding needed for affected counties. While supporters argue it combats childhood obesity and improves well-being, opponents like Anne Arundel County cite financial burdens and the need for local control over education policies.

title: Bill proposed to define and allow eSports in Maryland
summary: Maryland lawmakers are considering a bill to legally define eSports, separate them from gambling laws, and allow prize competitions to support the growing industry. The legislation aims to clarify rules around skill-based competitions and could boost the state’s economy while ensuring fair play and legal oversight.

title: Lawmakers React to Governor Hogan’s State of the State
summary: Lawmakers from both parties acknowledged Governor Hogan’s bipartisan approach in his State of the State address. However, Democrats expressed concerns over his tax relief proposal and lack of support for raising the minimum wage.

title: Governor Hogan again urges bipartisanship, sets priorities in State of the State
summary: Governor Larry Hogan, in his second-term State of the State address, praised the state's strong condition and called for continued bipartisan cooperation. He also outlined plans for $500 million in tax relief over the next five years.

title: Rams LB Micah Kiser’s football IQ dates back to time at Gilman
summary: Rams linebacker Micah Kiser's football IQ has been evident since his high school days at Gilman, where he showcased strong instincts and awareness. His ability to read plays and make key tackles, like intercepting an out route in a crucial game, highlights the potential that has carried over into his NFL career.

title: House Democrats launch effort to strengthen equal pay law
summary: House Democrats have introduced a bill to strengthen the Equal Pay Act, aiming to close loopholes and provide women with stronger tools to combat pay discrimination. The legislation, backed by all House Democrats, comes amid a historic moment with the largest number of women ever serving in Congress.

title: Maryland Legislature’s Democrats announce 2019 priorities
summary: Maryland Democrats announced their 2019 legislative priorities, including banning 3D-printed and ghost guns, raising the minimum wage to $15, increasing the tobacco purchasing age to 21, and expanding affordable child care and health care access. They emphasized a progressive agenda, vowing to uphold Democratic principles despite potential opposition from Republican Governor Larry Hogan and industry groups.

title: Gov. Hogan talks bipartisanship at fifth State of the State
summary: In his fifth State of the State address, Gov. Larry Hogan urged bipartisan support for his initiatives on taxes, healthcare, education, and infrastructure, highlighting Maryland's progress under a divided government.

title: Patriots’ rookie JC Jackson, undrafted out of Maryland, now a starter
summary: Undrafted rookie JC Jackson of the New England Patriots has become a key starter, earning a spot in Super Bowl LIII after an unexpected rise. Despite a challenging college career and early doubts, Jackson's perseverance led to a breakout season and a pivotal role on the team.

title: Maryland’s Hoyer says another shutdown is “off the table”
summary: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer stated that another government shutdown is "off the table" and announced a bill to provide a 2.6 percent cost-of-living adjustment for federal workers affected by the recent shutdown. While Democrats and Republicans continue negotiations on border security, Hoyer emphasized avoiding a repeat of the 35-day shutdown that left workers unpaid.

title: Local non-profit helps with meeting needs of pet owners impacted by government shut-down
summary: A local non-profit in Rockville, Maryland, is assisting pet owners affected by the government shut-down. The organization is also preparing federal workers for potential food and care shortages for their pets in case of a second shut-down.

title: State House Democrats present 2019 General Assembly priorities
summary: Maryland Senate and House Democrats have released their 2019 General Assembly priorities, which include raising the minimum wage to $15 an hour. Another key focus is increasing the minimum age to purchase tobacco products to 21.

title: Former Good Counsel standout Blake Countess is ‘Swiss Army knife’ of Rams’ special teams
summary: Former Good Counsel standout Blake Countess has become a versatile and essential player on the Rams’ special teams, taking on a quarterback-like role and earning praise as a “Swiss Army knife” from coach John Fassel. After overcoming injuries and coaching changes during his college career, Countess has emerged as an unsung hero in the Rams’ journey to Super Bowl LIII.

title: Maryland legislators pleased with shutdown deal, but Democrats hit Trump
summary: President Donald Trump announced a deal to reopen the government for three weeks, which Maryland lawmakers supported and quickly pushed through Congress. While Democrats praised the resolution, they criticized Trump for his approach and hinted at ongoing concerns over his leadership and constitutional respect.

title: Kirwan Commission chair gives recommendations to lawmakers
summary: The Kirwan Commission has recommended a $3.8 billion plan to improve Maryland’s public schools over the next decade, focusing on early childhood education, teacher support, and equity. The commission is seeking increased funding to expand access and ensure all students receive a high-quality education.

title: U.S. Senate votes down two bills to end record shutdown
summary: The U.S. Senate voted down two bills aimed at ending the government shutdown.

title: State offers free transportation to workers impacted by shutdown
summary: Governor Larry Hogan announced free transportation for federal workers affected by the government shutdown through Maryland's transit system. BWI-Marshall Airport is also hosting a food drive for impacted employees.

title: Maryland Senators meet with local business owners
summary: Maryland Senators met with local business owners in Rockville as the government shutdown enters its 34th day, with some offering discounts to federal workers. Business owners remain concerned about the long-term impact of the shutdown on their operations.

title: Hogan announces free rides for unpaid federal employees
summary: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan announced that unpaid federal employees will receive free rides on all MTA services during the government shutdown by showing a federal ID. Additionally, the state has set up food donation locations and Exelon, BGE, and Pepco will waive late fees for affected workers.

title: Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh, county executives, call for the end to partial federal government shutdown
summary: Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh and four county executives are calling on President Trump and Congress to resolve the longest federal government shutdown. They emphasized the impact on their constituents and urged bipartisan cooperation to end the crisis.

title: Baltimore food hand-out for federal workers impacted by government shutdown
summary: Baltimore's Maryland Food Bank provided groceries to 100 families impacted by the government shutdown. The assistance included fresh produce, canned goods, and other essentials to help them during their period of unemployment and financial hardship.

title: Governor proposes boost in funding for public charter schools
summary: Governor Larry Hogan has proposed a $2.6 million budget allocation and introduced the Public Charter School Facility Fund Act to improve Maryland's public charter schools. The plan includes $1,600 per student to fund construction and repairs.

title: Commission asks lawmakers for upgrades in antiquated emergency system
summary: A statewide commission in Maryland is asking lawmakers to pass bills to modernize the state’s aging 9-1-1 emergency system. The current system, which has been in place for more than 50 years, is in need of significant upgrades.

title: Retired state workers push to retain current prescription drug plan
summary: Retired state workers in Maryland are opposing a proposed change to their prescription drug plan, arguing it would reduce coverage and increase costs. They are advocating to maintain their current benefits.

title: Famous kitchen sets up in the heart of government to feed federal workers
summary: Chef José Andrés opened a World Central Kitchen resource center on Pennsylvania Avenue to provide free meals, groceries, and bill assistance to furloughed federal workers during the government shutdown. The initiative, supported by partners like Verizon and Xfinity, aims to help workers manage financial hardships as the shutdown enters its 33rd day.

title: Unions, Maryland Food Bank partner to help federal workers
summary: Unions and the Maryland Food Bank organized a food giveaway in Baltimore to assist furloughed federal workers affected by the government shutdown. The event marked the first large-scale effort to directly provide fresh food to struggling government employees.

title: Maryland’s Hoyer calls shutdown a “hostage” situation
summary: House Majority Leader Steny Hoyer criticized the government shutdown as a "hostage" situation caused by President Trump and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell, emphasizing that reopening the government is Democrats' top priority. Trump and some Republicans blame Democrats for the stalemate, even as polls show most Americans hold Trump and Republicans responsible.

title: Rising student loan debt hurts housing market, Fed says
summary: Rising student loan debt has contributed to a decline in home ownership rates, especially among young Americans, according to a Federal Reserve report. The study estimates that increased student debt has prevented over 400,000 young adults from buying a home.

title: Michael Bloomberg calls on Annapolis to talk gun control
summary: Michael Bloomberg visited Annapolis and met with Democratic lawmakers and Maryland Attorney General Brian Frosh to discuss gun control. The visit comes as the former New York City mayor is rumored to be considering a 2020 presidential run.

title: Union feeds 400 people furloughed during shutdown
summary: The Amalgamated Transit Union provided free lunches to furloughed workers during the government shutdown. By the end of the week, nearly 400 people had been fed.

title: Bill requiring environmental study would delay highway project
summary: A proposed bill in Maryland would require an environmental impact study before the state can move forward with its I-495 and I-270 highway expansion, potentially delaying the $9–$11 billion project by a year. Transportation officials warn the delay could cost up to $300 million and worsen traffic congestion, but lawmakers raised concerns about public input and toll transparency.

title: A Look at the D.C. Women’s March 2019: Photo Gallery
summary: The 2019 D.C. Women's March continued the annual tradition of advocating for women's rights and social justice.

title: Indigenous Peoples March – Photo Gallery
summary: The Indigenous Peoples March brought together participants from various tribes and communities to advocate for Native American rights and environmental justice. The event featured powerful speeches, cultural performances, and a visual display of solidarity through a photo gallery capturing the day's moments.

title: 2019 March for Life gallery
summary: The 2019 March for Life brought together thousands of participants in Washington, D.C., to protest against abortion and advocate for the protection of unborn children. The event featured speakers, religious services, and a visual display of thousands of photos representing lost lives due to abortion.

title: In Washington, indigenous peoples march against injustices
summary: Hundreds of indigenous people and supporters gathered in Washington for the Indigenous Peoples March, highlighting global injustices faced by Native communities, including violence against women and environmental and political mistreatment. Participants honored missing and murdered Indigenous women by carrying signs and red silhouettes, while ceremonial smudging was used to cleanse negative energy.

title: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan releases FY 2020 budget
summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan released a $44.6 billion FY 2020 budget emphasizing education, economic growth, and infrastructure, including a record $6.9 billion for K-12 schools and a 3% raise for state employees.

title: Getting to know BRITS nominee George Ezra
summary: George Ezra, a BRIT Award-nominated folk rock star, showcased his humble and witty personality during a casual Q&A in Washington, where he connected with fans through humor, music, and candid conversation. He has stepped back from social media to avoid its addictive nature, preferring to share content through others instead.

title: Audit finds conflict of interest in MTA contracts
summary: An audit revealed potential conflicts of interest involving a former MTA manager who awarded over $4.5 million in contracts to a vendor with close personal and business ties. The investigation found improper payments and unrelated charges, including over $15,000 for tasks like delivering bottled water and driving an employee to a store.

title: Thousands turn out for Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan’s inauguration celebration
summary: Governor Larry Hogan celebrated his inauguration and second term with a gala attended by thousands at the MGM National Harbor in Oxon Hill, Maryland. The event featured a purple-lit venue symbolizing his commitment to bipartisanship.

title: Federal contract workers say the continuing government shutdown is taking a toll
summary: Federal contract workers, including janitors and security guards, are expressing concern over the government shutdown, as they face uncertainty about compensation for lost income. They met with Maryland Senators Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen to highlight their financial struggles and lack of job security.

title: Governor Larry Hogan sworn in for second term
summary: Larry Hogan became the first Republican in Maryland history to be sworn in for a second consecutive term as governor. He urged lawmakers to reject divisive politics and continue working across party lines as a model for the nation.

title: Inauguration attendees express optimism for Gov. Larry Hogan’s second term
summary: Larry Hogan became the first Republican to win a second consecutive term as Maryland governor, sworn in for the first time since 1955. He urged lawmakers to reject divisive politics and promote bipartisan cooperation as a model for the nation.

title: Many workers, volunteers help to make a successful inauguration for Governor Hogan
summary: Numerous workers and volunteers contributed to the successful staging of Maryland Governor Larry Hogan’s inauguration. Their efforts ensured the event ran smoothly in Annapolis.

title: Federal workers to get back pay, but tales of woe mount

The plate will be available for purchase starting October 29, with an additional $20 fee that supports "Save the Bay" conservation efforts.

title: Growing sport of pickleball provides lifeline in cancer battle
summary: An Annapolis resident discovered pickleball through a new friend and a chance meeting, finding it to be a crucial lifeline during his cancer battle. The fast-growing sport has provided him with both physical activity and emotional support.

title: Anti-hunger programs in Maryland growing to meet demand
summary: Anti-hunger programs in Maryland are expanding to meet rising demand, with food pantry usage at the Light House emergency shelter in Annapolis increasing from 200 to 900 monthly pickups. The state, which has a 10 percent food insecurity rate, is recognized for its effective coordination of federal, state, and local programs, including strong school meal access and high enrollment in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program.

title: The Washington Bullpen, Episode 5
summary: The latest episode of the "Washington Bullpen" podcast covers U.S. Ambassador Nikki Haley's retirement plans and a new climate report from the United Nations.

title: Local agencies join in Hurricane Michael relief effort
summary: Montgomery County’s Urban Search and Rescue team is participating in relief efforts following Hurricane Michael. Local agencies are collaborating to aid recovery in the storm-affected areas.

title: Statue of pioneer African-American woman reporter points to ‘future of equality’
summary: The Newseum unveiled a statue honoring Alice Allison Dunnigan, the first African-American woman to cover the White House, highlighting her fight against racism and sexism. Despite her legacy, African-American women still remain underrepresented in the White House press corps and newsrooms, facing ongoing discrimination and barriers today.

title: Gaithersburg Elementary School participates in National Walk to School Day
summary: Students at Gaithersburg Elementary School participated in National Walk to School Day. The event promotes the health, environmental, and safety benefits of walking to school.

title: Frosh’s broad legal power: Partisanship or ‘long overdue’?
summary: Maryland Attorney General Brian Frosh gained the power to sue the federal government independently in 2017 after the state legislature passed the Maryland Defense Act in response to President Trump’s controversial travel ban. Legal experts argue that Frosh’s expanded authority reflects a long-overdue shift to empower attorneys general to represent public interest without state executive approval.

title: Preservation group report challenges county’s flood plan
summary: A preservation group has challenged Howard County’s flood mitigation plan, arguing it inadequately considers alternatives that balance safety and historic preservation in Ellicott City. The group advocates for exploring underground tunnel boring to divert floodwaters, rather than demolishing historic buildings.

title: Maryland’s U.S. Senators critical of FBI Kavanaugh report
summary: Maryland's U.S. Senators, Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen, criticized the FBI's follow-up report on Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh for being incomplete and raising more questions.

title: School safety app and hotline rolled out to help prevent school shootings
summary: Governor Hogan has launched a 24-hour tip line and mobile app in Maryland to help prevent school shootings. The anonymous tools allow students, parents, and teachers to report concerning behavior at any time.

title: Local elementary school students get hands-on lifesaving lessons for Fire Prevention Week
summary: Baltimore elementary school students received hands-on fire safety lessons during Fire Prevention Week. Local firefighters visited the school to teach lifesaving skills as part of National Fire Prevention month.

title: International ships set sail for Baltimore during Fleet Week
summary: International ships and sailors are gathering in Baltimore’s Inner Harbor for Fleet Week. The event showcases global naval presence and celebrates maritime cooperation.

title: Physical activity report shows poor health for children
summary: A 2018 report card reveals that children in the United States are not meeting recommended levels of physical activity. The findings highlight ongoing concerns about poor health and inactivity among young people.

title: Marylanders react to Justice Brett Kavanaugh’s #SCOTUS confirmation
summary: Brett Kavanaugh was confirmed as a Supreme Court justice despite allegations of sexual assault made by Christine Blasey Ford, which sparked national debate and an FBI investigation. Maryland politicians and social media users expressed concerns over the allegations and Kavanaugh's potential impact on key legal issues.

title: Juvenile detention centers use yoga to teach mindfulness
summary: Juvenile detention centers in Baltimore are using yoga and mindfulness programs to help detained youth manage stress and improve well-being. The non-competitive, structured classes are seen as a positive alternative to traditional disciplinary methods.

title: Jealous’ Facebook audience smaller, more active than Hogan’s
summary: Larry Hogan's Facebook page has over 10 times more followers than Ben Jealous', but Jealous' posts generate higher engagement relative to his smaller audience. Hogan posts more frequently and uses photos often, while Jealous relies more on videos and external links.

title: Moments from #CancelKavanaugh
summary: Protesters in Washington demonstrated against the confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh to the Supreme Court, citing his alleged sexual assault. The #CancelKavanaugh movement highlighted public outrage as the Senate prepared to vote on his nomination.

title: The Washington Bullpen, Episode 4
summary: The "Washington Bullpen" podcast covers the new U.S.-Canada-Mexico trade agreement and Amazon’s minimum wage increase. It also features a discussion on the FBI’s supplemental report regarding allegations against Brett Kavanaugh.

title: Maryland’s senators rip limited scope of FBI’s Kavanaugh report
summary: Maryland's Democratic senators criticized the FBI's supplemental investigation into Brett Kavanaugh as rushed and incomplete, noting it failed to interview key witnesses like Christine Blasey Ford. Senate Republicans defended Kavanaugh, asserting his innocence and accusing Democrats of delaying tactics.

title: Ahead of Senate vote, thousands march against Kavanaugh confirmation
summary: Thousands marched in Washington, D.C., chanting against Brett Kavanaugh's Supreme Court confirmation amid allegations of sexual misconduct, with protesters including survivors and advocates for women's rights. Organizers and speakers like Sen.

title: Veteran columnist: McNair case will force University of Maryland officials’ departures
summary: USA Today columnist Christine Brennan predicts that University of Maryland officials—including head coach DJ Durkin, athletic director Damon Evans, and president Wallace Loh—will be fired for mishandling the toxic culture that led to the death of football player Jordan McNair from heatstroke. Investigations revealed that McNair did not receive proper medical care after collapsing during practice, sparking widespread scrutiny and calls for accountability.

title: Move over soccer and flag football – quirkier social sports are growing
summary: Unusual social sports like skeeball are gaining popularity in Washington, D.C., offering a relaxed and inclusive alternative to traditional team sports. These leagues, which attract a diverse range of participants, provide a fun way to build relationships and compete without the pressure of formal athletics.

title: Maryland Democrats: Trump health care curbs could affect 260,000 in state
summary: Maryland Democrats warned that up to 260,000 residents could face higher health care costs or lose coverage due to Trump administration policies targeting the Affordable Care Act. They criticized the administration for undermining key protections and vowed to challenge the decision in court.

title: County approves $17 million for Ellicott City flood plan
summary: Howard County approved $17 million for the first phase of a $50 million flood mitigation plan in Ellicott City, which includes removing buildings and expanding a stream channel to reduce flood risks. Residents and officials argue the plan is essential to prevent further destruction after two severe floods in recent years.

title: Moviegoers don’t see best picture nominees anymore
summary: Best picture nominees no longer dominate the box office as they did in previous decades, with only one nominee since 2004 earning over $200 million in domestic sales. The Academy has introduced a new category for popular filmmaking in an effort to boost viewership and relevance.

title: Maryland governor and senators unite over FBI probe of Kavanaugh
summary: Maryland's governor and two Democratic senators supported a call for an FBI investigation into Supreme Court nominee Brett Kavanaugh following allegations of sexual misconduct. They urged a full and thorough probe, criticizing the White House's decision to limit the investigation to one week.

summary: In the latest episode of the "Washington Bullpen" podcast, host Jarod Golub covers the proposed green card law change by the Department of Homeland Security. He also discusses President Trump’s United Nations press conference and the Kavanaugh confirmation vote and testimonies.

title: Find fall fun at Maryland pumpkin patches, apple orchards, corn mazes
summary: Maryland residents are embracing fall by visiting pumpkin patches, apple orchards, and corn mazes across the state. The season offers a variety of fun activities as people prepare for Halloween and Thanksgiving.

title: Outside the Kavanaugh hearing, tears and anger
summary: Protesters and supporters of Brett Kavanaugh and Christine Blasey Ford gathered outside the Senate hearing in emotional and passionate demonstrations, with many expressing their views through signs, coordinated clothing, and silent protests. Opponents criticized the "old boys' network" and called for belief in survivors, while supporters emphasized the lack of evidence and the principle of innocence until proven guilty.

title: Grassroots group urges candidates to support drug-cost board
summary: A grassroots coalition in Maryland is urging gubernatorial and legislative candidates to support the creation of a Prescription Drug Affordability Board to monitor and control drug prices. Advocates argue that the board is essential to prevent drastic price hikes, like the infamous 5,000% increase of Daraprim, and ensure that life-saving medications remain accessible and affordable.

title: Hogan and Jealous square off in lone debate
summary: In the lone 2018 Maryland gubernatorial debate, Republican Gov. Larry Hogan and Democratic challenger Ben Jealous clashed on key issues like the economy and education, with their tense exchange failing to produce a clear winner.

title: McDonogh School retires football jersey of alum & Terp player Jordan McNair
summary: McDonogh School retired the football jersey of alum Jordan McNair before their 2018 home opener. McNair, a University of Maryland player, died in June from heatstroke after collapsing during practice.

title: Hogan announces lower 2019 insurance premiums in Maryland
summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan announced that individual health insurance premiums in the state will decrease by an average of 13% in 2019, following federal approval of a reinsurance program to stabilize the market.

title: The Washington Bullpen, Episode 2

Hogan leads his Democratic opponent, Ben Jealous, in polls and fundraising, with significant financial resources fueling his campaign.

title: Surprise! The Equal Rights Amendment is back
summary: The Equal Rights Amendment, first proposed in 1923, is closer than ever to becoming part of the U.S. Constitution after Illinois' recent ratification, with Virginia now the key state needed to meet the three-fourths requirement.

title: In wake of player’s death, area high schools remain vigilant against heatstroke
summary: In the wake of University of Maryland football player Jordan McNair's death from heatstroke, area high schools and athletic officials are increasing efforts to prevent heat-related illnesses through better training, monitoring, and safety practices. McNair's death has brought renewed public attention to the issue, prompting coaches and administrators to emphasize player health and safety more than ever.

title: Department of Transportation and Maryland Food Bank join forces to fight hunger
summary: The Maryland Food Bank is partnering with the Department of Transportation for a month-long food drive in September to combat hunger. The initiative aims to help the estimated 1-in-9 Maryland residents who struggle with food insecurity.

While officials argue the plan is necessary for life safety, residents and preservationists criticize its speed and potential impact on the town's historic character.

summary: Hurricane Florence weakened to a Category 2 storm as it approached the East Coast, though it had previously been a powerful Category 4 hurricane with winds up to 130 mph. The storm prompted over 1 million evacuations and led to emergency declarations, with concerns it could have intensified to a Category 5 before making landfall.

summary: Shelter animals in the path of Hurricane Florence are being relocated to safer facilities along the East Coast, including a shelter in Washington. This move protects the animals and creates space for pets displaced by the storm.

title: Annapolis prepares for Hurricane Florence
summary: Annapolis is preparing for the impact of Hurricane Florence as the storm approaches the U.S. coast.

summary: Maryland residents and businesses are preparing for Hurricane Florence, which could bring high winds and heavy rain to the state by the weekend. summary: Maryland leaders, including Gov. Larry Hogan and Annapolis Mayor Gavin Buckley, honored the victims of the Sept.

summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan and Democratic challenger Ben Jealous have agreed to a single, hour-long debate on Sept.

title: Hogan spends big on campaign ads; Jealous holds off
summary: Republican Governor Larry Hogan has heavily invested over $1 million in campaign ads since June, while Democratic challenger Ben Jealous has spent little on TV or radio ads due to financial constraints. Political analysts attribute Jealous's limited response to a significant funding gap, with Hogan holding around $8 million in campaign cash compared to Jealous's less than $300,000.

title: Local sheriffs join in effort to get Congress to approve immigration reform

summary: President Donald Trump has used pardons and commutations more frequently and differently than recent presidents, departing from established norms of restraint and procedural fairness. Unlike his predecessors, who avoided clemency in their early terms to prevent perceptions of corruption, Trump has granted pardons to multiple individuals within his first 18 months in office.

summary: Public health and environmental advocates are urging Maryland Governor Larry Hogan to strengthen regulations on the routine use of antibiotics in livestock, arguing that current draft rules do not adequately address concerns about antibiotic resistance. The 2017 Keep Antibiotics Effective Act aimed to limit such use, but the Department of Agriculture's proposed regulations have faced criticism for lacking clear definitions and sufficient enforcement.

title: Week 1 for local college football teams was highlighted by Maryland and Virginia Tech’s big wins
summary: Maryland defeated No. 23 Texas 34-29 at FedEx Field, marking their second straight win over the Longhorns and honoring fallen teammate Jordan McNair.

summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan created the Office of Education Accountability through an executive order to investigate allegations of corruption and mismanagement in the state's public school systems.

title: Analysis: NFL teams win more after moving
summary: NFL teams that relocate tend to improve their performance, with 12 out of 16 relocations resulting in a higher winning percentage and seven teams winning championships within five years of the move. Notable examples include the Washington franchise and the Baltimore Ravens, both of which saw significant success after relocating.

title: Congress, public bid farewell to “generational” Senator John McCain
summary: Senator John McCain was honored in a Capitol Rotunda memorial service, where he lay in state alongside 30 other notable Americans, praised for his courage and service. He will be buried at the U.S.

title: Maryland Sons of Confederates Veterans officers say Civil War not about slavery
summary: Maryland Sons of Confederate Veterans officers John Zebelean and Terry Klima reject claims that their group promotes racism, asserting that white supremacists like Dylann Roof have co-opted Confederate symbols. They argue that the media wrongly equates support for Confederate heritage with racism, citing Roof's unrelated background as an example of a false narrative.

title: In North Carolina city, political disenfranchisement colored Confederate statue debate
summary: In Elizabeth City, North Carolina, the debate over a Confederate statue has highlighted deep racial and political divisions, with the city's first Black female mayor, Bettie Parker, leading efforts to remove the monument. Despite local support, the majority-white county commissioners rejected the proposal, citing historical preservation, while state law continues to restrict the removal of Confederate-era symbols.

title: In Anderson, South Carolina, African-Americans underrepresented in local government
summary: Anderson, South Carolina, with a 34% African-American population, has only three Black members out of 16 seats in its city and county councils, despite historical civil rights activism by figures like council member Beatrice Thompson. Thompson, a trailblazer in education and community leadership, has worked to improve police-community relations and established initiatives like the Westside Community Center to support the local African-American population.

title: In South Carolina town, “Finding ways to get along;” Taking down statue is not one of them
summary: Anderson, South Carolina, is grappling with its history, particularly the 35-foot Confederate statue near the courthouse, as residents like public defender Joey Opperman suggest removing it but acknowledge the current climate is not conducive to such discussions. Many in the community prefer focusing on unity and addressing other pressing issues rather than reigniting divisive debates.

title: In Virginia town, African-American elders hold mixed views on confederate statue
summary: African-American elders in Leesburg, Virginia, hold mixed views on the Confederate statue near the courthouse, with some like Gertrude Evans believing it should remain to spark conversation and preserve history. Despite calls to relocate it to a battlefield site, state law restricts the county's ability to move the monument.

title: Friendship Games: Student-run Irish team enjoys ride
summary: The Ireland team at the Friendship Games embraced the experience with spirited social moments despite lacking basketball success and formal coaching. Comprised of students from top-ranked Trinity College, the team prioritized cultural exchange over competition, reflecting the event's emphasis on camaraderie over athletic achievement.

title: Diplomacy meets basketball at 2018 Friendship Games
summary: The 13th annual Friendship Games in Eilat, Israel, use basketball as a tool for diplomacy, bringing together teams from across the Middle East and beyond to foster cross-cultural interaction and peace. Despite the region's tensions, the event has grown to include both men's and women's teams from 15 countries, emphasizing unity over competition.

title: We interviewed five of the people who run NBA Twitter accounts
summary: NBA team social media managers, fluent in internet culture and memes, play a key role in making NBA Twitter accounts stand out through creative and engaging content. These managers, who often collaborate with one another, bring unique personalities and spontaneity to the league's online presence.

title: The top eight moments in NBA Twitter history
summary: The article highlights eight memorable moments in NBA Twitter history, including a tweet that led to a social media manager being fired and a team creatively tracking a winning streak. Other notable moments include the Sacramento Kings mocking the Cleveland Cavaliers with a photoshopped logo and a Twitter feud that prompted the league to address trash talk.

title: The hidden Twitter relationships of NBA teams
summary: A data analysis of NBA team interactions on Twitter since 2012 revealed the Charlotte Hornets had a lopsided relationship with the Atlanta Hawks, who engaged with them far less frequently. While many interactions align with conference rivalries, some teams like the Hawks and Suns developed unexpected, frequent communication despite being in different conferences.

title: On Twitter, creative, meme-filled conversations help NBA stand out
summary: The NBA uses Twitter to engage fans through creative, meme-filled content that includes GIFs, ASCII art, and slang, allowing teams to appear like relatable, humorous teenagers. This approach resonates with the league's younger audience and fosters a distinct, vibrant online culture.

title: CNS Investigates: Why defendants plead guilty to crimes they didn’t commit
summary: Defendants often plead guilty to crimes they did not commit due to factors such as pressure from the legal system, fear of harsher sentences if convicted at trial, and limited resources for adequate defense. This practice raises concerns about justice and the fairness of the criminal justice system.

title: Baltimore residents remain hopeful about the troubled city’s future
summary: Baltimore residents, despite the city's challenges, remain hopeful about its future and believe it is worth saving. They encourage others to look beyond the negative headlines and see the city's potential.

title: Basketball provides learning opportunities for teen from single parent home
summary: Everett Croslin, one of six children in a single-parent household in Baltimore, receives guidance from mentor Haneef Hardy. Basketball and mentorship help him navigate the challenges of growing up in a city where over 60 percent of children live with one parent.

title: Baltimore man overcomes drug abuse, wins family back
summary: Michael Lewis, a former cocaine addict from Baltimore, has overcome his drug abuse and successfully regained custody of his children. His story highlights the challenges faced by parents with substance abuse issues, as thousands of children are removed from their homes each year due to such problems.

title: Baltimore students take up track to help stay on the right path
summary: Baltimore students at Excel Academy are joining a track team to avoid getting into trouble during the high-risk hours after school. Despite their efforts, many lack the proper equipment to fully participate.

title: Students with limited options for getting to school seek improvements
summary: Over 27,000 Baltimore City Public School students depend on public transportation for their daily commute. Dashay McCrae highlights the need for improvements in the city's transportation system.

title: Finding foster care homes is a challenge in Baltimore
summary: Jamaica Briley has been a foster mom in Baltimore for 15 years, currently caring for three girls. Finding foster care homes remains a significant challenge in the city.

title: Limited resources leave many Baltimore residents digitally challenged

title: Baltimore students get help making prom possible

title: Baltimoreans remain optimistic despite many challenges
summary: Baltimore residents continue to confront significant challenges such as homelessness, substance abuse, violence, and single-parent households. Despite these struggles, many are working hard to overcome their circumstances and improve their lives.

title: Middle school students step out to protest violence
summary: Middle school students at Hampstead Hill Academy organized a walkout to protest violence in their city and across the nation, following a surge in homicides after the Parkland shooting.

title: We ran the numbers: Here’s how Democrats running for governor have been raising money
summary: Democrats running for Maryland governor in 2018 are raising significant funds, with some candidates like Ben Jealous relying heavily on small donations, while others, such as Jim Shea, depend more on large contributions. Jealous, inspired by Bernie Sanders, has raised the most from small donors, while Shea received the largest amount from high-dollar contributors.

title: Legislation aims to improve oversight of nursing homes
summary: Maryland passed two bills to improve nursing home oversight, requiring faster investigations into complaints and increasing staffing at the Office of Health Care Quality. The legislation aims to address long-standing issues of delayed responses and poor quality in the state's nursing homes.

title: One of Trump’s favorite words is ‘Hillary’
summary: President Donald Trump's frequent use of words like "great," "America," and "Hillary Clinton" reflects his rhetorical style and political focus, with social media analysis showing a clear bias against immigrants, the media, and women. His rhetoric, according to experts, challenges constitutional democracy and sets him apart from previous presidents in both tone and impact.

The program, supported by public and private partners, aims to prepare participants for jobs in utility, transportation, energy, and logistics sectors.

title: Md. police use DNA tool to identify the dead, find suspects
summary: Maryland police are using a DNA phenotyping tool called Snapshot to generate facial predictions from genetic samples, helping identify victims and narrow suspect lists in unsolved cases. Developed by Parabon NanoLabs, the service has been used in several Maryland investigations since 2016, though many remain confidential.

title: Maryland spay and neuter program photo slideshow
summary: Maryland has launched a spay and neuter program aimed at reducing the number of stray and unwanted animals. The initiative includes a photo slideshow highlighting the success stories of pets that have been spayed or neutered through the program.

title: Statewide Spay and Neuter program shows promising signs
summary: A statewide spay and neuter program in Maryland, funded in part by fees from pet food companies, has led to a 39% decrease in euthanasia of adoptable animals since 2013. title: Women sports journalists face new challenges on and off the field
summary: Female sports journalists continue to face significant challenges despite progress, as research shows women's sports receive minimal media coverage, often only during their season. summary: It has been 50 years since Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.

title: Gallery: Cherry blossoms prepare to reach peak bloom
summary: Cherry blossoms in Washington are expected to reach peak bloom this weekend, drawing visitors to the Tidal Basin as part of the National Cherry Blossom Festival. The festival, running from March 20 to April 14, will culminate with a parade.

title: The Other Games
summary: The article highlights lesser-known sports events that often overshadowed by major competitions, showcasing the passion and dedication of athletes in niche disciplines. These underappreciated games provide a platform for unique talents and foster community engagement worldwide.

title: Rally honors Martin Luther King Jr.’s legacy, pledges fight to end oppression
summary: A rally on the National Mall honored Martin Luther King Jr.'s legacy on the 50th anniversary of his assassination, drawing hundreds to address ongoing systemic racism and racial inequality. Prominent figures and activists called for action on issues such as police brutality, education, and voting rights, emphasizing the need to fulfill King's unfinished vision for racial justice.

title: Hogan vetoes cut to board’s school-construction oversight
summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan vetoed a bill that would have transferred oversight of school construction funding from the Board of Public Works to a new commission, calling it a politically motivated move against Comptroller Peter Franchot.

title: Washington’s Awesome Con celebrates ‘geek culture’
summary: Awesome Con in Washington, D.C. celebrated geek culture with events on comics, sci-fi, and gaming, featuring exhibits, panels, and screenings.

title: Annapolis lawmakers work to beat the clock on medical marijuana legislation
summary: Maryland lawmakers are working urgently to revise the state's Medical Marijuana law before time runs out in the legislative session. House Bill 2, which aims to ensure minority and women-owned businesses have access to medical cannabis licenses, has passed the House and received preliminary Senate approval.

title: Maryland hunters can soon wear pink, thanks to two sisters
summary: Two young Maryland sisters, Paige and Brooke Simonsen, successfully advocated for hunters in the state to wear daylight fluorescent pink safety gear, leading to the passage of a bill allowing the color as an alternative to blaze orange. Although their campaign referenced a disputed blog post by Stihl claiming pink is safer than orange—later revealed to be an April Fool’s joke—state officials say the study did not influence the legislation.

title: Maryland lawmakers tackle health care proposals
summary: Maryland lawmakers are advancing health care proposals aimed at countering federal policy changes, including applying for a federal waiver, creating a reinsurance pool, and reinstating an individual insurance mandate. Advocates argue these measures will protect the state's healthcare system, maintain affordability, and build on the Affordable Care Act.

title: Maryland bill would put an armed officer in every school
summary: Maryland lawmakers are pushing a bill to place an armed officer in every public school as part of a four-bill package aimed at improving school safety in the wake of recent shootings. The measure, set to take effect in July, would cost approximately $224 million in its first year to hire and train nearly 1,000 new officers.

title: Orioles fans celebrate the opening day of baseball season
summary: Baltimore Orioles fans celebrated the start of the 2018 baseball season with hopes of a playoff run. The team opened the season with optimism for a successful year.

title: Local high school lacrosse stand-out uses experimental treatment to battle rare disease
summary: Peighton Stone, a top high school lacrosse player from Maryland, faced a rare disease that nearly ended her athletic career before she received an experimental treatment from a Wyoming doctor. Now recovered, she is set to play for Division One Elon University’s lacrosse team.

title: Students talk school safety, gun control with Senator Ben Cardin
summary: Students from the Seed School in Baltimore met with Senator Ben Cardin to discuss school safety and gun control. They shared their concerns and suggestions for addressing the issue.

title: The Washington Bullpen, Episode 9
summary: In episode 9 of *The Washington Bullpen*, reporters Jarod Golub and Julia Karron cover the March For Our Lives, Stormy Daniels' interview on *60 Minutes*, and Mark Zuckerberg's possible congressional testimony over the Cambridge Analytica scandal.

title: Maryland craft brewers hope to press for revamping laws next year
summary: Maryland's craft brewers and allies failed to pass legislation this year to ease production and distribution restrictions, but plan to continue pushing for reform next session. Despite broad support, the Reform on Tap Act was defeated, with advocates arguing the state should make it easier for small businesses to thrive.

title: Maryland gerrymandering case makes its way to the U.S. Supreme Court
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court heard a gerrymandering case involving Maryland’s 6th congressional district, Benisek vs.

title: Maryland gerrymandering case gets Supreme Court hearing
summary: The Supreme Court heard oral arguments in *Benisek v. Lamone*, a case challenging Maryland’s 2011 redistricting as an unconstitutional partisan gerrymander under the First Amendment.

title: Prince George’s joins NAACP suit over 2020 Census
summary: Prince George’s County joined the NAACP in filing a lawsuit against the Trump administration, alleging that the 2020 Census plans risk undercounting minority populations and failing to meet constitutional standards. The lawsuit criticizes the administration's handling of the digital census and seeks legal action to ensure a fair and accurate count.

title: The hunt for exoplanets
summary: A planet potentially composed of diamonds has been discovered 40 light years from Earth. NASA researchers believe it orbits a distant star, making it a fascinating target in the search for exoplanets.

title: Supreme Court to hear Maryland gerrymandering case on Wednesday
summary: The U.S. Supreme Court will hear a gerrymandering case from Maryland, where congressional district lines drawn by Democrats in 2011 are accused of diluting Republican voting power.

title: Buildings demolished to help Baltimore fight crime, rebuild neighborhoods
summary: Baltimore is demolishing abandoned buildings as part of Project C.O.R.E. to combat crime and revitalize neighborhoods.

title: Pick your perfect breakfast and find out which WMATA lip balm you are
summary: The article invites readers to take a quiz matching their breakfast preference with a WMATA lip balm flavor. It also encourages watching CNS reporters sample all six lip balm flavors for a detailed review.

title: Maryland Senate considers bill banning gay  conversion therapy
summary: The Maryland Senate has given preliminary approval to a bill that would ban gay conversion therapy by health professionals on minors, making the state potentially the 10th to do so. Violators would face disciplinary action from the state's licensing board.

title: The Annapolis Bullpen: #Metoo in Annapolis
summary: The Annapolis Bullpen examines the impact of the Me Too movement on the Annapolis Legislature, focusing on recent sexual harassment allegations. Lawmakers are considering new bills aimed at addressing and preventing workplace harassment.

title: Thousands rally in DC for March for Our Lives
summary: Thousands of students and supporters gathered in Washington, D.C., for the March for Our Lives, calling for stronger gun laws and school safety measures. The rally, organized by Parkland survivors, followed a recent school shooting in Maryland and featured participants from across the U.S.

title: Do Ho Suh’s “Almost Home” premieres at the Smithsonian
summary: Do Ho Suh’s new immersive exhibit, “Almost Home,” premieres at the Smithsonian American Art Museum, featuring hand-sewn structures representing his homes in Seoul, Berlin, and New York City. It marks the artist’s first major East Coast exhibition, running from March 16 to August 5.

title: Local farm provides second chance for abused horses
summary: A local farm in Howard County, Maryland, is giving abused and neglected horses a second chance, rescuing them from potential slaughter. The 60-acre facility provides a safe haven for horses that might otherwise have no future.

title: New exhibit offers virtual, alternative cherry blossom experience
summary: A new virtual exhibit at ARTECHOUSE in Washington offers an interactive cherry blossom experience as cold weather delays the natural bloom. The exhibit is located near the National Mall and provides an alternative way to enjoy the blossoms.

title: International rugby to make history in Washington in June
summary: South Africa and Wales will play a historic international rugby match at RFK Stadium in Washington on June 2, marking the first time the venue hosts such a high-profile game. The event aims to boost rugby’s growing popularity in the region, which already has a strong grassroots presence and is one of the fastest-growing areas for the sport in the U.S.

title: CNS reviews new WMATA lip balm
summary: WMATA recently launched a pop-up shop featuring metro-themed merchandise, including a new line of flavored lip balms. Capital News Service reviewed six varieties, each named after and flavored to match a Metro line.

title: HBCU settlement pending; Md. lawmakers say it’s not enough
summary: Maryland lawmakers reject a $100 million settlement offer over a decade for historically Black colleges, calling it insufficient compared to the estimated $2.5 billion to $3 billion they claim the state owes. The dispute stems from a 2013 court ruling that found the state violated HBCUs' rights by duplicating academic programs at predominantly white institutions.

title: Bill would clarify Maryland law to try to save lives
summary: A proposed bill in Maryland seeks to clarify the state's Good Samaritan Law by removing the requirement that an overdose victim must "reasonably believe" they are experiencing a medical emergency to qualify for legal protection. The legislation aims to encourage witnesses to seek help without fear of incriminating the victim and clarifies that evidence obtained from the incident can only be used for non-drug-related charges.

title: The Washington Bullpen, Episode 8
summary: In the latest episode of “The Washington Bullpen,” hosts analyze the outcome of Pennsylvania’s special House election and its impact on the 2018 midterms. They also examine an upcoming Supreme Court case on Maryland gerrymandering.

title: Despite Sunshine Week, critics say secrecy plagues Trump administration
summary: Critics argue that the Trump administration has been marked by secrecy, with a high percentage of FOIA requests being withheld or censored and ongoing questions about financial conflicts and transparency. Lawmakers have highlighted these concerns, calling attention to the administration's lack of openness during National Sunshine Week.

title: Committee weighs bill to enforce Maryland hiring law
summary: A Maryland House committee debated a bill introduced by Delegate Clarence Lam to increase oversight of state hiring practices, in response to concerns that a 2017 policy change at the Department of Health may have improperly expanded the governor’s office’s role in employee vetting. Republicans and the governor’s office denied any policy shift, stating that vetting is standard and does not interfere with agencies’ hiring decisions.

title: In-state tuition bill aimed at Dreamers advances in Md.
summary: A new bill in Maryland aims to expand in-state tuition access for undocumented students, or "Dreamers," by allowing them to enroll directly in any public four-year university and removing credit and location requirements. If passed, the legislation would take effect in July and extend eligibility for six years after high school graduation.

title: Thousands of DMV students stage walkout for stricter gun regulation and greater school security
summary: Thousands of students in the DMV area participated in a walkout and 17-minute silent protest calling for stricter gun regulations and improved school safety. The demonstration aimed to pressure the White House and Congress to take action on student protections and gun control.

title: Women block State House entrance to protest Potomac Pipeline
summary: Five women, identifying as mothers and grandmothers, were arrested after blocking the entrance to the Maryland State House to protest the Potomac pipeline project. They were released without charges as a decision on the project was anticipated the following day.

title: Child gun deaths marked by display of thousands of empty shoes on the lawn of the Capitol
summary: Tom Mauser, whose son died in the Columbine shooting, brought his son's shoes to a Capitol display of 7,000 pairs representing child gun deaths since Sandy Hook. The emotional exhibit aimed to highlight the ongoing crisis of gun violence affecting children in the U.S.

title: Non-public school students rally at the State House to encourage continued state aid
summary: Non-public school students gathered at the Maryland State House to advocate for continued state support of the BOOST scholarship program. The event, organized by the Council of American Private Education, brought students from across the state to meet with lawmakers in Annapolis.

title: Hogan’s nonpublic schools funding gets ‘BOOST’ from students
summary: Hundreds of private school students and supporters rallied in Annapolis to support Governor Larry Hogan’s BOOST program, which provides scholarships for low-income students to attend nonpublic schools. Advocates emphasized the importance of funding for nonpublic education, while opponents argue public funds should prioritize public schools.

title: Baltimore man on a mission to get more kids to share his love of baseball
summary: Andy Weltlinger, a former collegiate baseball player, has launched the Baltimore Urban Baseball Association (BUBA Baseball) to revive interest in the sport among local youth. His mission aims to encourage more kids in Baltimore to experience and enjoy the game of baseball.

title: Maryland lawmaker wants state funding eliminated for artificial turf fields and playgrounds
summary: A Maryland senator is sponsoring legislation to eliminate state funding for artificial turf fields and playgrounds. The proposal is driven by concerns over potential health risks linked to synthetic turf surfaces.

title: Prince George’s Police Chief takes part in U.S. Senate democratic hearing on gun violence and school safety
summary: Prince George’s County Police Chief Hank Stawinski participated in a U.S. Senate Democratic hearing on gun violence and school safety, joining advocates urging Congress to prioritize action over politics.

title: Maryland bill addresses questions about state hiring policy
summary: A proposed Maryland bill seeks to address concerns over a potential shift in hiring policies at the state Department of Health, which some lawmakers believe may undermine a 2007 law limiting the Governor’s Appointments Office’s influence over certain state agency personnel decisions. The law was originally enacted after former Gov.

title: Metro’s M Shop draws rider backlash
summary: The Washington Metro has faced rider backlash for opening the M Shop, a retail store in Metro Center station selling branded merchandise, with critics arguing the transit authority should prioritize safety over sales. Despite the criticism, Metro officials say the store generates revenue for the system and allows commuters and visitors to take home a piece of the iconic Metro brand.

title: The Washington Bullpen, Episode 7
summary: In this week's episode of *The Washington Bullpen*, hosts Julia Karron and Jarod Golub discuss the resolved teachers' strike in West Virginia and Gary Cohn's resignation. They also explore the new WMATA M shop with reporter Julia Lerner.

title: Maryland schools need more physical education, lawmaker says
summary: A Maryland lawmaker is pushing for legislation to increase physical education time in elementary schools to 90 minutes per week, but the bill has stalled for years due to concerns over cutting academic time. Supporters argue current physical activity requirements are being skirted, with recess sometimes counted instead of structured PE.

title: Van Hollen, Rubio seek ballot protections against foreign meddling
summary: Sens. Chris Van Hollen and Marco Rubio introduced the DETER Act to impose strong sanctions on foreign entities, especially Russia, that attempt to interfere in U.S.

title: Wine enthusiasts celebrate #MarylandWineMonth
summary: Maryland Wine Month, hosted by the Maryland Wine Association, celebrates the state's growing wine industry with events, special offers, and social media engagement. With nearly 1,000 acres of grapevines, Maryland wineries invite visitors to enjoy local wines and participate in the Wine Month Challenge.

title: Annapolis Roundup: Medical cannabis, other bills advance
summary: Maryland's House of Delegates passed legislation expanding minority ownership in the medical cannabis industry, increasing license caps and creating a compassionate use fund. Separately, a constitutional amendment allowing same-day voter registration passed, aiming to improve electoral accessibility.

title: Resolutions address gender gap in Maryland businesses
summary: Lawmakers in Maryland are addressing the underrepresentation of women in top business leadership roles, with resolutions urging companies to increase gender diversity and aim for at least 30% female board representation by 2021. A recent census revealed slow progress, prompting calls for greater accountability and annual tracking of gender equity in leadership.

title: State may be paying more for some Purple Line properties
summary: Maryland may be paying more than appraised values for some properties critical to the Purple Line project due to limited negotiating power and the need to avoid costly delays. The state is acquiring these properties through either the Maryland Transit Administration or the State Highway Administration, depending on their location.

title: Baltimore City police use swimming to bridge gap with youth
summary: Baltimore City police are using a swimming program to build trust and strengthen relationships with local youth. The initiative brings together officers and children in a shared activity aimed at fostering community connections.

title: Legislative battle is personal for woman who lost family members to suicide
summary: Dorothy Paugh, a Bowie resident who lost her father and son to suicide, is advocating for Maryland's red flag legislation to allow the seizure of weapons from individuals with a history of domestic violence or depression. She hopes the bill will help prevent other families from experiencing similar tragedies.

title: Better ball movement comes at a cost for the Wizards
summary: The Washington Wizards have improved their ball movement and assist rates significantly in the absence of John Wall, with Bradley Beal and Tomas Satoransky stepping up as primary playmakers. However, this increased passing has come at a cost, as the team has also seen a rise in turnovers, ranking among the worst in the league in that category.
