title: General Assembly celebrates Shock Trauma leader’s decades of service
summary: Lawmakers in Annapolis honored Dr. Thomas Scalea for his two decades of leadership at the University of Maryland’s Shock Trauma Center.

title: High school culinary talents put to the test in annual competition
summary: High school cooking teams from across Maryland competed in the annual Prostart Student Invitation in Baltimore. Winners earned scholarships and recognition for their culinary talents.

title: Area readies for an early bloom for Washington’s famed cherry blossoms
summary: Washington's cherry blossoms are expected to reach peak bloom early, between March 17 and 20. The trees, a gift from Japan first planted in 1912, signal the arrival of spring.

title: Governor Larry Hogan commits $175 million to increase school safety
summary: Governor Larry Hogan has committed $175 million to enhance school safety in Maryland, including $125 million for physical security measures like metal detectors and $50 million for counselors, officers, and technology. The initiative follows the Parkland school shooting and aims to prevent similar incidents in the state.

title: Threats made against Maryland schools increase following Parkland massacre
summary: Maryland school systems, including Anne Arundel County, are experiencing an increase in threats following the Parkland school shooting. School officials and teachers' unions in the county remain opposed to arming instructors on school grounds.

title: Anne Arundel County animal shelter’s reading program helps community bond with animals
summary: An Anne Arundel County teenager has created a community-bonding initiative by combining books and shelter animals. The program, based at the local animal shelter, uses reading sessions to connect people with pets.

title: Supporters, opponents square off over proposed hike in state’s minimum wage
summary: Supporters of a proposed minimum wage increase in Maryland argue it would help lift working families out of poverty. Opponents warn it could harm small businesses and lead to job losses.

title: The Washington Bullpen, Episode 6
summary: In Episode 6 of the Washington Bullpen, the hosts cover recent Supreme Court of the United States (SCOTUS) actions and NCAA corruption. They also discuss proposed craft brewery legislation.

title: What you need to know about the SCMAGLEV project
summary: Transportation officials are advancing plans for the Northeast Maglev, a high-speed train aiming to connect Washington, D.C. and Baltimore in 15 minutes, with two potential routes under consideration.

title: In Congress, only one Maryland lawmaker gets NRA money
summary: Only one Maryland lawmaker, Rep. Andy Harris, has received NRA campaign contributions this year, totaling $25,447 since 2008.

title: Bills would update Maryland’s forest conservation law
summary: Maryland legislators are considering bills to strengthen the state's 1991 Forest Conservation Act by requiring a one-to-one replanting ratio and better protecting priority forest areas. Developers oppose the changes, arguing they are too restrictive, while environmentalists say the current law fails to safeguard the state’s most valuable forests.

title: Md. Senate passes revised cyberbullying law
summary: Maryland’s Senate passed "Grace’s Law 2.0," updating the 2013 cyberbullying law to address social media harassment and giving school officials more direct authority to report incidents. The legislation, inspired by similar efforts in Texas, aims to streamline legal protections for victims and respond more quickly to online bullying.

title: Baltimore is a popular site for Oscar-nominated movies filmed in Maryland
summary: Baltimore has served as a popular filming location for 15 Oscar-nominated movies since 1945, with a combined total of 42 nominations and six wins. Although being nominated doesn't guarantee box office success, Maryland remains a key location for award-worthy films.

title: Gallery: Trump, Congress honor Graham under Capitol Rotunda
summary: The late Rev. Billy Graham was honored in a memorial service under the Capitol Rotunda, becoming the first religious leader and fourth U.S.

title: The  Annapolis Bullpen: Where’s the line?
summary: The Annapolis Bullpen podcast examines gerrymandering in Maryland, discussing how districts are drawn and who represents residents. The episode highlights the unique aspects of Maryland's political landscape in comparison to other states.

title: WMATA delays prompt backlash on Twitter after #Back2Good campaign launch
summary: Significant delays on the Orange and Silver Metro Lines due to a brake malfunction sparked backlash on Twitter, overshadowing WMATA's recent "Back2Good" campaign promoting improved service. While WMATA highlighted achievements like on-time arrivals and safety improvements, many riders remain skeptical, criticizing the system's ongoing reliability issues.

title: Bill expanding medical cannabis licenses amended
summary: Maryland lawmakers have approved amendments to a bill aimed at expanding medical cannabis licenses and increasing minority and women's participation in the industry. The revised legislation includes additional funding for the state’s medical cannabis commission and raises the license cap for cannabis growers from 15 to 20.

title: Annapolis rally calls on Governor to fully fund mental health, addiction aid
summary: Hundreds gathered in Annapolis to call on Governor Hogan to fully fund mental health and addiction programs. They argue his budget proposal does not adequately support a recently expanded initiative to address the opioid crisis.

title: The Washington Bullpen, Episode 5
summary: Julia Karron and Jarod Golub discuss the Parkland shooting, gun control legislation, and the latest developments from the Mueller investigation on this week’s “Washington Bullpen.” Karron also interviews Hannah Yasharoff about the White House Historical Association’s new Christmas ornament.

title: Local teams are vying for trips to the NCAA Men’s Basketball Tournament
summary: Local college basketball teams from Maryland, Virginia, and Washington, D.C. are competing for spots in the NCAA Men’s Basketball Tournament as the regular season winds down.

title: Navy Marine-Corps Memorial Stadium begins transformation for Capitals Stadium Series match-up
summary: The Navy Marine-Corps Memorial Stadium in Annapolis is being converted into an outdoor hockey rink for the Washington Capitals' game against the Toronto Maple Leafs as part of the NHL's Stadium Series on March 3rd. This will be the third outdoor game for both teams.

title: Local health officials say risk of getting the flu is still high
summary: Local health officials in Maryland report that the risk of getting the flu remains high, despite this time of year typically seeing a decline. The flu season has been particularly severe, with new cases continuing to rise nationwide.

title: League of Dreams gives children with special needs a chance at baseball
summary: The University of Maryland baseball team partnered with League of Dreams to host a clinic for children with special needs. The event provided students from Prince George’s County and Washington D.C.

title: State delegate works to make streets safer following grandson’s murder
summary: Baltimore City Delegate Talmadge Branch is pushing for legislation to expand a violence prevention program after his grandson was one of the 342 homicide victims in the city last year. His goal is to prevent future tragedies by making the streets safer for residents.

title: Baltimore joint crime effort nets hundreds of arrests
summary: Federal, state, and local law enforcement in Baltimore collaborated over 60 days to combat violent crime, resulting in hundreds of arrests. The operation led to ten murder charges, ten attempted murder charges, and 76 assault-related charges.

title: Montgomery County students walk out of class, demand change in gun legislation
summary: Montgomery County students participated in a rally at the White House, joining regional peers to demand changes in gun legislation. They aimed to support calls for preventing school shootings like the one at Parkland, Florida, which resulted in 17 deaths.

title: College players and pros provide some special baseball lessons for area kids
summary: University of Maryland baseball players and former MLB players conducted a clinic for local children with special needs. The event was organized by League of Dreams, a non-profit dedicated to teaching baseball to children with mental or physical disabilities.

title: “Black Panther” dominates the box office — and social media
summary: "Black Panther" dominated the box office with a record-breaking $242 million opening weekend, praised for its diversity and portrayal of African cultures. Maryland celebrities and Hollywood stars alike celebrated the film on social media, highlighting its cultural impact and success.

title: Navy-Marine Corps Memorial Stadium starts transformation into hockey rink
summary: The National Hockey League is transforming the Navy-Marine Corps Memorial Stadium football field into a hockey rink for a historic outdoor game between the Washington Capitals and Toronto Maple Leafs on March 3. The event, the first NHL game at a service academy, will involve careful ice-making adjustments due to unpredictable weather and mark the largest professional event in the stadium's 58-year history.

title: Critics hit Trump’s food program plan as ‘devastating’ to Maryland
summary: President Trump’s 2019 budget proposal to overhaul the SNAP program has drawn sharp criticism from Maryland’s Democratic leaders, who warn it would devastate over 750,000 residents, including many children and seniors. Critics argue the plan, which includes replacing the current system with a meal delivery model and reducing benefits, would threaten food security while favoring corporate tax cuts over helping the poor.

title: Maryland SoccerPlex and D.C. United prep for unusual season home opener
summary: D.C. United will hold its 2018 MLS home opener against the Houston Dynamo at the Maryland SoccerPlex on March 17 due to the delayed opening of its new Audi Field stadium.

title: Hogan, Democrat introduce bills creating school watchdogs
summary: Republican Gov. Larry Hogan and a Democratic lawmaker have introduced bills to create independent investigative offices to oversee Maryland's public schools, prompted by allegations of grade-fixing and corruption.

title: It may be February, but it’s Christmas at the White House Historical Association
summary: The White House Historical Association unveiled its 38th official Christmas ornament, highlighting President Harry S. Truman and featuring design elements from his presidency, including the Truman Balcony, the renovated Blue Room, and the updated presidential seal.

title: Gun safety bills pushed in Congress after Florida shooting
summary: Following the Florida school shooting, some members of Congress are pushing for new gun safety legislation, including raising the minimum age to purchase semi-automatic rifles to 21. Additionally, bipartisan support is growing for the "Fix NICS Act," which aims to improve the reliability of background checks with apparent backing from President Trump.

title: Md. lawmakers want to increase sanctions for murder-for-hire
summary: Maryland lawmakers are pushing to eliminate the statute of limitations for murder-for-hire and upgrade solicitation to commit murder from a misdemeanor to a felony. They argue that the complexity of modern investigations often requires more time to build solid cases and hold all involved parties accountable.

title: Maryland delegate sponsors bill allowing school employees to carry guns
summary: Maryland Delegate Rick Impallaria is sponsoring a bill to allow school employees to carry firearms on school grounds in response to recent school shootings. The proposal aims to enhance school safety through additional protocols and a comprehensive protection plan.

title: Bill proposes age limits on tackle football for young athletes
summary: A proposed bill in Maryland would restrict tackle football in public schools to only high school athletes. The legislation comes as concerns grow over the long-term effects of youth participation in contact sports.

title: Anne Arundel County receives additional help to combat homelessness
summary: Anne Arundel County is receiving a new HUD grant to expand its efforts in helping homeless residents. The program has already helped individuals like Ossie Jones regain stability after job loss and homelessness.

title: The Washington Bullpen, Episode 4
summary: The Washington Bullpen podcast discusses recent political developments in the nation's capital, focusing on legislative challenges and policy debates. Guests analyze the implications of these events on the upcoming elections and public opinion.

title: Pipeline protesters take frustrations to Hogan’s doorstep
summary: Environmentalists protested in Annapolis, urging Maryland to thoroughly review the environmental impact of the proposed Potomac Pipeline, which would transport fracked gas under the river. While state officials claimed a "robust review" is underway, protesters argue the response has been insufficient and delayed.

title: Bill would criminalize knowing failure to report child abuse
summary: A Maryland bill aims to criminalize knowingly failing to report child abuse, making it a misdemeanor punishable by up to six months in jail and a $1,000 fine. While the Senate has passed the legislation, the House remains cautious, with some lawmakers concerned about potential over-reporting and the need to assess the impact of existing laws first.

title: #InfrastructurePlan versus #InfrastructureScam: Trump’s proposed plan sparks debate online
summary: President Trump proposed a $1.5 trillion infrastructure plan over 10 years, shifting more financial responsibility to states and local governments while allowing toll increases on interstates. Critics argue the plan would burden commuters, favor private investors, and neglect essential public assets.

title: Maryland politicians among those reacting to Florida school shooting on social media
summary: A mass shooting at Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Florida, left 17 people dead, with the suspect charged with 17 counts of premeditated murder. Maryland politicians, along with others, expressed grief on social media and called for gun reform in response to the tragedy.

title: Maryland Education panel releases recommendations
summary: A Maryland education panel has recommended expanding pre-kindergarten and special education funding, promoting early literacy, and reinstating vocational training to better prepare students for the workforce and higher education. The proposed reforms, to be implemented gradually over about a decade, aim to address educational inequities and improve outcomes for at-risk students.

title: Activists seek support for bills in Annapolis aimed at helping research animals find homes
summary: Animal advocates in Annapolis are urging legislators to support bills that would facilitate the adoption of research animals. The proposed legislation also requires research facilities to report on the post-study fate of the animals.

title: Legislative roundup: Oyster recycling; tobacco; female inmate health services
summary: Maryland’s Senate passed a bill to double the tax credit for oyster shell recycling, encouraging more restaurants to participate in the program, which supports oyster restoration in the Chesapeake Bay. The legislation also makes the program permanent, aiming to provide long-term benefits for restaurants, oyster producers, and the environment.

title: Investigation underway into shooting and SUV crash at NSA’s entrance
summary: Three people are in custody after an SUV crashed into the entrance of the National Security Agency headquarters in Fort Meade, Maryland. The FBI is investigating the incident, which involved gunfire directed at the vehicle.

title: Baltimoreans reflect after 12-day homicide-free streak
summary: Baltimore experienced a 12-day period without any homicides for the first time in years, offering a brief respite from its ongoing violent crime crisis. The streak ended with two murders, but Mayor Catherine Pugh remains hopeful about turning the city’s safety situation around.

title: Maryland health coaches and supporters hit Capitol Hill to mark “Health and Wellness Coach Week”
summary: Health and wellness coaches from Maryland gathered on Capitol Hill to celebrate the first-ever “Health and Wellness Coach Week.” They emphasized the transformative impact of promoting good nutrition and mental health education.

title: Supporters, opponents of high speed rail square off at Annapolis demonstration
summary: Supporters and opponents of a proposed high-speed Maglev rail line between New York and Washington gathered in Annapolis to voice their views. Supporters highlight environmental benefits and reduced travel time, while opponents argue the massive cost should be allocated elsewhere.

title: Bill gives parents ‘new tool’ to fight child’s addiction
summary: A new Maryland bill, sponsored by Delegate Nic Kipke, aims to give parents more authority to help adult children struggling with opioid addiction, particularly as fentanyl and carfentanil-related deaths have sharply increased. The legislation follows concerns over the potency and deadly impact of synthetic opioids, which are often manufactured in overseas labs.

title: Trump’s proposed Chesapeake Bay cleanup cuts face Hill battle
summary: President Donald Trump's proposal to cut 90% of Chesapeake Bay cleanup funding faces strong opposition from Maryland’s Democratic leaders, who warn it would jeopardize decades of environmental progress and the state’s economy. Critics argue the drastic reduction, part of broader EPA budget cuts, risks undoing gains in water quality and threatens industries reliant on a healthy bay.

title: Proposal to keep FBI headquarters in Washington meets resistance
summary: Maryland officials criticized the General Services Administration's proposal to build a new FBI headquarters in downtown Washington instead of Prince George’s County, calling it a waste of taxpayer money and missing economic opportunity. The plan, which includes demolishing and rebuilding on the current site at a cost of $3.3 billion, is part of President Trump’s broader $199 billion infrastructure initiative.

title: Sponsor of bill to legalize hemp in Maryland thinks this is the year
summary: Proponents of a bill to legalize industrial hemp in Maryland argue it offers economic potential and emphasize the need for public education to distinguish hemp from marijuana. Hemp contains less than 0.3% THC and is grown for fiber and oil, unlike marijuana, which is cultivated for its psychoactive properties.

title: Cardin introduces legislation banning military parades and exhibitions
summary: Senator Ben Cardin has introduced legislation to ban federal funding for military parades and exhibitions beyond routine operations, in response to President Trump's interest in hosting a large military display. The proposal has drawn support from several Democratic lawmakers and public opposition, with critics arguing the funds would be better spent on military readiness rather than symbolic events.

title: The Washington Bullpen, Episode 3
summary: The third episode of "The Washington Bullpen" covers topics including the upcoming Pyeongchang Olympics and the new budget bill. In a special segment, hosts discuss President Trump’s military parade and its potential cost to taxpayers.

title: Governor joins in effort to encourage screening for cancer
summary: Governor Hogan joined the Maryland Dermatologic Society in promoting regular cancer screenings, emphasizing their importance during an event at the State House. He highlighted the issue after undergoing treatment for non-malignant skin lesions, as skin cancer diagnoses in the U.S.

title: New study finds drowsy driving bigger problem than found in earlier studies
summary: A new study by Triple A reveals that 10 percent of car crashes are caused by drowsy driving, making it a more significant issue than previously thought. The findings are based on an analysis of dashcam footage from over 700 crashes.

title: Md. athletes competing for Team USA share excitement on social media
summary: Three Maryland athletes—Haley Skarupa, Thomas Hong, and Noah Grove—are competing for Team USA in the 2018 Winter Olympics and Paralympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea. They shared their excitement and preparation for the games through social media posts.

title: Md. juvenile agency says later school hours could curb crime
summary: Maryland's Department of Juvenile Services is advocating for later school start and end times to reduce juvenile crime, which spikes between 3 p.m. and 7 p.m.

title: The Annapolis Bullpen: Budget, taxes and your wallet
summary: The Annapolis Bullpen podcast examines Maryland’s budget and Governor Larry Hogan’s priorities. It also discusses the impact of new federal tax laws on the state and residents.

title: Curling and cocktails to mark an Olympic season
summary: Residents of Washington's Wharf District recently enjoyed a unique blend of curling and cocktails as part of an Olympic-themed event. The activity offered a preview of the upcoming Winter Games by allowing participants to experience the sport on the ice.

title: Lawmaker proposes bill for reducing community college tuition
summary: Maryland State Senator Paul Pinsky is proposing a bill to reduce community college tuition through new initiatives funded by a 19 percent income tax on investment management services. The measure aims to create a better-educated workforce as requested by the business community.

title: Montgomery County latest jurisdiction to sue opioid manufacturers
summary: Montgomery County has filed a lawsuit against 14 opioid manufacturers and distributors, joining other Maryland counties in holding them accountable. County Executive Ike Leggett claims the companies are responsible for excessive production and over-prescribing of prescription opioids.

title: State House Democrats push to ban bump stocks, repeal Handgun Permit Review Board
summary: Maryland State House Democrats are advocating for new gun safety measures, including a ban on bump stocks that can make semi-automatic weapons fire more rapidly. They also propose replacing the Handgun Permit Review Board with administrative law judges to handle permit reviews.

title: Legislative Roundup: elephants, artificial turf, unspecified gender
summary: Maryland legislators are considering bills to ban the use of elephants in traveling animal shows, prohibit state funding for artificial turf in playgrounds and fields, and add an "unspecified" gender option to state IDs and licenses. The elephant bill, sponsored by Delegate Aruna Miller, aims to penalize the inhumane treatment of elephants in traveling acts.

title: Proposed Annapolis bill would allow victims of abuse to keep property records private
summary: Maryland legislators are proposing bills to allow survivors of domestic violence, stalking, and human trafficking to keep their property records private by using a substitute address through the Safe At Home Address Confidentiality Program. The identical bills aim to formalize existing practices into law, ensuring victims can pursue homeownership without exposing their identities to potential abusers.

title: Mayors join Maryland Comptroller in call for change in craft brewery regulations
summary: Mayors from Annapolis, Frederick, Cambridge, and Ocean City joined Maryland Comptroller Peter Franchot in supporting the Reform on Tap Act of 2018. The legislation aims to remove production and sales restrictions for craft breweries and allow local control over operating hours.

title: Community celebrates 100th birthday of World War II veteran
summary: Vivian Millie Bailey, a World War II veteran and retired teacher, celebrated her 100th birthday in Columbia, Maryland. Though she acknowledges progress for African Americans since her time in service, she believes there is still work to be done.

title: Bills on live video, pink hunting gear, organ transplants
summary: The Hogan administration has proposed legislation to livestream Maryland General Assembly sessions, aiming to increase government transparency. Other bills address personal tax exemptions, repeal outdated slavery-era insurance provisions, and crack down on repeat drunk-driving offenses.

title: Eagles win first ever Super Bowl
summary: The Philadelphia Eagles won their first-ever Super Bowl with a 41-33 victory over the New England Patriots, sealing the win after a crucial fumble by Tom Brady late in the game. Despite a strong comeback attempt by Brady, the Eagles' defense and quarterback Nick Foles secured the historic win.

title: Maryland native Hollins took complex route to NFL
summary: Mack Hollins, a Maryland native and former Wootton High School standout, took an unconventional path to the NFL, including no Division I scholarship offers and a walk-on role at UNC Chapel Hill, before becoming a rookie with the Super Bowl-bound Philadelphia Eagles. His unique personality and determination have defined his journey, earning praise from coaches and teammates alike.

title: The Washington Bullpen, Episode 2
summary: The second episode of "The Washington Bullpen" podcast covers the State of the Union, the Washington Wizards, and the 2020 presidential campaign. Hosted by Julia Karron and Jarod Golub, the episode is part of Capital News Service's Washington Bureau offerings.

title: Gallery: D.C. United’s topping off ceremony at Audi Field
summary: D.C. United fans attended a topping off ceremony on Jan.

title: Patriots’ Belichick has maintained his lacrosse roots
summary: Bill Belichick, renowned for his NFL coaching career, has maintained a lifelong passion for lacrosse, regularly visiting Johns Hopkins University's team and engaging with players since 2006. His deep connection to the sport began during his college years at Wesleyan, where he played and helped strategize games as an assistant.

title: Before the Eagles, speedy Ronald Darby dominated in Maryland
summary: Ronald Darby, now a cornerback for the Philadelphia Eagles, showcased his exceptional speed and determination during his high school football career in Maryland, which helped propel him to Florida State and the NFL. Known as one of the fastest high school sprinters in the country, Darby credits his natural speed to his genes and has used it to become a key player in the Eagles' Super Bowl-bound defense.

title: Gov. Hogan announces cancer diagnosis; bills of interest
summary: Governor Larry Hogan announced he has a common, non-serious form of skin cancer and will undergo Mohs surgery, attributing it to past sun exposure, and is expected to return to work with stitches. Meanwhile, the Maryland General Assembly is considering a bill to decriminalize adultery, which is currently a minor offense in the state.

title: Three Maryland athletes competing in South Korea games
summary: Three Maryland athletes—Haley Skarupa, Thomas Hong, and Noah Grove—are competing in the 2018 Winter Olympics and Paralympics in Pyeongchang, South Korea, aiming to bring home gold. Skarupa, a top women’s ice hockey player from Rockville, has a strong collegiate and international hockey background and continues to represent Maryland on the global stage.

title: Maryland alum Smith playing in his second Super Bowl
summary: Former Maryland standout Torrey Smith is playing in his second Super Bowl with the Philadelphia Eagles, serving as a mentor to younger players after a decline in his own production. Smith, known for his speed and leadership, will face the New England Patriots in Sunday's game.

title: State House Democrats and educators want gambling revenue to fund public school system
summary: State House Democrats and Maryland educators are urging lawmakers to approve a constitutional amendment that would direct all state gambling revenue toward public school funding. They argue more financial support is essential to address the needs of Maryland’s public education system.

title: Hogan touts fiscal focus, criticizes national divisiveness in State of State
summary: In his final State of the State address before seeking re-election, Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan emphasized fiscal responsibility and bipartisan cooperation while distancing himself from national political conflicts, particularly those involving President Donald Trump.

title: Without John Wall, the Wizards’ success hinges on others
summary: The Washington Wizards face a critical six-to-eight-week stretch without All-Star point guard John Wall due to knee surgery, putting their playoff hopes at risk. The team will rely on backup Tomáš Satoranský, who has shown promise in increased playing time, to lead them through a challenging schedule.

title: Maryland presidential hopeful Delaney striking out for Iowa – again
summary: Maryland Rep. John Delaney is making a sixth trip to Iowa as part of a million-dollar ad campaign to boost his 2020 presidential bid, emphasizing bipartisan solutions and early voter outreach.

title: Maryland lawmakers promise to fight Trump “tooth and nail” after SOTU
summary: Maryland’s Democratic lawmakers criticized President Trump’s State of the Union address as lacking substantive policy and genuine bipartisan effort, calling out what they described as empty promises and false claims. They pledged to resist his policies "tooth and nail" if he continues his current approach.

title: Trump’s first State of the Union address prompts partisan response on Twitter
summary: President Trump's first State of the Union address covered topics like infrastructure, immigration, and bipartisanship, drawing strong partisan reactions. Republican leaders praised his message and policies, while Democrats criticized the speech for deepening divisions rather than promoting unity.

title: Experience at Maryland high school propelled Rodney McLeod to Super Bowl
summary: Rodney McLeod's standout high school career at DeMatha Catholic in Maryland, where he played multiple positions and won four league titles, laid the foundation for his NFL success. His work ethic, developed through film study and relentless preparation, has propelled him to a key role with the Philadelphia Eagles as they pursue their first Super Bowl victory.

title: ‘#MeToo’ movement could buoy success for Maryland bills
summary: Maryland lawmakers passed bills aimed at ending parental rights for rapists and addressing sexual assault and domestic violence, reflecting the influence of the #MeToo movement on shifting societal and legal attitudes. The legislation, now pending final approval, highlights increased support for survivors and aims to strengthen legal protections for women.

title: Protesters rally at the March on DC for a Better Tomorrow
summary: Thousands gathered in Washington for the “People’s March On Washington,” calling for a better tomorrow ahead of President Trump’s State of the Union address. Organized by “People Demand Action,” the protest marked the start of efforts to mobilize ahead of the 2018 elections.

title: D.C. United and fans celebrate topping-off new stadium
summary: D.C. United fans celebrated the placement of the final steel beam at the new Audi Field stadium in Buzzard Point, signing it with messages and team chants.

title: The Washington Bullpen, Episode 1
summary: The first episode of Capital News Service’s new podcast, *The Washington Bullpen*, hosted by Julia Karron and Jarod Golub, covers the March for Life, the Women’s March, and Maryland Olympic athletes. The podcast aims to explore key political and social issues from the Washington Bureau perspective.

title: Baltimore Blockade: Protesters block Guilford Avenue beside homeless encampment
summary: Protesters blocked Guilford Avenue in Baltimore to voice opposition as the last day approached for homeless residents at the encampment to move to a dorm-style shelter. Some residents resisted relocating, leading to demonstrations in the area.

title: Roundup of bills moving through Maryland’s legislature
summary: Maryland legislators are considering bills that would equip fire departments with bikes and motorcycles for faster emergency response, impose harsher penalties for laser pointer misuse targeting ship captains, and protect public record requesters from legal retaliation. These proposals aim to improve public safety, clarify legal consequences, and ensure transparency in government.

title: Justice Department calls for dismissal of MD-DC emoluments lawsuit against President Trump
summary: The Justice Department has urged a U.S. District Court to dismiss a lawsuit from Maryland and the District of Columbia, which alleges that President Trump violated constitutional emoluments clauses by profiting from foreign and state business transactions.

title: Prince George’s County files lawsuit against opioid drug makers
summary: Prince George’s County has filed a lawsuit against over two dozen opioid drug makers, accusing them of corporate greed in the face of a rising overdose crisis. The county reports a significant increase in opioid and fentanyl overdose deaths, with emergency responders handling twice as many overdose calls as in previous years.

title: Gallery: Women’s March on Washington 2018
summary: Thousands of people marched in Washington on January 20, 2018, to commemorate the first anniversary of the Women’s March on Washington following Donald Trump’s inauguration. The event was documented by photographer Julia Lerner, a journalist with the Capital News Service Washington bureau.

title: Maryland Dental Action Coalition promotes dental care improvements for Maryland adults
summary: The Maryland Dental Action Coalition urged lawmakers to improve access to dental care for adults, highlighting that many seek treatment only when facing severe dental issues. In fiscal year 2016, over 42,000 Maryland adults visited emergency rooms for chronic dental conditions.

title: Federal tax cuts prompting Maryland tax code revision
summary: Federal tax cuts under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act are expected to reduce Marylanders' federal taxes by $2.8 billion but may increase state and local tax payments by $572 million due to changes in deductions. Governor Larry Hogan and state lawmakers plan to adjust Maryland's tax code to offset the impact on residents.

title: Foster care bill aims to expand tuition grants
summary: Maryland legislators have approved a bill to expand tuition grants for former foster youth, allowing free in-state college tuition for those adopted or reunited with families after age 13. The bill also extends the time frame for completing degrees from 5 to 10 years, aiming to remove barriers to higher education and encourage permanency for older foster youth.

title: Gallery: 2018 March for Life in Washington
summary: The 2018 March for Life took place on the National Mall on January 19, featuring speeches from President Donald Trump and House Speaker Paul Ryan via satellite. Julia Lerner, a journalist with the Capital News Service, has previously worked as an intern, editor, and photographer in media roles.

title: State funds screens to block ‘fishing’ at detention center
summary: Maryland is installing metal screens in 96 cells at a Baltimore detention center to prevent inmates from retrieving contraband like drugs, weapons, and cellphones through a practice known as "fishing." The move, approved as an emergency expense, aims to improve security in maximum-security cells where the issue has recently escalated.

title: The Annapolis Bullpen: From the opening gavel to the opening controversy
summary: CNS and the NewsBIN have launched "The Annapolis Bullpen," a new podcast covering the Maryland legislature. The first episode explores the opening session, tax reform, and a veto override.

title: Family of woman left outside of Baltimore hospital speaks out
summary: The family of a 22-year-old mentally ill woman, who was turned away by a Baltimore hospital and left in freezing weather in only a gown and socks, called the treatment inhumane. They are now seeking legal action to strengthen state laws protecting vulnerable patients during hospital discharges.

title: Gov. Larry Hogan previews budget plan for the 2019 fiscal year
summary: Governor Larry Hogan previewed his 2019 fiscal year budget plan in Annapolis, which includes no new taxes. The plan focuses on boosting education funding and shielding residents from federal tax code changes.

title: Governor Hogan launches another effort for redistricting reform
summary: Governor Larry Hogan is urging Maryland lawmakers to reform the congressional redistricting process. He proposes creating an independent, non-partisan commission to oversee the redrawing of district boundaries.

title: Gov. Hogan dwarfs Maryland Democrats in campaign fundraising
summary: Governor Larry Hogan has significantly outpaced Maryland Democrats in campaign fundraising. His financial advantage highlights his strong support as he prepares for the 2022 elections.

title: Ukrainian reporter for U.S. news outlets imprisoned by separatists
summary: Ukrainian reporter Stanislav Aseyev, who worked for Radio Free Europe/Radio Liberty and Ukrainian media under a pseudonym, was imprisoned by Russia-backed separatists in Donetsk for covering the conflict and exposing regional issues. He has been held for over seven months, with evidence suggesting his arrest was directly linked to his investigative journalism on the separatist leadership and Russian occupation.

title: Legislative Black Caucus addresses its priorities for the 2018 Maryland General Assembly
summary: The Legislative Black Caucus outlined its priorities for the 2018 Maryland General Assembly, focusing on key issues at the start of the session. Among their top goals is continued advocacy for inclusion in Maryland’s medical marijuana industry.

title: Annapolis marks stop number one for nationwide public hearings on offshore drilling
summary: Annapolis hosted the first of many public hearings on the Trump administration's offshore drilling plan, drawing both supporters and opponents. The hearings, continuing until March, aim to gather public input on the plan's impact on coastal states, excluding Florida.

title: Bills heard on airplane seats, venison donations and more
summary: Maryland legislators considered several bills, including measures to improve access to birth certificates, enhance airplane passenger safety, regulate e-cigarette sales, and address cellphone use in classrooms. Additional proposals included providing tuition support for foster care graduates and offering tax credits for venison donations.

title: Hogan touts school spending among budget priorities
summary: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan has proposed a 2019 budget allocating significant funds to education, with 70 percent of capital spending going toward schools and higher education. Despite Hogan's claims of record education funding, concerns remain about underfunding in Prince George’s County and the adequacy of healthcare and infrastructure investments.

title: Can the Broken Baltimore Police Department Be Repaired?
summary: The Baltimore Police Department faces deep-rooted issues, including public distrust and systemic dysfunction, following years of misconduct and reform failures. Efforts to repair the department remain uncertain, as community leaders and officials debate whether reform is possible or if a complete overhaul is necessary.

title: Health coalition pushes ban on brand-name drug price gouging
summary: A Maryland health care coalition is pushing to extend the state's 2017 price gouging law to cover brand-name and specialty drugs, aiming to make them more affordable. The proposal comes amid rising drug costs, with patients like Parkinson’s advocate Larry Zarzecki highlighting the financial burden of life-sustaining medications.

title: Dems put tax relief atop Maryland legislative priorities
summary: Maryland Democratic leaders have prioritized tax relief legislation to counter the Republican federal tax bill, focusing on estate tax decoupling, restored personal exemptions, and charitable deductions. The plan aims to provide $1 billion in state-level tax relief, with lawmakers working to finalize details before the legislative session ends.

title: Maryland Legislature overrides two of Gov. Hogan’s vetoes
summary: The Maryland legislature overrode two vetoes by Gov. Larry Hogan, passing a paid sick leave law for businesses with 15 or more employees and the "Ban the Box" law to limit criminal history inquiries on college applications.

title: Afghan U-S aid worker faces challenges in new life in the United States
summary: An Afghan aid worker who supported U.S. troops now faces ongoing dangers and emotional struggles after relocating to the United States under a Special Immigration Visa.

title: Pedestrian accidents pile up on state roads across Maryland
summary: Pedestrian accidents have significantly increased on state roads across Maryland, raising concerns among safety officials. The rise has prompted calls for improved road safety measures and greater public awareness.

title: At FedEx Field, does Washington have home field advantage?
summary: A growing number of visiting fans at FedEx Field suggest Washington may not have a true home-field advantage, with thousands of opposing team supporters attending recent games. Capital News Service observed significant rival fan presence, including at least 3,345 Vikings fans in one game and a strong Dallas Cowboys fan contingent in another.

title: Egyptian reporter’s journey from think tank to prison cell
summary: Egyptian journalist Ismail Alexandrani was arrested upon returning to his home country after a year abroad, where he had researched Egypt's covert war in the Sinai at a U.S. think tank.

title: Turkey’s star investigative reporter imprisoned for second time
summary: Ahmet Şık, a prominent Turkish investigative journalist, was imprisoned for a second time on terrorism charges related to his reporting, despite his refusal to defend his work as a violation of journalistic ethics. He and three other Cumhuriyet journalists remain jailed, as Turkey continues to detain over 150 journalists since a 2016 coup attempt, drawing international concern over press freedom.

title: Drone-flying Vietnamese reporter sentenced to seven years
summary: Nguyen Van Hoa, a Vietnamese journalist, was arrested and later sentenced to seven years in prison for using a drone to report on environmental protests linked to a major industrial disaster. His reports, aired on Radio Free Asia, were deemed anti-state propaganda by Vietnamese authorities.

title: More than a Mascot: High schools drop Redskins mascot
summary: High schools across the U.S. are replacing the "Redskins" mascot due to its offensive and culturally insensitive connotations.

title: Concerns persist over school system for juvenile offenders
summary: Concerns persist over the quality of education provided to juvenile offenders in Maryland, as systematic issues prevent them from receiving instruction comparable to that in state schools. An independent monitoring unit has identified the need for more individualized educational structures to better meet the diverse needs of students in detention centers.

title: Community backlash blocks attempt to drop ‘Redskins’
summary: Efforts to change the "Redskins" mascot at Teton High School in Idaho faced strong opposition from the local community, leading the school superintendent to abandon the initiative. Similar resistance occurred at other schools using the name, with students, alumni, and residents fiercely defending the mascot despite calls for change from Native American groups.

title: ‘Redskins’ name change a costly decision for many schools
summary: Belding High School in Michigan dropped the "Redskins" name a year ago but cannot afford to fully remove all references due to budget constraints. Many schools nationwide face similar financial challenges in updating logos, uniforms, and facilities after changing their Native American-themed mascots.

title: Native voices carry weight as schools debate ‘Redskins’ name
summary: Native American voices have played a significant role in prompting several high schools to change their "Redskins" mascot name due to its perceived racial insensitivity. Schools like Goshen, Red Lodge, and Port Townsend transitioned to new names following advocacy from tribal groups and community pressure.

title: School paper becomes flashpoint in debate over ‘Redskins’
summary: A Pennsylvania high school newspaper refused to use the "Redskins" mascot name, leading to the paper being seized and the editor suspended. Students across the U.S.

title: California law cuts ‘Redskins’ over school objections
summary: A California law requiring public high schools to abandon the "Redskins" name led Calaveras High School and three others to remove the term, with one school choosing to have no team name at all. Similar efforts in Texas, Pennsylvania, and Michigan have faced strong resistance as government entities push for changes to what many view as traditional mascots.

title: At some schools, Redskins are gone, but not forgotten
summary: At least 41 high schools have changed their "Redskins" mascot in recent years due to community reflection, state mandates, or societal pressure, despite resistance from some supporters. Many former Redskins fans and schools continue to express pride in the name, clinging to a "once a Redskin, always a Redskin" mentality.

title: At Redskins high schools, students show pride in mascot
summary: High schools using the "Redskins" mascot continue to promote school pride through social media, despite the controversy surrounding the name. Some schools, like Goshen High School in Indiana, have transitioned to new names, while others maintain the mascot with widespread student support.

title: Pro sports leagues, teams spend millions lobbying Washington
summary: Professional sports leagues in the U.S. have spent over $41 million lobbying in Washington since 1999, with the NFL leading the effort at more than $27.5 million.

title: Turkish government jails editor on terror charges
summary: Murat Sabuncu, editor-in-chief of Turkey’s respected newspaper Cumhuriyet, has been imprisoned on terrorism charges, with the government citing tweets and published headlines as evidence. Critics argue the charges are baseless and represent a broader crackdown on free speech and political opposition in Turkey.

title: U.S. pressure aids release of imprisoned Azeri journalist
summary: Azerbaijani journalist Mehman Aliyev was arrested and imprisoned after refusing a government offer to control his independent news agency, Turan, which led to international condemnation and calls for his release. U.S.

title: Carrollton Ridge homeowner tethered to house by bad health
summary: Dawn Ford, a 62-year-old homeowner in Carrollton Ridge, Baltimore, is unable to leave her deteriorating home due to poor health and financial constraints. Despite owning a house passed down from her grandfather, its low market value and her medical conditions keep her tethered to a neighborhood with high poverty and low homeownership rates.

title: Maryland medical society aims to reduce diabetes
summary: The American Medical Association is partnering with MedChi and eight other state medical societies to develop models for preventing Type 2 diabetes, expanding efforts to Maryland and other states. The initiative aims to increase screening and referrals for prediabetes through the National Diabetes Prevention Program to reach more at-risk patients.

title: Gallery: Mail inspections key in war on drugs
summary: U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers, along with trained dogs, are inspecting international mail at John F.

title: People, machines and dogs hunt for drugs in the mail
summary: U.S. Customs and Border Protection officers at JFK International Airport use advanced technology and trained dogs to intercept illegal drugs, including fentanyl, hidden in international mail.

title: Russian occupiers silence Crimean journalist in court
summary: Russian authorities silenced Crimean journalist Mykola Semena by raiding his home, seizing his work, arresting him, and charging him with separatism for his critical reporting on Russia's occupation. In 2017, he was sentenced to a suspended term and barred from journalism for three years.

title: Chesapeake Bay advocates fear Trump admin. could threaten Bay’s progress
summary: Chesapeake Bay advocates are worried that the Trump administration's 2017 move to cut funding for the Bay Program could jeopardize ongoing environmental restoration efforts. They vow to continue pushing for the program's reinstatement in the federal budget.

title: Area artist turns a shining hobby into an artful lifestyle
summary: A man from Glen Burnie, Maryland, has transformed his hobby into a vibrant artful lifestyle, creating flashy pieces that showcase his passion. He credits this creative pursuit with keeping him active and inspired, regardless of his age.

title: Elon Musk hyperloop may have terminus near Camden Yards
summary: Elon Musk's Boring Co. plans to start constructing hyperloop tunnels in Baltimore, with a terminus near Camden Yards, as early as January 2018.

title: Growing old means many changes
summary: The article highlights the diverse and individual experiences of aging, showing that older adults engage in a wide range of activities and face challenges with positivity. It features insights gathered by Capital News Service’s ViewFinder team on how seniors navigate life with support from loved ones.

title: Shell recycling: It’s about the bay
summary: Wayne Witzke collects used oyster shells from restaurants for the Shell Recycling Alliance, helping to restore the Chesapeake Bay by providing habitats for baby oysters. These shells support programs that grow and eventually plant oysters in sanctuaries to improve water quality.

title: Nonprofit in Rockville restores bikes for charity
summary: Bikes for the World, a Rockville-based nonprofit, collects and restores used bicycles to send to developing countries in Africa, Asia, and South America, helping improve education and economic opportunities, especially for women. Partnering with local organizations, the group delivers thousands of bikes annually, offering training to ensure they are properly used and maintained in the communities.

title: The value of a smile
summary: At the Mission of Mercy Health Equity Festival in College Park, Maryland, people from across the state received free dental care, highlighting the significant number of Americans who lack access due to cost. The event, organized by the University of Maryland and Catholic Charities, showcased both the challenges and triumphs of those seeking essential dental services.

title: Puerto Rico Maria Updates: How a Facebook community served as a lifeline for families
summary: After Hurricane Maria devastated Puerto Rico, Patricia Pichardo created the Facebook group "Puerto Rico Maria Updates" to help locate her sister and share critical information, which grew to over 200,000 members. The community became a vital lifeline, connecting people globally and facilitating the sharing of news and success stories through coordinated efforts and the use of hashtags.

title: Analysis: Trump calls his use of social media “modern day presidential.” Here’s what that looks like.
summary: President Donald Trump describes his frequent and informal use of social media as "modern day presidential," characterized by thousands of tweets since his election. An analysis of his Twitter activity from November 2016 to November 2017 reveals a heavy focus on topics like "fake news," political opponents, and election-related themes.

title: Anne Arundel program tackles drug addiction but challenges remain
summary: Anne Arundel County's Safe Station program offers a multidisciplinary approach to combat drug addiction by providing immediate treatment at police and fire stations. Despite such efforts, the opioid crisis continues to claim thousands of lives in Maryland, with Anne Arundel being one of the most affected areas.

title: Prison gang investigation brings indictments of correctional officers and inmates
summary: Maryland Attorney General Brian Frosh announced over two dozen indictments related to gang activity inside and outside a state prison. Among those charged was a correctional officer who was also a high-ranking member of a violent national gang.

title: The “most famous reindeer of all” leads the way at local annual icy holiday celebration
summary: The most famous reindeer of all has arrived in National Harbor, Maryland, as part of the annual ICE exhibit at the Gaylord Hotel. The exhibit features colored, clear, and glowing ice sculptures imported from Harbin, China, just in time for the holidays.

title: Students turn trash into artistic treasure for annual competition
summary: High school students in Maryland participated in the 16th annual Rethink Recycling Sculpture Contest by creating artistic works from recycled materials. The competition highlights creative ways to repurpose trash into valuable art.

title: Colorado baker goes to Supreme Court over same-sex discrimination suit
summary: A Colorado baker, Jack Phillips, is before the Supreme Court after refusing in 2012 to create a custom wedding cake for a same-sex couple. The case has drawn strong support and protest as it addresses issues of religious freedom and anti-discrimination laws.

title: Dancing water bottle salesman keeps motorists entertained
summary: Jackie Wimbush, a Prince George’s County resident, entertains motorists by dancing while selling water along Adelphi Road in College Park. Despite difficult times, he spreads positivity through his cheerful and lively performances.

title: Montgomery County man brings rooftop ice skating to the Watergate Hotel
summary: A Montgomery County man has brought rooftop ice skating to the Watergate Hotel, with Mel’s Rink operating until March. The attraction offers more than just ice, drawing visitors to the iconic Washington, D.C.

title: “WAR on Hot Takes” Episode 12: Season finale, NFL recap, Ohtani and more
summary: The season finale of "WAR on Hot Takes" features a bonus segment with Dylan Sinn and Adam Zielonka discussing the "More Than a Mascot" project and reviewing recent NFL developments. The episode includes insights from fellow Capital News Service reporters on the project's challenges and future plans, along with updates on the Washington and Baltimore teams.

title: The bittersweet life for one Syrian refugee in Maryland
summary: Mohamad Nour, a Syrian refugee now living in Maryland, found stability through making desserts, a skill he learned as a child in Damascus. After fleeing the civil war and living in Jordan for three years, he and his family were selected to resettle in the U.S.

title: Revised plan underway for new FBI site, raising hopes in Maryland – again
summary: Maryland officials remain cautiously optimistic as the General Services Administration receives a 60-day extension to revise plans for a new FBI headquarters outside the District of Columbia, following a five-month delay. The project, stalled earlier due to funding concerns, now explores alternative financing options amid bipartisan support from Congress.

title: Maryland Democratic lawmakers press oversight of Trump administration
summary: Maryland Democratic lawmakers have led numerous oversight efforts targeting the Trump administration, including over 100 letters to federal agencies, focusing on potential misconduct and Russian connections. Rep.

title: Capitals’ first line dominates in 6-2 win over Blackhawks
summary: The Capitals' top line of Ovechkin, Backstrom, and Wilson dominated with a combined 11 points, leading Washington to a 6-2 win over the Blackhawks. The offensive surge continued as the line helped the Capitals win six of their last seven games.

title: Maryland’s deadline to enroll in health coverage nears
summary: Maryland is hosting “last chance” enrollment events this weekend to help residents sign up for 2018 Affordable Care Act health coverage before the Dec. 15 deadline.

title: How a wrongly imprisoned man got his life back
summary: Walter Lomax spent nearly 40 years in prison for a murder he did not commit, enduring harsh conditions at Maryland's notorious House of Correction for Men, known as "The Cut." After his release in 2006, he channeled his experience into writing and advocacy, publishing a book and working to raise awareness about wrongful incarceration.

title: Baltimore’s asthma hot spots are poor, African-American neighborhoods with lots of empty houses
summary: Baltimore's poorest, majority African-American neighborhoods, like ZIP code 21223 in Carrollton Ridge, experience the highest asthma rates due to environmental factors such as vacant homes and rodent infestations. Analysis of hospital records shows emergency room and inpatient asthma diagnoses in this area are significantly higher than the state average.

title: At home, in schools, on the street, the triggers for asthma lurk everywhere
summary: In Carrollton Ridge, a neighborhood in Southwest Baltimore, poor housing conditions and pests like mice and roaches contribute to high asthma rates, with the area's emergency room asthma visits nearly double Maryland's average. Residents, like homeowner Dawn Ford, struggle to manage these triggers through limited means, such as using pesticides to control roach infestations.

title: Rare Carrollton Ridge homeowner tethered to her house by bad health
summary: Dawn Ford, a 62-year-old homeowner in Baltimore's Carrollton Ridge, is unable to leave her deteriorating house due to chronic health issues and financial constraints. Despite owning a home passed down from her grandfather, she faces significant challenges, as the property's low value and her limited income trap her in a declining neighborhood.

title: Landlords, tenants and city bureaucracy play role in housing problems
summary: Residents of Carrollton Ridge in Baltimore face substandard housing conditions, with tenants blaming landlords for neglect and landlords citing unpaid rent and poor tenant behavior. The situation is compounded by poverty, vacant homes, and a lack of government support, making it difficult to assign clear responsibility for the neighborhood's deteriorating living conditions.

title: Health educator: Carpets, even cleaning products can make asthma worse
summary: Ezinne Chinemere of the Green & Healthy Homes Initiative highlights that carpets and common household items like cleaning products can worsen asthma by harboring allergens and irritants. During home assessments, the organization identifies and addresses asthma triggers such as mold, pests, and poor ventilation to help families live in healthier homes.

title: Prison gang, drug investigation nets 26, including guards
summary: A multi-agency investigation in Maryland led to the indictment of 26 individuals, including two correctional officers, for their roles in a prison-based drug trafficking and money laundering operation linked to the 8-Trey Crips gang. The conspiracy involved inmates, prison staff, and family members exchanging contraband and money, with some correctional officers allegedly aiding gang activities inside and outside the facility.

title: Proposed legislation aims to stop online sex trafficking
summary: A proposed bipartisan bill, the "Allow States and Victims to Fight Online Sex Trafficking Act," aims to close legal loopholes that currently protect online platforms from liability for user-generated content, including sex trafficking. The legislation, backed by 171 House co-sponsors, would enable states to prosecute websites involved in facilitating sex trafficking and give victims the right to sue such sites.

title: Increased animal abuse in Baltimore viewed as indicator of growing crime problem
summary: Baltimore is experiencing a rise in both violent crime and animal abuse, with many drawing a direct connection between the two trends. The increase in mistreatment of animals is now being viewed as a troubling indicator of the city's broader crime problem.

title: Hundreds gather to honor slain Baltimore City Detective Sean Suiter
summary: Hundreds gathered in Baltimore to honor slain Detective Sean Suiter during his funeral and burial. Suiter was killed two weeks ago while investigating a homicide, and a $215,000 reward is being offered for information leading to the suspect's arrest.

title: Harford County opens mobile house to open eyes about addiction
summary: Harford County has launched a mobile home called H.O.P.E–Heroin Overdose Prevention Effort–House to raise awareness about drug addiction. The initiative, led by the Harford County Sheriff’s Office, aims to educate the public and combat the opioid crisis.

title: Maryland’s first stand-alone in-patient addiction center breaks ground
summary: Maryland’s first stand-alone in-patient addiction detox center, the Maryland House Detox, broke ground in Linthicum Heights. The facility is set to open in spring and will provide specialized care for addiction treatment.

title: House committee seeks input on opioid crisis in visit to Baltimore
summary: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan, Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh, and New Jersey Governor Chris Christie shared their perspectives on the opioid crisis with a House committee during a visit to Baltimore. Christie, leading a presidential commission on drug addiction, emphasized that the epidemic began in doctor’s offices and hospitals, not just in urban neighborhoods.

title: Purple Line agreement addresses community’s concerns
summary: Private and community stakeholders in College Park, Maryland, signed an agreement to maintain affordable housing and accessible job opportunities along the Metro Purple Line route. The initiative aims to achieve four key goals: preserving affordability, fostering strong communities, supporting local businesses, and expanding the local labor market.

title: Hurricane victims from Puerto Rico get help resettling in Baltimore
summary: The Tavarez family relocated to Baltimore after enduring the aftermath of Hurricane Maria in Puerto Rico, with the help of a local charity, Fundación Janet Arce. The organization, along with a sympathetic landlord, provided housing and support to the family and three other Puerto Rican families seeking stability in the U.S.

title: Maryland officials sign agreement on Purple Line development
summary: Maryland officials and community stakeholders signed an agreement to promote responsible economic development, including affordable housing and job growth, along the planned Purple Line light rail route. The 16.2-mile project, set to connect Bethesda to New Carrollton, aims to foster sustainable communities and equitable benefits across the region.

title: Christie urges Congressional panel to fund opioid fight
summary: New Jersey Gov. Chris Christie urged Congress to fund the fight against the opioid crisis during a House committee hearing in Baltimore, emphasizing the urgent need to address the surge in synthetic opioids like fentanyl and carfentanil.

title: Hogan introduces new paid leave measure for Marylanders
summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan introduced a new paid leave bill requiring companies with 25 or more employees to offer paid leave by 2020, backed by a $100 million tax credit for small businesses.

title: Despite fast start, Alex Ovechkin still trails all-time hat trick leaders
summary: Despite a strong start to the season and 20 career regular season hat tricks, Alex Ovechkin remains far behind the all-time leaders like Wayne Gretzky, who holds the record with 50. Ovechkin's era, marked by larger goalie equipment and stronger defenses, makes scoring more difficult compared to the high-scoring 1980s when many top hat trick leaders played.

title: Maryland’s Chesapeake Bay defenders hold breath, wait on Senate
summary: Maryland's conservation efforts for the Chesapeake Bay face uncertainty as the Senate considers whether to restore a $13 million cut to the EPA program proposed by the House. While Maryland's representatives advocate for at least $60 million, the state's influence is weakened by the retirement of a key Senate ally and the replacement by a less influential senator.

title: Deep pass struggles doom Flacco in worst season of career
summary: Joe Flacco is having the worst season of his career in 2017, struggling with deep passes and posting career lows in key quarterback statistics despite a career-high completion percentage. His performance has raised concerns, as he is among the league's most inconsistent passers and has thrown more interceptions than touchdowns this season.

title: Maryland Made: A deep dive into the state’s film industry
summary: Maryland has become a notable hub for film and television production, hosting over 78 films and five TV shows since 2000, including popular series like *House of Cards* and *Veep*. Its proximity to Washington, D.C., combined with iconic locations and major productions like *The Blair Witch Project*, has helped establish the state as a key player in the entertainment industry.

title: Washington, Baltimore bid for 2026 World Cup matches
summary: Washington, D.C. and Baltimore are competing as potential host cities for 2026 FIFA World Cup matches, with their bids centered around NFL stadiums in each city.

title: Trump administration dives into fish fight with conservationists
summary: The Trump administration overruled an Atlantic States Marine Fisheries Commission decision finding New Jersey noncompliant with flounder fishing limits, sparking criticism over environmental concerns and favoring commercial interests. Conservationists warn the move undermines efforts to prevent overfishing and weakens the commission's role in managing shared coastal resources.

title: Students urge state lawmakers to raise tobacco age of sale to 21
summary: Students at Damascus High School in Maryland are urging state lawmakers to raise the tobacco purchase age to 21. They argue that doing so will help reduce youth smoking rates.

title: Maryland senators introduce legislation to protect TPS recipients
summary: Maryland Senators Chris Van Hollen and Ben Cardin have introduced legislation to allow Temporary Protected Status (TPS) recipients to apply for legal permanent residency after three years. The move comes as the status of over 400,000 TPS holders in the U.S.

title: TURKEY DONATION: Maryland Food Bank prepares for holiday needs
summary: Giant supermarket chain donated 5,000 turkeys, including 1,000 to the Maryland Food Bank, to help provide meals for over 51,000 people during the holidays. The food bank serves a diverse range of individuals, including working families and those facing unexpected hardships, highlighting that food insecurity can affect anyone.

title: Ornery, ugly and wild – turkeys you won’t look forward to seeing
summary: Wild turkeys are increasingly appearing in urban areas of New England, raising concerns about whether the trend will spread south along the East Coast, though Maryland has not yet seen the same frequency of aggressive turkey behavior. While turkey populations in Maryland are declining in reproduction, officials note occasional problematic behavior, but it remains rare and largely isolated.

title: Veteran Baltimore police detective killed, search for gunman underway
summary: A veteran Baltimore homicide detective, Sean Suiter, was shot while investigating a murder and later died at Shock Trauma. Authorities are still searching for the suspect responsible for his killing.

title: MDOT and SHA remind motorists safety is first during holiday travel
summary: MDOT and SHA are urging Marylanders to prioritize safety as more than 1 million are expected to travel during Thanksgiving. Motorists are reminded to be cautious for the safety of both drivers and road workers.

title: Silver Spring elementary school is first in Montgomery County with an all-student language immersion program
summary: An elementary school in Silver Spring, Maryland, has become the first in Montgomery County to implement an all-student language immersion program. The initiative requires every student to become bilingual as part of their education.

title: TSA provides travel tips for painless security checks this holiday season
summary: The Transportation Security Administration is offering holiday travel tips to help passengers navigate security checkpoints more smoothly. While items like baked potatoes are allowed, others such as mashed potatoes should be left behind to avoid delays or disposal.

title: Montgomery school challenges students in two languages
summary: Kemp Mill Elementary School in Montgomery County is implementing a mandatory dual-language program in English and Spanish for all students, expanding from an optional enrichment since 2001. The program, set to fully integrate both languages into the curriculum by 2021-22, is unique in that it applies to the entire student body, not just a subset.

title: Maryland senators introduce bill to aid “temporary status” immigrants
summary: Maryland Senators Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen introduced the SECURE Act to provide a pathway to legal residency for immigrants under Temporary Protected Status (TPS) after three years. The bill aims to protect approximately 437,000 TPS holders, many of whom have lived in the U.S.

title: “WAR on Hot Takes” Episode 11: Washington takes on the Saints, Capitals update, John Wall plays forever
summary: The 11th episode of "WAR on Hot Takes" discusses Washington's crucial NFL matchup with New Orleans, John Wall's potential longevity mirroring Tom Brady, and the Capitals' recent performance and challenges. Topics include player insights, team trends, and analysis from a data-driven perspective.

title: Japanese phenom Ohtani could become best two-way MLB player since Babe Ruth
summary: Shohei Ohtani, a Japanese phenom who excels both as a pitcher and hitter, could become the best two-way MLB player since Babe Ruth if he successfully adjusts to the U.S. league, though past Japanese stars have often seen declines in performance after making the move.

title: Panel weighs new school-construction funding bill
summary: A state panel in Maryland is reviewing a revised bill aimed at addressing school overcrowding and reducing reliance on temporary classrooms, with an estimated $23.3 billion in school construction needs statewide. The proposed legislation seeks to standardize construction costs and improve efficiency in school building and maintenance across jurisdictions.

title: Advocates demonstrate on Capitol Hill for additional funding to fight opioid addiction
summary: Advocates gathered on Capitol Hill to demand increased funding for addressing the opioid epidemic. They protested outside the offices of House Speaker Paul Ryan and Senate Majority Leader Mitch McConnell.

title: Vision for Baltimore providing free eyeglasses to thousands of students
summary: A public-private partnership in Baltimore has given free eyeglasses to approximately 2,000 students. Educators report improvements in behavior and academic performance among the students who received them.

title: Congressional Democrats vow to keep U.S. in the fight against carbon emissions
summary: Congressional Democrats, including Senator Ben Cardin and Congressman Steny Hoyer, pledged to maintain U.S. involvement in the Paris climate agreement despite the President's decision to withdraw.

title: Commission considers solutions to public school overcrowding
summary: The 21st Century School Facilities Commission is exploring ways to move 65,000 Maryland public school students from temporary classrooms into permanent facilities. The initiative also aims to reduce the cost of new school construction.

title: Baltimore charity takes aid to Puerto Rico
summary: Janet Arce, founder of a Baltimore-based charity, led a team of volunteers to Puerto Rico to deliver aid after Hurricane María, though many donated boxes remain delayed at a port. With help from local donors and volunteers, the group provided supplies to vulnerable communities, including foster children and elderly residents.

title: Olympic curling dream is a family affair for one Howard county resident
summary: Hunter Clawson, a 21-year-old from Howard County, is striving to qualify for the 2018 Winter Olympics in curling. With curling as a family tradition, he is working hard to make his Olympic dream a reality.

title: Kings’ Fox sees Wizards’ Wall as mentor, key to improving play on the court
summary: Sacramento Kings' rookie De’Aaron Fox views Wizards guard John Wall as a mentor, learning from their matchups and Wall's advice to stay humble and persistent through early struggles. Despite Wall's dominance in their recent game, Fox sees the challenge as crucial to his growth as a player.

title: Amtrak unveils comfier seats, better lighting in coaches
summary: Amtrak is upgrading over 450 coaches with new seat cushions, LED lighting, and improved restrooms to enhance passenger comfort and modernize the train experience. The $16 million project, focusing on Amfleet I trains, features upgraded materials for durability and easier maintenance, responding to customer demand for modernized rail travel.

title: Gallery: Amtrak overhauls passenger coaches
summary: Amtrak is overhauling its passenger coaches to offer improved comfort and convenience. Upgrades include more supportive seating, LED lighting, easier-to-clean carpets, and enhanced restrooms.

title: Trump temperament gives senators nuclear jitters
summary: Sen. Ben Cardin and Sen.

title: Maryland ethics committee closes doors in first meeting after new ethics law
summary: A Maryland ethics committee held its first meeting under a new ethics law, reviewing brief public disclosures before closing the session to discuss confidential matters. The meeting focused on disclaimers from four lawmakers, with no major issues identified, as part of the implementation of the Public Integrity Act of 2017.

title: Despite sickness, Wall’s defense a reason for Wizards’ optimism
summary: Despite being sick and receiving IV treatment before the game, John Wall delivered a strong defensive performance, helping the Wizards secure a 113-94 win over the Hawks. Wall, motivated by a challenge from Kobe Bryant, has been focusing on improving his two-way play, resulting in continued success on defense despite physical struggles.

title: Carlson’s two-point night lifts Capitals over Penguins
summary: John Carlson recorded two points, including a key power-play goal, helping the Capitals to a 4-1 victory over the Penguins. With increased ice time due to a depleted defense, Carlson has emerged as a top-performing defenseman, contributing 13 points this season.

title: Pastry arts program brightens futures of local kids
summary: A local bakery in Gaithersburg, Maryland, is offering young adults with disabilities a unique opportunity through a pastry arts program. This initiative helps them gain skills, build confidence, and work toward a brighter future.

title: Hundreds rally on Capitol Hill to support DREAM Act
summary: Hundreds gathered on Capitol Hill to demand Congress pass legislation to reinstate DACA protections for undocumented young people. The push comes after President Trump announced the end of the program in September, urging lawmakers to find a legislative solution.

title: Cardin, other Senate Democrats determined to keep U.S. in climate talks
summary: Senate Democrats, including Sen. Ben Cardin, are committed to participating in global climate talks despite President Trump's decision to withdraw the U.S.

title: National Archives kicks off new Vietnam War exhibit with helicopter display
summary: The National Archives is launching a new Vietnam War exhibit to honor veterans and preserve the war's history. The exhibit opened with a display of three helicopters used during the conflict.

title: St. Mary’s County offers help to veterans in need of resources
summary: St. Mary’s County held its second annual Veterans Resources Day to assist former military members with needs such as health and housing.

title: Dentist takes up sweet collection to spread some cheer
summary: Dental Designs of White Marsh in Maryland is participating in Operation Gratitude for the third consecutive year. The program collects candy to send care packages to active duty military and veterans worldwide.

title: SHA rolls out new technology to help keep winter roads clear and safe
summary: The Maryland State Highway Administration is introducing new winter road maintenance technology, including infrared measurement systems and larger trucks, to improve road safety. The efforts also aim to reduce salt usage by incorporating more salt brine.

summary: Maryland’s tourism industry, which generated over $17 billion in visitor spending in 2017, is a vital part of the state's economy. Officials are now concerned that President Trump’s travel ban could negatively affect tourism and related tax revenues.

title: Md. schools commission aims for more career-bound programs
summary: Maryland's Center of Applied Technology South offers students hands-on career training through programs like carpentry, auto technology, and culinary arts, allowing them to earn certifications and workforce skills in just a few years. The school's focus on career-bound education aims to better prepare students for direct entry into the job market.

title: Gallery: Washington demonstration supporting the DREAM Act
summary: Sen. Kamala Harris showed solidarity with demonstrators supporting immigrants' rights during a rally in the Hart Senate Office Building.
