summary: Demonstrators gathered at the U.S. Senate building to demand Congress protect undocumented children by passing the DREAM Act, wearing orange shirts and chanting in support of a permanent immigration solution.

title: 365 days of @realDonaldTrump tweets
summary: President Donald Trump's @realDonaldTrump Twitter account, with over 40 million followers, frequently addresses topics such as media, international affairs, public figures, cultural events, and policy, often generating significant engagement. An analysis of his top 25 most retweeted messages shows they fall into these categories, with many garnering over 60,000 retweets.

title: “WAR on Hot Takes” Episode 10: Hot take rebuttal, Jay Gruden coaching tree, Ravens midseason report
summary: The episode of "WAR on Hot Takes" covers recent developments in the Wizards' and Ravens' seasons, including player performance and team strategies. It also explores NFL coaching connections, particularly focusing on Jay Gruden's influence on current coaches like Mike Zimmer.

title: Maryland shows off new snow plow and infrared reader
summary: Maryland is introducing new winter preparedness technology, including a larger snow plow and an infrared system that provides real-time road data. The infrared system, now being deployed widely, offers valuable information on road conditions to help improve safety and response efforts.

title: Raskin calls for tougher federal law on campus religious discrimination
summary: Rep. Jamie Raskin has called for expanding the Civil Rights Act of 1964 to include protections against religious discrimination on college campuses, particularly in response to a rise in anti-Semitic and other hate crimes.

title: Cardin among critics who want change in war-fighting policy
summary: The International Criminal Court announced it will investigate potential war crimes and crimes against humanity in Afghanistan, including actions by U.S. and British troops.

summary: Lawmakers in Maryland are considering a two-generation approach to end multi-generational poverty by integrating services such as early childhood development, mental health, and employment support. Proponents argue this holistic strategy, which has been implemented in states like Connecticut, Colorado, and Tennessee, can significantly improve family outcomes and reduce poverty over time.

summary: The release of the iPhone X generated significant excitement, with fans lining up at Apple stores and expressing enthusiasm online despite its high price of $999. While some praised its advanced features like facial recognition and OLED display, others questioned the need for in-person waits given its online availability.

title: Home landscaping project aims to help improve the health of the Chesapeake Bay
summary: Carroll County, Maryland, is participating in the Bay-Wise program to help improve the health of the Chesapeake Bay. The initiative encourages residents near waterways to adopt smarter gardening practices to enhance water quality.

title: Democratic members of House oversight committee sue for details about Trump Hotel
summary: Democratic members of the House Oversight Committee, led by Rep. Elijah Cummings, have sued to obtain details about President Trump’s Washington hotel.

title: Maryland Muslims brace for life under Trump
summary: Following Trump's election, Maryland Muslims, particularly women wearing hijabs, have experienced increased harassment, prompting civil rights groups to offer self-defense workshops. These classes, led by martial arts instructors, aim to empower the community amid rising concerns over discrimination and safety.

title: Maryland honors veterans at Welcome Centers throughout November
summary: Maryland is celebrating Veterans Appreciation throughout November for the first time. State agencies, Maryland Public Television, and the U.S.

title: Kids and music meet at National Philharmonic’s “instrument petting zoo”
summary: Local kids experienced a unique “instrument petting zoo” at the National Philharmonic event in Chevy Chase, Maryland. Instead of traditional Halloween treats, they enjoyed hands-on musical exploration and “sweet sounds.”

title: Visa used by New York terror suspect subject of earlier criticism
summary: The New York terror suspect entered the U.S. legally through a diversity visa, a program designed to allow immigration from countries with low application rates.

title: Deadly Edgewood workplace shooting 911 calls released
summary: The 911 calls from the deadly Edgewood workplace shooting have been released two weeks after the incident, which sparked a multi-state manhunt. The suspect, Radee Prince, is currently in custody in Delaware.

title: Maryland lawmakers sue for information on D.C. Trump hotel lease
summary: Maryland lawmakers, including Rep. Elijah Cummings, have sued the federal government to obtain information about the operations of President Trump’s Washington, D.C.

title: Hogan aims to draw more K-12 girls, minorities to tech jobs
summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan launched the "ACCESS" initiative to boost computer science education and workforce development, focusing on increasing participation by girls and minorities in STEM fields.

title: “WAR on Hot Takes” Episode 9: Kevin Blackistone in studio, MLB walk up music, Knight Commission meeting
summary: The ninth episode of "WAR on Hot Takes" features Kevin Blackistone discussing sports and protest, MLB walk-up music, and college sports governance. Topics also include the Nationals' new manager, the Ravens' performance, and player profiles for the week.

title: GOP senator: Maryland one of three states most targeted by Russian ads in 2016
summary: A GOP senator revealed that Maryland, a Democratic stronghold, was one of the three U.S. states most targeted by Russian ads during the 2016 election, with 262 ads compared to 55 in Wisconsin.

title: Puerto Rican couple among many living at least temporarily in Maryland
summary: A Puerto Rican couple is staying temporarily in Maryland with their daughter after Hurricane Maria devastated Puerto Rico, joining many others seeking shelter and stability in the Washington, D.C. area.

title: Retiring UMD archivist known for her ability to recall tales large and small
summary: Anne Turkos, the University of Maryland’s archivist for over 30 years, is retiring after serving as a librarian, historian, and professor who answered countless campus-related questions. Despite her retirement, she says the university will always remain her home.

title: Sen. McCain talks about service, leadership and political crisis with midshipmen
summary: Sen. John McCain addressed midshipmen at the U.S.

title: Maryland Zoo elephants celebrate Halloween with a tasty tradition
summary: The Maryland Zoo's elephants celebrated Halloween with a special treat as part of their annual tradition. The event highlights the zoo's efforts to engage and entertain the animals through seasonal festivities.

title: State commission offers help to those trying to pay off student loans
summary: The state's Financial Education Commission has endorsed legislation aimed at protecting students from defaulting on their student loans. The move is intended to provide support for individuals struggling to repay their educational debt.

title: Maryland lawmakers support special counsel, raise concerns about Russia
summary: Maryland's three Democratic lawmakers emphasized the importance of allowing Special Counsel Robert Mueller to continue his work without interference from Congress or the president. They also raised concerns about potential Russian involvement in the 2018 elections.

title: State slashes oyster restoration acreage goal
summary: Maryland has reduced its oyster restoration goal in the Little Choptank River by 118 acres due to navigation issues and construction errors at similar sites. The change comes amid ongoing concerns from watermen about boat damage and fishing disruptions caused by oyster reefs.

title: New Maryland law prevents drug price gouging
summary: Maryland has become the first state to pass a law preventing drug price gouging for both patented and generic medications. The new law aims to increase access to essential drugs by making them more affordable for residents.

title: Maryland lawmakers back Mueller, urge action on Russian meddling
summary: Maryland Democratic lawmakers expressed support for Robert Mueller’s investigation and emphasized the significance of the guilty plea by Trump campaign adviser George Papadopoulos, who admitted lying to the FBI about his Russian contacts. They criticized President Trump’s denial of campaign-Russia ties and highlighted the seriousness of Russian interference in the 2016 election.

title: Maryland officials tout new generic drug price-gouging law
summary: Maryland implemented a law to prevent price-gouging of generic and off-patent prescription drugs, which took effect in October despite legal challenges from the generic drug industry. Supporters, including local officials, highlight the law's importance in making medications more affordable, as seen in cases like a county executive whose wife's dementia medication costs more than tripled.

title: Major League Baseball players prefer hip-hop songs to get pumped up
summary: Major League Baseball players most commonly use hip-hop songs as their walk-up music, with artists like Drake and Future being the most popular choices. However, players who choose pop music tend to have higher on-field success compared to those who select hip-hop.

title: Public losing confidence in NCAA, president says
summary: The NCAA president acknowledged a growing loss of public confidence in the organization's ability to regulate college sports, particularly basketball, amid recent corruption scandals. The Knight Commission expressed deep concern over the NCAA's failure to maintain integrity and emphasized the need for significant reform to preserve its relevance.

title: Montgomery County teen a champion at climbing the wall that could lead to the Olympics
summary: Noah Bratschi, a 17-year-old from Montgomery County, is one of the top junior speed climbers in the U.S. His success could lead him to compete in the sport’s Olympic debut in Tokyo.

title: WMATA chair resolves dispute, issues challenge to Governor Hogan
summary: Maryland Gov. Larry Hogan accused WMATA board chairman Jack Evans of extortion and demanded land for the Purple Line.

title: State committee looks at impact  of federal deregulation on Maryland consumers
summary: A new state fiscal oversight group in Maryland held its first meeting in Annapolis. The meeting followed the U.S.

title: Maryland takes on compensation for the wrongly imprisoned
summary: Maryland has established a 10-member task force to create a compensation standard for individuals wrongfully imprisoned, no longer requiring a governor's pardon for damages. The group aims to report by December 15, addressing a lack of set compensation guidelines that exists in the state unlike in others such as California and North Carolina.

title: To build staff, Jay Gruden relied on his NFL coaching social network
summary: Jay Gruden built his coaching staff for Washington's NFL team primarily by relying on connections from his time working under his brother Jon Gruden in Tampa Bay, rather than those formed later with Marvin Lewis in Cincinnati. A social network analysis revealed the significant influence of Jon Gruden and Lewis in shaping the NFL coaching landscape by mentoring assistants who went on to become successful head coaches.

title: Under Armour’s “Curry 4” gets mixed reviews on social media
summary: Under Armour's latest Stephen Curry signature shoe, the "Curry 4," received mixed reactions on social media, with some praising it as the brand's best basketball shoe yet and others expressing disappointment. The release comes as Under Armour seeks to recover from significant financial losses and a sharp decline in stock price.

title: Maryland’s mysterious Russian compound gathers dust, awaits its fate
summary: A luxurious Russian diplomatic compound in Maryland, once used as a dacha, remains shuttered and unused following diplomatic tensions with the U.S. over Russian interference in the 2016 election.

title: Maryland fiscal panel braces for federal deregulation
summary: A Maryland fiscal commission is assessing the impact of recent federal financial deregulation, including the repeal of a rule that limited mandatory arbitration in consumer disputes. The move, supported by Senate Republicans, has raised concerns about reduced accountability for financial institutions.

title: As Maryland and other states struggle, Trump declares opioids a ‘public health emergency’
summary: President Donald Trump declared the opioid crisis a public health emergency, aiming to streamline federal responses, increase funding, and expand telemedicine and treatment access. The declaration comes as states like Maryland struggle, with Trump vowing to combat the epidemic that claims nearly 200 American lives daily.

title: Challenges remain for Musk’s hyperloop in Maryland
summary: Maryland has announced support for Elon Musk's hyperloop project, but significant technological and regulatory challenges remain. The project, which envisions high-speed travel between major East Coast cities, still requires approvals from multiple federal and state entities and lacks detailed planning.

title: State lawmakers use Twitter to urge renewal of CHIP funds
summary: State lawmakers are using Twitter to push for the reauthorization of the Children’s Health Insurance Program (CHIP), which expired in September, to prevent thousands of children from losing health coverage. CHIP provides health insurance to over 9 million low-income children nationwide, including more than 142,000 in Maryland.

title: A look back on the 20th anniversary of ‘Blair Witch’ in Maryland
summary: Twenty years ago, *The Blair Witch Project*—a low-budget film shot in Maryland with a $25,000 budget—became a massive success, grossing nearly $250 million after its 1999 release. Co-directed by Maryland native Eduardo Sanchez, the film was inspired by local legends and shot primarily in Burkittsville and Seneca Creek State Park.

title: “WAR on Hot Takes” Episode 8: Dusty Baker fired, Wizards early season returns, Flacco is not elite
summary: The latest episode of "WAR on Hot Takes" discusses Dusty Baker's firing as Nationals manager, the Wizards' early-season struggles, and critiques Joe Flacco's performance. It also covers player updates, managerial candidates, and key games impacting Washington's playoff hopes.

title: Stage is set for final DC United game at RFK Stadium
summary: RFK Stadium in Washington is set to host its final DC United game, marking the end of over 50 years of hosting various sports teams. The iconic venue, which opened in 1960, will soon close its doors to local sports events.

title: George Washington’s distillery celebrates 10-year anniversary
summary: George Washington’s distillery at Mount Vernon celebrated its 10-year anniversary with distillers and visitors from across the country. The reconstructed site honors Washington’s role in early American distilling.

title: Prince George’s County non-emergency call center celebrates 5 years
summary: Prince George’s County's 311 Call Center is marking its 5th anniversary during National Customer Service Week. In five years, it has processed over one million non-emergency service requests through various communication channels.

title: Religions intersect at annual conference to fight domestic violence
summary: The 5th Annual Maryland Interfaith Domestic Violence Conference convened in Annapolis to address domestic violence through a religious lens. Participants included clergy, law enforcement, and advocates from diverse faith communities.

title: D.C. United fans say goodbye to historic R.F.K. Memorial Stadium
summary: D.C. United played their final home game at R.F.K.

title: Car crashes into Prince George’s pub at lunchtime leaving several injured
summary: A car crashed into Babes Boys Tavern in Upper Marlboro, Maryland, during lunchtime, injuring ten people. Seven were hospitalized, two with serious but non-life-threatening injuries.

title: Congressman Cummings leads latest push to bring down prescription drug prices
summary: Congressman Elijah Cummings and other lawmakers are criticizing President Trump for not fulfilling his promise to lower prescription drug costs. They are pushing for action to address high drug prices in the U.S.

title: Prince George’s County Police offer “trunk or treat” as a safe trick-or-treating alternative
summary: Prince George’s County Police in Maryland hosted a "trunk or treat" event to provide a safe trick-or-treating experience for children. Police cars were decorated and handed out candy to costumed kids as part of the initiative.

title: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan accuses WMATA Board Chairman of “extortion”
summary: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan accused WMATA chairman Jack Evans of making excessive demands in exchange for state easements related to Metro’s Purple Line. The claims were made during a public statement in Hanover, Maryland.

title: New Stephen Curry sneakers may financially boost Under Armour
summary: Stephen Curry's new signature sneaker, the "Curry 4," is seen as a potential financial lifeline for Under Armour, which has faced significant losses and declining stock prices. The shoe, set to retail for $130, is expected to drive sales and could help offset concerns over Curry's future with the company beyond his 2024 contract expiration.

title: Md. Medical society asks hospitals to review opioid doses
summary: The Maryland State Medical Society is urging hospitals and physicians to reduce automated opioid prescriptions and prescribe only the minimum necessary, as part of efforts to combat the opioid crisis. Despite a slight decline in prescription opioid-related deaths this year, opioid-related fatalities in Maryland have more than doubled since 2014, prompting the society to establish an Opioid Task Force to promote safer prescribing practices.

title: Record label helps local music artists achieve their dreams
summary: Nick Arnold, a University of Maryland student with a passion for music, founded the Terrapin Record Label with help from campus connections and the Student Government Association. The student-run co-op supports local artists by selecting a featured artist each semester and assisting them through collaborative efforts and events.

title: Cummings wants Trump to deal for lower Medicare drug prices
summary: Rep. Elijah Cummings introduced legislation to give the government power to negotiate lower Medicare drug prices after expressing frustration with the Trump administration's lack of action.

title: #HandsoffmyBC gains traction — online and off — after Trump announces new birth control rule
summary: The Trump administration rolled back a rule requiring employers to cover birth control without co-pays, allowing businesses to opt out based on religious or moral objections. The decision sparked widespread backlash on social media, with users using the hashtag #HandsoffmyBC to advocate for continued access to contraception.

title: Van Hollen fights to preserve state and local tax deductions
summary: Sen. Chris Van Hollen is leading efforts to preserve state and local tax deductions, arguing that eliminating them would unfairly burden middle-class families, especially in Maryland where nearly half of taxpayers rely on the deduction.

title: Maryland a battleground state in fight against transgender military ban
summary: Two Maryland-based service members, Regan Kibby and Brock Stone, are central plaintiffs in legal challenges against President Trump's transgender military ban. Kibby, a Naval Academy student, faces uncertainty about his future in the military as the policy shift leaves transgender service members in limbo.

title: Maryland board approves 10 properties for city, campus revitalization
summary: Maryland’s Board of Public Works approved the transfer of 10 University of Maryland properties to a new LLC, Terrapin Development Co., to support the Greater College Park Initiative aimed at revitalizing the city and campus. University leaders emphasized the move will help institutionalize innovation and strengthen the partnership between the university and College Park community.

title: Harford County multiple murder suspect caught, held on $2.1 million bail
summary: Radee Prince opened fire at Advanced Granite Solutions in Harford County, killing three and injuring two. He was arrested by Wednesday evening with the help of public tips and is being held on $2.1 million bail.

title: Special sailing program aims to help veterans transition back to civilian life
summary: The Warrior Sailing Program, a four-year-old initiative, brought veterans to Annapolis to participate in a new community and learn sailing skills. The program aims to help veterans transition back to civilian life through challenging and supportive activities.

title: Goat yoga makes its way to Maryland
summary: Goat yoga has made its way to Maryland, becoming a popular fitness trend. Classes in Carroll County are in high demand and selling out quickly.

title: New Anne Arundel County agritourism law allows local farms to expand use of property

summary: U.S. Navy officials acknowledged that insufficient training and maintenance may have contributed to four naval ship collisions this year, resulting in the deaths of 17 sailors, including several from Maryland.

title: DeVos draws fire for plan to change handling of campus sexual assaults
summary: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos reversed Obama-era guidelines on handling campus sexual assault, sparking criticism from advocates who argue the move weakens protections for survivors. Colleges like the University of Maryland say they remain committed to student safety while awaiting further federal guidance.

title: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos draws reaction on social media with Title IX speech
summary: Education Secretary Betsy DeVos faced strong backlash on social media and at public protests after calling for a "reframing" of Title IX guidelines on campus sexual assault, with critics accusing her of downplaying survivors' rights. While some condemned her remarks as victim-blaming, a few supporters praised her for addressing concerns about false accusations and the misuse of Title IX.

title: NFL teams are breaking the bank on average quarterbacks
summary: NFL teams are increasingly signing quarterbacks to massive contracts, even when their performance doesn't justify the pay, as seen with high-earners like Kirk Cousins and Joe Flacco who rank below top performers in key metrics. Despite this trend, only a few of the highest-paid quarterbacks, such as Aaron Rodgers and Russell Wilson, consistently rank among the league's best in quarterback rating.

title: Orioles’ recent success due to many home runs, few walks
summary: The Orioles have built a successful lineup under Buck Showalter and Dan Duquette by emphasizing power hitting and minimizing walks, leading to high home run totals but poor on-base performance. While this aggressive approach has contributed to playoff appearances, it also limits baserunners and increases reliance on solo home runs.

title: Hogan’s $61 million in budget cuts given seal of approval
summary: Maryland’s Board of Public Works approved $61 million in budget cuts proposed by Gov. Larry Hogan, adjusting initial plans that faced criticism for disproportionately affecting low-income areas.

title: Nationals’ Anthony Rendon doesn’t have much MVP buzz, but he should
summary: Anthony Rendon of the Washington Nationals is having an elite season with strong performance at the plate, in the field, and on the bases, yet he remains overlooked in the MVP race. Despite leading the league in WAR alongside Jose Altuve, Rendon has long odds to win the award and is competing with several teammates for recognition.

title: Ocean City J-1 visa in jeopardy
summary: Ocean City businesses in Maryland are worried that the Trump administration may end the J-1 visa program, which brings international workers to fill seasonal jobs. These workers are vital for handling the busy summer employment needs in the area.

title: Hundreds protest White House DACA decision
summary: Hundreds of Maryland "Dreamers" protested outside the White House against the Trump administration's decision to end the DACA program. DACA, established under Obama, had protected immigrant children brought to the U.S.

title: Rally supporting DACA at the White House: Gallery
summary: A rally in support of the DACA program was held near the White House, with participants advocating for protections for young undocumented immigrants. Attendees gathered to express solidarity and call for legislative action to preserve the program.

title: Maryland immigrant rights supporters attack Trump move as cruel
summary: Maryland's congressional Democrats and immigrant rights advocates criticized the Trump administration's decision to end the DACA program, calling it cruel and harmful to families. While most condemned the move, Rep.

title: Ocean City businesses fear losing seasonal workforce if J-1 visa program is reduced
summary: Ocean City businesses are concerned that a potential reduction in the J-1 visa program could severely impact their seasonal workforce, which is essential for the local tourism industry. The program, which brings in thousands of international students to fill various roles, is under review as part of the Trump administration's immigration policy changes.

title: 8 Baltimore, Washington players to target in fantasy football
summary: The article highlights eight valuable fantasy football players from the Baltimore Ravens and Washington NFL teams, including WR Terrelle Pryor and TE Jordan Reed, both of whom offer strong performance potential for fantasy lineups. Players like Pryor and Reed are recommended as key targets for starting lineups or flex positions due to their production and team roles.

title: Maryland tennis pro gives Federer rare scare in U.S. Open match
summary: In a thrilling U.S. Open match, 19-year-old Maryland tennis player Frances Tiafoe pushed Roger Federer to five sets, marking only the fourth time since 2003 a player has taken Federer that far in the early rounds of a Grand Slam.

title: Silent Minute: University of Maryland honors a student killed on campus
summary: Students, faculty, and staff at the University of Maryland, College Park held a moment of silence to honor 2nd Lt. Richard W.

title: Kayla’s story: Recovering mom enjoying time with children
summary: Kayla, a mother from Arnold, Maryland, is working toward recovery from opioid and drug addiction. She is focusing on rebuilding her relationship with her children and cherishing time with them.

title: A step in the right direction, after 33 years
summary: "Junior" has struggled with addiction for 33 years, losing friends, family, and even his teeth. Now, he is taking a step in the right direction toward recovery.

title: From prescription painkillers ‘straight to heroin’
summary: Randy Forgette has battled drug addiction for years, tracing his journey from prescription painkillers to heroin. He finds temporary relief from drugs while in prison.

title: The missing half: Twins both have heroin addiction, but just one survives
summary: Denise Williams's twin sons, Matt and Ryan, both struggled with heroin addiction, but only one survived the deadly disease. The surviving twin now lives with the emotional pain of outliving his brother.

title: Fostering new hope: Family adopts three boys all born to addicted mothers
summary: The Rentfrow family has adopted three boys who were born to mothers struggling with heroin addiction. Their story highlights the impact of the opioid epidemic on children and the role of foster care in providing new beginnings.

title: Road to recovery: Jail provides methadone to inmates with addiction
summary: Ordnance Road Correctional Center in Glen Burnie, Maryland, offers methadone treatment to inmates with opioid addictions through its Road to Recovery program. This initiative aims to provide addiction support within the jail system, a rare practice in most correctional facilities.

title: Like mother, like son: Parent, child both addicted to heroin
summary: A mother and son in Anne Arundel County are both battling heroin addiction, highlighting the devastating impact of the opioid epidemic. The crisis has reached into families, with addiction affecting multiple generations.

title: Testing the poison: Chemists allow ‘evidence to speak for itself’
summary: Forensic chemists in Anne Arundel County, Maryland, are utilizing laboratory tests to identify fentanyl and other opioids as part of their role in the justice system. Their work ensures that evidence is analyzed accurately and objectively.

title: Samantha’s journey: Rehabilitation center houses mothers and their children
summary: Samantha Griebel is overcoming opioid addiction at Chrysalis House, a rehabilitation center in Maryland that allows mothers to live with their children. The facility helped her regain custody of her daughter and pursue sobriety while raising her child.

title: On the call: Some fire stations see high demand for naloxone
summary: The Anne Arundel County Fire Department is actively using naloxone to combat opioid overdoses. Some fire stations in the area are experiencing high demand for the life-saving drug.

title: Light House Bistro: Annapolis eatery supports recovery program
summary: Light House Bistro in Annapolis is an upscale restaurant that employs individuals in recovery from substance abuse. Many of its staff members graduate from the Light House rehabilitation program, which offers housing and job training.

title: ‘This is my last chance’: Structure, discipline mark recovery program
summary: Gaudenzia Inc. in Maryland offers a structured recovery program that many see as their final opportunity to achieve sobriety.

title: Hoops for hope: Police use basketball to build relationships
summary: Anne Arundel County police are using basketball as a way to connect with individuals in recovery from drug addiction. The initiative aims to build trust and strengthen community relationships through sports.

title: Angel’s house: Recovery residences support women’s sobriety
summary: Angel Traynor, a former opioid addict, now operates five recovery homes for women in Anne Arundel County. Jenn Twiford is one of the residents in recovery living in one of these homes.

title: Blindsided: Annapolis police detective loses son to heroin
summary: Annapolis police detective John Lee and his wife were devastated to learn their son, Patrick, struggled with heroin addiction. Despite their efforts, the addiction ultimately took his life, leaving the family and community heartbroken.

title: A chief’s promise: Police encourage addicts to get help with disease
summary: Anne Arundel County Police, under Chief Timothy Altomare, are shifting focus from incarceration to treatment for opioid addiction. The department now encourages addicts to seek help, viewing addiction as a disease rather than a criminal issue.

title: ‘Tale of two cities’: Heroin afflicts black, white communities
summary: Heroin addiction has long plagued Annapolis' Clay Street neighborhood, but the crisis is now gaining broader attention as it increasingly affects white communities. The drug epidemic continues to impact diverse populations across the country.

title: Flicker of remembrance: Vigil honors those lost to addiction
summary: A candlelight vigil in Glen Burnie, Maryland, honored those lost to the opioid epidemic, providing a space for survivors to share their grief and find support. Aleta Daley, who lost her son Sean to addiction, joined others seeking healing and connection in the face of the ongoing crisis.

title: Maryland cyclist bikes cross-country to raise money for pediatric heart disease
summary: Spencer Buchness, a 24-year-old from Maryland, cycled over 4,000 miles across 14 U.S. states to raise $15,000 for the Save a Child’s Heart foundation.

title: Waiting on weed: Medical marijuana delays in Maryland
summary: Maryland legalized medical marijuana in 2013, but patients continue to face delays in establishing a legal access process. Two patients with chronic illnesses highlight the importance of cannabis in managing their conditions.

title: Inside a Honey Bee Hive, a Threatened Population
summary: Honey bee populations are declining globally, with beekeepers in Maryland losing over half of their hives in 2016. The decline of bees poses a threat not just to ecosystems but also to human food security.

title: For some veterans, rehab means a kayak on a raging river
summary: Blind veteran Lonnie Bedwell became the first person to kayak the entire length of the Colorado River through the Grand Canyon after joining Team River Runner (TRR), a nonprofit founded in 2004 to help wounded veterans through whitewater kayaking. What began as a simple idea to teach kayaking to injured soldiers has grown into a national movement with over 50 active chapters.

title: Opioid abuse may be rural Maryland’s worst problem
summary: Rural Maryland is facing a severe opioid crisis that strains resources, damages communities, and takes a heavy emotional toll on first responders. However, the close-knit nature of these areas is fostering coordinated, multi-faceted efforts to combat the epidemic more effectively.

title: Repopulating rural: Can Salisbury and other small urban enclaves make rural cool again?
summary: Salisbury Mayor Jake Day is leading efforts to revitalize rural Maryland by focusing on arts, culture, and entertainment to attract and retain residents. Cities like Salisbury aim to reverse population decline and serve as anchors for broader rural revitalization.

title: Big Chicken is still king on Maryland’s Eastern Shore, but can solar and aquaculture make economic inroads?
summary: Maryland’s Eastern Shore remains dominated by large-scale chicken farming, which contributes significantly to the state’s agricultural economy but faces changes in industry practices. While aquaculture and solar energy are emerging as potential economic alternatives, they struggle to create enough jobs and market demand to rival traditional industries.

title: For Maryland’s northern counties, the economic riddle is blending the old with the new
summary: Maryland’s northern counties are striving to balance their agricultural heritage with growing industries like tech, tourism, and brewing, as seen in the success of farmers like Greg Clabaugh who now profit from malting grains. However, the challenge remains whether these regions can sustain traditional farming, especially dairy, amid rapid population growth and economic change.

title: In Western Maryland, ‘whales’ are out and a fight over fracking reveals divergent economic visions
summary: Allegany County in western Maryland struggles with economic decline due to the departure of large employers and the coal industry, prompting a shift toward smaller, more sustainable job creators. Meanwhile, neighboring Garrett County faces a different challenge: deciding how to responsibly use its natural resources, including whether to allow fracking, to fuel future economic growth.

title: In Maryland, an urban-rural divide that mirrors the nation
summary: Maryland reflects the nation's urban-rural divide, with cities leaning Democratic and rural areas favoring Republicans. This political split highlights broader national trends in voter behavior and regional identity.

title: In Maryland politics, the war on rural is dead — long live the war on rural?
summary: Former Maryland Governor Martin O’Malley faced criticism for closing the Sideling Hill Visitor Center in Western Maryland, seen by many as emblematic of neglect toward rural areas, while current Governor Larry Hogan has sought to reverse that trend by reopening the center and declaring the "war on rural Maryland" over. Despite Hogan’s efforts to improve rural relations, challenges remain in delivering infrastructure funding and reducing regulatory burdens due to the political dominance of urban and suburban Democrats in the state legislature.

title: High-tech system blocks inmates’ cell phones in Md. prisons
summary: Maryland prisons are implementing high-tech systems to block inmates from using smuggled cell phones, which are used to coordinate illegal activities and threaten staff and public safety. Inmates have creatively smuggled phones inside, leading to violence and contraband smuggling, prompting prison officials to take stronger measures to prevent such incidents.

title: House debates child-marriage restrictions
summary: Maryland's House of Delegates advanced a bill to ban all marriages involving individuals under 18, aiming to prevent forced child marriages that disproportionately affect girls and can be used to cover up sexual abuse. Supporters, including the Tahirih Justice Center and the Maryland Catholic Conference, argue the law would protect minors and promote more mature, successful marriages.

title: Trump, corruption, state finances color legislative session
summary: The 2017 Maryland General Assembly session was marked by partisan tensions over anti-Trump policies, budget shortfalls, and Democratic corruption scandals, yet Republicans and Democrats managed to pass bipartisan legislation on issues like opioid abuse and education. Governor Larry Hogan and legislative leaders praised the session as highly productive and collaborative despite the political challenges.

title: When supply exceeds demand, wages for Langley Park day laborers suffer
summary: In Langley Park, Maryland, an oversupply of day laborers leads to wages being driven below minimum wage as workers compete for jobs. While the informal labor market provides employment opportunities for immigrants, advocates argue it undermines their long-term economic interests by suppressing wages.

title: Stolen paychecks: how immigrant workers get ripped off
summary: Immigrant workers in the U.S., particularly day laborers, are frequently victims of wage theft, with many reporting not being paid what they were promised. This issue is especially prevalent in immigrant communities, where off-the-books hiring and language barriers make workers vulnerable to exploitation.

title: Pedestrian casualties mount in Maryland town as officials defer action
summary: At least 138 pedestrians have been struck by vehicles in eight years on a dangerous two-mile stretch of University Boulevard in Langley Park, Maryland, resulting in eight deaths and numerous serious injuries. Despite the high casualty rate, officials have deferred action, as the road was not originally designed for a walking community.

title: Pedestrian deaths on the rise nationally
summary: Pedestrian deaths in the U.S. reached their highest level since 1996 in 2016, with a significant increase attributed to a lack of safe walking infrastructure, especially in low-income and immigrant neighborhoods.

title: Coast Guardsman loses all in fire, garners community support
summary: Coast Guardsman Quinten Maggio lost everything in a devastating house fire that destroyed his rented room and belongings. The Annapolis community has rallied to support him, offering assistance as he rebuilds his life.

title: Researcher: Allergies, mice, even gas stoves linked to asthma
summary: Dr. Elizabeth Matsui, an asthma expert, explains that asthma is often triggered by environmental factors such as allergens and that poor children are disproportionately affected due to higher exposure to these triggers.

title: How to build an MLB team that will win the World Series–or at least come close
summary: Building an MLB team that can win the World Series largely depends on having a strong run differential, where the team scores more runs than it allows. While this is the most predictive factor for success, playoff performance can still be unpredictable due to short-term fluctuations and October surprises.

title: Annapolis native with Down syndrome enjoys lobbying, working
summary: Madelyn Monzo, a 24-year-old from Annapolis with Down syndrome, works at a local discount store and uses a specialized purple box cutter to open packages, having found employment through the Providence Center. She enjoys her job and aspires to take her father to Walt Disney World with the money she saves.

title: Trump’s defense plan would have mixed impact on Maryland
summary: President Trump’s 2018 budget proposal could benefit Maryland’s large defense industry but would harm the state’s broader economy through cuts to other federal programs. Analysts and Democratic lawmakers argue that the plan prioritizes military spending over essential domestic initiatives, potentially weakening both national security and economic stability.

title: Spring semester 2017 highlights
summary: The CNS team covered numerous stories during the spring semester 2017. The provided timeline highlights the most visited articles on cnsmaryland.org during that period.

title: Washington bookshop is part of independent bookstores’ comeback
summary: Laurie Gillman opened East City Bookshop in Washington in 2016 to fill a local gap left by the closure of an independent bookstore, becoming part of a national resurgence in such retail spaces. Despite challenges from online sellers and e-books, independent bookstores like hers are thriving by offering community-focused experiences and events.

title: Celebrate Arbor Day!
summary: Arbor Day originated in Nebraska in 1854 and was founded by Julius Sterling Morton. It is celebrated nationally on the last Friday in April.

title: Planes, trains and automobiles: the best transportation stories from 2017
summary: The article highlights the transportation challenges faced in the Washington, D.C. area in 2017, including traffic congestion, low Metro ridership during Trump's inauguration, and long commutes.

title: What makes for an exciting NBA postseason?
summary: Mike Beuoy developed an "excitement index" to quantify thrilling NBA playoff games by measuring fluctuations in win probability throughout matches. Using this index, the Cleveland Cavaliers vs.

title: Local woman searches for family’s stories of the Holocaust
summary: Rachel Miller, a Montgomery County resident, is researching her parents' Holocaust experiences at D.C.’s Holocaust Memorial Museum, as they rarely spoke about their survival. Her goal is to uncover and preserve the family history lost to silence.

title: New Baltimore distillery opens with the backing of businessman Kevin Plank
summary: Sagamore Spirits distillery has opened in Baltimore with the support of businessman Kevin Plank, featuring whiskey production, a visitor center, and a forthcoming restaurant. A ribbon-cutting ceremony marked the official start of operations at the waterfront facility.

title: Kids travel to Washington with a message for President Trump
summary: Young people from across the East Coast gathered near the White House to express their concerns about President Trump's immigration policies. They aimed to highlight the impact of deportation threats on vulnerable families.

title: Rounding up a herd of top animal stories
summary: The article highlights the most popular animal-related stories of the spring semester, including Maryland's proposed state duck, a student-friendly bill to allow refusal of frog dissection, and the naming of a baby giraffe at the Maryland Zoo. Other notable mentions include a panda's return to China, a 360-degree oyster farming video, and an initiative using chicken manure for renewable energy.

title: Maryland could host the nation’s largest offshore wind farm
summary: Maryland is considering two proposals to build offshore wind farms off the coast of Ocean City, which could make it home to the nation’s largest such project. The projects aim to generate clean energy while keeping monthly electricity cost increases minimal for both residential and non-residential ratepayers.

title: Ticket promotions help big league clubs draw in fans
summary: The Baltimore Orioles and other Major League Baseball teams use promotions like Kids Run the Bases to attract fans, especially families with young children. These events, offered after select games, allow kids under 14 to experience the field and create excitement around ticket sales.

title: Netflix DVD subscribers are holding on, 4 million strong
summary: Despite a decline, Netflix still has over 4 million DVD subscribers who appreciate the service, even as most users have shifted to streaming. The company continues to profit slightly from the DVD service, maintaining it as long as it remains financially viable.

title: These 7 sports stories were home runs
summary: The first four months of the year featured a wide range of major sports events covered extensively by the CNS team, including the Super Bowl, March Madness, and post-Olympic updates. The team highlighted their top-performing sports stories across various categories, with one story even being published by external outlets like The Daily Record and The Arizona Republic.

title: Rounding Up Our Twitter Reaction Stories
summary: The CNS social team rounded up top Twitter reactions from Maryland users in early 2017, highlighting events like #ADayWithoutImmigrants, Lenten struggles, and discussions on the wage gap. They encouraged followers to stay connected through multiple social media platforms for future updates.

title: The data doesn’t lie – top 8 data visualization stories of 2017
summary: In 2017, the CNS Data Lab team highlighted key data visualization stories ranging from political transitions and sports stats to cultural events and natural phenomena. The year's visual narratives included early presidential approval trends, historic NBA duos, record-early cherry blooms, and in-depth analyses of government shutdowns and March Madness upsets.

title: Fanalytics Ep. 7: Rajon Rondo injured and “Playoffs in DC”
summary: Gabe and Connor discuss Rajon Rondo's injury and its implications while celebrating the arrival of the playoffs in Washington, D.C., with an original song highlighting hopes for local teams' success. The song humorously reflects on past disappointments and the high stakes of the current playoff season.

title: Compared to Obama, Trump drew fewer Maryland donors and dollars for inauguration
summary: Maryland donors contributed significantly less to President Trump’s 2017 inauguration compared to President Obama’s 2013 inauguration, reflecting the state’s strong Democratic leanings. Experts suggest that the political climate and fear of backlash likely discouraged both individuals and businesses in Maryland from supporting a Republican president’s event.

title: Opioid and heroin overdoses have reached ‘crisis level’ in Maryland
summary: Opioid and heroin overdoses have reached crisis levels in Maryland, ranking among the state's top causes of death. In response, the Maryland General Assembly passed several bills, including measures to increase naloxone access, restrict opioid prescriptions, and improve education and treatment programs, which now await Governor Larry Hogan's signature.

title: Baltimore’s arabbers keep history alive
summary: Baltimore's arabbers, African-American horse-drawn cart vendors, are a fading tradition that dates back to the 1800s and represent the last of their kind in the United States. Efforts by the Arabber Preservation Society aim to keep the tradition alive by increasing the number of active wagons on the city's streets.

title: New teams are economic boost to some cities, including Washington and Baltimore
summary: The Washington Nationals' arrival in 2005 sparked a major revitalization of Washington's Navy Yard neighborhood, transforming it from high crime to high rise with new businesses and housing. Similarly, the relocation of sports teams can have a significant economic impact on their new host cities, as seen in the contrasting stories of Washington and Baltimore.

title: Ellicott City flood recovery inspires local business to open despite the challenges
summary: Inspired by the community's resilience after the 2016 flood, the owners of EC Pops opened their specialty popcorn store in Ellicott City. Despite challenges, the business had a successful grand opening on April 1st.

title: Oldest running duckpin bowling alley has its home in Baltimore and marks its 9th decade
summary: Patterson Bowling in Baltimore is the oldest continuously operating duckpin bowling alley in the United States. It is celebrating its 90th year of providing a nostalgic duckpin bowling experience.

title: History comes alive at Rockville museum one piece of furniture at a time
summary: A Rockville museum showcases 18th and 19th century furniture, bringing history to life through each piece. Curator Elizabeth Lay reveals the hidden stories behind the exhibits.

title: The Farm Women’s Market has more than eight decades of local tradition
summary: The Farm Women’s Market in Bethesda, Maryland, was founded over 80 years ago by a group of women during a time when many men were away at war. It remains a thriving community staple open to everyone.

title: Maryland Black Caucus agenda tallies some wins, some losses
summary: The Maryland Legislative Black Caucus ended the 2017 session with mixed results, achieving wins on prescription drug affordability and pre-kindergarten suspension bans but failing to pass key medical marijuana and bail reform bills. Delegates are now calling for a special session to address the stalled medical marijuana legislation and promote diversity in the industry.

title: First Whole Foods Market in Prince George’s County is now open
summary: The first Whole Foods Market in Prince George’s County has officially opened. This new store brings organic and natural grocery options to the area.

title: Teams with no mascot are worth more than teams with one
summary: Teams without a mascot are valued higher than those with one, according to recent data. This suggests that branding and tradition may play a bigger role in team value than on-field entertainment features like mascots.

title: Talking Pop Culture Ep. 4 The Finale!
summary: Rachel and Quanny conclude their podcast with a look back at the 2017 highlights in pop culture and entertainment. The episode features music from bensound.com.

title: Talking Pop Culture Ep. 3 Let’s talk Disney
summary: Rachel and Quanny discuss Disney's past, present, and future in the latest episode of Talking Pop Culture, inspired by the new *Beauty and the Beast*. The episode explores the impact and evolution of Disney films.

title: Talking Pop Culture Ep. 2 It’s the Oscars!
summary: Rachel and Quanny discuss Oscar nominations and the issue of diversity in the latest episode of Talking Pop Culture. The episode serves as a pre-Oscar special, featuring music from bensound.com.

title: Talking Pop Culture Ep. 1 Valentine’s Day
summary: Rachel and Quanny discuss Valentine’s Day while reflecting on the evolution of the TV and movie industry over time. The episode features music from bensound.com.

title: Marylanders file #taxday struggles and triumphs on Twitter
summary: Marylanders shared their humorous and frustrating experiences with tax day on Twitter, highlighting the confusion and procrastination many face during tax season. Some used creative analogies, like comparing taxes to ice cream, to explain the concept of taxation.

title: John Wall’s Misplaced MVP Season
summary: John Wall is having a career season with career highs in points and assists while leading the league in steals, yet he remains a strong contender for MVP in past seasons but is overshadowed this year by historic performances from Russell Westbrook and James Harden. A comparison of his 2017 stats to past MVP candidates suggests he would have earned at least one vote in several previous seasons, possibly even winning the award.

title: Fanalytics Ep. 6: Playoffs?!?! and Orioles
summary: Connor and Gabe discuss the NHL and NBA playoffs, along with bird watching and Canada on Fanalytics Ep. 6.

title: Ready, set, file! Tax Day is April 18
summary: Tax Day for federal income taxes is typically April 15, but it is postponed to April 18 this year. The delay gives taxpayers three extra days to file their returns.

title: Why does Easter fall on a different Sunday each year?
summary: Easter's date varies each year because it is determined by a combination of lunar and solar calendar calculations. It is set as the first Sunday following the Paschal Full Moon after the vernal equinox.

title: Legislation creates task force to study surveillance tactics
summary: A Maryland bill, HB 1065, aims to establish a task force to study and assess the constitutional use of surveillance technologies by law enforcement, including facial recognition and cell-site simulators. The task force would receive disclosures from police departments and make recommendations to ensure these tactics align with constitutional rights, particularly the Fourth Amendment.

title: Trump, corruption, state finances color legislative session
summary: The 2017 Maryland General Assembly session was marked by partisan tensions, including Democrats' efforts to counter Trump administration policies and a Republican governor's push for reforms amid Democratic corruption scandals. Despite conflicts, the session saw bipartisan cooperation on key issues like opioid abuse and education, with both parties claiming success.

title: After United incident, Van Hollen wants protections for airline passengers
summary: Sen. Chris Van Hollen is drafting the Customers Not Cargo Act in response to a violent United Airlines incident, aiming to ban airlines from forcibly removing passengers after boarding.

title: Maryland lawmakers share their post-session plans
summary: The 2017 Maryland General Assembly session concluded on April 10 with the "Sine Die" end-of-session deadline. Lawmakers shared post-session plans ranging from family time and hobbies to community activities.

title: Battle over requiring helmets for female lacrosse players
summary: Currently, male lacrosse players are required to wear helmets, while female players generally are not. Some are now calling for a rule change to mandate helmet use for girls and women in the sport.

title: The Legislative Black Caucus calls for a special session on medical marijuana legislation
summary: The Maryland Legislative Black Caucus is urging a special session to pass medical marijuana legislation that would expand the number of licensed growers. The push comes after the bill failed to pass during the recent 90-day legislative session.

title: State comptroller supports local brewers after bill passes that could impact future businesses
summary: State Comptroller Peter Franchot visited Attaboy Beer in Frederick to show support for local brewers following new legislation. The Maryland General Assembly passed a bill that limits the operating hours for future craft breweries in the state.

title: Peeps lovers gather for Peeps-eating contest in National Harbor
summary: The Peeps & Company store in National Harbor hosted its second annual World Peeps Eating Championship. Spectators were asked how many Peeps they could eat if they competed.

title: Growing craft brewing industry holds national convention
summary: The growing craft brewing industry is being celebrated at a national convention in Washington, despite ongoing regulatory debates in Maryland. The Craft Brewers Conference offers education, tastings, and trade shows to enhance brewery quality and performance.

title: Baltimore shooting victim turns his personal tragedy into a positive program for young boys
summary: Damion Cooper, a Baltimore man who survived a shooting over 20 years ago, has developed a program using yoga and martial arts to help middle school boys manage stress and anger. His initiative aims to guide young men in discovering their identity and potential through positive self-expression.

title: Carroll Arts Center’s sweet PEEPS art display is a seasonal favorite
summary: The Carroll Arts Center in Westminster, Maryland, is hosting its tenth annual Peep Show, featuring nearly 200 artworks made from Peeps candies. The sweet and creative display has become a beloved seasonal favorite.

title: State lawmakers override Gov. Hogan’s education legislation veto
summary: Maryland state lawmakers have overridden Governor Hogan’s veto of the "PROTECT OUR SCHOOLS ACT," which limits the state's involvement in under-performing schools. The bill passed with strong support in both the House and Senate and survived the veto override vote.

title: A military plane crashes in Prince George’s County
summary: An F-16 military plane crashed in a wooded area of Prince George’s County shortly after takeoff from Joint Base Andrews due to a mechanical issue. The pilot safely ejected and landed a mile from the crash site, with no reported injuries on the ground.

title: A Breakdown of Government Shutdowns
summary: The federal government faces a potential shutdown by April 28 if Congress fails to pass a budget, which would be a major embarrassment for the Trump administration and Republicans in control of Congress. Government shutdowns have occurred numerous times since 1976 under various political configurations, with disagreements over issues like funding and policy often being the cause.

title: Cherry Blossom Festival crowds talk gifts from Japan, other countries
summary: Attendees of the National Cherry Blossom Festival in College Park, Maryland, discussed the best gifts the U.S. has received from other countries.

title: Local organization recognizes Autism Awareness Month
summary: The Autism Society of Baltimore-Chesapeake is hosting various events in April to celebrate Autism Awareness Month. Activities include educational sessions, support groups, and resources for families, parents, and educators.

title: Maryland lawmakers back U.S. strike on Syria, but many worried about what’s next
summary: Maryland lawmakers supported the Trump administration’s airstrike on a Syrian airfield in response to a chemical weapons attack but urged the president to consult Congress and develop a broader strategy. While some praised the targeted response, others warned against escalating into a full-scale military conflict and emphasized the need for clear, consistent action against Assad's regime.

title: Lawmakers override Hogan’s veto of Protect Our Schools Act
summary: Maryland lawmakers overrode Governor Larry Hogan’s veto of the Protect Our Schools Act, which limits state intervention in failing schools and prohibits student testing as a measure of school quality. Supporters argue the bill empowers parents and reduces educational disparities, while opponents and the state education board claim it weakens accountability.

title: Maryland 2018 budget increases spending over last year
summary: Maryland's 2018 budget approved by Governor Larry Hogan increases overall spending compared to the previous year. The budget focuses on infrastructure, education, and healthcare while maintaining a balanced approach to state finances.

title: Lewis museum expects bright future under new management
summary: Wanda Draper, the new director of the Reginald F. Lewis Museum, aims to enhance community engagement and educational programs after the museum faced leadership and management challenges.

title: Md. legislator proposes bill to help secure sporting events
summary: Maryland is considering legislation that would allow the state to form private-public partnerships to more efficiently bid for and host major sporting events like the Army-Navy football game. The proposed bill, SB1148, would let these non-profit corporations accept private donations, reducing state liability while supporting event funding.

title: Guac is extra, but worth it: National Burrito Day
summary: Today is National Burrito Day, a celebration of everyone's favorite handheld meal. Share your burrito love by tweeting @CNSmd.

title: Marching through history: Sexual Assault Awareness Month
summary: April is National Sexual Assault Awareness Month, established in the 1990s to promote awareness and prevention through campaigns led by the National Sexual Violence Resource Center. This year’s Day of Action emphasizes the theme "Engaging New Voices" to inspire collective efforts in ending sexual violence.

title: Lawmakers blast Trump budget cutting Chesapeake Bay cleanup
summary: Lawmakers from Chesapeake Bay states strongly criticized President Trump’s budget proposal to eliminate federal funding for the Chesapeake Bay Program, calling it harmful to the environment and economy. The program, which has restored the bay’s ecosystem since 1983, remains a priority for bipartisan support amid the administration’s proposed cuts.

title: Governor Hogan signs fracking ban into law
summary: Governor Larry Hogan signed a law banning fracking in Maryland, making the state the third in the nation to prohibit the practice. The legislation, passed with strong bipartisan support, will take effect on October 1st when the current temporary ban expires.

title: State and feds team up to promote work zone safety
summary: The Maryland Department of Transportation and the U.S. Department of Transportation have partnered to launch Work Zone Awareness Week.

title: Annual event provides  overdue welcome home for Vietnam Vets
summary: The Hospice of the Chesapeake held its third annual "welcome home" event for Vietnam Veterans, offering recognition they largely missed upon their return over four decades ago. The event honored hundreds of vets on the 50th anniversary of the last U.S.

title: House debates child-marriage restrictions
summary: Maryland's House of Delegates advanced a bill to ban marriages for individuals under 18, citing concerns over forced child marriages, particularly affecting girls, and the use of such marriages to cover up sexual abuse. Advocates argue current laws allow adults to exploit legal loopholes to enforce these unions, often with parental coercion.

title: North Carolina outperforms their seed more than almost all other teams
summary: North Carolina has consistently outperformed their tournament seeding more than all but one team over the past three decades, winning 16.27 more games than expected. The only team with a better record in this regard is Kentucky, while Duke, despite the most wins, had the highest expected performance.

title: #EqualPayDay hashtag sparks conversation on Twitter
summary: Equal Pay Day highlighted the persistent gender and racial wage gaps in the U.S., with women of color facing the largest disparities. Social media campaigns like #EqualPayDay and #20PercentCounts sparked conversations and promotional efforts to raise awareness and support for equal pay.

title: Prince George’s steps up efforts to clean-up the county
summary: Prince George’s County is launching a “Litter Movement” campaign to encourage residents to help clean up public spaces. The initiative includes collaboration with the school system and the use of inmates to support the cleanup and promote community responsibility.

title: Annapolis proposal would crack down on left-lane drivers
summary: A proposed bill in Maryland aims to restrict the use of the far left lane to passing vehicles on roads with three or more lanes in one direction. The legislation, currently under consideration by a state senate committee, could result in fines for drivers who violate the rule.

title: Fanalytics Ep. 4: Unstoppable Bulls, the Sleepy Floyd Award & Baseball
summary: Connor and Gabe explore unusual basketball trends, award the inaugural Sleepy Floyd Award, and humorously blame the Cavaliers' losing streak. They also imagine hitting hypothetical baseballs in a lighthearted segment.

title: Hogan signs budget, teacher retirement plans; Pugh visits
summary: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan signed two bills to stabilize state budgets and provide financial relief to local education boards by suspending their 2017 pension obligations, using surplus revenue to cover potential shortfalls and build a rainy day fund. Meanwhile, Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh attended a legislative meeting but recently vetoed a bill to raise the city's minimum wage to $15.

title: Maryland could expand options to treat addiction remotely
summary: Maryland is considering a bill to expand telemedicine for substance abuse counseling, aiming to combat the opioid epidemic by increasing access to addiction treatment. The legislation seeks to ensure insurance coverage for virtual counseling and address barriers like Medicaid reimbursement restrictions.

summary: Maryland Senate President Thomas V. Miller Jr.

summary: Disney's live-action "Beauty and the Beast" has been a box office success, earning over $300 million in the U.S. and nearly $700 million worldwide, starring Emma Watson as Belle.

title: Maryland’s Women’s History: Katie Ledecky
summary: Katie Ledecky, born in Maryland in 1997, became an Olympic swimming star at age 15 and has since won multiple gold medals, making her one of only two women to achieve such a feat in multiple distances in a single Games. A Stanford student, she continues to break records in collegiate swimming during Women’s History Month.

title: Maryland’s Women’s History: Gloria Richardson
summary: Gloria Richardson, a key figure in Maryland’s civil rights history, led the Cambridge Movement in the 1960s, advocating for racial equality and challenging segregation through protests and activism. As a prominent leader, she promoted self-defense tactics and played a pivotal role in shaping the community's fight for justice.

title: Driver hits officer, rams police vehicle near U.S. Capitol
summary: A driver struck an officer and a police vehicle near the U.S. Capitol while attempting to evade a traffic stop.

summary: A Maryland Senate bill aiming to increase the use of cash bail has sparked opposition from advocates and officials who argue it undermines recent bail reform efforts and disproportionately impacts low-income defendants. Supporters, including the bill's sponsor, claim it enhances public safety by ensuring dangerous defendants are detained, while critics emphasize the need to eliminate profit-driven bail practices and protect vulnerable communities.

title: As Trump touts regulation rollbacks, CNS analysis shows Maryland coal jobs didn’t evaporate under Obama
summary: President Trump claims that rolling back Obama-era emissions regulations will revive coal jobs, but a CNS analysis shows Maryland coal employment remained stable during Obama’s first term and had already declined significantly before he took office. While the Trump administration argues the changes will boost coal industry confidence, critics say the move will lead to increased pollution and public health risks.

title: Maryland lawmakers appear to be on same page opposing NIH cuts
summary: Maryland lawmakers, both Democrats and Republicans, have united in opposition to President Trump’s proposed $6 billion NIH funding cut, warning it would harm biomedical research and talent retention. Rep.

title: Baltimore says its final goodbye to Cardinal William Keeler
summary: Thousands gathered in Baltimore to honor Cardinal William Keeler, the city's 14th archbishop, before his final public viewing. His body was later laid to rest at the Baltimore Basilica.

title: Bail reform supporters take their fight to the steps of the Maryland State House

summary: Democrats in the Maryland Senate passed several bills opposed by Gov. Larry Hogan, including measures on school evaluations and Planned Parenthood funding, aiming to override potential vetoes before the legislative session ends.

title: Natural Resources Dept. may regulate cownose-ray killing contests
summary: Maryland's Department of Natural Resources is considering new regulations on cownose-ray killing contests, potentially including temporary moratoriums and bans on certain equipment, in response to state legislation and public feedback. title: Meet Maryland’s Superfoods: Elderberries
summary: Maryland is home to nutrient-rich "superfoods," including locally grown elderberries, offering both health benefits and a delicious taste. A new superfood is highlighted weekly through the #FitFoodMonday campaign on Twitter @CNSmd.

summary: Seven women in Potomac, Maryland, are discovering new careers as artists. Their journey has brought not only a new passion but also lasting friendships.

summary: The U.S. Senate Judiciary Committee questioned Rod Rosenstein, President Trump’s nominee for Deputy U.S.

title: Metro’s Finance Committee approves budget with service cuts, fare hikes
summary: Metro’s Finance Committee approved a revised $1.8 billion budget that includes service reductions and fare increases. The budget now awaits final approval from the full Metro board.

title: Cherry Blossoms see early peak bloom in Washington
summary: The cherry blossom trees in Washington are expected to bloom earlier than usual due to unusually warm weather, according to the National Park Service. This early peak bloom highlights the impact of rising temperatures on seasonal natural events.

summary: Maryland lawmakers are being urged to expand the criteria for protective orders to better assist domestic violence victims. The push comes as part of ongoing efforts to reinterpret the legal definition of "abuse" in state law.

summary: The Talbot Avenue bridge in Montgomery County holds significant African American heritage for the Lyttonsville community. Its future is now linked to the development of Metro’s Purple Line.

title: Remember Maryland’s “Oh, he steal” game?
summary: In a pivotal 2002 matchup, Maryland's Steve Blake stole the ball from Duke's Jay Williams at halftime, leading to a game-changing layup and a 38-29 halftime lead. The play fueled Maryland's momentum, helping them secure an 87-73 victory over the top-ranked Blue Devils.

title: For Maryland Twitter users, the Lenten struggle is real
summary: Lent, the 40-day Christian observance before Easter, involves many people giving up certain habits or luxuries, with abstaining from meat on Fridays being a common practice. title: Do MLB pitchers suffer from World Baseball Classic participation?
summary: MLB pitchers who participate in the World Baseball Classic appear to experience a decline in performance the following season, with a 16.5% drop in WAR and fewer starts and innings pitched. Pitchers who skip the tournament may avoid potential short-term risks and long-term consequences such as injury or diminished performance.

title: Black colleges face huge hit in Trump budget

title: Terrapins hit century mark in rolling to NCAA first-round win over Bucknell

summary: Planned Parenthood supporters in Maryland are working with Democratic lawmakers to pass legislation that would maintain state funding for its health care services if federal support is reduced. The effort aims to ensure continued access to reproductive health services amid potential federal funding cuts.

summary: She-sheds are becoming a popular alternative to man caves, offering women a private space for relaxation and connection. These spaces are gaining traction in Maryland and across the United States.

summary: St. Patrick’s Day originated as a religious feast day in Ireland to honor St.

summary: Chris Van Hollen, Maryland’s junior U.S. Senator, is a seasoned Capitol Hill figure who remains optimistic about advancing Senate work despite the current political polarization.

title: Perfect brackets almost never survive past day one of the NCAA tournament
summary: The odds of creating a perfect NCAA tournament bracket are 1 in 9.2 quintillion, and even the best brackets rarely survive past the first round, with only 0.002% of entries remaining after day one in 2015. Former President Obama's best performance in 2012 saw him correctly predict 44 out of 63 games, but he never achieved a perfect bracket.

summary: New Town High School's girls' basketball team defeated Largo High 61-47 to win the Division 2A state championship, fueled by a strong defensive game plan and early scoring by forward Khariah Kosh. Coach Richard Hibbert credited the team's belief in defense as the key to their victory.

title: Maryland Terps at B1G Tournament
summary: The Maryland Terps are set to compete in the Big Ten Tournament. No further details are provided due to the JavaScript-dependent content.

summary: D.C. United has struggled to maintain its past success in recent years, partly due to spending significantly less than the MLS average on player salaries, especially for forwards.

summary: The Big Ten Tournament has brought a surge of Indiana University fans to Washington, D.C., boosting local businesses like Rocket Bar with watch parties and alumni events. The tournament is expected to generate over $33 million in direct spending for the district.

title: You’re invited to turn your clocks forward!
summary: The U.S. observes Daylight Saving Time this weekend by turning clocks forward, though not all states participate.

title: The Undefeated staff: Let athletes be political, because they’re people, too

While some fans prefer athletes to "stick to sports," the modern landscape demands they either speak out or face criticism for their silence.

title: Hogan announces tech upgrades to better connect Md. agencies
summary: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan announced tech upgrades to modernize state agencies, starting with caseworkers who assist low-income residents, through a cloud-based system aimed at improving efficiency and reducing bureaucratic hurdles. The initiative, supported by federal funding and privacy safeguards, also includes forming a commission to explore a "two-gen" approach to addressing multi-generational poverty.

title: Maryland has a budget problem — but no one can agree on why
summary: Maryland faces a persistent budget deficit despite strong economic indicators, with conflicting views on whether the issue stems from excessive spending or declining revenues. Experts point to factors like taxpayer behavior, federal policy impacts, and legislative mandates as potential causes.

title: The other ‘Road Kill Bill’: This one is about dead animals

The bill, which allows residents to report roadkill, is designed to avoid political opposition and is expected to pass without resistance from the administration.

The bipartisan-supported legislation aims to provide a legal process for victims to seek termination of an assailant's parental rights, ensuring such decisions are not made lightly.

title: Family reunion for Baltimore’s Williams cut short by Ohio State loss

title: Maryland Terps aim to prove freshmen’s worth in Big Ten tournament

title: Lead-paint bill would let Baltimore sue for past damages

title: Maryland lawmakers push state funding for Planned Parenthood
summary: Maryland Democratic lawmakers are pushing for state funding to support Planned Parenthood's health services if federal support is cut in the wake of efforts to repeal and replace the Affordable Care Act. Republican lawmakers criticize the move as politically motivated, arguing that other providers can offer necessary care without federal funding.

title: U.S. women’s soccer team upset by France
summary: The U.S. women’s soccer team suffered an upset 3-0 loss to France in the final match of the SheBelieves Cup, ending their chances of winning the tournament.

title: Maryland’s Women’s History: Elizabeth Ann Seton

summary: Women across the U.S. participated in the “A Day Without a Woman” strike to advocate for equity and human rights, with many in the Maryland and D.C.

summary: Republican leaders have proposed replacing the Affordable Care Act with the American Health Care Act, which would cut tax credits for low-income and elderly Marylanders. An analysis shows the plan would benefit younger and higher-income individuals while hurting vulnerable populations.

title: Three unique challenges of those newly-discovered exoplanets
summary: NASA has discovered seven Earth-sized exoplanets orbiting the star TRAPPIST-1. However, several unique challenges suggest that traveling to or inhabiting the system may not be feasible.

title: Chicken ‘Flockstars’ prove music is for the birds

title: Justice Department nominee from Maryland won’t commit on special prosecutor

title: Big Ten tournament seeds, based on teams’ Twitter popularity

title: Meet Maryland’s Superfoods: Cherries
summary: Maryland produces a variety of nutrient-rich "superfoods," including cherries, that are both healthy and locally available. A weekly campaign by @CNSmd highlights these local superfoods, encouraging residents to share their favorites using #FitFoodMonday.

summary: Governor Larry Hogan is pushing for redistricting reform in Maryland by advocating for an independent, non-partisan commission to handle the process, criticizing the current partisan system as "disgraceful." summary: Most Maryland Democrats are urging Attorney General Jeff Sessions to resign after he failed to disclose meetings with the Russian ambassador during the 2016 presidential campaign. Lawmakers, including Rep.

summary: Analysts warn that potential Trump administration trade policies targeting China could negatively impact the Port of Baltimore and Maryland’s economy by reducing trade and causing job losses. With China being a major trading partner, a trade war could disrupt the region’s significant import and export activities.

title: Republican states lower in U.S. News ‘best states’ rankings
summary: Republican-controlled states dominate the bottom half of U.S. News’ “Best States” rankings, while Democratic-majority states are overrepresented in the top 25.
