summary: Harriet Tubman, born in Maryland around 1820, was a key figure in the Underground Railroad, a Civil War military leader, and a women’s suffrage advocate. She concludes Maryland’s Black History Month series and also marks the start of the state’s Women’s History Month coverage.

title: Trump speech gets thumbs down from Maryland Democrats
summary: Maryland's Democratic lawmakers criticized President Trump's joint session speech as lacking substance and failing to address his recent record, despite a more optimistic tone than his inaugural address. While some saw a shift toward a presidential style, critics argued the speech prioritized rhetoric over meaningful policy.

title: Olympic gold medalist Phelps: International sports plagued with doping
summary: Michael Phelps and Adam Nelson testified before Congress, highlighting the widespread issue of doping in international sports and urging stronger anti-doping measures. They emphasized the need to protect the integrity of competitions and ensure fair play for all athletes.

title: Maryland ranks eighth in new “best states” ranking
summary: Maryland ranked eighth in U.S. News and World Report's latest "Best States" list, evaluated based on factors such as growth, employment, healthcare, and education.

title: Meet Maryland’s Superfoods: Eggs
summary: Maryland produces a variety of nutrient-rich "superfoods," including eggs, that are both healthy and locally available. Each week, new superfoods are highlighted through the #FitFoodMonday campaign on Twitter.

title: Maryland’s Cardin hits Trump on Russia policy, border and immigration
summary: Maryland Sen. Ben Cardin criticized President Trump's foreign policy, citing failures in addressing Russian aggression, mishandling U.S.-Mexico relations, and promoting a travel ban inconsistent with American values.

title: Marylander a leading contender for Democratic Party leader
summary: Thomas Perez, a former Maryland labor secretary and Obama administration official, is a leading contender for Democratic National Committee chairman, facing strong competition from Rep. Keith Ellison.

title: Will ‘Hidden Figures’ win first PG best picture Oscar in decades?
summary: "Hidden Figures" could become the first PG-rated film in nearly 30 years to win the Oscar for best picture. Since the 1990s, Oscar voters have increasingly favored R-rated or PG-13 films over family-friendly options.

title: Maryland’s Black History: Taraji P. Henson
summary: Taraji P. Henson, a Maryland native and Howard University graduate, gained fame for her role as Cookie Lyon on *Empire* and was the first African-American to win a Critics’ Choice Television Award for Best Actress in a Drama Series.

title: Beyond the inaugural celebrations, many protest the new president
summary: Protesters in Washington, D.C., clashed with police during Donald Trump’s inauguration, resulting in vandalism, arrests, and the use of tear gas and pepper spray. While some demonstrators criticized Trump's policies, others expressed support, with tensions also flaring during the arrival of former President Obama and Secretary Clinton.

title: Hogan’s legislative priorities go to committee
summary: Governor Larry Hogan's push to repeal the Maryland Open Transportation Investment Decision Act, which he calls "the Road Kill Bill," has become a major point of contention with the Democrat-controlled legislature. The law, which requires justifications for funding lower-scoring transportation projects, faces fierce opposition from Hogan, who claims it unfairly cancels essential projects, while supporters argue his criticisms are inaccurate.

title: Cousins, Davis poised to be best big man duo in NBA history
summary: DeMarcus Cousins and Anthony Davis are set to form one of the most prolific big-man duos in NBA history, with the potential to average 55 points per game combined. However, their high usage rates may make it challenging for both to sustain their individual scoring levels while playing together.

title: Remember when Phil predicted more winter?
summary: Punxsutawney Phil may be confused about his winter prediction. The article questions the accuracy of his forecast.

title: Black history at the Oscars
summary: A timeline in the article highlights the groundbreaking achievements of African-American artists at the Oscars, including actors, directors, and producers who were first in their categories. The piece also notes that Denzel Washington's first paid acting role was in a play in Saint Mary’s City, Maryland.

title: 360 video: Oyster aquaculture seeks to preserve Eastern Shore industry
summary: Oyster aquaculture is being explored as a solution to restore the severely depleted Chesapeake Bay oyster population, which is now just one percent of historical levels due to disease and pollution. Scientists, politicians, and local watermen hope this approach will help revive the industry and preserve the Eastern Shore's cultural heritage.

title: Deforestation, fracking bills draw protesters before hearing
summary: Protesters gathered in Annapolis to support forest conservation and oppose fracking as the House Environment and Transportation Committee prepared to hear testimony on three related bills. The proposed legislation includes a ban on fracking and stricter replanting requirements, aiming to address Maryland's significant forest loss due to development.

title: National Gallery show includes artist who spent time in Baltimore
summary: A National Gallery of Art exhibition titled *The Urban Scene: 1920-1950* includes work by Clare Leighton, a British-American engraver who briefly lived in Baltimore and befriended H.L. Mencken.

title: Katsucon conventiongoers invade Maryland’s National Harbor
summary: Anime, comic book, and superhero fans gathered in Maryland’s National Harbor for Katsucon, showcasing their costumes and enthusiasm. The event brought a vibrant crowd to College Park for the annual convention.

title: Maryland tied for worst commute time in U.S.
summary: Maryland is tied with New York for the longest average commute time in the U.S., according to a CNS analysis of U.S. Census data.

title: Area Jewish Community Center still coping with aftermath of bomb threats
summary: A local Jewish Community Center in Rockville is still dealing with the aftermath of a series of bomb threats. The incidents have occurred as President Trump addresses recent anti-Semitic hostilities.

title: Police transparency called for in Maryland counties
summary: ACLU and CASA are advocating for a bill in Maryland that would make police misconduct complaints public, supported by families affected by police brutality. Law enforcement officials declined to comment on the proposed legislation.

title: Area restaurants close in support of immigrants
summary: Restaurants in the D.C. metro area, including Busboys and Poets, closed for a "Day Without Immigrants" to highlight the contributions of immigrant workers.

title: Final farewell to Bao Bao at Washington’s National Zoo
summary: Bao Bao, a beloved panda at Washington’s National Zoo, is being sent to China as part of an agreement requiring cubs to return before age four. Despite the terms, the decision has sparked mixed reactions among zoo visitors and supporters.

title: Maryland Congressman calls for investigation following Flynn resignation
summary: Maryland Congressman Dutch Ruppersberger is calling for a bipartisan congressional investigation following the resignation of National Security Adviser Michael Flynn. He also urged President Trump to focus on leadership rather than Twitter activity.

title: State lawmakers asked to help with battle against skyrocketing drug prices
summary: Maryland lawmakers are being urged to pass bills aimed at addressing the issue of unaffordable prescription drugs for residents with life-threatening conditions. The legislation seeks to provide relief and better understanding for those struggling with skyrocketing medication costs.

title: Veterans hit the slopes for a good cause
summary: An adaptive sports program in Pennsylvania hosts a fundraiser to provide free skiing lessons and equipment for wounded veterans. A local veteran highlights the positive impact the program has had on his family.

title: Maryland Congressional Democrats react to Flynn resignation
summary: Maryland's congressional Democrats responded to the resignation of National Security Advisor Michael Flynn by urging an investigation into the circumstances surrounding his departure. They also called for greater oversight of U.S.-Russian relations.

title: Former Raven helps to promote importance of school breakfasts
summary: Former Ravens wide receiver Qadry Ismail visited Germantown Elementary School in Annapolis to highlight the importance of school breakfasts on Maryland Meals for Achievement Day. The event used Valentine’s Day as a theme to promote healthy eating habits among students.

title: Bill could make blocking a four-way intersection illegal
summary: A proposed Maryland bill would fine drivers who enter a four-way intersection but fail to clear it when the light turns red, aiming to reduce congestion and improve traffic flow. Exceptions are made for vehicles making left or right turns who yield properly, and similar laws already exist in several other states.

title: Bills curb Md. assistance in federal immigration enforcement
summary: Maryland lawmakers are advancing bills to limit state collaboration with federal immigration enforcement, prohibiting law enforcement from inquiring about or sharing immigration status with federal agencies. The legislation aims to protect undocumented residents and build trust within immigrant communities by ensuring their information remains confidential and not used for immigration purposes.

title: Senate Walk Out
summary: Most of Maryland's 14 Republican senators walked out of the Senate chamber in protest during a heated discussion. They objected to not having enough time to review the Maryland Defense Act, which would grant the state's Attorney General exclusive authority to sue the federal government.

title: Montgomery County says no change in policy despite presidential executive order on immigration
summary: Montgomery County Executive Ike Leggett stated the county will not alter its policies toward immigrants and refugees, regardless of their documentation status. This decision comes in response to a recent presidential executive order on immigration.

title: Illicit-drug use OK in ‘safe’ site under Maryland bill
summary: A Maryland bill proposes creating legal, supervised drug-consumption facilities to reduce overdose deaths and promote safer use. Similar facilities in other countries have shown no fatal overdoses and are supported by growing evidence of their effectiveness.

title: Lawmakers, educators push for less classroom testing time
summary: Maryland lawmakers and educators are advocating for the Less Testing, More Learning Act, which would limit standardized testing to 2 percent of classroom time and replace statewide social studies tests with locally designed assessments. The bill, supported by a majority of the state Senate and previously passed by the House of Delegates, aims to increase teacher autonomy and reduce excessive testing.

title: Legislators consider a bill to legalize aid-in-dying meds
summary: Maryland legislators are considering a third-year bill to legalize aid-in-dying, allowing terminally ill patients to receive lethal prescriptions to end their lives. Advocates emphasize patient dignity, while opponents argue the proposal represents dangerous physician-assisted suicide and risks undermining medical trust.

title: Sagging NHL power play opportunities hurting Capitals’ Alex Ovechkin
summary: Alex Ovechkin remains one of the NHL's most efficient power play scorers, but his production is being impacted by a league-wide decline in power play opportunities. Despite fewer chances, Ovechkin continues to maximize his time on the ice, showcasing elite efficiency during the man advantage.

title: State lawmakers debate bill allowing terminally ill patients to end their lives
summary: Maryland lawmakers are debating a bill that would allow terminally ill patients with less than six months to live and full mental capacity to receive medication to end their lives. If passed and signed by the governor, Maryland would become the seventh state to offer this option.

title: Local community fights to preserve a piece of its history
summary: A local African American church in Silver Spring, Maryland, faces a dispute among descendants and supporters over the future of the land above its cemetery. The community is divided on how to preserve or develop the historically significant site.

title: Bills would hike school bus-camera fine, include rental cars
summary: Maryland lawmakers propose doubling fines for repeat offenders who illegally pass school buses and extending liability to rental car companies. The push comes after a recent survey showed a significant increase in such violations, highlighting a growing concern for student safety.

title: Baseball writers: digital media, more press restrictions have changed coverage
summary: Baseball journalist Tim Kurkjian reflects on how the rise of digital media and stricter team press policies have reduced journalists' one-on-one access to players and managers, limiting opportunities for in-depth storytelling. He argues this shift affects the quality of coverage, as personal interactions once provided deeper insights into the game.

title: Achievement gaps contribute to Maryland’s fall in education rankings
summary: Maryland's public schools dropped to fifth in national education rankings due to significant achievement gaps between low and high-income students. Despite high overall test scores in some counties, the disparity between rich and poor students remains larger than in most other states.

title: Religious leaders gather in Annapolis to support earned sick leave
summary: Religious leaders in Annapolis have come together to advocate for earned sick leave legislation. Their goal is to promote worker fairness and public health through faith-based support.

title: Twitter users in Maryland react to #DayWithoutImmigrants
summary: Twitter users in Maryland responded to the #DayWithoutImmigrants protest with a range of opinions, from support for immigrants' rights to critical and sarcastic remarks. Some highlighted the contributions of immigrants, while others made distinctions between legal and illegal immigration.

title: Is another black president in America’s future?
summary: Some Democrats are considering figures like Michelle Obama, Cory Booker, and Kamala Harris as potential candidates for the 2020 presidential election, raising the possibility of another Black president. However, analysts remain divided, with some skeptical due to political shifts and white nationalist sentiments, while others believe current tensions could still pave the way for a Black leader.

title: Maryland’s Black History: Harry A. Cole
summary: Harry A. Cole became the first African-American assistant state attorney general in Maryland in 1953, the first African-American state senator in 1954, and the first African-American Court of Appeals judge in 1977.

title: Md. health officials call for drug affordability legislation
summary: Maryland health officials and advocates are urging lawmakers to pass legislation to address rising prescription drug costs, following stories like that of Bonnita Spikes, who can no longer afford her Alzheimer’s medication. Proposed bills would allow the state to sue drug companies for price gouging and require transparency on drug pricing and spending.

title: Lawmakers seek to protect bee colonies from bears
summary: Lawmakers in Maryland are pushing to classify bees as animals to grant beekeepers legal protection when using deadly force to defend colonies from black bears. Currently, bees are considered insects, leaving beekeepers vulnerable to penalties if they harm a bear in self-defense.

title: Maryland Democrats join in pressuring White House on Russia
summary: Maryland Democrats joined congressional efforts to hold the Trump administration accountable for its policies toward Russia, including introducing bipartisan legislation to allow Congress to review any sanctions relief. Lawmakers also pushed for an independent investigation into former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn’s communications with Russian officials.

title: Comptroller seeks power to combat tax fraud
summary: Maryland Comptroller Peter Franchot and Governor Larry Hogan support legislation to expand the comptroller’s powers in fighting tax fraud, including requiring tax preparers to be registered and extending the statute of limitations on tax offenses. The bill would also grant the comptroller’s Field Enforcement Bureau expanded police powers to independently obtain search warrants for suspected fraud cases.

title: Maryland Democrats press for Flynn-Russia probe
summary: Maryland Democratic lawmakers are calling for a congressional investigation into former National Security Adviser Michael Flynn's communications with Russia and the Trump administration's broader ties to the country. Sen.

title: Majority of Americans hope to receive chocolate on Valentine’s Day
summary: Most Americans hope to receive chocolate on Valentine’s Day, with 43 percent planning to buy it for themselves. A Twitter poll by Capital News Service invited followers to share their preferred Valentine’s Day gift.

title: Kids talk: Valentine’s Day
summary: Children at the Locust Grove Nature Center in Bethesda shared their ideas on what makes a great Valentine’s Day gift. Their suggestions ranged from handmade cards to small tokens of appreciation.

title: Many Marylanders use mobile apps to find love and live to tweet about it
summary: Mobile dating apps like Tinder are increasingly popular, especially among young adults, and have changed how people meet romantic partners. Marylanders frequently share their mixed experiences with the app on social media, highlighting both its success and its potential for awkward encounters.

title: Thousands in Maryland remain on organ transplant waiting list
summary: Thousands of Marylanders are currently waiting for life-saving organ transplants, despite over 2.8 million residents registered as potential donors. National Donor Day on Valentine’s Day highlights the importance of organ and tissue donation, with options to register online or at local DMV branches.

title: Participants run for charity in their Valentine’s Day best
summary: Participants in the Cupid’s Undie Run, an annual fundraiser for the Children’s Tumor Foundation, show off their Valentine’s Day outfits while running for charity. The event also features discussions about dating apps and romantic themes around Valentine’s Day.

title: Block of homes in Baltimore destroyed for city revival
summary: Gov. Larry Hogan and Baltimore Mayor Catherine Pugh are leading the demolition of a block of blighted homes on Chester Street as part of Project C.O.R.E, a $16 million initiative to revitalize the city through mixed-use development, job creation, and neighborhood improvement.

title: Irish firm brings renewable energy to Md. poultry industry
summary: An Irish agri-tech company has partnered with a Maryland poultry farm to implement manure-to-energy technology, aiming to reduce environmental impact on the Chesapeake Bay. The automated system, controlled remotely from Ireland, converts chicken waste into renewable energy while improving conditions for the birds.

title: Md. Senate approves resolution to empower attorney general
summary: The Maryland Senate passed a resolution allowing the state attorney general to challenge Trump administration policies in court, with Republicans opposing it and walking out in protest. The move, part of the Maryland Defense Act of 2017, aims to align Maryland with most states that let attorneys general independently pursue legal actions against harmful federal policies.

title: Prince George’s police prepare to roll out body camera program
summary: Prince George’s County Police Department is launching a body camera pilot program for 70 officers, aiming to increase accountability in a department with a history of misconduct. Despite nationwide adoption of such programs, it remains uncertain whether body cameras will address systemic issues, and the county provided significantly less funding than requested for the initiative.

title: Maryland’s Black History: Henrietta Lacks
summary: Henrietta Lacks, a Black woman from Maryland, died in 1951, and cells taken from her without consent became the first immortalized human cells, known as HeLa cells, which revolutionized medical research. Her legacy, along with that of Frederick Douglass, highlights the significant contributions of Maryland's Black history to science and society.

title: Protesters rally in front of State House to oppose fracking
summary: Protesters gathered in front of Maryland’s State House to demand a permanent statewide ban on fracking, citing environmental and water contamination risks highlighted in a 2016 EPA report. Activists and legislators emphasized the need for state action as a current moratorium on fracking is set to expire in eight months.

title: GOP senators walk out over resolution to fight Trump orders
summary: Republican senators in Maryland walked out during a heated debate over a Democratic resolution directing the state's attorney general to challenge Trump's executive orders, objecting to a failed effort to delay the vote. The walkout, described as "incredibly rare," highlighted deep partisan divisions over how quickly the Senate should act on the controversial measure.

title: Civil rights groups push legislation on police transparency
summary: Civil rights groups in Maryland are advocating for new legislation to increase transparency in police misconduct investigations, which would allow the public access to complaint records currently classified as personnel files. Supporters argue that transparency is essential for building trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve.

title: Maryland’s Black History: Frederick Douglass
summary: Frederick Douglass, a prominent writer, orator, and abolitionist, lived on Maryland’s Eastern Shore and in Baltimore during the 1800s. Maryland highlights influential African-American figures like Douglass and Henrietta Lacks during Black History Month.

title: Public and critics divide on video games — especially Call of Duty
summary: Critic and public reviews of video games often diverge, with the Call of Duty and Gears of War franchises showing the widest gaps, especially after key creative team changes. Remakes like Modern Warfare Remastered and Gears of War: Ultimate Edition helped narrow the divide between user and critic scores.

title: Lawmakers react to Governor’s third State of the State
summary: Governor Larry Hogan delivered his third State of the State address, discussing education, transportation, and the need for bipartisanship. Democratic lawmakers responded with a mix of hope and criticism.

title: A mix of supporters and opponents turn out for Trump inauguration
summary: Thousands gathered at the National Mall for President Donald J. Trump's inauguration.

title: CASA joins protest at White House opposing executive order on immigration
summary: CASA, a Prince George’s County organization, joined protesters near the White House to oppose President Trump’s executive order on immigration. The order threatens funding for sanctuary cities and initiates construction of a U.S.-Mexico border wall.

title: State lawmakers put passing bills aside for an annual game of roundball
summary: Maryland state lawmakers set aside legislative work for an annual game of roundball during their 90-day session. The event offers a rare moment of friendly competition among lawmakers in College Park.

title: UMD students protest, seek more action from university’s president
summary: University of Maryland students protested by walking out of classes to express opposition to President Trump’s executive order on refugees and immigrants. They are urging University President Wallace Loh to take stronger action in support of affected communities.

title: UMD Spring Sports Media Day
summary: The University of Maryland held a spring sports media day featuring several teams and notable figures like Mark Turgeon and Melo Trimble. They discussed their current status and preparations for future competitions.

title: Wacky Weather
summary: College Park students are enjoying record-breaking warm weather in February. However, warnings suggest that winter is set to return soon.

title: Maryland groups, citizens and attorney general join suits against travel order
summary: A Maryland-based refugee resettlement group, HIAS, has joined a lawsuit against President Trump’s travel ban, which suspends entry from seven predominantly Muslim countries, claiming it discriminates against Muslims. The legal challenge is part of broader efforts across the U.S., including a federal court case in Washington and a coalition of attorneys general opposing the executive order.

title: Washington’s two pro soccer teams face different challenges
summary: D.C. United and the Washington Spirit face contrasting challenges as their new soccer seasons approach, with the men's team strengthening its roster and the women's team losing several key players.

title: Md. lawmakers announce anti-voucher proposals
summary: Maryland lawmakers have introduced a legislative package aimed at blocking education vouchers, restoring education funding, and reducing standardized testing. The proposals include the Protect Our Schools Act, which would evaluate schools based on factors like teacher quality and course access rather than test scores.

title: Bill introduces criminal, civil penalties for ransomware
summary: A new Maryland bill seeks to impose criminal and civil penalties for ransomware attacks, classifying them as felonies with potential prison sentences of up to 10 years and fines of $10,000. The legislation also allows victims to pursue damages in civil court, though some aspects, such as how multiple devices affected by a single attack would be treated, remain unclear.

title: Maryland bills would ban, study early childhood suspensions
summary: Maryland lawmakers are pushing to ban suspensions for prekindergarten through second grade students, citing disparities that disproportionately affect students of color and those with disabilities. The proposed bill allows limited exceptions, such as bringing a firearm to school, and comes amid rising suspension rates and calls for reform from the state’s Black Caucus.

title: Maryland senators vote against DeVos confirmation
summary: Maryland's two Democratic senators, Ben Cardin and Chris Van Hollen, voted against Betsy DeVos's confirmation as U.S. Secretary of Education, citing her lack of experience and opposition to public schools.

title: Affordable Care Act substantially expanded mental health coverage
summary: The Affordable Care Act significantly broadened access to mental health services by requiring most health insurance plans to cover essential mental health benefits. This expansion aimed to reduce disparities and improve care for individuals with mental health conditions.

title: ‘Quack quack’: Meet Maryland’s proposed state waterfowl
summary: Maryland Delegate Mary Ann Lisanti is proposing the canvasback duck as the state's official waterfowl, highlighting its historical and cultural significance to the Chesapeake Bay region. The duck, which winters in the bay, faces threats from declining water quality and loss of aquatic vegetation.

title: Patriots’ late rally over Falcons powers Super Bowl’s first overtime thriller
summary: The New England Patriots staged the largest comeback in Super Bowl history, erasing a 25-point deficit in the fourth quarter to force overtime and eventually winning 34-28 against the Atlanta Falcons. Quarterback Tom Brady led the rally, securing his fifth Super Bowl title with a game-winning touchdown drive in overtime.

title: Super Bowl Notebook: Practices, injuries, Goodell and more
summary: The Atlanta Falcons and New England Patriots had nearly full participation in their final Super Bowl practices, though key players like Julio Jones and Alex Mack were limited by injuries. Meanwhile, NFL Commissioner Roger Goodell joined Walter Payton Man of the Year finalists for a fan forum in Houston.

title: How an advanced hockey stat measures luck in the NHL
summary: PDO, an advanced NHL statistic calculated by combining a team's shooting and save percentages, measures how much luck influences a team's performance. Teams with a PDO significantly above 102 or below 98 are likely experiencing unsustainable levels of luck, according to hockey analysts.

title: Teams in white jerseys win Super Bowl with improbable regularity
summary: Teams wearing white jerseys have won 32 of the last 50 Super Bowls, leading to speculation about a possible "white jersey curse" or advantage. While some teams, like the New England Patriots, have chosen to wear white in hopes of success, experts suggest the trend may simply be due to chance and a small sample size.

title: Maryland Democrats alarmed at possible attack on Russian activist
summary: Russian activist Vladimir Kara-Murza is in critical condition after suffering organ failure, with his lawyer suspecting another poisoning, following a similar incident in 2015. Maryland Democratic leaders expressed alarm and urged the Trump administration to maintain sanctions on Russia rather than ease them.

title: Beating the Buzzer: Wizards Keep Games Tight to the End
summary: The Washington Wizards frequently play close games that are decided late, according to a CNS analysis of win probability data. Their games tend to be more nail-biting compared to the average NBA team.

title: Falcons and Patriots to test NFL-best turnover rates in Super Bowl
summary: The Atlanta Falcons and New England Patriots enter Super Bowl LI with the best turnover margins in the NFL, each committed to ball protection as a key to victory. Both teams attribute their success to disciplined play, strong quarterback performances, and a mindset developed through consistent practice.

title: Former Baltimore high school star is Patriots rookie in Super Bowl
summary: Cyrus Jones, a former Baltimore high school standout and Alabama football star, is making his Super Bowl debut with the New England Patriots after a challenging rookie season. Despite limited playing time and setbacks, Jones remains optimistic, drawing strength from his past successes and the belief that his best is yet to come.

title: Families dressed as superheroes lobby for sick-leave bill
summary: Families dressed as superheroes rallied in Annapolis to support the Maryland Healthy Working Families Act, a paid sick-leave bill that would help over 700,000 workers avoid choosing between their jobs and health. While Democrats back the act, Republican Governor Larry Hogan has proposed an alternative bill he claims is more business-friendly.

title: Maryland Senate votes to override Clean Energy Jobs veto
summary: The Maryland Senate has voted to override Governor Larry Hogan’s veto of the Clean Energy Jobs bill, which aims to raise the state’s renewable energy requirement from 20% by 2022 to 25% by 2020. While environmental groups and supporters argue the law will boost clean energy, create jobs, and benefit public health, critics claim it will increase electricity costs for residents.

title: Maryland’s Cardin emerging as leading Trump foreign policy critic
summary: Maryland Sen. Ben Cardin has become a prominent Democratic voice opposing Trump's foreign policy, criticizing the president's approach to global issues and voting against Rex Tillerson's nomination as secretary of state.

title: For first time in NFL history, league’s best backs younger than 24
summary: For the first time in NFL history, the top five running backs by rushing yards this season were all under 24 years old, led by rookies Ezekiel Elliott and Jordan Howard. This shift reflects both the rising talent of young players and the impact of the league's collective bargaining agreement, which encourages teams to invest in cheaper, younger talent.

title: Falcons coach Quinn’s football career took root as Salisbury University player
summary: Dan Quinn, head coach of the Atlanta Falcons, began his football journey as a standout player at Salisbury University, where his leadership and work ethic were evident early on. Coached by Joe Rotellini, Quinn displayed consistent intensity and team-first values that foreshadowed his future success in the NFL coaching ranks.

title: National Zoo soon will wave bye-bye to Bao Bao
summary: Bao Bao, the beloved panda cub born at the National Zoo, will leave for China this winter as part of an agreement requiring all panda cubs born at the zoo to return to China by age four. The zoo will host a four-day farewell event before her departure, marking the end of her time in Washington.

title: INAUGURATION PROTESTS: Demonstrators rally at the inauguration of Donald Trump
summary: Protesters took to the streets of Washington during Donald Trump's inauguration, clashing with police in several confrontations. The demonstrations occurred as Trump was sworn in as the 45th president of the United States.

title: Traffic safety advocates push for more laws for safer Maryland roads
summary: Traffic safety advocates have released their annual report highlighting that Maryland needs to implement more measures to enhance road safety. The report emphasizes the need for additional laws to protect motorists and passengers.

title: Lawmakers lay passing bills aside for a night to pass the rock
summary: Maryland state lawmakers set aside legislative work for a night to play basketball. The event occurred during the 90-day session, offering a break from their usual political activities.

title: Maryland Democrats ready to play defense against President Trump
summary: Maryland Senate President Mike Miller and House Speaker Michael Busch have introduced several legislative measures aimed at countering the impact of President Trump’s executive orders and new regulations. The efforts reflect a broader strategy by Maryland Democrats to shield the state from policies they view as harmful.

title: 35 year anniversary of the crash of Air Florida Flight 90 observed
summary: The National Law Enforcement Museum in Washington marked the 35th anniversary of the 1984 Air Florida Flight 90 crash into the 14th Street Bridge. The event honored the victims and featured accounts from rescuers and witnesses, as 74 passengers and four motorists died in the disaster.

title: STATE OF THE STATE: Gov. Larry Hogan addresses Maryland General Assembly
summary: Governor Larry Hogan delivered his third state-of-the-state address to the Maryland General Assembly, highlighting accomplishments over the past two years. He emphasized that while progress has been made, there is still significant work remaining.

title: Gov. Hogan delivers third State of the State address
summary: In his third State of the State address, Gov. Larry Hogan praised bipartisan cooperation and highlighted economic progress under his leadership while strongly criticizing a transportation bill passed by state Democrats.

title: Dems propose withdrawal of constitutional convention calls
summary: Maryland Democrats proposed legislation to withdraw the state's past calls for a constitutional convention and to resist federal policies they deem harmful, reflecting concerns over potential conservative influence under Republican leadership. The move aims to prevent what lawmakers fear could be efforts to alter the Constitution in ways unfavorable to Maryland and its residents.

title: Bill mandates Baltimore police report surveillance tactics
summary: A Maryland bill requires the Baltimore Police Commissioner to report new tactics, including the use of "high crime" or "stop and frisk" zones, to city officials within 30 days. The legislation, inspired by a DOJ report and a consent decree, aims to increase transparency after civil rights concerns were raised over targeted policing practices.

title: Belichick vs. Lombardi: Comparing Patriots’ longtime leader to a coaching legend
summary: Bill Belichick's coaching success with the New England Patriots stems from his adaptable strategies and ability to develop players, allowing the team to thrive with diverse talent and frequent in-game adjustments. While his potential fifth Super Bowl victory would tie him with legendary coach Vince Lombardi, Belichick's flexible approach contrasts with Lombardi’s more rigid style.

title: Mike Pence has a double, only he wears short-shorts
summary: Glen Pannell, a New York City graphic designer who bears a striking resemblance to Mike Pence, has used his look—often with a humorous twist, including wearing short-shorts—to raise money for progressive causes and charities. He attended an anti-inauguration event in Washington as his "Mike Hot-Pence" persona, drawing attention and support for vulnerable communities.

title: Siblings meet Prince George’s firefighter 58 years after he saved their lives
summary: Toddler siblings Michael and Linda Hart were reunited with retired Prince George's firefighter Edwin Stuart "Stu" Newman, Jr. 58 years after he saved their lives during a house fire.

title: Lax seat belt law hurts Maryland highway safety rating, advocates say
summary: Maryland's highway safety rating remains at yellow due to lax seat belt laws, according to the Advocates for Highway and Auto Safety, which urges the state to require backseat passengers to wear seat belts. Law enforcement and safety advocates argue that stronger legislation is needed to improve safety and raise the state's rating.

title: Running backs on rookie contracts are economical options for Super Bowl teams
summary: The New England Patriots and Atlanta Falcons are leveraging cost-effective rookie contracts for running backs like Devonta Freeman, Tevin Coleman, and James White, who provide strong value in both rushing and passing games. These players outperform and outcost other top rookie-contract players, offering significant economic advantages to their teams.

title: At his second Super Bowl, former Maryland player faces his ex-teammates
summary: Former Maryland All-American Joe Vellano is set to play in his second Super Bowl with the Atlanta Falcons, facing his former team, the New England Patriots, just months after losing his home to a fire. Vellano, who previously joined the Patriots as an undrafted free agent, brings championship experience to the Falcons as they prepare for Sunday’s game.

title: Pro-Life demonstrators gather on National Mall for annual March for Life
summary: Pro-Life demonstrators gathered on the National Mall for the annual March for Life to advocate against abortion. The event drew thousands of participants from across the country, highlighting ongoing support for the pro-life movement.

title: MD Comptroller, Attorney General charge four with tax fraud
summary: Maryland's Attorney General and Comptroller have charged four individuals with tax fraud for allegedly stealing tens of thousands of dollars from the state. The announcement was made in Baltimore on Thursday.

title: Demonstrators take their protest of the president’s executive orders on refugees to Annapolis
summary: Demonstrators gathered outside the Maryland State House to protest President Trump’s executive orders on refugees. The protest was organized by CASA, an organization supporting low-income immigrant families.

title: With Patriots’ eyes on history, Atlanta looks for first Super Bowl win
summary: The New England Patriots, led by Tom Brady and Bill Belichick, aim to make history with a record seventh Super Bowl appearance and a potential fifth title, while the Atlanta Falcons seek their first-ever Super Bowl victory to break through their long championship drought. Both teams enter the week with high hopes, as the Patriots chase historic milestones and the Falcons look to end their 51-year title wait.

title: Maryland lawmaker revives drive for equal rights for women in Constitution
summary: Maryland Senator Ben Cardin has re-introduced the Equal Rights Amendment in response to renewed calls for gender equality, particularly in light of Donald Trump's presidency. The amendment, first proposed in 1923 and needing ratification by 38 states, remains stalled despite growing bipartisan support and ongoing efforts to secure its inclusion in the U.S.

title: Senate bill would allow student refusal of animal dissection
summary: A proposed Maryland Senate bill would require schools to allow students to opt out of animal dissection activities and provide alternative educational methods such as videos, models, and virtual simulations. Proponents argue these alternatives are more effective, humane, and cost-efficient, with many schools lacking updated policies on the issue.

title: Here’s the national park Twitter presence President Trump has directed to cease
summary: President Trump ordered the Interior Department to temporarily halt social media communication, affecting popular National Park Service accounts, though some resumed activity later. The Park Service's 243 official accounts have a combined following of 1.1 million, with National Parks typically having the largest audiences.

title: Delaware welcomes home favorite son, former Vice President Joe Biden
summary: Joe Biden and his wife Jill returned to Delaware for a welcome home celebration after his tenure as Vice President ended. The event in Wilmington honored the state's favorite son and his service to the nation.

title: In face of Trump’s new policy, Maryland’s Howard County could become official sanctuary
summary: Howard County officials in Maryland plan to move forward with legislation to declare the county a sanctuary for undocumented immigrants, despite President Trump's executive order threatening to cut federal funding for such jurisdictions. County Executive Allan Kittleman opposes the move, calling it a "hollow political statement" that would risk public services without altering existing policies.

title: INAUGURATION PARADE: Crowds line Trump inaugural parade route
summary: Crowds of supporters and protesters lined the route for President Donald Trump’s inaugural parade in Washington. The event took place immediately after his official swearing-in ceremony.

title: MTA looking to boost ridership with help from Baltimore Ravens QB Joe Flacco
summary: The Maryland Transit Administration is promoting increased ridership in Baltimore by unveiling new buses and improving transit connections. The initiative builds on Governor Larry Hogan's 2015 BaltimoreLink plan, which aims to revamp bus routes and enhance regional transit links.

title: Anne Arundel, Prince George’s Counties battle over new cardiac care location
summary: Anne Arundel Medical Center in Annapolis has received approval to start an open-heart surgery program. Prince George’s County officials oppose the move, arguing it will strain state resources needed for a new county hospital.

title: Ravens, state to spend $144 million on stadium improvements
summary: The Maryland Stadium Authority and the Baltimore Ravens will invest $144 million in upgrades to M&T Bank Stadium, with the team contributing $120 million and the authority using $24 million in retained earnings. The improvements, which include adding escalators and elevators, may lead to higher ticket prices, though the Ravens have not yet finalized their pricing decision.

title: Meet the men of the Women’s March
summary: Men participated in large numbers at the Women’s March in Washington, D.C., supporting issues like women’s rights, environmental protection, immigrant safety, and LGBT equality. Their presence highlighted broad support for the causes beyond the event's name.

title: Maryland school safety training includes Sandy Hook speakers
summary: Maryland conducted school safety training featuring speakers from the Sandy Hook shooting, including law enforcement and family members of the victims, to enhance emergency preparedness and promote school safety. The initiative, part of the state's 2017 School Safety Initiative, aims to improve response strategies and foster community collaboration in creating secure learning environments.

title: Hogan announces new measures to address opioid addiction
summary: Maryland Governor Larry Hogan and Lieutenant Governor Boyd Rutherford announced new legislative measures to combat the opioid crisis, including limits on initial opioid prescriptions, stricter penalties for illegal opioid distribution leading to death, and expanded access to naloxone. The initiatives also include the creation of a virtual Opioid Operations Command Center to coordinate efforts and track data on opioid use and abuse.

title: Donald Trump’s inaugural parade brings out supporters and protesters
summary: Supporters and protesters alike gathered in Washington to watch the inaugural parade following Donald Trump's swearing-in as president. The event highlighted the divided public reaction to his leadership.

title: Counter inauguration celebration raises funds for progressive organizations
summary: A counter-inauguration event in Montgomery County raised funds for progressive organizations, offering an alternative to the celebrations marking the Trump administration's start. The event featured live music and attracted a sold-out crowd concerned about the new administration's impact on progressive causes.

title: Analyst: Md. could lose $1.4 billion under health care repeal
summary: A federal repeal of the Affordable Care Act could cost Maryland $1.4 billion in the 2018 fiscal year, largely due to lost Medicaid funding and other health-related programs. The state would face a difficult choice to either reduce coverage or cover the costs if the law is repealed.

title: Maryland League of Conservation Voters rates Gov. Hogan
summary: The Maryland League of Conservation Voters gave Gov. Larry Hogan an "excellent" rating in land preservation but an overall "Needs Improvement" grade due to a gap between his environmental rhetoric and legislative actions.

title: Trump set to govern with whitest cabinet in decades
summary: Donald Trump's cabinet is the whitest and most male-dominated in decades, according to a Capital News Service analysis. It contrasts sharply with the more diverse cabinets of previous presidents like Obama, Clinton, and George W.

summary: Kids share their opinions on who should be president, offering a unique perspective on leadership. The discussion comes amid the inauguration of the 45th president.

summary: Men joined the Women’s March on Washington in significant numbers, supporting women's rights alongside family members and advocating for gender equality. summary: Hundreds of thousands gathered in Washington for the Women’s March on Washington, a peaceful protest against Trump’s inauguration and in support of women’s rights and social justice. The event, marked by pink "pussy hats" and global sister marches, drew larger crowds than the inauguration and emphasized unity, hope, and democratic resistance.

summary: The Women's March on Washington drew thousands of participants advocating for women's rights, social justice, and equality. Organizers and attendees emphasized unity and resistance against policies perceived as threatening to marginalized communities.

summary: Thousands of people, including women and men, marched in Washington to advocate for women’s rights, diversity, and human rights. The demonstration also expressed opposition to President Donald J.

summary: Thousands of Marylanders joined the Women’s March on Washington to protest President Trump’s policies and rhetoric, emphasizing concerns over reproductive rights, gender equality, and social justice. Participants, many inspired by personal and family histories, expressed fears that Trump’s administration threatens progress made by women over generations.

title: Trump’s words worry Maryland Democrats but Republicans praise them
summary: Maryland Democrats expressed concern over President Trump's inaugural address, which they viewed as divisive and lacking unity, while Republicans welcomed his promises to represent everyday Americans. Democratic leaders and lawmakers criticized Trump's rhetoric and business conflicts, urging him to uphold constitutional duties and set aside partisan divisions.

summary: President Donald J. Trump used few of his signature phrases, known as "Trumpisms," in his inaugural address.

summary: Protesters advocating for marijuana legalization gathered in Dupont Circle, lighting up in public as a form of demonstration during the inauguration. The act was intended to highlight calls for cannabis policy reform and challenge current federal restrictions.

summary: President Donald J. Trump was sworn into office in Washington, D.C., marking the beginning of his term as the 45th president of the United States.

title: Trump takes oath, declares Washington’s power going back to “American people”
summary: Donald Trump was sworn in as the 45th U.S. president, vowing to return power to the American people and emphasizing his "America first" agenda amid a divided nation.

title: Trump’s inauguration has lowest Metro ridership since 2005
summary: Trump’s inauguration saw the lowest Metro ridership since 2005, with only 225,000 people using the system. This marked a significant drop compared to previous presidential inaugurations.

title: Trump’s inaugural address had fifth-lowest reading level since Lincoln
summary: President Donald Trump’s inaugural address had a reading grade level of 7.6, tying for the fifth-lowest since Abraham Lincoln. This marked the 11th time an inaugural speech since Lincoln’s has reached middle school reading levels.

summary: Five first ladies each selected a designer to create their inaugural attire, showcasing evolving fashion trends and personal styles. The choices reflected both historical continuity and modern influences in American political fashion.

summary: Donald Trump, the 45th U.S. president, is a businessman and reality TV personality known for his real estate empire, three marriages, and prominent pop culture presence.

summary: The infographic provides a visual history of U.S. presidential inaugurations, highlighting key events and traditions over time.

title: Thanks, Obama event attracts hundreds to show gratitude
summary: Hundreds gathered in Washington D.C. on January 19, 2017, for the "Thanks, Obama" event to express gratitude for his eight years as president.

title: “Thanks, Obama”: Hundreds pay tribute on his last day in office
summary: Hundreds gathered in Washington on Obama's last day in office to celebrate his presidency and express gratitude for his legacy through music, art, and speeches. Attendees, inspired by the "Thanks, Obama" slogan, came from across the country to honor what they consider an admirable and impactful eight-year presidency.

title: Maryland Comptroller hosts taxpayer security summit to address tax fraud

summary: U.K. residents express uncertainty and concern over the impact of Donald Trump's presidency on U.S.-British relations.

summary: A pro-marijuana group in Washington, D.C., plans to distribute thousands of joints on Inauguration Day as part of their advocacy efforts. The event highlights the ongoing push for marijuana legalization and public awareness.

summary: In response to the uncertainties of the new Trump era, people across the U.S. are using poetry to express their concerns, as seen in a Washington reading organized by Writers Resist.

title: Marylanders Stand Up For The Affordable Care Act
summary: Maryland residents gathered in Clinton to show support for the Affordable Care Act. The event featured local lawmakers including Senators Chris Van Hollen and Ben Cardin.

title: METRO DISPARITIES: Proposed plan to study impact of projects postponed a month
summary: The Metropolitan Washington Council of Governments postponed a proposed plan to study the impact of transportation projects on low-income and minority communities. The plan aims to address transportation access disparities in the greater Washington area.

summary: Obama’s inaugural musicians achieved significantly more commercial success than Trump’s, with six times as many gold, platinum, and diamond certifications. summary: Governor Larry Hogan proposed a 2018 fiscal year budget that reduces general fund spending by $19.5 million but increases overall state spending by 1 percent to $43.541 billion.
